Complete excision with clear margins is the preferred treatment for Spitz nevus, although conservative approaches such as observation or partial excision may be appropriate in select cases. Follow-up is crucial to monitor for any signs of progression or recurrence. Further studies are needed to better understand the biology, management, and long-term outcomes of this enigmatic lesion.

Leukocyte alkaline phosphatase score in patients with cerebrovascular disease and in patients with primary and metastatic brain tumors. Evaluation of leukocyte alkaline phosphatase (LAP) score has shown promise as a prognostic marker in various medical conditions. The aim of this study was to assess LAP score in patients with cerebrovascular disease (CVD) and primary or metastatic brain tumors. The LAP scores were obtained from peripheral blood samples of CVD patients (n=50), primary brain tumor patients (n=50), and metastatic brain tumor patients (n=50). The results showed significantly lower LAP scores in patients with primary brain tumors compared to both CVD patients (p<0.001) and metastatic brain tumor patients (p=0.003). However, there was no significant difference in LAP scores between CVD patients and metastatic brain tumor patients (p=0.271). These findings suggest that LAP score may have clinical utility in differentiating primary brain tumors from metastatic ones, but further research is required to validate its potential as a diagnostic or prognostic marker in these conditions.

Enhanced expression of c-myc and H-ras oncogenes in Letterer-Siwe disease. We present a study investigating the expression of c-myc and H-ras oncogenes in Letterer-Siwe disease. Tissue samples from patients with Letterer-Siwe disease were analyzed for the presence of c-myc and H-ras oncogene expression using immunohistochemistry and polymerase chain reaction. We found that both c-myc and H-ras oncogenes were significantly upregulated in the affected tissue compared to normal control tissue. Moreover, the level of expression correlated with disease severity. These findings support the hypothesis that dysregulation of c-myc and H-ras oncogenes may contribute to the pathogenesis of Letterer-Siwe disease. Further studies are warranted to explore the potential use of c-myc and H-ras as prognostic markers and therapeutic targets in this rare disorder.

Gastric contents retained in rat stomach following mild irritant exposure contribute to adaptive cytoprotection.  Fluid retained in the gastric lumen immediately preceding the administration of a damaging product will dilute that product and decrease its injurious capacity. This study investigates the role of gastric contents in cytoprotection following exposure to mild irritants. It is known that fluid retained in the stomach prior to the administration of damaging products can decrease their injurious effects. The aim of this study was to explore the mechanisms underlying this protective effect. Using a rat model, the researchers demonstrated that gastric contents retained in the stomach after mild irritant exposure contribute to adaptive cytoprotection. The results suggest that the dilution of damaging products by retained fluid may be a mechanism by which the stomach protects itself against injury. Further research is needed to fully understand the specific cytoprotective mechanisms involved and their potential therapeutic applications in preventing gastric injury.

Non-vesicular release of glutamate from glial cells by reversed electrogenic glutamate uptake. Glutamate is the major excitatory neurotransmitter in the central nervous system and its release is tightly regulated. It was previously thought that glutamate was primarily released from neurons in a vesicular manner. However, recent studies have revealed that glial cells, specifically astrocytes, can also release glutamate via a non-vesicular mechanism. This non-vesicular release of glutamate is mediated by the reversed electrogenic glutamate uptake mechanism, in which glutamate transporters on astrocytes function in reverse mode, releasing glutamate into the extracellular space. This mode of glutamate release is important in various physiological processes, including synaptic plasticity and neuronal communication. Dysregulation of glutamate release from glial cells has been implicated in various neurological disorders, such as epilepsy and ischemic stroke. Understanding the mechanisms underlying non-vesicular glutamate release from glial cells may provide new insights into the pathophysiology of these disorders and potentially lead to the development of novel therapeutic strategies targeting glial cells.

Major histocompatibility complex antigen expression in the affected tissues in amyotrophic lateral sclerosis.  Monoclonal antibody immunocytochemistry was used to examine spinal cord and muscle in amyotrophic lateral sclerosis for changes that would indicate ongoing or potential immune activity. The role of immune activity in the pathogenesis of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) remains unclear. In this study, we examined major histocompatibility complex (MHC) antigen expression in affected tissues of ALS patients. Monoclonal antibody immunocytochemistry was performed on spinal cord and muscle samples from ALS patients to detect any changes indicative of immune activity. Results showed significant upregulation of MHC antigen expression in the spinal cord and muscle tissues of ALS patients compared to controls, suggesting ongoing immune activity in these tissues. Our findings support the hypothesis that immune dysregulation may play a role in ALS pathogenesis. Further investigation into the specific immune mechanisms involved could lead to the development of targeted therapies for ALS patients.

Management of selected cystic adnexal masses in postmenopausal women by operative laparoscopy: a pilot study.  Twenty-five postmenopausal patients were predicted to have benign masses by screening criteria that included ultrasonographic findings of a cystic adnexal mass less than 10 cm with distinct borders and no evidence of irregular solid parts, thick septa, ascites, or matted bowel, and a normal serum CA 125 value (less than 35 U/ml). The study examined the feasibility and outcomes of operative laparoscopy in managing cystic adnexal masses in postmenopausal women. Twenty-five patients with benign masses, as determined by screening criteria, were included. These criteria included specific ultrasonographic findings and a normal serum CA 125 value. Operative laparoscopy successfully managed all cases, resulting in the removal of the masses without any complications or conversions to laparotomy. The results suggest that operative laparoscopy is a viable option for managing selected cystic adnexal masses in postmenopausal women. Further larger-scale studies are required to validate these findings and assess long-term outcomes.

Perivascular innervation of the cerebral arteries in spontaneously hypertensive rats--an immunohistochemical study. In this study, the authors examined the perivascular innervation of cerebral arteries in spontaneously hypertensive rats (SHR) using immunohistochemistry. They found that SHR exhibited a significant increase in the nerve density surrounding the cerebral arteries compared to normotensive control rats. Additionally, there was a significant increase in the expression of calcitonin gene-related peptide (CGRP), substance P, and neuropeptide Y in the perivascular nerves of SHR. These findings suggest an abnormal innervation pattern in the cerebral arteries of hypertensive rats, potentially contributing to the pathogenesis of hypertension. Further studies are needed to elucidate the functional significance of these alterations and their potential role in the development of hypertensive cerebrovascular diseases.

Lung injury in a surfactant-deficient lung is modified by indomethacin. Indomethacin, a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug, has been shown to have a protective effect on lung injury in certain animal models. However, its effect on lung injury in a surfactant-deficient lung has not been well studied. This study aimed to evaluate the effect of indomethacin on lung injury in a surfactant-deficient lung. Surfactant-deficient lung injury was induced in rats, and they were then treated with either indomethacin or placebo. Histological analysis, as well as evaluation of lung mechanics and inflammatory markers, was performed. The results showed that indomethacin treatment significantly reduced the severity of lung injury, as evidenced by improved histological findings and lung mechanics. Additionally, indomethacin treatment was associated with decreased levels of inflammatory markers. These findings suggest that indomethacin may have a beneficial effect on lung injury in a surfactant-deficient lung, providing potential therapeutic options for this condition. Further studies are warranted to elucidate the underlying mechanisms of this protective effect.

The acute lupus hemophagocytic syndrome [published erratum appears in Ann Intern Med 1991 Jun 1;114(11):993] OBJECTIVE: To characterize an unusual mode of presentation of systemic lupus erythematosus: acute and severe pancytopenia related to reactive hemophagocytosis.  DESIGN: Retrospective case series. The objective of this retrospective case series was to characterize an unusual mode of presentation of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE): acute and severe pancytopenia related to reactive hemophagocytosis. The study involved a review of multiple cases presenting with this syndrome. Results showed that patients presented with fever, cytopenias, hepatomegaly, and a highly activated cytotoxic T-lymphocyte immune response, characterized by reactive hemophagocytosis. Bone marrow examination revealed hemophagocytosis and variable degrees of erythroid and myeloid dysplasia. Treatment involved aggressive immunosuppression using glucocorticoids and immunosuppressive agents. The study highlights the importance of recognizing this unique presentation of SLE and implementing early aggressive treatment. It also emphasizes the need for further research to better understand the pathogenesis and optimal management of this syndrome.

Early-onset dementia and extrapyramidal disease: clinicopathological variant of Gerstmann-Straussler-Scheinker or Alzheimer's disease? A case of progressive dementia and extrapyramidal signs beginning at age 29, with a ten year course until death, is presented. This clinical case presents a 29-year-old patient who developed progressive dementia and extrapyramidal signs, which persisted for ten years until death. The clinical presentation raises questions regarding the underlying pathology, specifically whether it is a variant of Gerstmann-Straussler-Scheinker disease or Alzheimer's disease. The patient's symptoms and course indicate early-onset dementia with extrapyramidal involvement. Further studies, including histopathological examination, would be necessary to determine the exact diagnosis and differentiate between these two possibilities. This case highlights the need for comprehensive evaluation and characterization of atypical dementia cases for accurate diagnosis and management.

Plasma histamine in patients with chronic renal failure and nephrotic syndrome. We investigated the levels of plasma histamine in patients with chronic renal failure and nephrotic syndrome. In 20 patients with chronic renal failure and normal histamine levels, there was no significant difference in plasma histamine levels compared to healthy controls. However, in 28 patients with nephrotic syndrome, plasma histamine levels were significantly elevated compared to controls (p < .001). Furthermore, there was a positive correlation between plasma histamine levels and proteinuria (r = .68, p < .001) in the nephrotic syndrome group. These findings suggest that histamine may play a role in the pathogenesis of nephrotic syndrome, potentially contributing to the increase in proteinuria. Further research is needed to explore the mechanisms underlying these findings and to investigate the potential therapeutic implications of targeting histamine in nephrotic syndrome management.

Value of ventricular electrogram recordings in the diagnosis of arrhythmias precipitating electrical device shock therapy. This study aimed to evaluate the diagnostic value of ventricular electrogram (VEGM) recordings in identifying arrhythmias that lead to electrical device shock therapy. A retrospective analysis was conducted on 87 patients who experienced device shock therapy for arrhythmias. VEGM recordings were analyzed to determine the type and characteristics of the arrhythmias preceding the therapy. The results were compared with the clinical diagnosis made by electrophysiologists. It was found that VEGM recordings accurately identified the arrhythmia type in 68% of cases. Additionally, VEGM recordings provided important information on the arrhythmia characteristics, such as duration, morphology, and rate. This information was helpful in tailoring the appropriate therapy for each patient. However, in some cases, VEGM recordings were inconclusive or did not match the clinical diagnosis. Further research is needed to optimize the use of VEGM recordings in the diagnosis of arrhythmias precipitating electrical device shock therapy.

A controlled trial of psychological treatment for the irritable bowel syndrome. Irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) is a chronic functional gastrointestinal disorder that can significantly impact a patient's quality of life. This study aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of psychological treatment in managing symptoms of IBS. A controlled trial design was employed, with a total of 120 IBS patients randomly assigned to either a treatment group receiving psychological treatment or a control group receiving standard medical care. The primary outcome measures included changes in IBS symptom severity, abdominal pain, and quality of life. Secondary outcome measures included psychiatric symptoms and healthcare utilization. The psychological treatment consisted of cognitive-behavioral therapy and relaxation techniques delivered by trained therapists. Results showed that patients in the treatment group experienced significant reductions in IBS symptom severity, abdominal pain, and psychiatric symptoms compared to the control group. Additionally, improvements in quality of life and reduced healthcare utilization were observed in the treatment group. These findings suggest that psychological treatment can be an effective approach for managing symptoms of IBS.

Clot-trapper device for transjugular thrombectomy from the inferior vena cava. The use of a clot-trapper device for transjugular thrombectomy from the inferior vena cava (IVC) is a promising technique for the management of acute deep vein thrombosis (DVT). This retrospective study evaluated the efficacy and safety of the clot-trapper device in 50 patients with acute DVT.

The clot-trapper device consists of a self-expanding nitinol frame with a porous membrane that allows for aspiration and removal of the thrombus. The procedure was performed under local anesthesia using a transjugular approach. Successful thrombus removal was achieved in 92% of the patients, with a mean procedure time of 45 minutes. No major complications such as pulmonary embolism or procedural-related deaths were observed.

Post-procedural follow-up showed significant improvement in symptomatology and reduction in DVT-related morbidity. The patency rate of the IVC at 12 months was 88%. Minor complications, such as access site hematoma and transient procedural-related pain, were seen in a small percentage of patients.

In conclusion, the use of a clot-trapper device for transjugular thrombectomy from the IVC is a safe and effective technique for the management of acute DVT. Further studies are warranted to confirm these findings and explore the long-term outcomes of this innovative approach.

Intrapericardial extralobar pulmonary sequestration in a neonate. Intrapericardial extralobar pulmonary sequestration is an extremely rare congenital anomaly characterized by abnormal lung tissue located outside the normal lung parenchyma, within the pericardial sac. We report a case of a neonate with intrapericardial extralobar pulmonary sequestration that was incidentally detected on prenatal ultrasound. The neonate presented with respiratory distress shortly after birth and further imaging studies revealed a cystic lesion within the pericardium. Surgical resection of the lesion was performed and histopathological examination confirmed the diagnosis of intrapericardial extralobar pulmonary sequestration. The postoperative course was uneventful and the neonate was discharged in good condition. To our knowledge, this is the youngest reported case of intrapericardial extralobar pulmonary sequestration. This case highlights the importance of prenatal ultrasound screening to detect and manage congenital pulmonary anomalies, particularly in cases with atypical presentations or complex anatomical variations. Further studies are needed to better understand the etiology and optimal management of this rare condition.

Comparison of four pulse oximeters: effects of venous occlusion and cold-induced peripheral vasoconstriction. This study aimed to compare the performance of four pulse oximeters under different conditions of venous occlusion and cold-induced peripheral vasoconstriction. Venous occlusion was achieved using a blood pressure cuff, and peripheral vasoconstriction was induced by immersing the participant's hand in cold water. Oxygen saturation (SpO2) values obtained from the pulse oximeters were compared to arterial blood gas analysis measurements. Results showed that all four pulse oximeters produced accurate SpO2 readings under normal conditions. However, during venous occlusion and cold-induced vasoconstriction, one pulse oximeter consistently underestimated SpO2 values. This highlights the importance of considering the impact of these factors on pulse oximeter accuracy, especially in clinical settings where accurate oxygen saturation measurements are crucial.

Early carcinoma of the gallbladder: macroscopic features and US findings. To investigate the macroscopic features and ultrasound (US) findings of early carcinoma of the gallbladder, we analyzed 22 cases of early gallbladder carcinoma confirmed by histopathological examination. Macroscopically, the tumors were polypoid or papillary in 16 cases, flat in 4 cases, and nodular in 2 cases. US examination revealed gallbladder wall thickening in 18 cases, while intraluminal mass or polypoid lesion was detected in 20 cases. In 2 cases, no abnormalities were observed on US. Among the 20 cases with detectable lesions, low echoic lesions were observed in 14 cases, high echoic lesions in 4 cases, and mixed features in 2 cases. The shape of the lesions was irregular in 12 cases and regular in 8 cases. Color Doppler imaging demonstrated hypervascularity in 14 cases. Our findings suggest that early gallbladder carcinoma can present with various macroscopic features and US findings, including wall thickening, intraluminal mass, and polypoid lesion. US examination can be a valuable tool in the early detection and diagnosis of gallbladder carcinoma.

Intravenous immunoglobulin treatment in patients with chronic inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy. We conducted a study to evaluate the efficacy of intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG) treatment in patients with chronic inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy (CIDP). A total of 50 CIDP patients were enrolled and treated with IVIG for a duration of 6 months. Clinical assessments, including muscle strength, disability scales, and electromyography (EMG) findings, were recorded before and after the treatment. Out of the 50 patients, 40 (80%) showed significant improvement in muscle strength following IVIG treatment. Disability scales also demonstrated a reduction in functional impairment, with 38 patients (76%) reporting improvement. EMG findings showed remyelination and decreased conduction block in 35 patients (70%). Adverse effects were minimal, with only mild infusion-related reactions reported in 7 patients (14%). Our results indicate that IVIG treatment is an effective therapeutic option for CIDP patients, leading to improvement in muscle strength, reduction in functional impairment, and remyelination on EMG. Further studies are warranted to investigate long-term outcomes and optimal dosing strategies for IVIG in CIDP patients.

Magnetic resonance imaging in neurological disorders. The use of magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) in diagnosing neurological disorders was evaluated in this study. A total of 100 patients with various neurological disorders underwent MRI examinations. The MRI findings were compared with the clinical diagnoses made by neurologists. MRI was found to be a valuable tool in diagnosing neurological disorders, with a sensitivity of 85% and a specificity of 90%. It provided detailed imaging of brain structures, allowing for the identification of abnormalities such as tumors, vascular lesions, and white matter changes. MRI also aided in determining the extent and location of the lesions. Additionally, it helped in evaluating disease progression and treatment response. Overall, MRI has proven to be an effective diagnostic modality in the assessment of neurological disorders.

Dysplasia and DNA aneuploidy in a pelvic pouch. This study aimed to investigate dysplasia and DNA aneuploidy in a pelvic pouch. A total of 37 patients who underwent colectomy and ileal pouch-anal anastomosis were included in the analysis. Histopathological examination revealed dysplasia in 10 patients (27%), with low-grade dysplasia in 7 cases and high-grade dysplasia in 3 cases. DNA ploidy analysis using flow cytometry demonstrated aneuploid DNA content in 8 patients (21.6%). The presence of dysplasia and DNA aneuploidy was found to be significantly associated (p = 0.01). In addition, patients with dysplasia had a significantly higher frequency of pouchitis compared to those without dysplasia (p = 0.04). These findings suggest that dysplasia and DNA aneuploidy may play a role in the development of pouchitis in patients with a pelvic pouch. Further studies are warranted to validate these findings and explore the underlying mechanisms.

Successful treatment of recurrent corneal erosion with Nd:YAG anterior stromal puncture I used a new technique to create anterior corneal stromal punctures for the treatment of traumatic recurrent corneal erosions that had not responded to conventional therapy. In this study, we present a novel approach using Nd:YAG laser to perform anterior corneal stromal punctures for the treatment of non-responsive traumatic recurrent corneal erosions. Conventional therapy had failed to alleviate symptoms in these patients. The technique involved creating punctures in the anterior corneal stroma using laser energy. The procedure was successful in treating the recurrent corneal erosions and alleviating symptoms. This new technique offers a potential solution for patients who do not respond to conventional therapy and could be considered as an alternative treatment option. Further studies are warranted to evaluate the long-term efficacy and safety of this approach.

DNA analysis of multiple synchronous renal cell carcinomas.  The authors used retrospective quantitative DNA analysis to study interrelationships between multiple synchronous renal cell carcinomas in seven patients. Multiple synchronous renal cell carcinomas (RCCs) are a rare occurrence and their interrelationships remain poorly understood. This study aimed to investigate interrelationships between multiple synchronous RCCs through retrospective quantitative DNA analysis. Seven patients with multiple synchronous RCCs were included in the study. Tumor DNA samples were analyzed using flow cytometry and DNA index (DI) was determined. Results showed that all patients had concordant DI values across their multiple synchronous RCCs. Interestingly, four patients had the same DI value in all their tumors, supporting a clonal relationship. In contrast, three patients had different DI values in their tumors, suggesting independent origin or clonal divergence. These findings suggest the presence of both clonal and independent RCCs in patients with multiple synchronous tumors. Further research is needed to elucidate the underlying mechanisms and clinical implications of these interrelationships.

Macroscopic hematuria and proteinuria preceding renal IgA deposition in patients with IgA nephropathy. This retrospective study aimed to investigate the relationship between macroscopic hematuria and proteinuria preceding renal IgA deposition in patients with IgA nephropathy. A total of 132 patients diagnosed with IgA nephropathy were included in the study. The results showed that 69% of patients had a history of macroscopic hematuria, while 87% had proteinuria preceding renal IgA deposition. Additionally, the duration between the appearance of macroscopic hematuria and renal IgA deposition was significantly shorter than that for proteinuria (p<0.001). Furthermore, patients with macroscopic hematuria had a higher risk of developing renal IgA deposition compared to those without hematuria (odds ratio: 2.34, 95% confidence interval: 1.12-4.90, p=0.023). In conclusion, the presence of macroscopic hematuria and proteinuria may be early indicators of renal IgA deposition in patients with IgA nephropathy, with macroscopic hematuria appearing to be a stronger predictor.

Alanine aminotransferase in clinical practice.  A review. This review examines the clinical utility of alanine aminotransferase (ALT) in various disease states. ALT is commonly measured as a liver function test, with elevated levels indicating liver injury. The review highlights the role of ALT in diagnosing and monitoring liver diseases such as hepatitis, alcohol-related liver disease, and non-alcoholic fatty liver disease. It also discusses the limitations of ALT as a marker of liver injury, including its lack of specificity and its inability to differentiate between different causes of liver damage. Additionally, the review explores the potential use of ALT as a prognostic marker in diseases such as cardiovascular disease and cancer. Overall, ALT is considered a valuable tool in clinical practice for assessing liver health, but its interpretation should be done in conjunction with other clinical and laboratory findings.

Botulinum treatment of childhood strabismus.  Four hundred thirteen children ranging in age from 2 months to 12 years were treated for strabismus by botulinum injection of extraocular muscles. This study aimed to evaluate the efficacy of botulinum injection in treating childhood strabismus. A total of 413 children with ages ranging from 2 months to 12 years were included in the study. All patients received botulinum injection in their extraocular muscles. The success of the treatment was assessed based on improvements in ocular alignment and visual acuity. Results showed that botulinum treatment led to significant improvement in strabismus in the majority of cases. Ocular alignment was achieved in 84% of the patients, with a mean improvement of 15 degrees. Visual acuity also improved in 76% of the children. Furthermore, the procedure was well-tolerated, with only minor complications reported. Therefore, botulinum injection can be considered a safe and effective treatment option for childhood strabismus.

Factors associated with soft- and hard-tissue compromise of endosseous implants. Various factors can contribute to the compromise of soft and hard tissues surrounding endosseous implants. This study aimed to identify these factors and assess their impact on implant success. A total of 200 patients with implants were included in the analysis. The main factors analyzed were implant type, implant location, implant surface characteristics, and presence of any systemic diseases. The results showed that implant type and location significantly influenced tissue compromise, with subperiosteal implants and mandibular location being associated with a higher risk. Additionally, implants with rough surfaces showed a higher risk compared to those with smooth surfaces. Systemic diseases, especially diabetes and periodontitis, also contributed to tissue compromise around the implants. These findings highlight the importance of considering these factors when planning implant placement and managing patients with systemic diseases to achieve optimal implant outcomes.

Bilateral phrenic nerve palsy associated with open-heart surgery.  The incidence of phrenic nerve palsy after open-heart surgery has been estimated at 10%, but it is usually unilateral and does not cause symptoms. Phrenic nerve palsy is a known complication of open-heart surgery, occurring in approximately 10% of cases. Typically, this condition is unilateral and asymptomatic. However, we report a case of bilateral phrenic nerve palsy following open-heart surgery, resulting in symptomatic respiratory distress. A 58-year-old male patient underwent a coronary artery bypass graft and aortic valve replacement. Postoperatively, the patient developed acute respiratory failure due to bilateral diaphragmatic paralysis. Electrophysiological studies confirmed the diagnosis of bilateral phrenic nerve palsy. The patient required mechanical ventilation and showed gradual improvement over several weeks. This case emphasizes the importance of monitoring phrenic nerve function postoperatively, especially in high-risk patients, to timely identify and manage this potentially life-threatening complication.

Rupture of atheromatous plaque as a cause of thrombotic occlusion of stenotic internal carotid artery. Rupture of atheromatous plaque leading to thrombotic occlusion is a well-established cause of ischemic stroke. However, its association with stenotic internal carotid artery (ICA) remains unclear. In this study, we examined 78 patients with symptomatic stenotic ICA to evaluate the role of plaque rupture in thrombotic occlusion. Histological analysis of the occluded plaques revealed evidence of rupture in 54% of cases. These ruptured plaques exhibited characteristics of vulnerability, such as fibrous cap thinning or erosion. Furthermore, we found a significant correlation between plaque rupture and thrombus size. Our findings suggest that rupture of atheromatous plaque is an important mechanism underlying thrombotic occlusion in stenotic ICAs. Understanding the pathophysiology of plaque rupture may provide valuable insights into the prevention and management of ischemic stroke in these patients.

Untying the gordian knot: the genetics of Tourette syndrome. Tourette syndrome (TS) is a complex neurodevelopmental disorder characterized by motor and vocal tics. The underlying genetic basis of TS has been elusive, with multiple genes implicated in its etiology. Recent advances in genetic research, such as genome-wide association studies and exome sequencing, have shed light on the complex genetics of TS. This review provides an overview of the current understanding of the genetic architecture of TS, including the involvement of multiple genes and pathways. The identification of specific genetic variants and their functional implications may pave the way for targeted therapeutic interventions in the future. However, further research is needed to unravel the complete genetic landscape of TS and its interactions with environmental factors.

Prophylaxis of deep venous thrombosis after acute abdominal operation. Deep venous thrombosis (DVT) is a common complication after acute abdominal operations. Prophylaxis with anticoagulant therapy has been used to reduce the risk of DVT, but the optimal duration and type of therapy remains uncertain. A retrospective study was conducted to assess the efficacy and safety of different prophylactic measures for DVT in patients after acute abdominal operations. A total of 250 patients were included in the study, with 123 receiving pharmacological prophylaxis and 127 receiving mechanical prophylaxis. The incidence of DVT was found to be significantly lower in the pharmacological prophylaxis group compared to the mechanical prophylaxis group (8.1% vs. 17.3%, p=0.036). However, there was no significant difference in the incidence of bleeding complications between the two groups (4.8% vs. 3.1%, p=0.460). These findings suggest that pharmacological prophylaxis may be more effective than mechanical prophylaxis in reducing the risk of DVT after acute abdominal operations, without significantly increasing the risk of bleeding complications. Further prospective studies are warranted to confirm these findings and determine the optimal duration and type of pharmacological prophylaxis.

Cytomegalovirus colitis and wasting. Cytomegalovirus (CMV) colitis is a rare but significant cause of diarrhea, particularly in immunocompromised individuals. We present a case of a 45-year-old male with known human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) infection who presented with worsening diarrhea and unintended weight loss. Colonoscopy revealed findings consistent with CMV colitis, which was confirmed by biopsy. Antiviral treatment with ganciclovir was initiated, resulting in resolution of symptoms and improvement in weight. CMV colitis should be considered in the differential diagnosis of chronic diarrhea, especially in immunocompromised patients. Prompt diagnosis and treatment are crucial to prevent complications such as perforation and allow for optimal management of the underlying immune deficits. Further research is needed to determine the most effective treatment strategies in immunocompromised individuals with CMV colitis.

Adult T-cell leukemia/lymphoma of the tongue. Adult T-cell leukemia/lymphoma (ATLL) is a rare malignancy primarily caused by human T-cell lymphotropic virus type 1 (HTLV-1) infection. While ATLL commonly involves lymphoid tissues, extranodal involvement, particularly in the oral cavity, is extremely rare. We present a case of ATLL presenting as a primary lesion on the tongue in a 59-year-old male. The patient initially presented with a painful ulcerative lesion on the tongue, which gradually increased in size. Biopsy and immunohistochemistry confirmed the diagnosis of ATLL. The patient underwent systemic chemotherapy and local radiotherapy, resulting in a partial response. Despite aggressive treatment, the prognosis for ATLL remains poor, with a median survival of less than one year. Clinicians should consider ATLL in the differential diagnosis of oral lesions, especially in regions endemic for HTLV-1 infection. Further research is needed to explore optimal treatment strategies for ATLL with oral involvement.

Long-term outcome of massive small bowel resection.  The long-term outcome for seven patients 4-17 yr (mean 7. The long-term outcome of massive small bowel resection in seven patients aged 4 to 17 years (mean 7.7 years) was evaluated. The patients had undergone surgical resection due to various conditions including volvulus, necrotizing enterocolitis, and midgut volvulus. The median length of remaining small bowel was 40 cm. Five patients required total parenteral nutrition postoperatively, with a mean duration of 6.3 years. Three patients had intermittent episodes of obstruction requiring surgery. Four patients developed short bowel syndrome, requiring long-term nutritional support. The overall survival rate was 71%. The mean height and weight percentiles for age were below the 10th percentile at follow-up. Five patients had abnormal liver function tests, and three had cholestatic liver disease. It is concluded that massive small bowel resection in children has significant long-term morbidity and requires long-term management for nutritional and liver-related complications.

Long-term medical consequences of incest, rape, and molestation. This study aims to examine the long-term medical consequences of incest, rape, and molestation. A total of 200 survivors were interviewed about their experiences and assessed for physical and psychological health outcomes. Results indicate that survivors of incest, rape, and molestation experience a range of long-term medical consequences, including higher rates of depression, anxiety, post-traumatic stress disorder, chronic pain, and sexual dysfunction compared to non-survivors. Additionally, survivors had higher rates of substance abuse, suicide attempts, and chronic health conditions such as cardiovascular diseases and autoimmune disorders. These findings highlight the need for comprehensive healthcare and support services for survivors of sexual abuse to address their unique medical needs.

Estimation of PR and ER by immunocytochemistry in breast cancer.  Comparison with radioligand binding methods. This study evaluates the utility of immunocytochemistry (ICC) in estimating progesterone receptor (PR) and estrogen receptor (ER) levels in breast cancer, compared to radioligand binding methods. Tissue samples from 60 breast cancer patients were analyzed using both ICC and radioligand binding assays to measure PR and ER expression. ICC results were categorized as positive or negative based on staining intensity, and radioligand binding results were quantified using receptor saturation analysis. The correlation between ICC and radioligand binding measurements was assessed using the Spearman's rank correlation coefficient. The results showed a strong positive correlation between ICC and radioligand binding methods for both PR and ER measurements (p<0.001). Overall, ICC demonstrated a sensitivity of 87% and specificity of 92% for PR estimation, and a sensitivity of 90% and specificity of 95% for ER estimation. These findings suggest that ICC is a reliable and feasible alternative to radioligand binding methods for PR and ER estimation in breast cancer.

LDH isoenzymes in cerebrospinal fluid in various brain tumours.  This study examined the isoenzymatic pattern of LDH in the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) as well as the ratio between the five fractions of LDH among patients with various brain tumours, carcinomatous meningitis and control groups. This study investigated the isoenzymatic pattern of lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) in cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) samples from patients with different types of brain tumors, as well as in patients with carcinomatous meningitis and control groups. LDH fractions were analyzed, and the ratio between the five fractions of LDH was determined. The results revealed significant differences in the LDH isoenzyme pattern among the different brain tumor types and the control group. Additionally, the LDH ratio varied among the various tumor types and the control group. These findings suggest that examining LDH isoenzymes in CSF could provide valuable information for diagnosing and monitoring brain tumors and carcinomatous meningitis. Further research is needed to validate these findings and assess their clinical significance.

Analgesic use: a study of treatments used by patients for migraine prior to attending the City of London Migraine Clinic. This study aimed to investigate the use of analgesics by patients with migraine prior to attending the City of London Migraine Clinic. A total of 250 patients were included in the study. The majority of patients (85%) reported using analgesics for migraine treatment. Over-the-counter medications were the most commonly used type of analgesic (68%), followed by prescription medications (22%). Only a small percentage of patients (10%) reported using alternative therapies or no treatment at all. The use of triptans, a specific class of prescription medication for migraines, was relatively low (12%). The findings highlight the common use of analgesics, particularly over-the-counter medications, for migraine management among patients attending the clinic. Further research is needed to explore the effectiveness and safety of these treatment approaches.

Biological correlates of mental activity studied with PET. PET imaging has emerged as a valuable tool for investigating the biological correlates of mental activity. This study aimed to explore the relationship between brain metabolism, as measured by PET, and different mental activities. A total of 30 participants were recruited and underwent PET scanning while engaged in various cognitive tasks. Results showed significant increases in regional cerebral blood flow and glucose metabolism in brain regions associated with specific mental processes, such as memory retrieval, attention, and language processing. These findings provide further evidence for the dynamic nature of brain function during mental activities and highlight the potential of PET imaging in understanding the neural basis of cognitive processes. Future research should focus on replicating these findings in larger and more diverse populations.

A model of pneumococcal pneumonia in chronically intoxicated rats. Pneumococcal pneumonia is a significant cause of morbidity and mortality, particularly in individuals with chronic alcohol abuse. This study aimed to develop a model of pneumococcal pneumonia in chronically intoxicated rats to better understand the pathogenesis and evaluate potential therapeutic interventions. Rats were administered ethanol by intragastric infusion for 4 weeks, followed by intratracheal inoculation with Streptococcus pneumoniae. Lung histology, bacterial burden, inflammatory markers, and survival were assessed. Compared to control rats, chronically intoxicated rats displayed increased susceptibility to pneumococcal pneumonia, as evidenced by higher bacterial burden, greater lung inflammation, and lower survival rate. Furthermore, chronic alcohol intoxication significantly impaired the influx of neutrophils into the lungs and impaired bacterial clearance. Treatment with antibiotics improved survival in both groups but was less effective in chronically intoxicated rats. This model provides a valuable tool for investigating the mechanisms underlying the increased susceptibility to pneumococcal pneumonia in chronic alcohol abuse and for testing potential therapeutic strategies.

Combined hepatic and vena caval resection with autogenous caval graft replacement. This study aimed to evaluate the safety and efficacy of combined hepatic and vena caval resection with autogenous caval graft replacement in the treatment of extensive hepatic tumors invading the vena cava. Twenty-two patients with hepatic tumors involving the vena cava underwent this procedure, and their outcomes were analyzed retrospectively. The surgical technique involved en bloc resection of the tumor with a portion of the vena cava, followed by autogenous caval graft replacement. The postoperative complications and long-term survival were evaluated. Results showed that the combined hepatic and vena caval resection with autogenous caval graft replacement was a safe and effective treatment option. The procedure provided good local tumor control and acceptable long-term survival rates, with an overall complication rate consistent with those reported in the literature. This technique can be considered as a feasible option for patients with extensive hepatic tumors invading the vena cava.

Effects of radiation therapy on skeletal growth in childhood. Radiation therapy is a vital treatment modality for various childhood malignancies, yet it can have detrimental effects on skeletal growth. This review aimed to assess the impact of radiation therapy on skeletal growth in children. Several studies were analyzed, and the findings suggested that radiation therapy during childhood can lead to growth delay, skeletal deformities, and compromised bone quality. These effects are primarily dose-dependent and influenced by the age of the child at the time of treatment. Growth hormone deficiency and disrupted endocrine function are also associated with radiation-induced skeletal growth impairment. The underlying mechanisms involve damage to growth plates, impaired osteoblast and osteoclast function, and altered bone remodeling. Early identification and management of radiation-induced skeletal growth impairment are crucial to optimize long-term outcomes. Interventions such as growth hormone therapy, physical therapy, and orthopedic interventions can be beneficial in mitigating the effects of radiation therapy on skeletal growth. Close monitoring and multidisciplinary care involving oncologists, endocrinologists, and orthopedic specialists are essential to minimize the impact of radiation therapy on childhood skeletal growth.

Clinical spectrum of leber's congenital amaurosis in the second to fourth decades of life. Leber's congenital amaurosis (LCA) is a rare inherited retinal dystrophy characterized by severe visual impairment from birth. This study aimed to describe the clinical spectrum of LCA in patients aged 10-40 years. Retrospective data were collected from 25 individuals with genetically confirmed LCA. The most frequent symptoms were decreased visual acuity, nystagmus, and photophobia. Fundus examination revealed a range of abnormalities including macular atrophy, hyperpigmentation, and vessel attenuation. Electroretinography demonstrated severe rod-cone dysfunction in all patients. Genetic analysis identified mutations in known LCA-associated genes in 19 individuals. Additional phenotypic variability was observed, with some patients showing a later age of onset and milder visual impairment. This study highlights the diverse clinical presentation of LCA beyond childhood and underscores the importance of genetic testing for accurate diagnosis and counseling of affected individuals. Further research is needed to understand the underlying mechanisms and potential treatment options for this complex condition.

Quadriceps myopathy: forme fruste of Becker muscular dystrophy. Quadriceps myopathy is a rare condition that has been recognized as a milder variant of Becker muscular dystrophy (BMD), an X-linked recessive disorder caused by mutations in the dystrophin gene. This study aimed to investigate the clinical and genetic features of quadriceps myopathy in order to further understand its relationship with BMD. We evaluated five patients with isolated quadriceps muscle weakness and found characteristic features consistent with BMD, such as elevated levels of serum creatine kinase and abnormal electromyography findings. Genetic analysis revealed deletions in the dystrophin gene in all patients, confirming the diagnosis of BMD. Our findings suggest that quadriceps myopathy should be considered a forme fruste, or mild form, of BMD. This information is valuable for accurate diagnosis and genetic counseling of patients with quadriceps myopathy.

Response of spinal cord blood flow and motor and sensory evoked potentials to aortic ligation. This study aimed to investigate the response of spinal cord blood flow and motor and sensory evoked potentials to aortic ligation in a sample of 15 patients. Spinal cord blood flow was measured using laser Doppler flowmetry, while motor and sensory evoked potentials were recorded using surface electrodes. Results showed a significant decrease in spinal cord blood flow after aortic ligation, indicating impaired spinal cord perfusion. Motor and sensory evoked potentials also demonstrated significant changes, suggesting dysfunction in motor and sensory pathways. These findings highlight the potential impact of aortic ligation on spinal cord function and the need for monitoring and intervention to mitigate potential complications.

Prediagnostic serum levels of carotenoids and vitamin E as related to subsequent cancer in Washington County, Maryland. This study aimed to investigate the relationship between prediagnostic serum levels of carotenoids and vitamin E and the risk of subsequent cancer in Washington County, Maryland. A total of 2,564 participants aged 45-74 years were included in the study. Serum levels of alpha-carotene, beta-carotene, lycopene, lutein/zeaxanthin, and vitamin E were measured at baseline. Participants were followed for cancer incidence over a mean follow-up period of 10 years. Cox proportional hazards models were used to analyze the data, adjusting for potential confounders. The results showed that higher prediagnostic serum levels of alpha-carotene, beta-carotene, lutein/zeaxanthin, and vitamin E were associated with a decreased risk of total cancer. Specifically, higher levels of lutein/zeaxanthin were associated with a reduced risk of lung, colorectal, and skin cancers. These findings suggest that higher serum levels of certain carotenoids and vitamin E may have a protective effect against the development of cancer. Further research is needed to confirm these associations and explore potential underlying mechanisms.

Recovery from vegetative state of six months' duration associated with Sinemet (levodopa/carbidopa). A patient in a vegetative state for six months showed signs of recovery after treatment with Sinemet (levodopa/carbidopa). The patient experienced improvements in consciousness, swallowing function, and motor responses. The treatment was initiated based on the hypothesis that a deficit in dopamine neurotransmission may contribute to the vegetative state. Sinemet, a dopamine precursor, was administered orally in increasing doses over a period of three weeks. The patient's condition improved gradually, and after six weeks, the patient achieved a level of alertness consistent with minimal conscious state. This case suggests that Sinemet may have potential as a treatment option for patients in vegetative states. Further research is needed to explore the underlying mechanisms and potential benefits of this treatment approach.

Treatment of pyoderma gangrenosum with cyclosporine: results in seven patients. This study aims to assess the effectiveness of cyclosporine in treating pyoderma gangrenosum by evaluating the outcomes in seven patients. Cyclosporine, a calcineurin inhibitor, was chosen due to its immunosuppressive and anti-inflammatory properties. Data were collected through a retrospective analysis of medical records, examining patient characteristics, treatment duration, and response to therapy. All patients demonstrated positive outcomes, with complete healing observed in six individuals and significant improvement in one patient. No major adverse events or relapses were reported during treatment. These findings suggest that cyclosporine can be a viable and effective option for the treatment of pyoderma gangrenosum, warranting further investigation in larger cohort studies.

Randomised single blind trial to compare the toxicity of subconjunctival gentamicin and cefuroxime in cataract surgery.  Comparatively little attention has been paid to the conjunctival toxicity of antibiotics administered at the time of cataract surgery. This randomized single-blind trial aimed to compare the conjunctival toxicity of subconjunctival gentamicin and cefuroxime in cataract surgery. Limited attention has been given to the conjunctival toxicity associated with the use of antibiotics during this procedure. The study involved participants undergoing cataract surgery who were randomly assigned to receive either gentamicin or cefuroxime subconjunctivally. Conjunctival toxicity was assessed at various time points postoperatively. The results showed no significant difference in conjunctival toxicity between the two antibiotic treatments. These findings suggest that both gentamicin and cefuroxime are well-tolerated and safe options for the prevention of postoperative infection in cataract surgery. Further research is warranted to confirm these results.

Neuropsychological aspects of learning disabilities in epilepsy. This study aimed to investigate the neuropsychological aspects of learning disabilities in epilepsy. A total of 65 patients with epilepsy were assessed using various cognitive tests and compared to a control group of 50 healthy individuals. Results showed that patients with epilepsy had significantly lower scores in measures of intelligence, attention, memory, and executive function compared to the control group. Furthermore, the severity and frequency of seizures were found to be associated with worse cognitive performance. Specifically, patients with uncontrolled seizures and those with early-onset epilepsy were more likely to experience learning difficulties. These findings highlight the importance of considering neuropsychological factors in the diagnosis and management of learning disabilities in individuals with epilepsy. Further research is needed to develop tailored interventions to address these specific cognitive deficits in this population.

Longitudinal histopathologic assessment of rejection after bladder-drained canine pancreas allograft transplantation. In this study, we performed a longitudinal histopathologic assessment of rejection following bladder-drained canine pancreas allograft transplantation. Six dogs underwent allograft transplantation and were followed for a period of 90 days. Serial bladder-drained urine samples were collected for analysis of urinary amylase levels, which served as an indicator of pancreatic allograft viability and rejection. Additionally, pancreas biopsies were obtained at various time points post-transplantation for histopathologic evaluation. 

Histologic examination revealed a progressive increase in lymphocytic infiltration, interstitial fibrosis, and acinar atrophy over time. Immunohistochemical staining demonstrated the presence of infiltrating T lymphocytes within the islets of transplanted pancreas, indicative of rejection. 

Furthermore, urinary amylase levels showed a significant increase following transplantation, peaking at around day 40 and subsequently declining. This temporal correlation suggests a direct association between rejection and pancreatic injury. 

In conclusion, our findings demonstrate the occurrence and progression of histologic rejection in bladder-drained canine pancreas allograft transplantation. Further understanding of the underlying mechanisms contributing to rejection will aid in the development of targeted therapeutic strategies to improve the long-term outcomes of pancreas transplantation.

Postoperative pancreatic abscess due to Plesiomonas shigelloides.  Plesiomonas shigelloides is being recognized with increasing frequency as a human pathogen. Postoperative pancreatic abscess is a serious complication following surgery. Plesiomonas shigelloides, a Gram-negative bacterium, is an emerging pathogen causing various infections. Here, we report a case of postoperative pancreatic abscess caused by Plesiomonas shigelloides. The patient presented with fever, abdominal pain, and elevated inflammatory markers. Imaging studies revealed a localized fluid collection in the pancreatic region. Plesiomonas shigelloides was isolated from the drained fluid. The patient was successfully treated with antibiotics targeting this specific pathogen. This case highlights the importance of considering Plesiomonas shigelloides as a potential cause of postoperative pancreatic abscess, especially in patients with compatible clinical and radiological findings. Prompt diagnosis and appropriate management are crucial to prevent severe complications and reduce morbidity in these patients.

Uniparental paternal disomy in Angelman's syndrome. Angelman's syndrome (AS) is a neurogenetic disorder characterized by severe intellectual disability, developmental delay, speech impairment, and characteristic behaviors. It is caused by the loss of function of the maternally inherited UBE3A gene. In a small subset of AS cases, uniparental paternal disomy (UPD) is observed, where both copies of chromosome 15 are inherited from the father instead of one from the mother and one from the father. We examined the frequency of UPD in a cohort of AS patients and found that it occurred in 12% of cases. Furthermore, we identified several clinical features associated with UPD, including a higher prevalence of epilepsy and a more severe phenotype. This study highlights the significance of UPD in the pathogenesis of AS and emphasizes the need for genetic testing in patients with a suspected diagnosis.

Pleuropulmonary manifestations of hepatic amebiasis Pleuropulmonary manifestations of hepatic amebiasis occurred in 30 patients; 18 (60%) presented with at least 1 pulmonary complaint and 10 (33%) had multiple pulmonary symptoms. This study focuses on the pleuropulmonary manifestations of hepatic amebiasis. A total of 30 patients were included, with 18 (60%) presenting with at least one pulmonary complaint and 10 (33%) experiencing multiple pulmonary symptoms. The findings suggest a strong association between hepatic amebiasis and pleuropulmonary involvement. The most common pulmonary complaints reported were cough, chest pain, and dyspnea. Radiological examinations revealed lung parenchymal lesions in 22 patients and pleural effusion in 10 patients. Additionally, pleural fluid analysis showed the presence of amebic organisms in 15 patients. These findings highlight the importance of considering hepatic amebiasis as a potential cause of pleuropulmonary symptoms, particularly in regions where this parasitic infection is prevalent.

Acute tumor lysis syndrome after intrathecal methotrexate administration. Acute tumor lysis syndrome (TLS) is a rare but potentially fatal complication of chemotherapy that primarily occurs in patients with high-grade lymphomas and leukemias. We report a case of TLS following intrathecal methotrexate (IT MTX) administration in a 26-year-old patient with acute lymphoblastic leukemia. The patient presented with hyperuricemia, hyperkalemia, and acute renal failure, along with laboratory findings consistent with TLS. Prompt initiation of aggressive therapy including hydration, allopurinol, rasburicase, and aggressive diuresis led to the resolution of TLS and improvement in renal function. This case highlights the importance of recognizing TLS as a potential complication of IT MTX and the need for prompt intervention to prevent morbidity and mortality associated with TLS. Further research is warranted to identify risk factors and develop preventative strategies specific to IT MTX-induced TLS.

Intradural spinal cord tumor presenting as a subarachnoid hemorrhage: magnetic resonance imaging diagnosis. Intradural spinal cord tumors are rare and often present with nonspecific symptoms. We present a case of a 60-year-old male who presented with sudden onset severe headache and neck pain, associated with loss of consciousness. Initial evaluation revealed subarachnoid hemorrhage on brain computed tomography scan. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the spine was performed and revealed an intradural spinal cord tumor at the level of T8-T9. The tumor was hypointense on T1-weighted images and hyperintense on T2-weighted images, with heterogeneous enhancement following contrast administration. Surgical resection of the tumor was performed, and histopathological examination confirmed a schwannoma. Postoperatively, the patient's symptoms improved, and there was no evidence of tumor recurrence on follow-up MRI. In conclusion, intradural spinal cord tumors can rarely present as subarachnoid hemorrhage, and MRI is crucial for accurate diagnosis and treatment planning. Early surgical resection can lead to favorable outcomes in these cases.

Transferrin receptor activity as a marker in transitional cell carcinoma of the bladder. Transitional cell carcinoma (TCC) of the bladder is a common form of bladder cancer. This study aimed to investigate the potential use of transferrin receptor activity as a marker for TCC. Transferrin receptor activity was measured in tumor tissue samples from 55 patients with TCC of the bladder. Results were compared to 30 control tissue samples from individuals without TCC. Transferrin receptor activity was significantly higher in TCC tumor tissue compared to control tissue. Furthermore, receptor activity was found to be correlated with tumor stage and grade. Patients with higher levels of transferrin receptor activity were more likely to have advanced tumor stage and higher grade tumors. This suggests that higher transferrin receptor activity may be associated with more aggressive forms of TCC. Therefore, transferrin receptor activity may serve as a potential marker for the diagnosis and prognosis of TCC, as well as a target for therapeutic interventions. Further studies are warranted to validate these findings and explore the underlying mechanisms.

The significance of moderate and severe inflammation on class I Papanicolaou smear The significance of a cytologic diagnosis of moderate and severe inflammation with a normal (class I) Papanicolaou smear has not been addressed.  A retrospective review of 596 consecutive cervical smears performed over 13 months revealed 85 women who had a class I cytologic smear with moderate to severe inflammation. The significance of moderate and severe inflammation on a normal Papanicolaou smear is not well understood. A review of 596 consecutive cervical smears found 85 cases with moderate to severe inflammation and a normal cytologic smear. The impact of this finding on patient management and the need for further evaluation requires further investigation.

Infrarenal abdominal aortic disease: a review of the retroperitoneal approach. This review aimed to evaluate the retroperitoneal approach in the management of infrarenal abdominal aortic disease. The authors analyzed various studies and case reports to assess the feasibility and outcomes of this surgical approach. The retroperitoneal approach was found to offer advantages such as reduced risk of bowel injury, decreased operating time, and improved postoperative recovery. It was particularly beneficial in patients with anatomical challenges or previous abdominal surgeries. Additionally, the retroperitoneal approach was associated with low morbidity and mortality rates. The authors concluded that this technique provides a safe and effective alternative for treating infrarenal abdominal aortic disease.

Urogenital dysfunction after abdominoperineal resection for carcinoma of the rectum. Urogenital dysfunction is a common complication following abdominoperineal resection for carcinoma of the rectum. This review aims to summarize the available literature regarding the prevalence, risk factors, and management strategies for urogenital dysfunction in these patients. It is essential to recognize the impact of this complication on patients' quality of life and to proactively address its management. The most frequently reported symptoms include urinary incontinence, erectile dysfunction, and decreased sexual function. Risk factors identified include male gender, advanced age, neoadjuvant therapy, and pelvic floor injury. Various treatment options, such as pelvic floor exercises, pharmacotherapy, and surgical interventions, have been proposed to manage urogenital dysfunction. Further research is needed to determine the most effective strategies for prevention and management.

Antibodies to nuclear lamin C in chronic hepatitis delta virus infection. In this retrospective study, we aimed to investigate the presence of antibodies to nuclear lamin C in patients with chronic hepatitis delta virus (HDV) infection. Serum samples from 85 patients with chronic HDV infection were evaluated for the presence of antibodies to nuclear lamin C using an enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay. Of the 85 patients, 65 (76%) tested positive for antibodies to nuclear lamin C. Further analysis revealed a significant association between the presence of these antibodies and disease severity, as indicated by higher levels of liver enzymes and more advanced liver fibrosis. Additionally, patients positive for antibodies to nuclear lamin C had a higher rate of viral replication and lower response to antiviral therapy. These findings suggest that antibodies to nuclear lamin C may serve as a potential biomarker for disease severity and treatment response in patients with chronic HDV infection.
 

Keywords: chronic hepatitis delta virus infection, antibodies, nuclear lamin C, disease severity, antiviral therapy.

Middle cerebral artery flow velocity waveforms in fetal hypoxaemia. This study aimed to investigate the changes in middle cerebral artery (MCA) flow velocity waveforms in fetal hypoxemia. A total of 47 pregnant women with suspected fetal hypoxemia were included in the study. Doppler ultrasound was used to measure the MCA peak systolic velocity (PSV), end diastolic velocity (EDV), pulsatility index (PI), and resistance index (RI). The results showed that in cases of fetal hypoxemia, there was a significant decrease in PSV and EDV, as well as an increase in PI and RI, indicating impaired cerebral blood flow. These changes were more pronounced in severe cases of hypoxemia. The study suggests that measurement of MCA flow velocity waveforms can be a useful tool in the assessment of fetal hypoxemia, allowing for early intervention and management to prevent adverse outcomes.

The acutely affected abdomen in paraplegic spinal cord injury patients. Paraplegic spinal cord injury (SCI) patients commonly present with acute abdominal symptoms. This study aimed to investigate the etiology and management of the acutely affected abdomen in these patients. Thirty paraplegic SCI patients with acute abdominal symptoms were included in the study. The most common presenting symptoms were abdominal pain, distension, and constipation. Causes of the acutely affected abdomen included paralytic ileus, fecal impaction, urinary tract infection, and mesenteric ischemia. Non-operative management was successfully applied in the majority of cases, with surgical intervention required in a small proportion. Prompt recognition and appropriate management of the acutely affected abdomen in paraplegic SCI patients is essential to prevent complications and improve outcomes.

Clinical recognition and evaluation of peptic ulcer disease. Peptic ulcer disease (PUD) is a common gastrointestinal disorder characterized by mucosal damage in the stomach or duodenum. Prompt clinical recognition and evaluation are crucial for effective management. Identification of risk factors such as Helicobacter pylori infection, nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) use, smoking, and alcohol consumption can aid in the diagnosis. Patients with PUD often present with abdominal pain, which can range from epigastric discomfort to severe pain. Other symptoms may include dyspepsia, nausea, vomiting, and melena. Physical examination may reveal epigastric tenderness, while laboratory tests may show anemia or evidence of H. pylori infection. Upper gastrointestinal endoscopy is the gold standard for confirming the diagnosis and evaluating the severity and location of ulcers. It also allows for biopsy and testing for H. pylori. Treatment strategies include lifestyle modifications, eradication of H. pylori infection, cessation of NSAIDs, and acid-suppressive therapy. Complications such as bleeding, perforation, and gastric outlet obstruction may require urgent intervention. Overall, early recognition and appropriate evaluation of PUD can guide effective management and prevent complications.

Persistent mullerian duct syndrome. Persistent Mullerian Duct Syndrome (PMDS) is a rare genetic disorder characterized by the persistence of Mullerian duct derivatives, including the uterus, fallopian tubes, and upper part of the vagina in individuals with male karyotype. This condition results from a defect in anti-Mullerian hormone (AMH) signaling, leading to the persistence of the Mullerian ducts in an otherwise phenotypically male individual. 

In this case series, we present three cases of PMDS diagnosed in adulthood. The first case involves a 30-year-old male who presented with bilateral inguinal hernias and was incidentally found to have a uterus during laparoscopic inguinal hernia repair. The second case involves a 25-year-old male who presented with right groin pain and was diagnosed with an obstructed right fallopian tube. The third case involves a 28-year-old male who presented with infertility and was found to have a uterus and bilateral fallopian tubes during an infertility workup.

In all three cases, the patients had normal male external genitalia and male karyotype (46,XY). Genetic testing confirmed the presence of mutations in the AMH gene, confirming the diagnosis of PMDS. 

PMDS is a rare condition and often remains undiagnosed until adulthood when the development of secondary sexual characteristics or reproductive difficulties prompts further investigation. Awareness of this syndrome is crucial for accurate diagnosis and appropriate management. Surgical removal of the Mullerian duct derivatives may be necessary in symptomatic cases, such as those with obstructed fallopian tubes or recurrent hernias. Genetic counseling is also essential for affected individuals and their families to understand the inheritance pattern and potential implications for future pregnancies.

Introducing the 'walk-up' flap. The 'walk-up' flap is a novel technique for reconstructive surgery in the lower extremities. It involves the elevation of a proximally-based fasciocutaneous flap through sequential incisions, allowing for increased mobilization and versatility in flap placement. A retrospective study was conducted on 52 patients who underwent reconstruction using the 'walk-up' flap technique. The average flap size was 35.6 cm2, and the most common indications for surgery were trauma-related soft tissue defects and chronic wounds. The overall success rate of the flap was 94.2%, with 4 cases of partial flap loss and 1 case of complete flap loss. Complications included wound dehiscence and infection, but these were managed successfully with appropriate wound care. The 'walk-up' flap provides a reliable and effective option for soft tissue reconstruction in the lower extremities, offering improved outcomes and patient satisfaction.

Sudden death due to delayed rupture of hepatic subcapsular hematoma following blunt abdominal trauma. Delayed rupture of hepatic subcapsular hematoma following blunt abdominal trauma is a rare but potentially fatal condition. We report a case of a 35-year-old male who presented with abdominal pain and hypovolemic shock three days after sustaining a blunt abdominal injury. Imaging studies revealed a large hepatic subcapsular hematoma with signs of active bleeding. Despite immediate surgical intervention, the patient developed sudden cardiac arrest due to massive hemorrhage from the ruptured hematoma. Despite aggressive resuscitation efforts, the patient could not be revived. This case highlights the importance of prompt recognition and early intervention in patients with hepatic subcapsular hematoma to prevent life-threatening complications such as delayed rupture and sudden death.

Long-term potentiation of electrotonic coupling at mixed synapses. This study investigated long-term potentiation (LTP) of electrotonic coupling at mixed synapses. Mixed synapses are characterized by their ability to transmit both chemical and electrical signals. The authors used electrophysiological techniques to examine the changes in electrotonic coupling strength in the neurons of the goldfish optic tectum following high-frequency stimulation (HFS). They found that HFS led to a long-lasting increase in electrotonic coupling strength at mixed synapses, indicating LTP. This LTP was dependent on the activation of N-methyl-D-aspartate receptors and protein kinase C. The authors also identified the involvement of gap junction proteins in this process. These findings suggest that LTP of electrotonic coupling at mixed synapses contributes to the plasticity of neuronal networks in the goldfish optic tectum. Further studies are warranted to explore the functional implications of this LTP and its potential role in information processing and integration in the visual system.

Limb-salvage surgery in the treatment of osteosarcoma in skeletally immature individuals. Osteosarcoma is the most common primary malignant bone tumor in children and adolescents. Limb-salvage surgery has emerged as a viable alternative to amputation for the treatment of osteosarcoma in skeletally immature individuals. This paper provides an overview of the current body of literature on limb-salvage surgery in this patient population. The benefits of limb-salvage surgery include the preservation of limb function and a decrease in psychosocial impact compared to amputation. Various surgical techniques, such as allograft reconstruction, endoprosthesis, and biological reconstruction, are discussed in terms of their advantages and drawbacks. The importance of proper patient selection and the use of neoadjuvant chemotherapy to improve surgical outcomes are highlighted. Long-term outcomes, including local recurrence, infection, and functional outcomes, are also addressed. Overall, limb-salvage surgery in skeletally immature individuals with osteosarcoma provides an effective method for preserving limb function and improving quality of life. Ongoing research efforts are warranted to further optimize surgical techniques and improve long-term outcomes.

The management of postoperative chylous ascites. Chylous ascites is a rare condition characterized by the accumulation of milky fluid in the peritoneal cavity. This study aimed to evaluate the management strategies and outcomes of postoperative chylous ascites in a cohort of patients. A retrospective analysis of medical records identified 32 patients who developed chylous ascites following various surgical procedures. The majority of cases were managed conservatively with dietary modifications, including a medium-chain triglyceride (MCT) diet and total parenteral nutrition (TPN). Additional interventions, such as paracentesis, peritoneovenous shunting, and somatostatin analog therapy, were required in a small subset of patients. The overall success rate of conservative management was 69%, with resolution of chylous ascites observed in the majority of patients within 4 weeks. In conclusion, conservative management with dietary modifications is effective in the majority of cases of postoperative chylous ascites, with additional interventions reserved for refractory cases.

Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease--more than a renal disease.  Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD) is the most common genetic disease, affecting a half million Americans. Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD) is a prevalent genetic disorder that not only affects the kidneys but also has multi-system manifestations. This disease affects approximately half a million Americans. ADPKD is characterized by the presence of numerous cysts in the kidneys and is associated with various complications, including hypertension, chronic kidney disease, and intracranial aneurysms. Additionally, ADPKD can also affect the liver, pancreas, spleen, and other organs. This disease has a significant impact on the quality of life and can lead to end-stage renal disease. Management of ADPKD focuses on symptomatic treatment, lifestyle modifications, and surveillance for complications. New targeted therapies, such as tolvaptan, have shown promise in slowing disease progression. This abstract highlights the importance of recognizing ADPKD as more than just a renal disease and emphasizes the need for comprehensive management approaches.

Endoscopic nasobiliary catheter drainage in biliary and pancreatic disease. Endoscopic nasobiliary catheter (ENBC) drainage is a minimally invasive procedure used in the management of biliary and pancreatic diseases. This retrospective study aimed to assess the efficacy of ENBC drainage in a cohort of patients with various biliary and pancreatic conditions. A total of 72 patients underwent ENBC placement, including those with obstructive jaundice, post-operative bile leak, pancreatitis, and cholangitis. Successful ENBC placement was achieved in 69 patients (95.8%), with a median drainage duration of 16 days. The procedure resulted in improved liver function tests, resolution of biliary obstruction, and relief of symptoms in the majority of patients. Complications were rare and mostly minor. ENBC drainage appears to be a safe and effective therapeutic option for selected patients with biliary and pancreatic diseases.

Speech, velopharyngeal function, and hearing before and after orthognathic surgery.  Articulation, voice, resonance, hearing sensitivity, and middle ear function were examined in 34 patients before and 3, 6, 9, and 12 months after orthognathic surgery. This study aimed to evaluate the effects of orthognathic surgery on speech, velopharyngeal function, and hearing. A total of 34 patients underwent a comprehensive assessment before surgery and at 3, 6, 9, and 12 months post-surgery. The assessment included measures of articulation, voice quality, resonance, hearing sensitivity, and middle ear function. 

Results showed significant improvements in speech outcomes post-surgery, with enhanced articulation and voice quality observed at all follow-up time points. Velopharyngeal function also demonstrated improvement, as indicated by decreased nasal resonance and improved closure of the velopharyngeal port. Additionally, hearing sensitivity remained stable throughout the follow-up period, indicating no detrimental effects of the surgery on auditory function. Middle ear function, assessed via tympanometry, showed no significant changes post-surgery. 

In conclusion, orthognathic surgery positively impacted speech and velopharyngeal function, while maintaining stable hearing sensitivity. These findings support the effectiveness of orthognathic surgery in improving both functional and aesthetic outcomes for patients with dentofacial deformities.

Osteoid osteoma of the scapula. Osteoid osteoma is a benign bone tumor that commonly affects long bones in young adults. However, its occurrence in the scapula is rare. We present a case of osteoid osteoma located in the scapula of a 25-year-old male, who presented with chronic shoulder pain. Radiographic imaging revealed a well-defined, sclerotic lesion with a central radiolucent nidus in the scapular body. Computed tomography scan confirmed the diagnosis, showing a small, round lesion with central calcification. The patient underwent surgical excision of the lesion, with subsequent resolution of symptoms. Osteoid osteoma should be considered in the differential diagnosis of chronic shoulder pain, even in unusual locations such as the scapula. Early recognition and appropriate management can lead to successful outcomes.

Role of membrane proteins in monosodium urate crystal-membrane interactions. Monosodium urate crystal (MSU) deposition in joints is a key characteristic of gout. Here, we investigated the role of membrane proteins in MSU crystal-membrane interactions. Using atomic force microscopy, we observed that MSU crystals interacted with lipid bilayers and induced membrane deformation. Additionally, we observed that the presence of membrane proteins, such as toll-like receptor 4 (TLR4) and CD14, enhanced MSU crystal adhesion to the membrane, resulting in increased membrane deformation. Furthermore, blocking TLR4 or CD14 with specific antibodies reduced MSU crystal-induced membrane deformation.
