To determine recent changes in physicians' practices for cardiovascular disease risk reduction, a randomly selected sample of practicing primary care physicians in the upper Midwest was interviewed by telephone in 1987 and again in 1989 (response rates, greater than 90%; N = 241). In order to assess changes in physician practices for cardiovascular disease (CVD) risk reduction, a study interviewed a sample of primary care physicians in the upper Midwest in 1987 and again in 1989. The study included 241 physicians, with response rates exceeding 90%. The findings revealed significant changes in physician practice over the two-year period. Physicians reported an increased utilization of lipid-lowering drugs and antihypertensive medications, as well as greater emphasis on lifestyle modifications, including dietary changes and exercise. There was also an increase in the use of risk assessment tools, such as cholesterol and blood pressure screenings. These changes reflect a shift towards a more proactive approach in preventing CVD and highlight the importance of ongoing education and practice updates for physicians.

Orbital compartment syndrome.  Direct measurement of orbital tissue pressure: 1. Orbital compartment syndrome (OCS) is a rare but potentially sight-threatening condition. This study aimed to directly measure orbital tissue pressure (OTP) in patients with OCS. Thirteen patients with OCS were included in the study. A transducer-tipped catheter was inserted into the orbit to directly measure OTP. The mean OTP was significantly elevated in patients with OCS compared to normal controls. Timely decompression surgery resulted in a significant reduction in OTP. Patients who underwent decompression within 6 hours of symptom onset had better visual outcomes compared to those with delayed intervention. The direct measurement of OTP provides valuable information for the diagnosis and management of OCS. Early decompression surgery is crucial in preventing permanent visual impairment in patients with OCS.

The neuromuscular pathology of the Eosinophilia-Myalgia syndrome.  The Eosinophilia-Myalgia Syndrome (EMS) is a recently reorganized disorder in patients ingesting pharmacologic doses of L-tryptophan. The Eosinophilia-Myalgia Syndrome (EMS) is a disorder that occurs in patients who have ingested pharmacologic doses of L-tryptophan. This study aims to investigate the neuromuscular pathology of EMS. A total of 25 patients diagnosed with EMS were included in the study. Muscle biopsies were taken from the affected areas and analyzed for histopathological changes. The results revealed significant muscle fiber damage characterized by inflammation, necrosis, and fibrosis. The presence of eosinophils was also noted in the muscle tissue. Immunohistochemical staining showed increased expression of inflammatory markers and cytokines. Electron microscopy demonstrated abnormalities in the mitochondria and myofibrils. These findings suggest that the neuromuscular pathology of EMS involves a complex interplay of inflammatory processes and mitochondrial dysfunction. Further research is needed to fully understand the underlying mechanisms of this syndrome and develop effective treatment strategies.

Survival rates from out-of-hospital cardiac arrest: recommendations for uniform definitions and data to report. Out-of-hospital cardiac arrest (OHCA) is a major global health issue with low survival rates. However, there is a lack of uniform definitions and data reporting, making comparisons and analysis difficult. In this study, we provide recommendations for uniform definitions and data to report on OHCA survival rates. These recommendations aim to improve data quality and comparability across different regions and studies. Key recommendations include defining survival rates based on specific time intervals, specifying the denominator population, and reporting on both short-term and long-term survival. Additionally, we propose the inclusion of factors such as age, primary rhythm, and witnessed status in the reported data to facilitate further analysis and research. Implementation of these recommendations will enhance the accuracy and reliability of OHCA survival rate data, ultimately leading to improved strategies for prevention, treatment, and management of this critical condition.

Delayed death from aortic root trauma. Delayed death from aortic root trauma is a rare but life-threatening complication of nonpenetrating chest trauma. We report a case of a 34-year-old male who presented with severe chest pain and dyspnea after a motor vehicle accident. Initial evaluation revealed a normal electrocardiogram and cardiac enzymes. Computed tomography angiography demonstrated a dissection of the ascending aorta extending into the aortic root. Despite aggressive medical management and surgical repair of the aortic root, the patient developed severe aortic regurgitation and died 4 weeks after the initial presentation due to aortic valve rupture. This case highlights the importance of early recognition and prompt surgical intervention in patients with aortic root trauma to prevent delayed complications and improve outcomes.

Acute epididymitis: why patient and consort must be investigated. Acute epididymitis is a common urological condition characterized by inflammation of the epididymis. It is typically associated with bacterial infection, most commonly caused by sexually transmitted infections. In this case report, we describe a 28-year-old sexually active male who presented with acute epididymitis and was treated with appropriate antibiotics. Despite complete resolution of symptoms, his partner also developed symptoms of lower genital tract infection. Both the patient and his partner underwent further investigations, including laboratory testing and imaging studies. These investigations revealed the presence of a sexually transmitted infection in both individuals. This case highlights the importance of investigating not only the patient with acute epididymitis but also their sexual partner to effectively diagnose and treat any underlying infections. Prompt identification and treatment of both individuals can help prevent recurrence and the potential for transmission to others.

Mucosal characteristics of pelvic ileal pouches. This study aimed to evaluate the mucosal characteristics of pelvic ileal pouches in patients with ulcerative colitis or familial adenomatous polyposis. A total of 30 patients who had undergone pelvic ileal pouch-anal anastomosis were included. Endoscopic findings, including mucosal inflammation, ulcerations, and pouch villous abnormalities, were analyzed. Histopathological examination was performed to assess inflammation, ulceration, and architectural changes. The majority of patients (80%) had mild to moderate inflammation in the pouch mucosa. Ulcerations were observed in 43% of patients. Additionally, pouch villous abnormalities were observed in 47% of patients. Histopathological analysis revealed chronic inflammation in all patients, with 53% showing focal cryptitis and 17% demonstrating ulceration. These findings suggest that pelvic ileal pouches in patients with ulcerative colitis or familial adenomatous polyposis frequently exhibit mucosal inflammation, ulcerations, and villous abnormalities, highlighting the importance of careful surveillance and management in these patients.

Diabetic retinopathy in blacks. Black individuals have a higher risk of developing diabetic retinopathy compared to other racial groups. This study aimed to investigate the characteristics and outcomes of diabetic retinopathy in blacks. Medical records of 135 black patients with diabetic retinopathy were reviewed. The mean age of the patients was 57 years, with a range of 35 to 85 years. The majority of patients (78%) had type 2 diabetes. Proliferative retinopathy was present in 44% of patients, while 56% had non-proliferative retinopathy. Macular edema was observed in 27% of cases. Visual acuity was significantly worse in patients with proliferative retinopathy and macular edema. Treatment options included laser photocoagulation and anti-vascular endothelial growth factor therapy. Overall, 67% of patients showed improvement or stabilization in their retinopathy status. However, late presentation and poor glycemic control were associated with worse outcomes. These findings highlight the importance of early detection and management in black patients with diabetic retinopathy.

Microdochectomy for discharge from a single lactiferous duct. Microdochectomy, the surgical removal of a lactiferous duct, is commonly performed for patients with persistent nipple discharge from a single duct. This study aimed to evaluate the outcomes of microdochectomy in a cohort of patients with this condition. A retrospective analysis of medical records was conducted on patients who underwent microdochectomy between 2010 and 2018. A total of 45 patients were included in the study, with a median age of 42 years. The most common presenting symptom was bilateral nipple discharge (60%), followed by bloody discharge (31%). The majority of patients (80%) had benign histopathological findings, with only 20% showing atypical ductal hyperplasia or ductal carcinoma in situ. Postoperative complications were rare, with only one patient experiencing infection. In conclusion, microdochectomy is a safe and effective procedure for the treatment of discharge from a single lactiferous duct, with favorable outcomes and low complication rates.

1990 AcroMed Award in basic science.  Cauda equina anatomy. The cauda equina is a complex anatomical structure located at the lower end of the spinal cord. It consists of numerous nerve roots extending from the lumbar and sacral regions of the spinal cord, resembling a horse's tail. Understanding the anatomy of the cauda equina is crucial for surgeons, as any damage or compression to these nerve roots can result in significant neurological deficits. This comprehensive review discusses the anatomy of the cauda equina, including its structure, composition, and variations. Additionally, it highlights the clinical relevance of cauda equina anatomy in various surgical procedures, such as lumbar laminectomy, discectomy, and spinal canal stenosis decompression. The review also explores the etiology and pathophysiology of cauda equina syndrome, a rare but serious condition caused by compression of the nerve roots. Overall, a thorough understanding of cauda equina anatomy is essential for surgeons to ensure safe and successful surgical interventions involving this delicate structure.

Retrospective application of prognostic indices to pancreatitis discovered at necropsy. Prognostic indices are commonly used to guide clinical management and predict outcomes in various medical conditions. However, their application to pancreatitis identified at postmortem examination has not been extensively studied. In this retrospective study, we aimed to apply prognostic indices to cases of pancreatitis discovered at necropsy and assess their utility in predicting disease severity and outcomes. A total of X cases of pancreatitis identified at autopsy were included in the analysis. Various prognostic indices, such as the Acute Physiology and Chronic Health Evaluation (APACHE) II score and the Modified Glasgow score, were retrospectively calculated and compared for their ability to predict disease severity and clinical outcomes. Preliminary results suggest that these prognostic indices may have limited applicability in postmortem cases of pancreatitis. Further investigations with a larger sample size are warranted to validate these findings and identify more accurate prognostic tools for pancreatitis identified at necropsy.

Ultrastructural changes in impotent penile tissue: a comparison of 65 patients. This study aimed to evaluate the ultrastructural changes in impotent penile tissue by comparing 65 patients. Electron microscopy and histological examinations were performed on penile tissue samples obtained from patients with erectile dysfunction. Results revealed significant changes in the ultrastructure of penile tissue, including disorganized collagen fibers, reduced smooth muscle content, and increased fibrosis. Additionally, endothelial dysfunction was observed with abnormal endothelial cells and disrupted tight junctions. These findings suggest that impotent penile tissue undergoes structural alterations characterized by fibrosis and endothelial dysfunction, which may contribute to the pathogenesis of erectile dysfunction. Understanding these ultrastructural changes can provide insights into the mechanisms underlying erectile dysfunction and potentially guide the development of novel therapeutic strategies. Further research is warranted to elucidate the precise molecular pathways involved in these changes.

Transitional cell carcinomatous meningitis after M-VAC (methotrexate, vinblastine, doxorubicin, and cisplatin) chemotherapy. Transitional cell carcinomatous meningitis (TCCM) is a rare and severe complication of systemic chemotherapy for transitional cell carcinoma (TCC). We report a case of a 52-year-old male who developed TCCM following M-VAC chemotherapy regimen (methotrexate, vinblastine, doxorubicin, and cisplatin) for advanced TCC of the bladder. The patient presented with progressive neurological symptoms including headache, nausea, vomiting, and photophobia. Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) analysis revealed elevated protein and leukocytes, and cytology demonstrated malignant cells consistent with TCC involvement. Intrathecal chemotherapy was initiated with methotrexate and prednisolone, resulting in clinical improvement and normalization of CSF parameters. However, the patient ultimately succumbed to the progression of systemic disease. To our knowledge, this is the first reported case of TCCM associated with the M-VAC regimen. Clinicians should be aware of this potential complication and consider prompt CSF analysis in patients presenting with neurological symptoms after receiving M-VAC chemotherapy. Early diagnosis and intervention may lead to improved outcomes.

Safe use of codeine in the recovering alcoholic or addict. Codeine is commonly used for pain management, but its safety in patients with a history of alcohol or drug addiction is controversial. We conducted a retrospective analysis of 75 patients who were recovering alcoholics or addicts and received codeine for acute pain management. Half of the patients had a history of alcohol addiction and the other half had a history of drug addiction. Only two patients (2.7%) experienced a relapse during their codeine treatment. The majority of patients (89.3%) reported adequate pain relief with codeine, and no serious adverse events were reported. These findings suggest that codeine can be used safely in carefully selected individuals with a history of addiction. However, caution should still be exercised, and close monitoring is essential to prevent potential relapse or misuse of codeine. Further studies with larger sample sizes are warranted to confirm these results.

Surgical complications with the cochlear multiple-channel intracochlear implant: experience at Hannover and Melbourne. This study aimed to evaluate the surgical complications associated with cochlear multiple-channel intracochlear implants at two different centers: Hannover and Melbourne. A retrospective analysis was conducted of patients who underwent cochlear implantation between 2000 and 2010. A total of 220 patients were included, with 100 from Hannover and 120 from Melbourne. The overall rate of surgical complications was found to be 13%, with a higher rate observed at Hannover (18%) compared to Melbourne (9%). The most common complications included electrode misplacement, device failure, and dural penetration. Notably, the rate of persistent facial nerve paralysis was significantly higher in the Hannover group. These findings highlight the importance of careful surgical technique and patient selection in reducing surgical complications associated with cochlear implants. Further research is needed to identify strategies for minimizing complications and improving outcomes in cochlear implantation procedures.

Incidence and survival rates of children and young adults with osteogenic sarcoma.  Gender-specific and race-specific incidence and survival rates of osteogenic sarcoma over a 14-year period are presented for persons aged 0 to 24 years from eight Surveillance, Epidemiology, and End Results (SEER) registries. This study examines the incidence and survival rates of osteogenic sarcoma in children and young adults over a 14-year period. Using data from eight SEER registries, we analyzed gender-specific and race-specific rates for individuals aged 0 to 24 years. Our findings reveal that osteogenic sarcoma incidence rates remained stable over the study period, with a slight male predominance. Survival rates improved over time, with a five-year survival rate of 68% for all patients. However, disparities in survival were observed based on race, with lower rates for Black and Hispanic individuals compared to White individuals. These results emphasize the need for targeted interventions to improve outcomes for all populations affected by osteogenic sarcoma.

Racial differences in the anterior circulation in cerebrovascular disease. Racial differences in cerebrovascular disease have been studied extensively, but few studies have specifically examined racial differences in the anterior circulation. This study aimed to investigate racial differences in the anterior circulation in cerebrovascular disease. Data from a large, multi-ethnic cohort of patients with cerebrovascular disease were analyzed. The cohort included 500 Caucasian, 500 African American, and 500 Hispanic patients. Imaging findings of the anterior circulation were compared among the three racial groups. The results showed that African American patients had a significantly higher prevalence of stenosis in the anterior circulation compared to Caucasian and Hispanic patients. Additionally, African American patients were more likely to have multiple sites of stenosis in the anterior circulation. These findings suggest that there are racial differences in the anterior circulation in cerebrovascular disease, with African American patients being at higher risk for stenosis in this region. Further research is needed to understand the underlying factors contributing to these racial disparities and to develop targeted interventions for high-risk populations.

Dysplasia and DNA aneuploidy in a pelvic pouch. Dysplasia and DNA aneuploidy are common complications in patients with a pelvic pouch, but their correlation and significance in predicting neoplastic progression remain unclear. This study aimed to evaluate the relationship between dysplasia and DNA aneuploidy in a pelvic pouch. A total of 52 patients with pelvic pouch were included in the study. Biopsies were taken from the pouch and analyzed for dysplasia using the Vienna classification and for DNA aneuploidy using flow cytometry. The results showed that dysplasia was present in 21 patients (40.4%), while DNA aneuploidy was detected in 13 patients (25.0%). There was a significant association between dysplasia and DNA aneuploidy (p = 0.032), suggesting that these two factors may be interrelated in the development of neoplastic changes in the pelvic pouch. Further long-term follow-up is needed to determine the clinical implications of this finding and to identify high-risk patients who may benefit from closer surveillance and intervention.

Survival after hypertonic saline resuscitation from hemorrhage.  There has been recent increased interest in hypertonic saline resuscitation from shock and hemorrhage. Hypertonic saline resuscitation has emerged as a potential therapeutic approach for shock and hemorrhage. This study aimed to evaluate the survival outcomes after hypertonic saline resuscitation in patients with hemorrhage. A retrospective analysis was conducted on a cohort of patients who received hypertonic saline resuscitation for hemorrhagic shock between 2010 and 2015. The primary endpoint was survival to hospital discharge. Secondary endpoints included rebleeding rates and complications. A total of 100 patients were included in the analysis. The overall survival rate was 70%, with 30% of patients experiencing mortality. Rebleeding rates were low, with only 10% of patients experiencing recurrent bleeding. Complications such as hypernatremia and hyperchloremia were observed in a small number of patients. These findings suggest that hypertonic saline resuscitation may be a viable option for improving survival outcomes in patients with hemorrhage. Further prospective studies are warranted to validate these findings and optimize the hypertonic saline resuscitation protocol.

The cellular composition of basal cell adenoma of the parotid gland: an immunohistochemical analysis. Basal cell adenoma (BCA) is a rare benign tumor of the parotid gland. This study aimed to analyze the cellular composition of BCA using immunohistochemical techniques. A total of 20 cases of BCA were included in the study. Immunohistochemical staining was performed for various markers including cytokeratin 7, cytokeratin 14, S100 protein, smooth muscle actin, and vimentin. The results showed that the cellular composition of BCA consisted of a mixture of basaloid cells, myoepithelial cells, and stromal cells. Basaloid cells expressed cytokeratin 7 and cytokeratin 14, indicating their origin from the basal cell layer of the salivary gland. Myoepithelial cells expressed S100 protein and smooth muscle actin, confirming their myoepithelial differentiation. Stromal cells expressed vimentin, suggesting their fibroblastic nature. This study provides valuable insights into the cellular composition of BCA and highlights the importance of immunohistochemical analysis for accurate diagnosis and classification of salivary gland tumors.

Mammographic measurements before and after augmentation mammaplasty. The purpose of this study was to evaluate the changes in mammographic measurements before and after augmentation mammaplasty. A total of 50 patients who underwent augmentation mammaplasty were included in the study. Mammographic measurements including breast thickness, breast density, and implant position were assessed before surgery and at follow-up appointments. 

The results showed a significant increase in breast thickness postoperatively compared to preoperatively (p<0.001). There was also a significant decrease in breast density (p<0.001), indicating improved visualization of breast tissue on mammograms. 

Implant position analysis revealed that the majority of implants were placed in the subglandular position. However, there were a few cases where the implants were placed in the submuscular position. 

Overall, mammographic measurements showed positive changes after augmentation mammaplasty, with increased breast thickness, decreased breast density, and favorable implant positioning. These findings highlight the potential benefits of augmentation mammaplasty in improving breast aesthetics and mammographic assessment.

Postoperative hypertension: a prospective, placebo-controlled, randomized, double-blind trial, with intravenous nicardipine hydrochloride.  Nicardipine hydrochloride, a new calcium channel blocker for intravenous use, has been compared with placebo in a prospective, randomized, double-blind trial on postoperative hypertension. This study aimed to evaluate the efficacy of intravenous nicardipine hydrochloride, a calcium channel blocker, in postoperative hypertension. A prospective, randomized, double-blind trial was conducted, comparing nicardipine hydrochloride with placebo. Patients with postoperative hypertension were randomly assigned to receive either nicardipine hydrochloride or placebo. Blood pressure measurements were taken at regular intervals during the study period. The primary outcome measure was the reduction in blood pressure from baseline. Secondary outcome measures included adverse events and the need for additional antihypertensive therapy. The results of this study will provide valuable information on the effectiveness and safety of intravenous nicardipine hydrochloride in managing postoperative hypertension.

Two-dimensional echocardiographic features of double outlet left ventricle. To investigate the two-dimensional echocardiographic features of double outlet left ventricle (DOLV), a retrospective analysis was conducted on 16 patients diagnosed with DOLV. Echocardiography was performed using standard techniques and measurements were taken to assess the various anatomical abnormalities associated with DOLV. The results showed that all patients had a ventricular septal defect with ventriculo-arterial discordance, indicating the presence of DOLV. Additionally, aortic override and pulmonary artery stenosis were observed in the majority of patients. The left ventricular outflow tract was found to be narrowed in all cases, while the right ventricular outflow tract showed normal dimensions. These findings highlight the characteristic echocardiographic features of DOLV, providing valuable insights for accurate diagnosis and management of this congenital heart defect.

Cholecystectomy and right colon cancer in Puerto Rico. The incidence of right colon cancer following cholecystectomy has been inconsistently reported in various populations. This study aims to determine the association between cholecystectomy and right colon cancer in Puerto Rico. A retrospective cohort study was conducted, involving patients who underwent cholecystectomy and had no history of colon cancer prior to the procedure. These patients were followed for the development of right colon cancer over a 10-year period. The incidence rates of right colon cancer among patients with and without cholecystectomy were compared using standardized incidence ratios. The study found a significantly increased risk of right colon cancer following cholecystectomy, with a standardized incidence ratio of 1.45 (95% confidence interval: 1.12-1.86). These findings suggest that cholecystectomy may be a risk factor for the development of right colon cancer in the Puerto Rican population. Further research is warranted to explore the underlying mechanisms for this association.

Late cholangitis after successful surgical repair of biliary atresia.  Bacterial cholangitis is a frequent complication of successful surgical repair of biliary atresia, occurring in 93% of patients before the age of 1 year, but thought to be rare after 2 years of age. Late cholangitis, characterized by bacterial infection of the bile ducts, is commonly observed after surgical repair of biliary atresia in infants. However, its occurrence in older children is generally considered rare. In this study, we retrospectively analyzed a cohort of patients who underwent successful surgical repair of biliary atresia to investigate the prevalence of late cholangitis after the age of 2 years. Among the patients included, cholangitis was observed in 7 out of 56 cases (12.5%) during a mean follow-up period of 5 years. The presenting symptoms included abdominal pain, jaundice, and fever. Bacterial cultures from bile samples demonstrated diverse organisms, with Escherichia coli being the most commonly isolated pathogen. These findings suggest that late cholangitis remains a potential complication even after successful surgical intervention for biliary atresia, highlighting the importance of long-term monitoring and appropriate management in older children.

Hyperplastic polyps seen at sigmoidoscopy are markers for additional adenomas seen at colonoscopy.  Asymptomatic individuals undergoing screening flexible sigmoidoscopy were prospectively studied. A prospective study was conducted to evaluate the correlation between hyperplastic polyps detected during sigmoidoscopy and the presence of additional adenomas seen during colonoscopy in asymptomatic individuals undergoing screening. The study included a total of [number] participants who underwent flexible sigmoidoscopy followed by colonoscopy. It was found that [percentage] of individuals who had hyperplastic polyps during sigmoidoscopy also had additional adenomas identified during colonoscopy. The presence of hyperplastic polyps thus served as a marker for the presence of additional adenomas. This finding highlights the importance of thorough examination and surveillance for individuals with hyperplastic polyps, as they may be at increased risk for colorectal adenomas. Early detection and removal of these adenomas can help prevent the development of colorectal cancer.

Interventional radiology of the biliary tract. This study aimed to assess the effectiveness and safety of interventional radiology procedures in the management of biliary tract disorders. A total of 150 patients with various biliary tract diseases underwent interventional radiology procedures between January 2010 and December 2015. The procedures included percutaneous transhepatic biliary drainage, balloon dilation of strictures, biliary stent placement, and radiofrequency ablation. The success rate of these procedures was 94%, with a low complication rate of 6%. These results indicate that interventional radiology is a viable treatment option for patients with biliary tract disorders, providing effective and safe management of these conditions. Further studies with larger sample sizes are warranted to confirm these findings.

Does age affect outcomes of out-of-hospital cardiopulmonary resuscitation? We examined the relation between age and outcomes in patients treated for out-of-hospital cardiac arrest in Seattle, Wash. We conducted a study to evaluate the impact of age on outcomes in patients who received out-of-hospital cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) for cardiac arrest in Seattle, Washington. A total of XX patients were included in the analysis. We assessed various outcome measures, such as survival to hospital admission, survival to hospital discharge, and neurologic outcomes. Our findings indicate that there is a significant association between age and outcomes of out-of-hospital CPR. Specifically, older age was associated with lower rates of survival to hospital admission, lower rates of survival to hospital discharge, and poorer neurologic outcomes. These results suggest that age should be considered when making decisions regarding out-of-hospital CPR and its potential benefits.

Increased microvascular permeability in vivo in response to intradermal injection of neutrophil-activating protein (NAP-2) in rabbit skin. In this study, the authors investigated the effects of neutrophil-activating protein (NAP-2) on microvascular permeability in rabbit skin. Intradermal injections of NAP-2 were administered, and the permeability of skin microvessels was assessed using the Evans blue dye method. The results showed a significant increase in microvascular permeability in response to NAP-2 injection compared to control. This suggests that NAP-2 has the ability to induce an inflammatory response leading to increased permeability of the microvasculature. The findings of this study contribute to our understanding of the mechanisms involved in inflammation and may have implications for the development of treatments targeting inflammation-related conditions. Further research is needed to explore the specific pathways and mediators involved in NAP-2-induced microvascular permeability.

Beta-carotene's effects on serum lipoproteins and immunologic indices in humans. This study aimed to investigate the effects of beta-carotene supplementation on serum lipoproteins and immunologic indices in humans. A randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial was conducted on 100 healthy individuals. The participants were divided into two groups, with one group receiving beta-carotene supplementation (30 mg/day) for a duration of 12 weeks, and the other group receiving a placebo. Blood samples were collected at baseline and at the end of the study to evaluate changes in serum lipoprotein levels and immunologic indices. 

The results showed that beta-carotene supplementation led to a significant increase in serum levels of high-density lipoprotein cholesterol (HDL-C) (p < 0.001), while no significant changes were observed in low-density lipoprotein cholesterol (LDL-C) or total cholesterol levels. Additionally, beta-carotene supplementation was associated with an improvement in immunologic indices, including an increase in lymphocyte count (p < 0.05) and a decrease in C-reactive protein (CRP) levels (p < 0.01). 

These findings suggest that beta-carotene supplementation may have beneficial effects on serum lipoprotein profiles, particularly by increasing HDL-C levels. Moreover, it may also have immunomodulatory effects, as evidenced by the improvements in lymphocyte count and reduction in CRP levels. Further studies are needed to elucidate the underlying mechanisms and determine the optimal dosage and duration of beta-carotene supplementation.

Pulmonary malakoplakia in a patient with the acquired immunodeficiency syndrome. Malakoplakia is a rare chronic granulomatous disease characterized by the presence of distinctive granulomas in various organs. It has been associated with immunocompromised states such as the acquired immunodeficiency syndrome (AIDS). We present a case of pulmonary malakoplakia in a 45-year-old male with AIDS. The patient presented with persistent cough, shortness of breath, and weight loss. Chest imaging revealed multiple nodules in the lungs. Histopathological examination of lung tissue showed characteristic Michaelis-Gutmann bodies, which are pathognomonic for malakoplakia. Microbiological analysis revealed Escherichia coli as the causative agent. The patient was started on antimicrobial therapy and showed improvement in symptoms. To our knowledge, this is the first reported case of pulmonary malakoplakia in a patient with AIDS. This case highlights the importance of considering malakoplakia as a differential diagnosis in immunocompromised patients presenting with pulmonary nodules. Further studies are needed to better understand the association between malakoplakia and AIDS.

Rigid spine syndrome with respiratory failure. Rigid spine syndrome is a rare genetic disorder characterized by progressive muscle stiffness and rigidity, leading to spinal deformities and impaired mobility. This case report presents a 62-year-old male who presented with respiratory distress and was subsequently diagnosed with rigid spine syndrome. The patient had a history of progressive muscle weakness and stiffness, along with limited range of motion in the spine. Physical examination revealed ankylosis of the spine and decreased chest expansion. Pulmonary function tests indicated restrictive lung disease, with decreased vital capacity and forced expiratory volume. The patient required non-invasive ventilation support to manage respiratory failure. This case highlights the importance of recognizing rigid spine syndrome as a potential cause of respiratory compromise and the need for timely interventions to improve patient outcomes. Further research is warranted to better understand the pathophysiology and management of respiratory complications in rigid spine syndrome.

Use of plasmid profiles in the investigation of a patient with Helicobacter pylori infection and peptic ulcer disease. We present a case of a 43-year-old male patient with Helicobacter pylori infection and peptic ulcer disease. The patient underwent endoscopy and biopsy to confirm the presence of H. pylori and to assess the severity of the ulcer. Plasmid profiles were used to further investigate the strain of H. pylori. Four plasmid bands were identified, indicating the presence of different plasmids. This finding suggests potential variability in the virulence and antibiotic resistance of the H. pylori strain. Plasmid profiling may serve as a valuable tool in understanding the pathogenesis and management of H. pylori infection and associated peptic ulcers.

Microspectrophotometric DNA analysis in ulcerative colitis with special reference to its application in diagnosis of carcinoma and dysplasia.  The deoxyribonucleic (DNA) content was measured by microspectrophotometry in 100 specimens from 60 patients with ulcerative colitis, including six patients in whom the colitis was associated with carcinoma. This study investigated the use of microspectrophotometric DNA analysis in the diagnosis of carcinoma and dysplasia in patients with ulcerative colitis. DNA content was measured in 100 specimens from 60 patients, including six patients with colitis-associated carcinoma. The results revealed variations in DNA content among the specimens, indicating the presence of abnormalities. These variations were particularly significant in the patients with carcinoma. The findings suggest that microspectrophotometric DNA analysis can be a valuable tool in detecting carcinoma and dysplasia in patients with ulcerative colitis. Further research is needed to validate these findings and to explore the application of this technique in clinical practice.

Limitation of transcatheter arterial chemoembolization using iodized oil for small hepatocellular carcinoma. Transcatheter arterial chemoembolization (TACE) is a widely used treatment for hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC). However, the efficacy of TACE for small HCC remains controversial. This study aimed to evaluate the limitations of TACE using iodized oil for small HCC. A total of 78 patients with small HCC (鈮3 cm) were included in the study. The tumor response rate after TACE was only 61.5%, and the overall survival rate at 1 year was 75.6%. Tumor size and tumor vascularity were identified as independent factors affecting the response rate. Moreover, tumor size and Child-Pugh class were independent factors affecting overall survival. These findings emphasize the limitations of TACE using iodized oil for small HCC and highlight the need for further improvements in treatment strategies for this patient population.

Long-term results of the Belsey Mark IV antireflux operation in relation to the severity of esophagitis A retrospective analysis of the results of the Belsey Mark IV operation has been conducted, relating these to the degree of esophagitis present preoperatively.  Analysis of 89 patients showed a 91. This retrospective analysis evaluated the long-term outcomes of the Belsey Mark IV antireflux operation in relation to the severity of esophagitis. A total of 89 patients were included in the study, and the degree of esophagitis was assessed preoperatively. The results showed a 91.0% success rate of the Belsey Mark IV operation in treating gastroesophageal reflux disease. However, the success rate varied depending on the severity of esophagitis, with a 100% success rate in patients with mild esophagitis, a 92.3% success rate in those with moderate esophagitis, and an 80.0% success rate in patients with severe esophagitis. These findings emphasize the importance of considering the severity of esophagitis when selecting surgical intervention for reflux disease.

Expression of HLA-DR and secretory component antigens and lymphocyte infiltration in human gastric nonmalignant and malignant tissues: an immunohistochemical study. In this immunohistochemical study, we aimed to investigate the expression of human leukocyte antigen (HLA)-DR and secretory component (SC) antigens, as well as lymphocyte infiltration, in human gastric nonmalignant and malignant tissues. A total of 40 gastric tissue samples, including 20 nonmalignant and 20 malignant tissues, were analyzed. Immunohistochemical staining revealed significantly higher expression of HLA-DR and SC antigens in malignant tissues compared to nonmalignant tissues. Additionally, there was a significant increase in the infiltration of lymphocytes in malignant tissues compared to nonmalignant tissues. These findings suggest that the upregulation of HLA-DR and SC antigens, along with increased lymphocyte infiltration, may play a role in the pathogenesis and progression of gastric malignancies. Further studies are warranted to elucidate the underlying mechanisms and explore the potential of these antigens as therapeutic targets for gastric cancer.

Elevated serum tumor markers in patients with testicular cancer after induction chemotherapy due to a reservoir of markers in cystic differentiated mature teratoma. Elevated serum tumor markers are commonly observed in patients with testicular cancer after induction chemotherapy. However, the underlying cause of this phenomenon remains unclear. This retrospective study aimed to investigate the association between elevated serum tumor markers and the presence of cystic differentiated mature teratoma in patients with testicular cancer. A total of 50 patients were included in the study, with 25 patients showing elevated serum tumor markers and 25 patients with normal levels. Histopathological analysis revealed the presence of cystic differentiated mature teratoma in all patients with elevated serum tumor markers. In contrast, none of the patients with normal tumor marker levels had teratoma. These findings suggest that the presence of cystic differentiated mature teratoma may contribute to the elevation of serum tumor markers in patients with testicular cancer after induction chemotherapy.

Repetitive conservative surgery for recurrence of endometriosis.  We evaluated the recovery of fertility and the relief of pain symptoms in a long-term follow-up of 42 women undergoing repetitive conservative surgery for recurrent endometriosis.  The mean age of the patients was 31. This study aimed to evaluate the long-term outcomes of repetitive conservative surgery in 42 women with recurrent endometriosis. The mean age of the patients was 31. The main objectives were to assess the recovery of fertility and relief of pain symptoms. The results showed that 75% of the patients reported a significant reduction in pain symptoms after surgery. Of the 26 women who desired pregnancy, 19 (73%) were able to conceive within the follow-up period. The mean time from surgery to conception was 10 months. Furthermore, the rate of recurrent endometriosis was only 17% during the follow-up period, indicating a successful treatment approach. However, it should be noted that this study has limitations, including a relatively small sample size and lack of control group. Further studies with larger cohorts and comparison groups are recommended to validate these findings.

Human atherosclerotic coronary artery xenografts: a model for investigation of transluminal recanalization. Human atherosclerotic coronary artery xenografts provide a valuable model for studying transluminal recanalization techniques. These grafts, obtained from deceased human donors, are used to recreate the pathology and anatomy of atherosclerotic coronary arteries in experimental settings. By employing this model, researchers can investigate the efficacy and safety of different recanalization methods, such as invasive catheter-based interventions or minimally invasive techniques. The use of human xenografts allows for the assessment of relevant clinical outcomes and provides a clinically relevant platform for the development and optimization of recanalization strategies. Ultimately, the findings from these studies may contribute to the advancement of interventional cardiology and the improvement of patient outcomes in the context of coronary artery disease.

Cervical screening with cervicography and the Papanicolaou smear in women with genital condylomata.  Cervicography has been shown to be a very sensitive screening tool in the general population. In women with genital condylomata, screening for cervical cancer using cervicography and the Papanicolaou smear is recommended. Cervicography has been found to be highly sensitive in the general population. The purpose of this screening approach is to detect any abnormalities or precancerous changes in the cervix. It involves taking detailed photographs of the cervix to identify any abnormalities that may be missed by visual inspection alone. The Papanicolaou smear, also known as a Pap smear, involves collecting cells from the cervix to examine for any abnormal changes or signs of cervical cancer. These screening methods can help in early detection and treatment of cervical cancer.

Surgical treatment of low rectovaginal fistulas.  Forty women with low rectovaginal fistulas were operated upon over a 9-year period. This study aims to evaluate the surgical treatment outcomes of low rectovaginal fistulas in 40 women over a 9-year period. The average age of the patients was 42 years. Various surgical techniques, including primary repair, muscle interposition, and sphincteroplasty, were employed depending on the characteristics of the fistula. Post-operative complications, such as wound infection and urinary tract infection, were monitored. The primary outcome measure was fistula closure rate. Secondary outcomes included continence status and sexual function. The overall fistula closure rate was 90%, with successful closure achieved in 36 out of 40 patients. Continence status improved in 83% of the cases, while 75% reported improvement in sexual function. These findings demonstrate that surgical intervention can effectively treat low rectovaginal fistulas, providing satisfactory closure rates and improved patient outcomes. Further studies with larger sample sizes and longer follow-up periods are recommended to validate these results.

Contiguous enlarged dental follicles with histologic features resembling the WHO type of odontogenic fibroma Defective odontogenesis and/or retarded eruption of teeth can be associated with histologic features akin to odontogenic fibroma in the dental follicles. Enlarged dental follicles with histologic features resembling odontogenic fibroma are a rare finding. These follicles are often associated with defective tooth development and delayed tooth eruption. We present a case of contiguous enlarged dental follicles showing histologic features similar to the World Health Organization (WHO) type of odontogenic fibroma. Radiographic examination revealed impacted teeth and bone expansion. The histological analysis confirmed the presence of fibrous tissue and islands of odontogenic epithelium resembling odontogenic fibroma. This case highlights the potential association between defective odontogenesis and histologic features resembling odontogenic fibroma in dental follicles. It emphasizes the importance of considering odontogenic fibroma in the differential diagnosis of enlarged dental follicles with abnormal tooth development and eruption patterns.

Selenium in forage crops and cancer mortality in U. S. This study aimed to investigate the relationship between selenium levels in forage crops and cancer mortality rates in the United States. Selenium is an essential trace element that plays a critical role in various physiological processes, including antioxidant defense and DNA repair, which may influence cancer development and progression. Using data from the U.S. Department of Agriculture and the National Cancer Institute, selenium levels in forage crops were measured across different states, while cancer mortality rates were obtained from national databases. Multiple regression analyses were conducted to examine the association between selenium levels in forage crops and cancer mortality rates, controlling for potential confounding variables. The findings indicated that higher selenium levels in forage crops were significantly associated with lower cancer mortality rates, suggesting a potentially protective effect of selenium against cancer. These results highlight the importance of selenium supplementation in forage crops for cancer prevention and warrant further investigation into the underlying mechanisms of this association.

Abnormal epidermal changes after argon laser treatment. This study aimed to evaluate the epidermal changes following argon laser treatment. Biopsies were obtained from 30 patients who underwent skin resurfacing using the argon laser. Histological examination revealed significant changes in the epidermis, including thickening, acanthosis, and parakeratosis. Additionally, a decrease in the granular layer and disruption of the basal layer were observed. Immunohistochemical analysis showed a significant increase in the expression of keratinocyte proliferation markers, such as Ki-67 and p63. These changes were accompanied by increased staining for matrix metalloproteinases (MMPs), indicating increased extracellular matrix remodeling. These findings suggest that argon laser treatment leads to significant alterations in the epidermis, affecting both the structural and cellular components. Further studies are warranted to investigate the long-term effects of argon laser treatment on epidermal health.

An angiographic technique for three-dimensional determination of arterial supply patterns in cadaver soft tissue. This study introduces a novel angiographic technique for the three-dimensional analysis of arterial supply patterns in cadaver soft tissue. The technique involves injecting a contrast agent into the arterial system and visualizing the vasculature using computed tomography (CT) imaging. By combining CT data with advanced image processing algorithms, the arterial supply patterns can be reconstructed in three dimensions. The study demonstrates the feasibility and accuracy of this technique through the analysis of 10 cadaver specimens. The results reveal a wide variation in arterial supply patterns across different soft tissue regions, providing valuable insights for surgical planning and anatomical studies. This technique holds promise for enhancing our understanding of vascular anatomy and improving clinical interventions.

Prolonged paralysis following suxamethonium and the use of neostigmine. We report a case of prolonged paralysis following the administration of suxamethonium and the subsequent use of neostigmine in a 62-year-old male undergoing surgery for a fractured femur. The patient initially received suxamethonium for rapid sequence induction, but failed to regain muscle strength postoperatively. Despite the administration of neostigmine and atropine, the paralysis persisted for several hours. Further investigation revealed the presence of a rare genetic variant, butyrylcholinesterase deficiency, which was responsible for the prolonged effect of the neuromuscular blockade agents. Close monitoring and supportive care were provided until the patient regained muscle strength. This case highlights the importance of considering atypical responses to muscle relaxants and the need for genetic testing in cases of unexpected prolonged paralysis.

Rectal mucosal dysplasia in Crohn's disease.  Serial sections of 812 rectal biopsy specimens from 356 Crohn's disease patients were analysed for mucosal epithelial dysplasia. The presence of rectal mucosal dysplasia in Crohn's disease patients was investigated through the analysis of serial sections of 812 rectal biopsy specimens from 356 individuals. The aim was to determine the prevalence of mucosal epithelial dysplasia in this population. The results showed that 27 out of 356 patients (7.6%) had evidence of mucosal dysplasia. Of these, 16 patients (4.5%) had low-grade dysplasia and 11 patients (3.1%) had high-grade dysplasia. There was a significant association between the presence of dysplasia and longer duration of Crohn's disease, as well as a history of colorectal cancer. The findings suggest that rectal mucosal dysplasia is a relatively common occurrence in Crohn's disease patients and may be associated with disease progression and increased risk of colorectal cancer. Further studies are needed to better understand the clinical implications of these findings and to develop appropriate management strategies.

Synergism of herpes simplex virus and tobacco-specific N'-nitrosamines in cell transformation. The synergistic effect of herpes simplex virus (HSV) and tobacco-specific N'-nitrosamines (TSNAs) on cell transformation was investigated. Human lung fibroblast cells were infected with HSV and treated with TSNAs. The presence of transforming cells was determined using colony formation assay. Results showed a significant increase in cell transformation with the combination of HSV and TSNAs compared to either factor alone or control groups (p<0.05). Furthermore, the synergistic effect was confirmed by the increased expression of oncogenes and decreased expression of tumor suppressor genes in the co-exposed cells. These findings suggest that the combination of HSV and TSNAs has a potent synergistic effect on cell transformation, highlighting the potential role of viral infection in tobacco-related carcinogenesis.

Corpus callosotomy for intractable seizures in the pediatric age group. We present a case series of pediatric patients with intractable seizures who underwent corpus callosotomy as a surgical treatment. A total of 10 patients, aged 3 to 15 years, were included in the study. All patients had a long history of medically refractory seizures and had failed multiple antiepileptic drugs. Corpus callosotomy was performed using either open or endoscopic techniques. The average follow-up period was 2 years. Outcomes were assessed based on seizure frequency, seizure severity, and quality of life measures. The majority of patients (8 out of 10) experienced a significant reduction in seizure frequency, with 5 patients becoming seizure-free. Two patients showed a partial reduction in seizures, while none reported worsening of seizures. Complications were minimal, with no cases of permanent neurological deficits. Corpus callosotomy appears to be an effective and safe treatment option for pediatric patients with intractable seizures. Further studies with larger sample sizes are warranted to confirm these findings.

Low incidence of asymptomatic brain metastases in patients with renal cell carcinoma.  Brain metastases from renal cell carcinoma are uncommon. Brain metastases from renal cell carcinoma are relatively rare, with a low incidence of asymptomatic cases. This study aimed to determine the frequency of brain metastases in patients with renal cell carcinoma who showed no symptoms. A retrospective analysis was conducted on a cohort of 150 patients diagnosed with renal cell carcinoma between 2010 and 2019. The results showed that only 15 patients (10%) developed brain metastases. Among these cases, only 3 patients (2%) were asymptomatic. The majority of patients with brain metastases presented with symptoms such as headaches, seizures, and neurological deficits. These findings suggest that routine screening for brain metastases in asymptomatic patients with renal cell carcinoma may not be warranted. However, further research is needed to identify predictive factors for the development of brain metastases in this population.

The use of ultrasound in evaluating neurologic diseases of childhood. Ultrasound has become a valuable tool in evaluating neurologic diseases in children. This study aims to review the current literature on the use of ultrasound in pediatric neurology and provide insights into its diagnostic capabilities. Various neurologic conditions, including hydrocephalus, intracranial hemorrhage, and brain tumors, have been successfully evaluated using ultrasound. The advantages of ultrasound include its non-invasive nature, real-time imaging capabilities, and absence of ionizing radiation. Additionally, ultrasound can be performed at the bedside, making it readily accessible for pediatric patients. However, there are certain limitations to ultrasound, including limited penetration in bony structures and the need for operator expertise. Further research and technological advancements are needed to optimize the utility of ultrasound in pediatric neurology.

Expandable biliary metal stents for malignancies: endoscopic insertion and diathermic cleaning for tumor ingrowth. This study aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of expandable biliary metal stents in the management of malignancies, specifically focusing on endoscopic insertion and diathermic cleaning for tumor ingrowth. A total of 65 patients with malignant biliary strictures were included in the study. The success rate of stent insertion was 96.9%, with a mean procedure time of 19.3 minutes. During a follow-up period of 12 months, 9 patients (13.8%) experienced tumor ingrowth. For these cases, diathermic cleaning was performed, resulting in complete removal of tumor tissue without any major complications. The median time to recurrence of tumor ingrowth was 5.2 months. The overall median patency of the stents was 9.6 months. The authors conclude that expandable biliary metal stents, with the use of endoscopic insertion and diathermic cleaning for tumor ingrowth, are effective and safe in the management of malignancies. Further studies are warranted to validate these findings and explore long-term outcomes.

Laparoscopic cholecystectomy: an initial report.  Sixty consecutive patients underwent an elective attempt at laparoscopic cholecystectomy between March 15 and July 31, 1990 at the Mount Sinai Hospital in New York. This study presents the initial report on laparoscopic cholecystectomy, a minimally invasive surgical procedure for gallbladder removal. Sixty consecutive patients underwent the procedure at Mount Sinai Hospital in New York between March 15 and July 31, 1990. The study aims to evaluate the feasibility and safety of laparoscopic cholecystectomy as an alternative to open cholecystectomy. The results show that laparoscopic cholecystectomy was successfully completed in all patients, with a mean operative time of 94 minutes, shorter hospitalization duration, and faster postoperative recovery compared to open surgery. Additionally, no major complications or conversions to open surgery were reported. The authors conclude that laparoscopic cholecystectomy is a feasible and safe technique for gallbladder removal, offering potential benefits in terms of reduced morbidity, shorter hospital stays, and quicker return to normal activities.

Laparoscopic cholecystectomy using intracorporeal lithotripsy.  Over a 13-month period (November 1988 to December 1989), we performed our first 104 laparoscopic cholecystectomies using an intracorporeal ultrasonic lithotripsy technique. This study presents the outcomes of laparoscopic cholecystectomy using intracorporeal lithotripsy in 104 patients over a 13-month period. The procedure involved the use of an intracorporeal ultrasonic lithotripsy technique. The results showed successful completion of the laparoscopic cholecystectomy in all cases without any major complications. The technique allowed for efficient fragmentation and removal of gallstones within the gallbladder. The average operating time was within acceptable limits, and the postoperative recovery was uneventful in most patients. This suggests that intracorporeal lithotripsy is a safe and effective method for managing gallstones during laparoscopic cholecystectomy. Further studies with larger sample sizes are warranted to validate these findings and assess long-term outcomes.

In vitro and in vivo consequences of VLA-2 expression on rhabdomyosarcoma cells. Rhabdomyosarcoma (RMS) is a highly aggressive soft tissue tumor with poor prognosis. In this study, we investigated the in vitro and in vivo consequences of VLA-2 expression on RMS cells. Using immunohistochemistry and flow cytometry, we found that VLA-2 expression was significantly upregulated in RMS cells compared to normal muscle cells. In vitro studies revealed that VLA-2 expression promoted cell adhesion, migration, and invasion of RMS cells. Silencing VLA-2 expression resulted in reduced RMS cell proliferation and increased apoptosis. In vivo xenograft experiments demonstrated that VLA-2 knockdown led to decreased tumor growth and enhanced survival in mice. Our findings suggest that targeting VLA-2 could be a potential therapeutic strategy for RMS.

Plasma epinephrine levels in resuscitation with cardiopulmonary bypass.  Since the highest plasma epinephrine levels have been recorded during resuscitation, we evaluated the isolated effect of cardiac arrest upon adrenomedullary secretion. This study aimed to evaluate the effect of cardiac arrest on adrenomedullary secretion by measuring plasma epinephrine levels during resuscitation with cardiopulmonary bypass. A total of 24 patients who underwent cardiac surgery were included in the study. Blood samples were collected at different time points during the resuscitation process, and plasma epinephrine levels were measured using radioimmunoassay. The results showed that the highest levels of epinephrine were observed during resuscitation, confirming previous findings. Furthermore, the study found that the increase in epinephrine levels was significantly associated with the severity of cardiac arrest. These findings suggest that adrenomedullary secretion of epinephrine is significantly increased during resuscitation with cardiopulmonary bypass, and the level of secretion is related to the severity of cardiac arrest. Understanding these mechanisms may help in optimizing resuscitation strategies and improving outcomes for patients undergoing cardiac surgery.

Recurrent peripheral facial nerve palsy after dental procedures. Recurrent peripheral facial nerve palsy is a rare but known complication of dental procedures. This study aims to analyze the characteristics and outcomes of patients who experienced recurrent facial nerve palsy after dental treatment. The medical records of 25 patients with recurrent peripheral facial nerve palsy were reviewed. The mean age of the patients was 42 years, and the majority were female. The most common dental procedures associated with recurrent facial nerve palsy were tooth extraction and dental implant placement. Most patients had a complete recovery within three to six months with appropriate medical treatment. Awareness of this potential complication is essential for dental practitioners to ensure prompt recognition and management.

Brain stem tuberculoma in adult patients: diagnosis and treatment. Brain stem tuberculoma is a rare manifestation of tuberculosis, particularly in adult patients. The diagnosis can be challenging due to its nonspecific clinical features and imaging findings. Various diagnostic modalities, including cerebrospinal fluid analysis and magnetic resonance imaging, can aid in establishing the diagnosis. Early initiation of anti-tuberculosis treatment is crucial in order to prevent further neurological damage. Surgical intervention may be considered in cases of diagnostic uncertainty or neurological deterioration. We present a case series of adult patients with brain stem tuberculoma, discussing the diagnostic approach and treatment strategies. Awareness of this rare entity is essential for timely diagnosis and management, as delayed treatment can lead to significant morbidity and mortality.

Prognostic factors in acute renal failure following aortic aneurysm surgery. Acute renal failure (ARF) is a common complication following aortic aneurysm surgery, with significant impact on patient outcomes. This study aimed to identify prognostic factors for ARF in this specific surgical population. Retrospective analysis was conducted on 132 patients who developed ARF post-surgery. The overall incidence of ARF was 23.1%, associated with higher mortality (72.7% vs. 8.7%). Multivariate analysis identified several significant prognostic factors for ARF, including advanced age, preoperative renal dysfunction, prolonged cardiopulmonary bypass time, intraoperative hypotension, and the need for postoperative renal replacement therapy. The presence of these factors increased the risk of mortality, ICU stay, and prolonged hospitalization. This study highlights the importance of early identification and monitoring of these prognostic factors to improve outcomes and guide appropriate management strategies for ARF in aortic aneurysm surgery patients. Further research is warranted to validate and expand upon these findings.

Association of acute colonic pseudo-obstruction (Ogilvie's syndrome) with herpes zoster. This study aims to investigate the association between acute colonic pseudo-obstruction, also known as Ogilvie's syndrome, and herpes zoster. A total of 34 cases of acute colonic pseudo-obstruction were identified, and 9 of them were associated with herpes zoster. The average age of patients with herpes zoster-associated acute colonic pseudo-obstruction was higher compared to those without herpes zoster. Additionally, patients with herpes zoster had a longer duration of symptoms and a higher rate of complications. These findings suggest a potential link between herpes zoster and the development of acute colonic pseudo-obstruction. Further research is needed to better understand this association and its implications for clinical practice.

Autologous transplantation of adrenal medulla in Parkinson's disease. Parkinson's disease is a neurodegenerative disorder characterized by the loss of dopaminergic neurons in the substantia nigra of the brain. Current therapeutic approaches aim to restore dopamine levels by administering dopamine precursors or dopamine receptor agonists. However, these treatments often lead to adverse effects and do not halt the progression of the disease. 

In recent years, autologous transplantation of the adrenal medulla has emerged as a potential therapy for Parkinson's disease. The adrenal medulla contains a population of cells that synthesize and release dopamine. Transplantation of these cells into the striatum of Parkinson's disease patients has shown promising results in restoring dopamine levels and improving motor function. 

This abstract presents an overview of the current research and clinical studies investigating the efficacy and safety of autologous adrenal medulla transplantation in Parkinson's disease. It highlights the various methodologies used for cell isolation, transplantation techniques, and outcomes observed in patients treated with this approach. Additionally, it discusses the challenges and limitations of this therapy, such as variability in cell survival and function post-transplantation. Continued research is necessary to optimize the procedure and identify ways to enhance the long-term efficacy of autologous adrenal medulla transplantation in Parkinson's disease.

Unilateral hydrocephalus in adults. Unilateral hydrocephalus, a rare condition typically seen in pediatric patients, is uncommon in adults. We present three cases of unilateral hydrocephalus in adults, illustrating the diagnostic challenges and treatment options. All patients presented with gradually worsening neurological symptoms, including headaches and gait disturbances. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) revealed asymmetric enlargement of the lateral ventricle on the affected side, without evidence of mass lesions or other underlying causes. Cerebrospinal fluid diversion procedures, such as ventriculoperitoneal shunting or endoscopic third ventriculostomy, were performed to relieve symptoms and prevent further neurological deterioration. Unilateral hydrocephalus should be considered in adults presenting with gradual onset of neurological symptoms, and prompt diagnosis and intervention are crucial to prevent irreversible damage.

Bleeding ectatic vascular lesion involving the sigmoid colon, endoscopically indistinguishable from angiodysplasia, in an 8-yr-old boy. We present a case of an 8-year-old boy with bleeding ectatic vascular lesion involving the sigmoid colon. The lesion appeared endoscopically indistinguishable from angiodysplasia. The patient presented with recurrent episodes of lower gastrointestinal bleeding and underwent colonoscopy for further evaluation. The lesion was found in the sigmoid colon and appeared as a reddish, friable lesion with a variable appearance, resembling angiodysplasia. Histopathological examination confirmed the diagnosis of a bleeding ectatic vascular lesion. This case highlights the importance of considering bleeding ectatic vascular lesions as a possible differential diagnosis in pediatric patients presenting with lower gastrointestinal bleeding. It also emphasizes the need for careful endoscopic examination and histopathological evaluation to accurately diagnose and manage these lesions in children. Further studies are warranted to better understand the etiology, pathogenesis, and optimal management strategies for bleeding ectatic vascular lesions in pediatric patients.

Pulmonary vascular steal in chronic thromboembolic pulmonary hypertension.  After pulmonary thromboendarterectomy, performed for relief of chronic thromboembolic pulmonary hypertension, perfusion lung scans have frequently disclosed new perfusion defects in segments served by undissected pulmonary arteries. Chronic thromboembolic pulmonary hypertension (CTEPH) is a rare but serious condition characterized by elevated pulmonary artery pressure due to chronic pulmonary embolism. Pulmonary thromboendarterectomy (PTE) is the recommended surgical treatment for CTEPH, but it can lead to the development of new perfusion defects in segments supplied by undissected pulmonary arteries. This phenomenon, known as pulmonary vascular steal, has been identified in perfusion lung scans post-operatively. The exact mechanism causing this steal phenomenon is not completely understood, but it is thought to be related to altered blood flow dynamics and redistribution of blood through collateral vessels. The presence of pulmonary vascular steal can impact the efficacy of PTE and may require additional interventions or management strategies. Further research is needed to better understand the pathophysiology and optimal management of pulmonary vascular steal in CTEPH patients undergoing PTE.

Controlled trial of antimycobacterial therapy in Crohn's disease.  Clofazimine versus placebo. Crohn's disease is an inflammatory bowel disease characterized by chronic inflammation of the gastrointestinal tract. Recent studies suggest that Mycobacterium avium subspecies paratuberculosis (MAP) may play a role in the pathogenesis of Crohn's disease. This study aimed to evaluate the efficacy of antimycobacterial therapy in Crohn's disease patients by comparing clofazimine, an antimycobacterial agent, with placebo.

In this controlled trial, 100 patients with active Crohn's disease were randomly assigned to receive either clofazimine or placebo for 26 weeks. The primary endpoint was the proportion of patients achieving clinical remission at week 26. Secondary endpoints included endoscopic remission, change in fecal calprotectin levels, and quality of life assessments.

Preliminary results showed a significant improvement in clinical remission rates in the clofazimine group compared to the placebo group (60% vs. 30%, p=0.03). Endoscopic remission rates were also higher in the clofazimine group (50% vs. 20%, p=0.02). Fecal calprotectin levels significantly decreased in the clofazimine group compared to placebo (p<0.01). Quality of life assessments showed improvements in both groups, but no significant difference between them.

These findings suggest that antimycobacterial therapy with clofazimine may be effective in inducing clinical and endoscopic remission in Crohn's disease patients. Further studies with larger sample sizes are warranted to confirm these results and determine the long-term effects of antimycobacterial therapy in Crohn's disease management.

Recurrent herpetic keratitis: failure to detect herpes simplex virus infection using the Syva MicroTrak HSV1/HSV2 direct specimen identification/typing test. This study aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of the Syva MicroTrak HSV1/HSV2 test in detecting herpes simplex virus (HSV) infection in patients with recurrent herpetic keratitis. A total of 31 patients were included in this prospective study, which was conducted between July 1988 and January 1990. The test results were compared to clinical findings and viral isolation. The study found that the Syva MicroTrak test failed to detect HSV infection in all cases of recurrent herpetic keratitis. This failure was particularly evident in patients with prior surgery or radiotherapy. The test's inability to identify HSV infection was associated with poor nutrition, accelerated radiation, and recurrence. Out of all patients, 61% experienced uneventful healing, while complications such as plate exposure, fistula formation, or both occurred in 12 patients. After excluding patients who had complications secondary to recurrence and subsequently died, the success rate of the reconstruction using titanium plates was 73%. However, one patient experienced an unacceptable outcome, resulting in a cosmetic and functional deformity despite secondary repair.

Obstructive sleep apnea presenting with nocturnal angina, heart failure, and near-miss sudden death. We report a case of obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) presenting with atypical symptoms including nocturnal angina, heart failure, and near-miss sudden death. A 56-year-old obese male presented with recurrent episodes of chest pain and shortness of breath during sleep. Diagnostic workup revealed severe OSA with an apnea-hypopnea index of 70 events/hour. Cardiac evaluation demonstrated left ventricular dysfunction and elevated cardiac biomarkers, suggestive of acute myocardial ischemia. Further investigations ruled out coronary artery disease, myocarditis, or pericarditis. Treatment with continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) resulted in resolution of symptoms and normalization of cardiac function. OSA can present with atypical symptoms, mimicking cardiac events, and should be considered in the differential diagnosis of nocturnal angina and heart failure. Early recognition and management with CPAP can prevent life-threatening complications associated with OSA.

Late metastases of cutaneous melanoma: case report and literature review.  The development of delayed metastases, although rare, is well documented in patients with invasive cutaneous melanoma. This case report and literature review aims to discuss the occurrence of late metastases in patients with invasive cutaneous melanoma. While rare, delayed metastases are well-documented in this population. The case report presents a patient who developed late metastases, highlighting the importance of ongoing surveillance and follow-up for these patients. The literature review discusses previous studies on late metastases in cutaneous melanoma, emphasizing the need for long-term monitoring and awareness among healthcare professionals. Increased understanding of this phenomenon can aid in early detection and management of late metastases, potentially improving patient outcomes.

Resolved and unresolved issues in the prevention and treatment of coronary artery disease: a workshop consensus statement. Coronary artery disease (CAD) remains a significant global health burden, despite advancements in its prevention and treatment. A workshop was conducted to discuss and provide a consensus on the current status of CAD prevention and treatment. Several key issues were identified. Firstly, the identification and management of traditional risk factors, such as hypertension, dyslipidemia, and smoking, remain crucial in preventing CAD. Secondly, novel risk factors such as inflammation, oxidative stress, and genetic predisposition were highlighted as areas requiring further research and targeted interventions. Thirdly, lifestyle modifications, including healthy diet and regular exercise, were emphasized as essential components of CAD prevention and management. Fourthly, advancements in pharmacotherapy, including antiplatelet agents, statins, and newer anticoagulants, were discussed, with a focus on individualized treatment strategies. Finally, the workshop identified the need for improved patient education, multidisciplinary collaboration, and development of novel therapeutic approaches to address unresolved issues in CAD prevention and treatment.

Audit of results of operations for infantile pyloric stenosis in a district general hospital Because of the proposal that infants with hypertrophic pyloric stenosis should only be treated by surgeons with an interest in paediatric surgery, we carried out a retrospective study to audit our experience in a district general hospital. In this retrospective study, we aimed to audit the results of operations for infantile pyloric stenosis in a district general hospital. The proposal to limit treatment of this condition to surgeons with expertise in paediatric surgery prompted this investigation. The study included infants diagnosed with hypertrophic pyloric stenosis who underwent surgery in our hospital. The outcomes of the operations were examined and analyzed. The audit revealed the effectiveness of the operations performed by our team, showcasing successful outcomes and minimal complications. These findings support the ability of surgeons in a district general hospital to treat infantile pyloric stenosis competently. This study emphasizes the importance of evaluating and monitoring surgical outcomes to ensure appropriate patient care and optimize surgical practices.

Cup containment and orientation in cemented total hip arthroplasties.  We reviewed the radiographs of 864 Charnley and STH (Zimmer) cemented total hip arthroplasties with a mean follow-up of seven years (maximum 16 years). Cup containment and orientation are important factors in the success of cemented total hip arthroplasties. We conducted a retrospective study to evaluate the radiographs of 864 patients who underwent Charnley or STH (Zimmer) cemented total hip arthroplasties, with an average follow-up of seven years (maximum 16 years). We analyzed the cup containment and orientation parameters using the criteria established by D'Antonio and McCarthy. In our cohort, 91.5% of cups were within the optimal range of abduction and anteversion angles. However, 8.5% of cups had suboptimal containment or malposition. We found a significant association between suboptimal cup containment and an increased risk of radiographic evidence of osteolysis (p < 0.001). These findings highlight the importance of careful cup positioning in cemented total hip arthroplasties to avoid potential complications such as implant loosening and osteolysis.

Inner ear cholesteatoma and the preservation of cochlear function. Cholesteatoma is a benign but progressive epidermoid cyst that can lead to severe complications, including hearing loss, dizziness, and facial nerve paralysis. The preservation of cochlear function is of utmost importance in the management of inner ear cholesteatoma. This retrospective study aimed to evaluate the audiological outcomes in patients who underwent surgery for inner ear cholesteatoma, focusing on the preservation of cochlear function. The study included 68 patients who underwent surgical treatment for cholesteatoma. Pure tone audiometry and speech audiometry were performed preoperatively and postoperatively to assess hearing outcomes. The results showed that cochlear function was preserved in the majority of patients, with a significant improvement in hearing thresholds postoperatively.
