Femorofemoral bypass: a profile of graft failure. Femorofemoral bypass is a surgical procedure used to treat occlusive disease in the iliofemoral arteries. However, graft failure can occur, leading to a loss of limb perfusion and the need for reintervention. This study aimed to profile factors associated with graft failure in 45 patients who underwent femorofemoral bypass. The overall incidence of graft failure was 26.7%, with the most common cause being thrombosis. Preoperative risk factors, such as smoking and diabetes, were associated with a higher risk of graft failure. In conclusion, careful patient selection and addressing modifiable risk factors may help reduce the incidence of graft failure in femorofemoral bypass procedures.

Pulmonary embolism presenting as exercise-induced hypotension. Pulmonary embolism is a serious condition that can present with a wide range of symptoms. We report a case of a 45-year-old male who presented with exercise-induced hypotension as the only initial symptom of pulmonary embolism. The patient had no previous medical history, and his physical examination was unremarkable except for mild tachycardia. However, a computed tomography angiography revealed a large clot in the pulmonary artery, confirming the diagnosis of pulmonary embolism. Immediate treatment with anticoagulation therapy was initiated, and the patient showed significant improvement. This case highlights the importance of considering pulmonary embolism in the differential diagnosis of patients presenting with exercise-induced hypotension, even in the absence of typical symptoms.

Problems of resistant dermatophytes. Dermatophytes are fungal pathogens that commonly cause infections on the skin, hair, and nails. In recent years, the incidence of resistant dermatophytes has been on the rise, posing significant challenges in their management. This review highlights the problems associated with resistant dermatophytes and explores potential solutions. Resistance mechanisms such as alterations in the fungal target site, increased production of efflux pumps, and enzymatic degradation of antifungal drugs are discussed. Additionally, the role of factors like host immunity, improper antifungal therapy, and suboptimal patient adherence in the development and persistence of resistant dermatophyte infections is examined. Strategies for the diagnosis and management of resistant dermatophyte infections, including combination therapy, optimization of drug dosages, and the use of novel antifungal agents, are also addressed. Overall, understanding the mechanisms of resistance and adopting appropriate management strategies are essential to effectively combat the growing problem of resistant dermatophytes.

Computed tomography for evaluation of puerperal infections. Puerperal infections, also known as postpartum infections, are a common complication of childbirth and can lead to significant morbidity and mortality if not promptly diagnosed and treated. Computed tomography (CT) has emerged as a useful tool in the evaluation of these infections, offering detailed visualization of the pelvic structures and identifying the extent of the infection. This retrospective study aimed to evaluate the utility of CT in the diagnosis and management of puerperal infections. The study included 50 patients with suspected or confirmed puerperal infections who underwent CT imaging. CT findings were compared with clinical, laboratory, and surgical findings to determine the accuracy of CT in diagnosing the infection and guiding appropriate treatment. Results showed that CT had a high sensitivity and specificity in detecting pelvic abscesses, identifying pelvic inflammatory disease, and determining the extent of infection. CT can therefore play a crucial role in the early diagnosis, accurate assessment, and effective management of puerperal infections.

Imaging modalities in recurrent head and neck tumors. Recurrent head and neck tumors pose a significant challenge in terms of diagnosis and management. This study aimed to evaluate the role of different imaging modalities in the detection and characterization of recurrent head and neck tumors. A retrospective analysis of 65 patients with suspected recurrent tumors was conducted. The imaging modalities utilized included computed tomography (CT), magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), and positron emission tomography (PET). The results showed that CT had a high sensitivity (95%) and specificity (92%) in detecting recurrent tumors. MRI demonstrated superior soft tissue resolution and was especially useful in evaluating tumor extent and involvement of adjacent structures. PET imaging had the highest accuracy (98%) in detecting recurrent tumors, with increased uptake suggesting an active disease process. In conclusion, a multimodal imaging approach utilizing CT, MRI, and PET provides valuable information in the diagnosis and management of recurrent head and neck tumors, allowing for appropriate treatment planning and improved patient outcomes.

Fucosylated oligosaccharides of human milk protect suckling mice from heat-stabile enterotoxin of Escherichia coli.  Human milk protects suckling mice from the diarrheagenic effects of heat-stabile enterotoxin of Escherichia coli (ST). The presence of fucosylated oligosaccharides in human milk has been shown to provide protection against the diarrheagenic effects of heat-stabile enterotoxin of Escherichia coli (ST) in suckling mice. In this study, suckling mice were fed human milk containing fucosylated oligosaccharides and then exposed to ST. It was observed that the mice fed with milk containing fucosylated oligosaccharides had significantly reduced diarrheal symptoms compared to those fed with milk lacking these compounds. Fucosylated oligosaccharides appear to act as inhibitors of ST binding to intestinal receptors, thereby preventing the toxin-induced diarrhea. These findings highlight the importance of fucosylated oligosaccharides in human milk as a protective factor against ST-induced diarrheal diseases in infants. Further investigation into the specific mechanisms by which fucosylated oligosaccharides inhibit ST binding is warranted.

Intrathoracic fibrin glue for postoperative pleuropulmonary fistula.  Twenty cases of persistent pleuropulmonary fistula after a thoracic surgical procedure were successfully treated with fibrin glue injection into the thoracic cavity through a drainage tube. This study aimed to evaluate the efficacy of intrathoracic fibrin glue for the treatment of postoperative pleuropulmonary fistula. Twenty cases of persistent fistula after thoracic surgery were included in the study. Fibrin glue was injected into the thoracic cavity through a drainage tube. The success of the treatment was assessed based on closure of the fistula and resolution of symptoms. Results showed that fibrin glue injection successfully treated all cases of pleuropulmonary fistula, with complete closure achieved in all patients. No adverse events related to the treatment were reported. The use of intrathoracic fibrin glue offers a minimally invasive and effective approach for the management of postoperative pleuropulmonary fistula, providing a viable alternative to more invasive procedures. Further studies are warranted to validate these findings.

The long-distance effects of brain lesions: visualization of myelinated pathways in the human brain using polarizing and fluorescence microscopy. Brain lesions can have long-distance effects on myelinated pathways in the human brain, which can be visualized using polarizing and fluorescence microscopy. In this study, postmortem brain tissue from individuals with brain lesions was examined using these imaging techniques. The results showed alterations in the myelinated pathways in areas distant from the actual lesion site. These alterations included changes in myelin density, thickness, and axonal organization. Furthermore, these changes were observed not only in pathways directly connected to the lesion site but also in pathways that were indirectly connected. These findings suggest that brain lesions can disrupt the integrity and functionality of myelinated pathways throughout the brain, even in regions far from the lesion site. This understanding of the long-distance effects of brain lesions can help improve diagnosis and treatment strategies for individuals with brain disorders.

Mitral valve disruption following percutaneous balloon valvuloplasty. This study reviews cases of mitral valve disruption following percutaneous balloon valvuloplasty. Thirty-nine patients were evaluated, with a mean age of 58 years. Mitral valve disruption was observed in 10 patients, with all cases occurring in females. The most common presenting symptom was severe mitral regurgitation. Transthoracic echocardiography confirmed the diagnosis in all patients. Surgical intervention was required in 8 cases, while the remaining 2 patients were managed conservatively with medical therapy. The clinical course was complicated by heart failure and pulmonary edema in 3 patients. Hemodynamic stability improved in all patients after treatment. Follow-up evaluations showed favorable outcomes with decreased mitral regurgitation severity. The occurrence of mitral valve disruption following percutaneous balloon valvuloplasty is a rare but serious complication, often necessitating surgical intervention. Female patients appear to be at higher risk for this complication.

Traditional versus laparoscopic cholecystectomy.  Laparoscopic cholecystectomy is a minimally invasive procedure whereby the gallbladder is removed using laparoscopic techniques. Cholecystectomy, the surgical removal of the gallbladder, can be performed using either traditional open surgery or laparoscopic techniques. Laparoscopic cholecystectomy is a minimally invasive procedure that involves the use of a laparoscope to visualize and guide the removal of the gallbladder. This technique offers several advantages over traditional open surgery, including smaller incisions, reduced postoperative pain, shorter hospital stays, and quicker recovery times. 

In this study, the outcomes of traditional cholecystectomy were compared to laparoscopic cholecystectomy in a group of patients. The results showed that laparoscopic cholecystectomy had significantly lower rates of operative complications, such as wound infections and bile leakages, compared to traditional surgery. Furthermore, patients who underwent laparoscopic cholecystectomy had shorter hospital stays and less postoperative pain. 

In conclusion, laparoscopic cholecystectomy is a safe and effective alternative to traditional open surgery for the removal of the gallbladder. It offers several advantages and should be considered as the first-line approach for eligible patients.

Angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors and cough.  Prevalence in an outpatient medical clinic population. This study aimed to determine the prevalence of cough associated with angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitor use in an outpatient medical clinic population. A total of 500 patients were included in the study, with 250 currently taking ACE inhibitors and 250 not taking ACE inhibitors. Among the ACE inhibitor users, 20% reported experiencing a cough, while only 5% of non-users reported cough symptoms. The difference in prevalence of cough between the two groups was statistically significant (p<0.001). In addition, among the ACE inhibitor users who reported cough, 80% experienced symptoms within the first month of starting the medication. Cough resolved in 60% of patients after discontinuation of ACE inhibitors. These findings support the well-known association between ACE inhibitor use and the development of a persistent, nonproductive cough. Healthcare providers should be aware of this adverse effect when prescribing ACE inhibitors and consider alternative medications for patients who develop cough symptoms.

Management of perineal wounds following abdominoperineal resection with inferior gluteal flaps. The management of perineal wounds following abdominoperineal resection (APR) can be challenging. One technique that has shown promise is the use of inferior gluteal flaps for wound closure. We present a retrospective study of patients who underwent APR with subsequent perineal wound reconstruction using inferior gluteal flaps. A total of 25 patients were included in the study, and the outcomes were evaluated in terms of wound healing, complications, and functional outcomes. The results showed that the use of inferior gluteal flaps was associated with a high rate of successful wound closure, minimal complications, and satisfactory functional outcomes. This technique provides a reliable option for the management of perineal wounds following APR, offering improved wound healing and functional recovery. Further studies are warranted to validate these findings.

Cytologic features of poorly differentiated 'insular' carcinoma of the thyroid, as revealed by fine-needle aspiration biopsy. Fine-needle aspiration biopsy (FNAB) is a valuable diagnostic tool for evaluating thyroid nodules. We report cytologic features of poorly differentiated 'insular' carcinoma of the thyroid, a rare and aggressive subtype of thyroid cancer, based on FNAB specimens. Eight cases of poorly differentiated 'insular' carcinoma were identified and evaluated cytologically. The FNAB smears showed a uniform appearance, consisting of cohesive clusters, microfollicles, and small papillary fragments. The tumor cells demonstrated moderate to severe pleomorphism, high nuclear-cytoplasmic ratio, and hyperchromasia. Nuclear irregularities, such as nuclear grooves, pseudo-inclusions, and multinucleation, were present. Mitotic figures were observed in all cases. Immunocytochemical staining for thyroid-specific markers (thyroglobulin and TTF-1) was negative. These cytologic features, in combination with the clinical presentation and histologic findings, support the diagnosis of poorly differentiated 'insular' carcinoma of the thyroid. Awareness of these characteristic cytologic features is crucial for accurate diagnosis and appropriate management of this aggressive subtype of thyroid cancer. FNAB can play a significant role in the initial assessment of thyroid nodules suspicious for poorly differentiated 'insular' carcinoma.

Magnetic resonance imaging of facial nerve neuromas. Facial nerve neuromas, also known as facial nerve schwannomas, are rare benign tumors that arise from the nerve sheath of the facial nerve. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) has become an essential tool for the imaging of these lesions. This study aimed to evaluate the use of MRI in the assessment of facial nerve neuromas. A retrospective analysis of 28 patients with facial nerve neuromas who underwent MRI was conducted. MRI successfully identified the location, size, and extent of the tumors in all cases. Additionally, MRI provided valuable information regarding the involvement of adjacent structures, such as the internal auditory canal and the parotid gland. The findings suggest that MRI is a reliable imaging modality for the diagnosis and preoperative planning of facial nerve neuromas. Further research is required to evaluate the sensitivity and specificity of MRI in differentiating facial nerve neuromas from other facial nerve pathologies.

Treatment of advanced squamous cell carcinoma of the skin with cisplatin, 5-fluorouracil, and bleomycin. A case report. A 62-year-old man with advanced squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) of the skin presented with a large, ulcerating tumor on the left cheek. He received treatment with cisplatin, 5-fluorouracil (5-FU), and bleomycin, which are commonly used in the treatment of SCC in other sites. The patient received cisplatin at a dose of 50 mg/m虏 on day 1, followed by a continuous infusion of 5-FU at a dose of 1 g/m虏/day for five days, and bleomycin at a dose of 15 units once a week. After completing four cycles of chemotherapy, the tumor showed a significant reduction in size and was no longer ulcerating. The patient tolerated the treatment well, with no significant adverse events observed. This case highlights the potential efficacy of cisplatin, 5-FU, and bleomycin in the treatment of advanced SCC of the skin. Further studies are warranted to evaluate the optimal dosing and sequencing of these agents in this setting.

Localization of the human angiogenin gene to chromosome band 14q11, proximal to the T cell receptor alpha/delta locus. This study aimed to determine the localization of the human angiogenin gene on chromosome band 14q11, which is located proximal to the T cell receptor alpha/delta locus. Using fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH) analysis, we confirmed the precise chromosome location of the angiogenin gene in human lymphoblastoid cell lines. Our results show that the angiogenin gene is situated on the long arm of chromosome 14 at the q11 band. This finding provides valuable information regarding the genomic organization of the angiogenin gene and its proximity to the T cell receptor alpha/delta locus. Understanding the precise chromosomal location of the angiogenin gene is crucial for further investigation into its role in angiogenesis and its potential as a therapeutic target for various diseases, including cancer and neurodegenerative disorders.

Use of H2-receptor antagonists in children. The use of H2-receptor antagonists (H2RAs) in children is widespread due to their efficacy in managing various gastrointestinal conditions such as gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) and peptic ulcers. However, concerns about potential adverse effects have been raised. This review aimed to assess the safety and efficacy of H2RAs in pediatric patients. The findings indicate that while H2RAs are generally well-tolerated, there is limited evidence regarding their efficacy in children. Additionally, certain adverse effects, such as central nervous system effects, have been reported. Further research is needed to determine the optimal dosing, duration, and long-term safety of H2RAs in pediatric populations.

Serous papillary adenocarcinoma of the tunica vaginalis of the testis with metastasis. Serous papillary adenocarcinoma of the tunica vaginalis is an extremely rare malignancy. We report a case of a 55-year-old male who presented with painless scrotal swelling. Histological examination confirmed the diagnosis of serous papillary adenocarcinoma. Imaging investigations revealed retroperitoneal lymph node involvement, consistent with metastasis. The patient underwent radical orchiectomy followed by adjuvant chemotherapy. Despite treatment, he experienced disease progression with the development of liver metastases. The patient's disease course and treatment outcomes are discussed, highlighting the challenges in managing this rare and aggressive tumor. Further research is needed to better understand the optimal management strategies for this rare type of testicular cancer.

Historical review of pancreaticoduodenectomy. Pancreaticoduodenectomy, also known as the Whipple procedure, is a surgical procedure used to treat various diseases of the pancreas, including pancreatic cancer. The procedure involves the resection of the head of the pancreas, duodenum, and other surrounding structures. The history of pancreaticoduodenectomy dates back to the early 20th century when it was initially described as a two-stage procedure. Over time, modifications were made to improve surgical techniques and outcomes. The development of anesthesia, blood transfusion, and advances in surgical instruments facilitated the evolution of this complex procedure. In the 20th century, gradual improvements in perioperative care and surgical techniques, such as the use of pylorus-preserving techniques and the introduction of laparoscopy, led to decreased morbidity and mortality rates. Today, pancreaticoduodenectomy is considered the standard treatment for selected pancreatic and periampullary malignancies, and ongoing research aims to further refine its indications and improve patient outcomes.

Electroencephalography should not be routine in the evaluation of syncope in adults We reviewed the reports of all electroencephalograms obtained at the Nashville (Tenn) Veterans Administration Hospital from September 1987 to August 1989.  Seventy-three patients were referred for evaluation of syncope or near syncope. Electroencephalography (EEG) is commonly used in the evaluation of syncope in adults, although its routine use for this purpose remains debatable. We conducted a retrospective review of all EEG reports from a Veterans Administration Hospital over a two-year period, focusing specifically on patients referred for evaluation of syncope or near syncope. Out of the 73 patients included in the study, there was no evidence of any pathological EEG findings related to syncope in any of the cases. These findings suggest that routine EEG may not be necessary in the evaluation of syncope in adults. Further research is needed to determine the clinical utility and cost-effectiveness of routine EEG in this population.

Clustered tRNA genes in Schizosaccharomyces pombe centromeric DNA sequence repeats. Centromeric DNA sequence repeats in Schizosaccharomyces pombe were found to contain clustered tRNA genes. Using a combination of bioinformatics analysis and experimental techniques, it was demonstrated that these tRNA genes are transcribed and produce functional tRNAs. The presence of these tRNA genes within centromeric DNA repeats suggests a potential role in regulating centromere function or stability. Additionally, the clustering of tRNA genes within these repeats may provide a mechanism for coordinated expression or regulation of multiple tRNA molecules. Further studies are needed to elucidate the specific functions and mechanisms underlying the presence of clustered tRNA genes in centromeric DNA sequence repeats in S. pombe.

Brucella endocarditis: the role of combined medical and surgical treatment. Brucella endocarditis is a rare but serious infectious disease that affects the heart valves. We present a case of Brucella endocarditis treated successfully with a combination of medical and surgical interventions. The patient initially presented with fever, fatigue, and valvular insufficiency. Blood cultures confirmed the presence of Brucella melitensis. The patient was started on a combination of antibiotics, but persistent valvular dysfunction necessitated surgical intervention. Aortic valve replacement was performed, and antibiotic therapy was continued postoperatively. The patient showed significant improvement in symptoms and echocardiographic findings after combined treatment. This case highlights the importance of a multidisciplinary approach involving both medical and surgical interventions in the management of Brucella endocarditis.

Treatment of fulminant hepatic failure with insulin and glucagon.  A randomized, controlled trial. A randomized, controlled trial was conducted to evaluate the effectiveness of insulin and glucagon in the treatment of fulminant hepatic failure. Patients with this life-threatening condition were randomly assigned to receive either standard medical therapy alone or standard therapy plus continuous intravenous infusions of insulin and glucagon. The primary outcome assessed was patient survival at 30 days. Secondary outcomes included changes in liver function tests, hepatic encephalopathy score, and need for liver transplantation. There was no difference in survival rates at 30 days between the two groups (p=0.74). Additionally, there were no significant differences in liver function tests or hepatic encephalopathy scores. However, the need for liver transplantation was significantly lower in the insulin and glucagon group (p=0.03). These findings suggest that although insulin and glucagon may not improve overall survival in patients with fulminant hepatic failure, they may decrease the need for liver transplantation. Further research is warranted to determine the optimal timing and dosing of these medications in this patient population.

Crohn's disease in the city of Derby, 1951-85. This study aimed to investigate the epidemiology of Crohn's disease in the city of Derby from 1951 to 1985. A total of 459 patients with Crohn's disease were identified, with an incidence rate of 11.3 per 100,000 population per year. The incidence showed a significant increase over the study period. The male to female ratio was 1:1.2 and the median age at diagnosis was 31 years. The ileocolonic region was the most commonly involved site (63.2%), followed by the colon (26.5%). This study provides valuable information on the temporal and demographic characteristics of Crohn's disease in the city of Derby during the study period.

Patients' expectations of patient-controlled analgesia. Patient-controlled analgesia (PCA) has become a widely utilized method for managing pain in hospitalized patients. This study aimed to explore patients' expectations of PCA and their experiences with this approach. A total of 150 patients who had undergone surgery and were offered PCA participated in the study. The majority of patients (73%) had positive expectations of PCA, citing factors such as increased control over pain management and decreased reliance on healthcare professionals. However, a small portion of patients (16%) had negative expectations, expressing concerns about understanding the device and potential adverse effects. Overall, patients reported high levels of satisfaction with PCA and found it to be effective in controlling their pain. The findings suggest that clear and comprehensive education on PCA should be provided to patients to address any concerns and optimize their experience with this pain management technique.

Laser angioplasty: results of a prospective, multicenter study at 3-year follow-up.  A prospective multicenter trial was initiated to evaluate the efficacy and safety of laser angioplasty. Laser angioplasty is a potential treatment option for patients with arterial blockages. This prospective multicenter study aimed to assess the long-term outcomes and safety of laser angioplasty. A total of [number of patients] patients were enrolled and followed up for 3 years. The primary efficacy endpoint was the improvement in arterial diameter after laser angioplasty, while the primary safety endpoint included any adverse events related to the procedure. Secondary endpoints included clinical success rates and patency rates at follow-up.

The study demonstrated [results of primary efficacy endpoint], indicating a significant improvement in arterial diameter after laser angioplasty. Moreover, the procedure was generally safe, with only [number] adverse events reported, [brief description of adverse events]. The clinical success rate at follow-up was [percentage], and the patency rate was [percentage], suggesting the durability of the treatment effect.

In conclusion, this prospective multicenter study provides evidence supporting the efficacy and safety of laser angioplasty for the treatment of arterial blockages. Further research and longer-term follow-up studies are warranted to validate these findings and establish the role of laser angioplasty in the management of arterial disease.

Optimum results of the surgical treatment of carotid territory ischemia. The surgical treatment of carotid territory ischemia aims to achieve optimum results in terms of reducing the risk of recurrent stroke and improving overall patient outcomes. Various surgical approaches and techniques have been developed with the goal of effectively restoring blood flow and preventing further ischemic events. This review aims to summarize the current literature on the surgical management of carotid territory ischemia and highlight the factors that contribute to optimal outcomes. Key factors include careful patient selection, appropriate timing of intervention, meticulous surgical technique, and close postoperative surveillance. The use of perioperative antiplatelet and anticoagulant therapy also plays a significant role in reducing the risk of thromboembolic events. Additionally, advancements in imaging technology and perioperative management have further contributed to improved outcomes. Despite these advancements, further research is required to refine surgical techniques and determine the most optimal approach for different patient populations.

Mechanical measures in the prophylaxis of postoperative thromboembolism in total knee arthroplasty. Postoperative thromboembolism is a common complication in total knee arthroplasty (TKA). Mechanical measures such as compression stockings and intermittent pneumatic compression (IPC) are widely used for thromboprophylaxis. However, there is limited evidence on the effectiveness of these measures. In this study, we conducted a systematic review and meta-analysis to evaluate the role of mechanical measures in preventing postoperative thromboembolism in TKA. Our analysis included 15 randomized controlled trials with a total of 2,500 patients. The results showed that mechanical measures significantly reduced the risk of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and pulmonary embolism (PE) compared to control groups. Compression stockings and IPC were both effective in preventing postoperative thromboembolism in TKA. These findings support the use of mechanical measures as an adjunctive prophylactic intervention in TKA. Further research is needed to determine the optimal duration and timing of mechanical prophylaxis.

Standards for analysis of ventricular late potentials using high-resolution or signal-averaged electrocardiography. This study aimed to establish standardized criteria for the analysis of ventricular late potentials (VLPs) using high-resolution or signal-averaged electrocardiography (ECG). A total of 50 patients with a history of ventricular arrhythmias and 50 healthy controls were included. Multiple criteria were assessed including signal duration, root mean square voltage, signal amplitude, and duration of terminal low voltage. Receiver operating characteristic analysis was performed to determine the optimal cutoff values for identifying VLPs. The results showed that signal duration, root mean square voltage, and signal amplitude were significantly different between the two groups. The optimal cutoff values were determined for each criterion. These findings indicate that standardized analysis criteria can accurately identify VLPs using high-resolution or signal-averaged ECG, providing valuable clinical information for risk stratification and management of patients with ventricular arrhythmias.

Application of INSTAT hemostat in the control of gingival hemorrhage in the patient with thrombocytopenia. Thrombocytopenia, a condition characterized by low platelet counts, poses challenges in achieving hemostasis during dental procedures. This case report discusses the application of INSTAT hemostat, a local hemostatic agent, in controlling gingival hemorrhage in a patient with thrombocytopenia. The patient, a 45-year-old male, presented with severe gingival bleeding following a routine dental extraction. INSTAT hemostat was applied topically, resulting in prompt and effective hemostasis. The patient experienced no adverse effects, and his platelet count remained stable throughout the procedure. This case highlights the potential utility of INSTAT hemostat as a safe and effective adjunctive therapy in managing gingival bleeding in patients with thrombocytopenia. Further research is warranted to evaluate its benefits in larger cohorts.

Nonoperative management of bile duct stones.  The treatment of choice for most retained bile duct stones is by nonoperative means. Nonoperative management is the preferred treatment for retained bile duct stones in most cases. This approach avoids the need for invasive surgical procedures and their associated risks. Nonoperative techniques include endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) with stone extraction, sphincterotomy, and bile duct clearance. In cases where ERCP is not feasible or unsuccessful, alternative nonoperative methods such as oral dissolution therapy with medications like ursodeoxycholic acid can be considered. These nonoperative interventions have shown promising results in the removal of bile duct stones and can be effective in reducing symptoms and preventing complications. However, individual patient factors and stone characteristics should be carefully considered when deciding the most appropriate management approach.

Simultaneous hepatoblastoma in identical male twins. Hepatoblastoma is a rare malignant tumor of the liver primarily affecting children. It is even rarer for this tumor to occur in identical twins simultaneously. This case report presents the occurrence of hepatoblastoma in two identical male twins. Both twins presented with hepatomegaly and elevated alpha-fetoprotein levels. Imaging and histopathological analysis confirmed the diagnosis of hepatoblastoma in both individuals. Treatment involved neoadjuvant chemotherapy followed by surgical resection of the tumors. Despite aggressive management, one of the twins experienced disease recurrence and succumbed to the illness, highlighting the challenges in the management of this aggressive tumor. The presence of hepatoblastoma in identical twins provides insight into potential genetic and environmental factors contributing to its development and emphasizes the importance of early detection and intervention in improving outcomes. Further research is needed to elucidate the underlying mechanisms and potential hereditary risk factors associated with simultaneous hepatoblastoma in twins.

Transcranial Doppler in acute hemispheric brain infarction. Transcranial Doppler (TCD) is a non-invasive imaging technique used in acute hemispheric brain infarction to assess cerebral hemodynamics. This study aimed to evaluate the role of TCD in predicting the prognosis of patients with acute hemispheric brain infarction. A total of 100 patients presenting with acute hemispheric brain infarction were included in the study. TCD examination was performed within 24 hours of symptom onset, and the results were correlated with clinical and radiological findings. The study found that decreased mean flow velocity (MFV) in the affected middle cerebral artery was significantly associated with poor prognosis, including larger infarct size, higher National Institutes of Health Stroke Scale score, and increased risk of hemorrhagic transformation. Additionally, the presence of microembolic signals detected on TCD was predictive of early neurological deterioration. These findings suggest that TCD can be a valuable tool in the initial assessment and prognostic evaluation of patients with acute hemispheric brain infarction. Further studies are warranted to validate these findings and determine the optimal TCD parameters for predicting patient outcomes.

Esophageal motility, heartburn, and gastroesophageal reflux: variations in clinical presentation of esophageal dysphagia. This study aimed to investigate the clinical presentation of esophageal dysphagia in relation to esophageal motility, heartburn, and gastroesophageal reflux (GER). A total of 120 patients with esophageal dysphagia were included in the study. All patients underwent esophageal manometry, 24-hour pH monitoring, and upper gastrointestinal endoscopy. The results showed that abnormal esophageal motility was observed in 68% of patients, with the most common finding being ineffective esophageal motility. Heartburn was reported by 74% of patients, with 44% having frequent heartburn. GER was diagnosed in 38% of patients based on pH monitoring. The clinical presentation of esophageal dysphagia varied according to the presence of abnormal esophageal motility, heartburn, and GER. Patients with abnormal esophageal motility had a higher prevalence of chest pain and regurgitation, while those with heartburn had a higher prevalence of regurgitation and belching. Patients with GER had a higher prevalence of heartburn and chest pain. These findings suggest that the clinical presentation of esophageal dysphagia may be influenced by underlying esophageal motility disorders, heartburn, and GER. Further studies are needed to better understand the relationship between these factors and the presentation of esophageal dysphagia.

Research and policy directions. Hepatocellular carcinoma with tumor thrombus extending into the right atrium is typically considered unresectable. Patients with this condition usually have a poor prognosis due to complications such as pulmonary embolism, heart failure, or cancer progression. The only effective treatment is hepatic resection with removal of the tumor thrombus. In this case report, we describe a successful surgery carried out on a 38-year-old woman who underwent left lobectomy with removal of the tumor thrombus using cardiopulmonary bypass. The patient had an uneventful recovery and remained disease-free 15 months after the surgery. Despite this successful outcome, the main challenge remains in prolonging the lives of patients with this condition through surgical intervention. Further research and policy initiatives are needed in this area.

The prolonged burner syndrome. The prolonged burner syndrome is a condition characterized by recurrent episodes of burning pain and numbness in the upper extremities, typically following repetitive, forceful arm movements. This case report describes a 32-year-old male who presented with a 6-month history of these symptoms, which were exacerbated by activities such as weightlifting and playing guitar. Physical examination revealed tenderness over the median and ulnar nerve distribution, as well as mild weakness in grip strength. Electromyography confirmed the presence of focal nerve conduction abnormalities. The patient was managed conservatively with activity modification, physical therapy, and non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs, resulting in gradual improvement of symptoms. This case highlights the importance of recognizing and managing the prolonged burner syndrome in individuals engaged in repetitive upper extremity activities.

Significance of magnetic resonance imaging in acute head injury. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) has become a valuable tool in the evaluation of acute head injury. This study aimed to assess the significance of MRI findings in predicting the clinical outcome in patients with acute head injury. A total of 100 patients with acute head injury underwent MRI within 24 hours of admission. The MRI findings were categorized into three groups: normal, focal abnormalities, and diffuse abnormalities. The clinical outcome was assessed using the Glasgow Outcome Scale (GOS) at 6 months post-injury. The results showed that the presence of focal abnormalities on MRI was significantly associated with a worse clinical outcome compared to normal MRI findings or diffuse abnormalities. MRI can provide valuable information in the early assessment and prognostication of patients with acute head injury.

Infantile systemic hyalinosis: newly recognized disorder of collagen? Four infants with stiff skin and painful joint contractures in the first few months of life are described.  Other features included small papules, particularly on the face and trunk, perianal nodules, hyperpigmentation over the metacarpophalangeal joints and over the malleoli, gingival hyperplasia, persistent diarrhea, and failure to thrive. This study describes four infants presenting with stiff skin, painful joint contractures, and various other clinical features. These included small papules, perianal nodules, hyperpigmentation, gingival hyperplasia, persistent diarrhea, and failure to thrive. The authors propose the term "infantile systemic hyalinosis" to describe this newly recognized disorder, suggesting a possible involvement of collagen. This disorder appears to be distinct from other known collagenopathies, and further investigation is warranted to understand its underlying pathophysiology and potential treatment options. Recognition of this condition is important to provide early intervention and improve outcomes for affected infants.

Treatment of metastatic prostate cancer of the spine. Metastatic prostate cancer commonly spreads to the spine, resulting in significant morbidity and mortality. Treatment strategies aim to alleviate pain, preserve neurological function, and improve overall survival. This report presents the case of a 62-year-old male with metastatic prostate cancer involving the spine and outlines the management approach. The patient received hormonal therapy to suppress androgen production, along with external beam radiation therapy to the affected spinal segments. Surgical intervention was considered due to spinal cord compression, and a decompressive laminectomy and tumor resection were performed. Postoperative adjuvant therapy consisted of radiation therapy to the surgical site. The patient experienced significant pain relief, improved neurological function, and satisfactory local tumor control. Treatment of metastatic prostate cancer involving the spine requires a multidisciplinary approach, incorporating hormonal therapy, radiation therapy, and surgical intervention when necessary. Further studies are warranted to optimize treatment protocols and outcomes for this patient population.

11 beta-hydroxyandrostenedione: a marker of adrenal function in hirsutism. Hirsutism, excessive hair growth in women, is often associated with hyperandrogenism due to adrenal dysfunction. This study aimed to evaluate the role of 11 beta-hydroxyandrostenedione (11-OHA) as a marker of adrenal function in hirsutism patients. Serum levels of 11-OHA were measured in 63 hirsute women and 32 controls. The hirsute group had significantly higher 11-OHA levels compared to the control group (p<0.001). Furthermore, mean 11-OHA levels were higher in patients with adrenal hyperplasia (p<0.01) and adrenal tumors (p<0.001) compared to those with idiopathic hirsutism. Receiver operating characteristic analysis demonstrated that 11-OHA had a high sensitivity and specificity in distinguishing adrenal hyperandrogenism from idiopathic hirsutism. In conclusion, 11-OHA can serve as a useful marker for adrenal function assessment in hirsutism patients, particularly in cases of adrenal hyperplasia or tumors. Further studies are needed to validate these findings and determine the clinical utility of 11-OHA measurement in the management of hirsutism.

Thalidomide: treatment of severe recurrent aphthous stomatitis in patients with AIDS. Severe recurrent aphthous stomatitis (RAS) in patients with AIDS can be debilitating and difficult to manage. Thalidomide has shown promise as a treatment option for this condition. We present two cases of patients with AIDS who experienced severe and refractory RAS. They were treated with thalidomide and demonstrated significant improvement in symptomatology and overall quality of life. Thalidomide was well-tolerated without any major adverse effects. This case series highlights the potential benefits of thalidomide as a therapeutic option for severe RAS in patients with AIDS. Further research is warranted to establish its efficacy and safety in a larger patient population.

Double-blind comparison of doxazosin and enalapril in patients with mild or moderate essential hypertension.  The antihypertensive efficacy and safety of doxazosin and enalapril were compared in the general practice setting (n = 54). In this double-blind study, we compared the antihypertensive efficacy and safety of doxazosin and enalapril in 54 patients with mild to moderate essential hypertension in a general practice setting. Patients were randomly assigned to receive either doxazosin or enalapril for a duration of 12 weeks. Blood pressure measurements were taken at baseline and at weeks 4, 8, and 12. Both doxazosin and enalapril significantly reduced systolic and diastolic blood pressure from baseline values. There were no significant differences in blood pressure reduction between the two treatment groups. Both medications were well tolerated, with no significant adverse events reported. These findings suggest that doxazosin and enalapril may be equally effective and safe options for the treatment of mild to moderate essential hypertension.

Acute naming deficits following dominant temporal lobectomy: prediction by age at 1st risk for seizures. This study aimed to evaluate the prediction of acute naming deficits following dominant temporal lobectomy by age at first risk for seizures. The study included 80 patients who underwent dominant temporal lobectomy for the treatment of drug-resistant epilepsy. Preoperative assessments included language evaluations, neuropsychological testing, and magnetic resonance imaging. The results showed that age at first risk for seizures was a significant predictor of acute naming deficits after surgery. Specifically, patients who had their first seizure at an earlier age had a higher likelihood of experiencing naming deficits postoperatively. These findings highlight the importance of considering the age of onset of seizures in the assessment and prediction of language deficits following dominant temporal lobectomy.

Maintenance and relapse after weight loss in women: behavioral aspects. Maintenance and relapse after weight loss in women is a common challenge that requires a deeper understanding of the behavioral aspects involved. We conducted a study to investigate the factors influencing maintenance and relapse in women who have successfully lost weight. Participants who had achieved a weight loss of at least 5% of their initial body weight were included in the study. We collected data on various behavioral factors, including dietary adherence, physical activity, self-monitoring, social support, and psychological factors such as motivation and self-esteem. Our findings revealed that maintaining weight loss was associated with consistent adherence to a healthy diet, regular physical activity, and ongoing self-monitoring. However, relapse was observed in women who experienced declines in motivation, faced challenges in maintaining a healthy lifestyle, or lacked social support. These findings underscore the importance of addressing behavioral factors to support long-term weight loss maintenance in women.

An open trial of high-dosage antioxidants in early Parkinson's disease. This study evaluated the effectiveness of high-dosage antioxidants in early Parkinson's disease. Forty-five patients with early-stage Parkinson's disease were enrolled in an open trial. They were randomly divided into two groups: the treatment group received high-dose antioxidants, including vitamins C and E, coenzyme Q10, and selenium, while the control group received no treatment. The primary outcome measure was the change in Unified Parkinson's Disease Rating Scale (UPDRS) score at 6 months. Secondary outcome measures included changes in levodopa dosage, activities of daily living, and quality of life. 

After 6 months, the treatment group showed a significantly greater improvement in the UPDRS score compared to the control group (p < 0.05). Moreover, a significant reduction in levodopa dosage was observed in the treatment group compared to the control group (p < 0.05). There were no significant differences in activities of daily living and quality of life between the two groups. 

These findings suggest that high-dosage antioxidants may have a beneficial effect in early Parkinson's disease by improving motor symptoms and reducing the need for levodopa. Further studies are needed to confirm these results and elucidate the underlying mechanisms.

Psychologic and behavioral aspects of chronic headache. Chronic headache is a complex condition that not only causes physical discomfort, but also has a significant impact on the psychological and behavioral well-being of individuals. This literature review explores the psychologic and behavioral aspects of chronic headache. It highlights the high prevalence of psychiatric comorbidities, such as depression and anxiety, in individuals with chronic headache. Additionally, the review discusses the role of psychosocial factors, such as stress, in the development and maintenance of chronic headache. The impact of chronic headache on daily functioning, including work productivity and social relationships, is also considered. Understanding these psychologic and behavioral aspects of chronic headache is crucial for comprehensive management strategies, which should include a multidisciplinary approach involving both medical and psychological interventions.

Ruptured mature cystic teratoma of the ovary with recurrence in the liver and colon 17 years later. We report a rare case of a 48-year-old female with a history of a ruptured mature cystic teratoma (MCT) of the ovary, who presented 17 years later with recurrent MCT in the liver and colon. The patient initially underwent a left salpingo-oophorectomy for a ruptured MCT, and the histopathological examination confirmed the diagnosis. Seventeen years later, she presented with abdominal pain, and imaging studies revealed a large liver mass and multiple colonic polyps. Surgical resection of the liver mass and partial colectomy were performed, and the histopathological examination confirmed recurrence of MCT in both sites. This case highlights the potential for late recurrence of MCT and the importance of long-term follow-up in patients with a history of this rare ovarian neoplasm.

Colonic histoplasmosis in acquired immunodeficiency syndrome.  Report of two cases. Histoplasmosis is a fungal infection that commonly affects the lungs, but can also involve other organs in immunocompromised individuals such as those with acquired immunodeficiency syndrome (AIDS). Colonic involvement is a rare manifestation of histoplasmosis. We report two cases of colonic histoplasmosis in patients with AIDS. Both patients presented with non-specific gastrointestinal symptoms and subsequently underwent colonoscopy, which revealed ulcers and nodules in the colon. Histopathological examination confirmed the diagnosis of histoplasmosis. Treatment with antifungal medications resulted in clinical improvement in both cases. Colonic histoplasmosis should be considered in the differential diagnosis of gastrointestinal symptoms in patients with AIDS, especially in endemic areas. Early diagnosis and appropriate treatment are crucial for successful management.

Reflex sympathetic dystrophy syndrome: consensus report of an ad hoc committee of the American Association for Hand Surgery on the definition of reflex sympathetic dystrophy syndrome. A consensus report on the definition of reflex sympathetic dystrophy syndrome (RSDS) was developed by an ad hoc committee of the American Association for Hand Surgery. RSDS is characterized by persistent pain, swelling, and limited range of motion in a limb after trauma or surgery. The committee proposed that RSDS be defined by the presence of at least three of the following criteria: presence of an initiating noxious event, disproportionate pain in relation to the inciting event, evidence of edema, skin temperature changes, and limited range of motion. This consensus definition aims to provide clinicians with a standardized framework for diagnosing RSDS and facilitating appropriate management of this challenging condition.

Expression of HLA-DR and secretory component antigens and lymphocyte infiltration in human gastric nonmalignant and malignant tissues: an immunohistochemical study. The expression of HLA-DR and secretory component antigens, as well as lymphocyte infiltration, was investigated in nonmalignant and malignant gastric tissues using immunohistochemistry. HLA-DR antigen expression was significantly increased in both nonmalignant gastritis (p<0.05) and gastric cancer (p<0.01) compared to normal gastric tissues. Secretory component antigen expression was significantly decreased in malignant tissues compared to nonmalignant tissues (p<0.01). Lymphocyte infiltration was higher in nonmalignant gastritis compared to normal gastric tissues (p<0.05), but it did not differ significantly between nonmalignant and malignant gastric tissues. Additionally, HLA-DR antigen expression showed a positive correlation with lymphocyte infiltration in both nonmalignant gastritis (p<0.01) and gastric cancer (p<0.05). These findings suggest that the expression of HLA-DR and secretory component antigens, as well as lymphocyte infiltration, play significant roles in the pathogenesis of gastric diseases and may have potential diagnostic and therapeutic implications.

Polypoid melanoma: a virulent variant of nodular melanoma. Polypoid melanoma is a rare but aggressive subtype of nodular melanoma. It presents as a raised, polyp-like growth on the skin, which can often be misdiagnosed or overlooked due to its unusual appearance. This variant is associated with a higher risk of metastasis and worse prognosis compared to other types of melanoma. Histopathological examination reveals invasive malignant cells forming polypoid projections, while deep tissue invasion is commonly observed. Early detection and appropriate management of polypoid melanoma are crucial for improving patient outcomes. Dermatologists and other healthcare professionals should be aware of this distinct subtype and consider it in the differential diagnosis of suspicious skin lesions, especially in individuals with risk factors for melanoma. In conclusion, polypoid melanoma represents a virulent variant of nodular melanoma that requires prompt recognition and multidisciplinary intervention for optimal patient care.

Characterization and histopathological correlation of cytosol proteins of benign and malignant breast tumors. The characterization and histopathological correlation of cytosol proteins were investigated in benign and malignant breast tumors. Cytosol proteins were extracted from breast tissue samples obtained from patients diagnosed with benign or malignant breast tumors. Protein profiles were analyzed using gel electrophoresis and compared between the two groups. The histopathological features of the tumors were examined, including tumor size, grade, and lymph node involvement. Significant differences in cytosol protein expression were observed between benign and malignant breast tumors, suggesting potential biomarkers for distinguishing between the two. Furthermore, correlations were found between specific cytosol proteins and histopathological features, providing insights into the pathogenesis and progression of breast cancer. This study contributes to a better understanding of breast tumor biology and may have implications for diagnosis and targeted therapy.

A comparison of parallel versus perpendicular placement of retention sutures in abdominal wound closure.  A new technique for placement of retention sutures is described. This study compares the effectiveness of parallel and perpendicular placement of retention sutures in abdominal wound closure. A new technique for placement of retention sutures is also described. A total of 80 patients undergoing abdominal surgery were randomly assigned to receive either parallel or perpendicular placement of retention sutures. Wound dehiscence, surgical site infection, and patient satisfaction were assessed as outcome measures. Wound dehiscence rates were significantly lower in the parallel placement group compared to the perpendicular placement group (10% vs. 25%, p=0.03). Surgical site infection rates and patient satisfaction did not differ significantly between the two groups. The new technique for placement of retention sutures was found to be safe and easy to perform. In conclusion, parallel placement of retention sutures may be more effective in preventing wound dehiscence compared to perpendicular placement.

Fibrillation potential amplitude and muscle atrophy following peripheral nerve injury. This study aimed to investigate the relationship between fibrillation potential amplitude and muscle atrophy following peripheral nerve injury. A total of 80 patients with peripheral nerve injury were included in the study. Fibrillation potential amplitude was measured using electromyography, and muscle atrophy was assessed using ultrasound imaging. The results showed that there was a significant correlation between fibrillation potential amplitude and muscle atrophy. Patients with higher fibrillation potential amplitude had more severe muscle atrophy. Furthermore, the duration of nerve injury was positively correlated with both fibrillation potential amplitude and muscle atrophy. These findings suggest that fibrillation potential amplitude could serve as a potential biomarker for evaluating the severity of muscle atrophy following peripheral nerve injury. Early detection and intervention based on fibrillation potential amplitude measurements may help prevent or minimize muscle atrophy in patients with peripheral nerve injury. Further studies are needed to validate these findings and explore potential therapeutic interventions.

Prevention of hypotension following spinal anaesthesia for elective caesarean section by wrapping of the legs.  Twenty-four parturients undergoing elective Caesarean section were allocated randomly to have the legs wrapped with elasticated Esmarch bandages immediately following spinal anaesthesia or to serve as controls. This study aimed to investigate the effectiveness of leg wrapping in preventing hypotension after spinal anesthesia for elective caesarean section. Twenty-four parturients undergoing the procedure were randomly assigned to either have their legs wrapped with elasticated Esmarch bandages or serve as controls. The occurrence of hypotension, defined as a systolic blood pressure decrease of more than 20% from baseline, was monitored. Results showed a significantly lower incidence of hypotension in the leg wrapping group compared to the control group (37.5% vs 87.5%). Additionally, the leg wrapping group required fewer vasopressor interventions and had shorter durations of hypotension. These findings suggest that leg wrapping with elasticated Esmarch bandages may effectively prevent hypotension following spinal anesthesia for elective caesarean section.

The natural history of non-arteritic anterior ischaemic optic neuropathy.  Seventy one patients with non-arteritic anterior ischaemic optic neuropathy were studied retrospectively. We conducted a retrospective study on seventy-one patients with non-arteritic anterior ischaemic optic neuropathy (NAION) to investigate its natural history. NAION is a condition characterized by sudden loss of vision due to reduced blood flow to the optic nerve. The patients were followed from the time of initial presentation until the final outcome. The mean duration of follow-up was 3.5 years. We found that the majority of patients experienced a decline in visual acuity within the first few weeks of onset, with only limited improvement observed during the follow-up period. Visual field defects were also common, affecting the inferior and nasal quadrants in most cases. Additional ocular complications, such as optic disc pallor and cupping, were observed in a subset of patients. Our study highlights the chronic and often irreversible nature of NAION, underscoring the need for early detection and appropriate management to prevent further visual impairment. These findings contribute to a better understanding of the disease's progression and aid in the development of interventions to optimize patient outcomes.

An immunofluorescence study of cerebral malaria. Cerebral malaria is a severe complication of Plasmodium falciparum infection, characterized by sequestration of infected erythrocytes in the brain microvasculature. Fibrin deposition and endothelial activation contribute to the pathogenesis of this condition. In order to investigate the immunological processes involved, we conducted an immunofluorescence study of cerebral malaria. We analyzed brain tissue sections from patients who died from cerebral malaria and compared them to control brain tissue sections. Our results revealed a significant increase in the expression of intercellular adhesion molecule-1 (ICAM-1) and vascular cell adhesion molecule-1 (VCAM-1) in the cerebral malaria group. Additionally, we observed a higher accumulation of CD8+ T cells and macrophages in the infected brain tissue. These findings highlight the role of immune cell infiltration and endothelial activation in the pathogenesis of cerebral malaria and provide valuable insights for potential therapeutic interventions.

Diagnostic significance of carcinoembryonic antigen in the differential diagnosis of malignant mesothelioma. Carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) is a tumor marker commonly used in the diagnosis and monitoring of various malignancies. This study aims to assess the diagnostic significance of CEA in differentiating malignant mesothelioma (MM) from other malignancies. A systematic review and meta-analysis were conducted on relevant studies identified from electronic databases. The pooled sensitivity, specificity, positive likelihood ratio (PLR), negative likelihood ratio (NLR), and diagnostic odds ratio (DOR) were calculated. A total of 14 studies met the inclusion criteria, involving 1674 patients. The results showed that the pooled sensitivity of CEA in differentiating MM was 0.61 (95% confidence interval [CI], 0.51-0.71), with a specificity of 0.89 (95% CI, 0.84-0.92). The PLR was 5.45 (95% CI, 3.12-9.53), and the NLR was 0.47 (95% CI, 0.34-0.66). The DOR was 11.59 (95% CI, 6.98-19.25). These findings suggest that CEA has moderate accuracy in distinguishing MM from other malignancies. Therefore, CEA can be considered as a valuable adjunctive tool in the differential diagnosis of MM. Further studies are warranted to elucidate its role in clinical practice.

Epidermoid cyst (monodermal teratoma) of the testis. Epidermoid cysts, also known as monodermal teratomas, are rare benign tumors that typically arise in the testis. We present a case of a 35-year-old male who presented with a painless testicular mass. Ultrasound imaging revealed a well-defined cystic lesion within the testis. Surgical excision was performed and histopathological examination confirmed the diagnosis of an epidermoid cyst. Epidermoid cysts are composed of squamous epithelium without any other germ cell or mesodermal components. They are believed to arise from embryonic epithelial rests during testicular development. Although rare, epidermoid cysts should be considered in the differential diagnosis of testicular masses. While testicular malignancies are of major concern, the benign nature of epidermoid cysts allows for complete resolution with surgical excision alone. Long-term follow-up is recommended to ensure absence of recurrence or malignant transformation.

Differentiation in embryonal neuroepithelial tumors of the central nervous system. Embryonal neuroepithelial tumors (ENTs) of the central nervous system (CNS) encompass a diverse group of neoplasms with overlapping histological features, making their accurate diagnosis challenging. This study aims to highlight the importance of differentiation in ENTs. A retrospective analysis of 50 cases revealed distinct histopathological and immunophenotypic characteristics that allowed for categorization into four subtypes: medulloepithelioma (ME), embryonal tumor with multilayered rosettes (ETMR), ependymoblastoma (EB), and atypical teratoid/rhabdoid tumor (AT/RT). ME exhibited abundant neuropil-like area and strong positivity for neural markers. ETMR demonstrated rosette formations, while EB exhibited ependymal features. AT/RT demonstrated a combination of rhabdoid and teratoid elements. Molecular analysis revealed distinct genetic alterations associated with each subtype. Understanding the differentiation patterns in ENTs is essential for accurate diagnosis, prognostication, and tailored treatment strategies. Further research on the molecular drivers of these tumors is warranted to improve therapeutic options and patient outcomes.

Immunohistochemical demonstration of the placental form of glutathione S-transferase, a detoxifying enzyme in human gliomas. In this study, we aimed to investigate the presence and localization of the placental form of glutathione S-transferase (GST-P) in human gliomas using immunohistochemical techniques. A total of 40 glioma samples were collected and analyzed for the expression of GST-P. Additionally, normal brain tissues adjacent to the tumor were used as controls. The results demonstrated that GST-P expression was significantly higher in glioma tissues compared to normal brain tissues (p<0.001). Immunoreactivity for GST-P was mainly observed in the cytoplasm of tumor cells, with varying degrees of intensity and distribution patterns. Moreover, high GST-P expression was associated with advanced tumor stage and poorer overall survival (p=0.023 and p=0.036, respectively). Our findings suggest that GST-P may play a role in glioma development and progression, potentially reflecting its involvement in detoxification processes within tumor cells. Further investigations are warranted to explore the potential utility of GST-P as a prognostic marker and therapeutic target for glioma patients.

Orthostatic hypotension after spinal cord injury: treatment with fludrocortisone and ergotamine. Orthostatic hypotension is a common complication following spinal cord injury. In this study, we evaluated the efficacy of fludrocortisone and ergotamine in the treatment of orthostatic hypotension in patients with spinal cord injury. A total of 15 patients with confirmed orthostatic hypotension were enrolled in the study. Treatment consisted of fludrocortisone and ergotamine administered orally. After 4 weeks of treatment, all patients showed significant improvement in orthostatic hypotension symptoms, with a mean increase in systolic blood pressure of 20 mmHg and a mean increase in diastolic blood pressure of 10 mmHg. Additionally, all patients reported a reduction in symptoms such as dizziness and lightheadedness. Fludrocortisone and ergotamine appear to be effective in the treatment of orthostatic hypotension following spinal cord injury, offering a potential therapeutic option for these patients.

Morphological and histopathological aspects of aneurysms after patch aortoplasty for coarctation. OBJECTIVES: Patch aortoplasty is a commonly used surgical technique for the treatment of coarctation of the aorta. However, the long-term morphological and histopathological aspects of aneurysms that can develop after this procedure are not well understood. This study aimed to investigate the morphology and histopathology of aneurysms following patch aortoplasty for coarctation. 
RESEARCH DESIGN AND METHODS: A total of 15 patients who underwent patch aortoplasty for coarctation were included in this study. Surgical specimens of aneurysms that developed at the site of the patch were retrieved and analyzed morphologically and histopathologically. 
RESULTS: The aneurysms exhibited a saccular morphology and were characterized by collagen deposition, elastic fiber fragmentation, and smooth muscle cell proliferation within the vessel wall. In some cases, the presence of thrombus and calcification was also observed. 
CONCLUSIONS: The findings of this study indicate that aneurysms following patch aortoplasty for coarctation display specific morphological and histopathological features, which may provide insights into their pathogenesis and potentially guide the development of improved treatment strategies.

Quantitative assessment of extradural bupivacaine analgesia.  Bupivacaine (0. Extradural bupivacaine analgesia is commonly used for pain management in various surgical procedures. This study aimed to evaluate the quantitative aspects of extradural bupivacaine analgesia. A total of 50 patients undergoing different types of surgeries were included in the study. Each patient received extradural bupivacaine analgesia using a standardized technique. The duration and quality of analgesia were assessed using visual analogue scale (VAS) scores and the time to the first rescue analgesic requirement. The mean duration of analgesia was found to be 10.5 hours, with a range of 6-15 hours. The VAS scores showed a significant reduction in pain intensity after the administration of extradural bupivacaine. Additionally, the time to the first rescue analgesic requirement was significantly prolonged. No major adverse effects or complications were observed. These findings suggest that extradural bupivacaine analgesia provides effective and prolonged pain relief in surgical patients, potentially reducing the need for rescue analgesics and improving postoperative recovery and patient satisfaction.

Visual losses after myopic epikeratoplasty. Visual losses after myopic epikeratoplasty, a surgical procedure used to correct myopia, were studied in a retrospective analysis. Eighteen patients were included in the study and underwent myopic epikeratoplasty with an average follow-up period of 24 months. The main outcome measure was visual acuity, assessed preoperatively and postoperatively at various time points. 
Results showed that nine out of the 18 patients experienced visual loss after myopic epikeratoplasty. Visual acuity declined to less than 20/40 in these patients, with three patients exhibiting visual acuity of worse than 20/200. The remaining nine patients had stable or improved visual acuity after the procedure. 
Factors significantly associated with visual loss included the degree of myopia and the presence of postoperative complications such as corneal haze and epithelial ingrowth. Patients with higher preoperative myopia and those who developed complications were more likely to experience visual loss. 
In conclusion, visual losses can occur after myopic epikeratoplasty, particularly in patients with higher degrees of myopia and those who experience postoperative complications. Close monitoring and proper management of complications are essential to optimize visual outcomes in patients undergoing this procedure.

Sudden death due to delayed rupture of hepatic subcapsular hematoma following blunt abdominal trauma. We present a case of sudden death due to delayed rupture of a hepatic subcapsular hematoma following blunt abdominal trauma. A 28-year-old male was involved in a car accident, and an abdominal CT scan showed a small hematoma in the liver. The patient was discharged with instructions to return if any symptoms developed. However, three days later, he suddenly collapsed and was pronounced dead upon arrival at the hospital. Autopsy revealed a large subcapsular hematoma with evidence of recent rupture. This case emphasizes the importance of close monitoring and early intervention in patients with hepatic injuries, even if initial imaging studies show small hematomas.

Identification and characterization of a regulated promoter element in the epidermal growth factor receptor gene. The epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) plays a crucial role in cell growth and development. In this study, researchers aimed to identify and characterize a regulatory promoter element in the EGFR gene. Through a series of experiments, they identified a region within the EGFR gene that displayed promoter activity, which was confirmed using luciferase reporter assays. Further analysis revealed that this promoter element was regulated in a tissue-specific manner and was responsive to specific cellular signals. Additionally, chromatin immunoprecipitation assays showed the binding of specific transcription factors to this promoter element, further supporting its regulatory function. Overall, this study provides valuable insights into the regulation of the EGFR gene and may contribute to a better understanding of its role in various cellular processes and diseases.

Partial characterization of Chlamydia trachomatis isolates resistant to multiple antibiotics.  In vitro susceptibility testing was done on urogenital isolates of Chlamydia trachomatis from five patients, four of whom were suspected treatment failures. We describe the phenotypic and genotypic characterization of Chlamydia trachomatis isolates resistant to multiple antibiotics. Urogenital isolates were obtained from five patients, four of whom were suspected treatment failures. In vitro susceptibility testing revealed resistance to multiple antibiotics, including azithromycin, doxycycline, and erythromycin. Molecular analysis showed the presence of mutations in the 23S rRNA gene associated with azithromycin resistance. Additionally, mutations in the gyrA gene were detected, indicating resistance to fluoroquinolones. Whole genome sequencing revealed genetic variations in other genes associated with antibiotic resistance, including mtrR and rrl. These findings highlight the emergence of multidrug-resistant C. trachomatis strains and emphasize the importance of ongoing surveillance and appropriate treatment strategies. Further studies are warranted to better understand the mechanisms of resistance and to guide the development of effective interventions against these multidrug-resistant strains.

Posthospital course and outcome in schizophrenia.  To study the early course of schizophrenia, we assessed 79 early phase, young, DSM-III schizophrenic patients at two successive posthospital follow-ups, 2. This study aimed to investigate the posthospital course and outcome of schizophrenia in 79 young patients diagnosed with DSM-III schizophrenia. The patients were assessed at two consecutive posthospital follow-ups, 2.7 and 4.3 years after the initial hospitalization. The assessment included measures of psychopathology, global functioning, and social and occupational outcomes. The results showed that there was a significant improvement in symptom severity and global functioning from the first to the second follow-up. However, a considerable proportion of patients still experienced persistent symptoms and functional impairment. Factors associated with a poorer outcome included higher initial symptom severity, longer duration of untreated psychosis, and lower baseline social and occupational functioning. These findings highlight the importance of early intervention and ongoing support in improving the long-term outcomes for individuals with schizophrenia.

A randomized clinical trial of scatter photocoagulation of proliferative sickle cell retinopathy. Proliferative sickle cell retinopathy (PSCR) is a potentially blinding complication of sickle cell disease. The standard treatment for PSCR is panretinal photocoagulation (PRP), but concerns exist about its potential adverse effects. This randomized clinical trial aimed to compare the efficacy and safety of scatter photocoagulation (SP) with PRP in patients with PSCR. A total of 120 patients were randomly assigned to receive either SP or PRP. The primary outcome was change in visual acuity at one year. Secondary outcomes included the development of neovascular glaucoma and the need for additional laser treatment. The results showed that both SP and PRP led to significant improvements in visual acuity at one year, with no significant difference between the two groups. However, SP was associated with a lower incidence of neovascular glaucoma and a lower need for additional laser treatment compared to PRP. These findings suggest that SP is a safe and effective alternative to PRP for the treatment of PSCR, with potentially fewer adverse effects.

Structural and ultrastructural study of the ovary in childhood leukemia after successful treatment. The aim of this study was to investigate the structural and ultrastructural changes in the ovaries of children who underwent successful treatment for leukemia. Ovarian specimens were obtained from ten female patients, aged 5 to 15 years, who had received chemotherapy and achieved complete remission of leukemia. Histological examination revealed a reduction in the number of primordial follicles and an increase in atretic follicles compared to normal ovaries. Ultrastructural analysis using transmission electron microscopy showed alterations in the granulosa and theca cells, including vacuolization, mitochondrial abnormalities, and irregular cell shapes. These findings suggest that chemotherapy used in the treatment of childhood leukemia can result in structural and ultrastructural changes in the ovaries, which may contribute to fertility issues and early menopause in these patients. Further studies are warranted to fully understand the impact of chemotherapy on ovarian function in childhood leukemia survivors.

Scleral buckle revision to treat recurrent rhegmatogenous retinal detachment. Rhegmatogenous retinal detachment (RRD) is a serious ocular condition that often requires surgical intervention for management. Despite successful primary repair using scleral buckle (SB) techniques, some patients may experience recurrent RRD. This study aims to evaluate the efficacy of SB revision as a treatment for recurrent RRD. A retrospective analysis of patients who underwent SB revision for recurrent RRD was conducted. Outcomes assessed included anatomical success rates and visual acuity improvement post-revision surgery. A total of X patients were included in the study, with a mean follow-up period of X months. The anatomical success rate was X%, with X patients achieving complete retinal attachment. Visual acuity showed improvement in X% of patients. No intraoperative complications or significant postoperative adverse events were reported. SB revision appears to be an effective and safe option for the management of recurrent RRD. Further prospective studies are warranted to validate these findings.

Essential fatty acid sufficiency does not preclude fat-soluble-vitamin deficiency in short-bowel syndrome.  Patients with extensive small-bowel resection may experience malabsorption and nutrient deficiencies. Short-bowel syndrome (SBS) patients who have undergone extensive small-bowel resection may suffer from malabsorption and nutrient deficiencies. This study aimed to investigate whether essential fatty acid (EFA) sufficiency could protect against fat-soluble-vitamin deficiency in SBS patients. Serum levels of vitamins A, D, and E were analyzed in 65 SBS patients with residual small-bowel lengths of less than 100 cm. The results showed that while all patients had normal EFA levels, 62% of them exhibited vitamin deficiencies. Specifically, 45% were vitamin A deficient, 12% were vitamin D deficient, and 52% were vitamin E deficient. These findings suggest that EFA sufficiency does not guarantee protection against fat-soluble-vitamin deficiency in SBS patients. Therefore, it is crucial to monitor and supplement these vitamins in individuals with SBS who have undergone extensive small-bowel resection to prevent potential deficiencies and associated health complications.

Results of treatment of persistent hyperplastic primary vitreous. Persistent hyperplastic primary vitreous (PHPV) is a congenital condition characterized by an abnormal development of the eye's vasculature, leading to visual impairment or even blindness. This study aimed to evaluate the outcomes of treatment for PHPV. A retrospective analysis was conducted on 35 patients who were treated for PHPV. Treatment modalities included surgery, laser therapy, and combination therapy. The main outcomes assessed were visual acuity and anatomical improvement of the eye.
