However, the lack of standardization raises concerns about the clinical comparability of data and the ability to draw consistent conclusions. There is a need for standardized protocols and further research to determine the optimal approach for performing SPR.

An objective score to predict upper tract deterioration in myelodysplasia.  Bladder dysfunction in myelodysplasia may present a significant hazard to the upper tract and a threat to kidney function. Bladder dysfunction in myelodysplasia can lead to upper tract deterioration and kidney function impairment. In this study, we aimed to develop an objective score to predict upper tract deterioration in patients with myelodysplasia. We retrospectively analyzed medical records of patients with myelodysplasia and identified factors that were significantly associated with upper tract deterioration. Based on these factors, we developed a scoring system that could accurately predict the risk of upper tract deterioration in patients with myelodysplasia. Our findings suggest that this objective score could be a valuable tool for clinicians in identifying patients who are at higher risk of upper tract deterioration, allowing for timely interventions to preserve kidney function.

Cerebrospinal fluid eicosanoid levels: endogenous PGD2 and LTC4 synthesis by antigen-presenting cells that migrate to the central nervous system. This study investigates the synthesis of prostaglandin D2 (PGD2) and leukotriene C4 (LTC4) by antigen-presenting cells (APCs) that migrate to the central nervous system (CNS) through the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF). CSF samples were collected from patients with various CNS disorders and analyzed for eicosanoid levels. Results showed that APCs in the CSF are capable of synthesizing both PGD2 and LTC4. Furthermore, levels of these eicosanoids were found to be significantly higher in patients with active CNS inflammation. These findings suggest that APCs migrating to the CNS may contribute to the inflammatory response through eicosanoid synthesis. Targeting this pathway may offer potential therapeutic strategies for CNS disorders associated with inflammation.

Primary malignant melanoma of the lower respiratory tract.  Report of a case and literature review. Primary malignant melanoma of the lower respiratory tract is an extremely rare and aggressive malignancy. We report a case of a 56-year-old male who presented with hemoptysis and was diagnosed with primary malignant melanoma of the bronchus. The patient underwent surgical resection followed by adjuvant chemotherapy and radiation therapy. Despite aggressive treatment, the patient experienced disease progression and succumbed to metastatic disease within 10 months of diagnosis. Literature review revealed only a limited number of reported cases, with a male predominance and a median age of diagnosis in the sixth decade. The majority of cases presented with nonspecific respiratory symptoms, making the diagnosis challenging. Due to its rarity and poor prognosis, primary malignant melanoma of the lower respiratory tract poses significant diagnostic and therapeutic challenges. Further research is needed to better understand the molecular characteristics and optimal management strategies for this aggressive malignancy.

Solid and cystic ultimobranchial body remnants in the thyroid. The presence of solid and cystic ultimobranchial body remnants in the thyroid is a rare finding. We present a case of a 45-year-old woman who underwent thyroidectomy for a suspicious thyroid nodule. Histopathological examination revealed the presence of solid and cystic structures resembling the ultimobranchial body within the thyroid parenchyma. Immunohistochemical analysis confirmed the presence of calcitonin and thyroglobulin in these structures, further supporting their ultimobranchial origin. The ultimobranchial body is an embryologic structure that typically regresses during development, but in some cases, remnants can persist within the thyroid gland. These remnants are usually incidental findings on histopathological examination and are associated with a low risk of malignancy. It is important for pathologists to be aware of this entity to avoid misdiagnosis. Further studies are needed to better understand the pathogenesis and clinical implications of ultimobranchial body remnants in thyroid nodules.

New active analogues of vitamin D with low calcemic activity. Vitamin D analogues with reduced calcemic activity are of interest due to their potential therapeutic applications. In this study, a series of new active analogues of vitamin D were synthesized and evaluated for their calcemic activity using a cell-based assay. Several compounds showed significantly lower calcemic activity compared to the natural hormone, vitamin D. These analogues also exhibited potent antiproliferative effects on cancer cell lines, suggesting their potential use in cancer therapy. Furthermore, certain analogues demonstrated enhanced metabolic stability and improved oral bioavailability. Overall, these findings highlight the promising potential of these novel analogues as therapeutic agents for various diseases.

Meropenem pharmacokinetics and penetration into an inflammatory exudate.  The pharmacokinetics and penetration into a cantharidine-induced inflammatory exudate of meropenem was studied in six volunteers following a single 1-g intravenous dose. The study aimed to investigate the pharmacokinetics and penetration of meropenem into an inflammatory exudate induced by cantharidine. Six volunteers were administered a single intravenous dose of 1g meropenem. The pharmacokinetics of meropenem showed a rapid elimination, with a mean half-life of 1.5 hours. The penetration into the inflammatory exudate was excellent, with concentrations exceeding the minimum inhibitory concentration for susceptible pathogens. No adverse effects or complications were observed. These findings highlight the potential efficacy of meropenem in treating infections associated with inflammatory exudate, suggesting its suitability for use in these conditions.

Granulomatous prostatitis and poorly differentiated prostate carcinoma. Granulomatous prostatitis is a benign inflammatory condition frequently mistaken for prostate carcinoma due to overlapping clinical and histological features. We present a case of a 62-year-old male who underwent prostate biopsy due to elevated prostate-specific antigen (PSA) levels. Histopathological examination revealed granulomatous prostatitis with focal areas of poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma. The coexistence of granulomatous prostatitis and prostate carcinoma is extremely rare, with less than 30 cases reported in the literature. The differential diagnosis between these entities can be challenging, as they share similar clinical and imaging characteristics. Immunohistochemical staining, particularly for PSA and CD68, is crucial in differentiating between the two. Although granulomatous prostatitis is generally considered a benign condition, the presence of poorly differentiated carcinoma warrants further investigation, including whole-mount histopathological examination and assessment of lymph node involvement. This case emphasizes the importance of considering granulomatous prostatitis as a potential confounding factor in the diagnosis and management of prostate cancer patients, highlighting the need for careful evaluation and multidisciplinary collaboration.

Multiple gunshot wounds of the head: an anthropological view.  A decomposed body was judged at the scene to have two gunshot wounds of the thorax and three of the head. This case study presents a decomposed body with multiple gunshot wounds, focusing on the anthropological perspective of the head injuries. The body was initially examined at the scene and determined to have two gunshot wounds in the thorax and three in the head. Anthropological analysis of the head wounds involved studying the location, trajectory, and characteristics of the injuries. The findings were consistent with ballistic evidence and provided valuable information for reconstructing the sequence of events leading to the individual's death. Additionally, the study shed light on the potential weapon used, the angles of entry, and the distance from which the gunshots were fired. Such anthropological insights contribute to forensic investigations and aid in understanding the circumstances surrounding violent deaths.

Epidemiology of acute respiratory infections in young children from Thailand. This study aimed to investigate the epidemiology of acute respiratory infections (ARIs) in young children from Thailand. A total of 500 children aged 6 months to 5 years (mean age 2.3 +/- 1.2 years) were included in the study. Nasal swab samples were collected from these children and tested for respiratory viruses using polymerase chain reaction. The results showed that 65% of the children tested positive for at least one respiratory virus, with the most common viruses detected being respiratory syncytial virus (RSV), influenza virus, and adenovirus. Children aged 6-23 months had the highest prevalence of ARIs, accounting for 43% of the cases. The peak incidence of ARIs occurred during the rainy season. Furthermore, children with underlying medical conditions had a higher risk of developing severe ARIs. This study provides important insights into the epidemiology of ARIs in young children from Thailand, emphasizing the need for preventive measures and healthcare interventions to reduce the burden of these infections.

Arterial responses during migraine headache. During a migraine headache, there are significant changes in arterial function, which contribute to the symptoms experienced. These changes include dilation and constriction of the cerebral arteries and altered blood flow patterns. The exact mechanisms behind these arterial responses are not fully understood, but it is believed that neurogenic inflammation and the release of vasoactive substances play a role. Additionally, the activation of trigeminal nerves and the release of calcitonin gene-related peptide (CGRP) have been implicated in the arterial responses during a migraine attack. Understanding the underlying mechanisms of these arterial responses is important for the development of targeted treatments for migraines, which can alleviate symptoms and improve the quality of life for affected individuals.

Expression of P-glycoprotein in adult T-cell leukemia cells. This study aimed to investigate the expression of P-glycoprotein (P-gp) in adult T-cell leukemia (ATL) cells. P-gp is an efflux pump that plays a crucial role in multidrug resistance. Samples from 30 ATL patients were analyzed for P-gp expression using immunohistochemistry. Results showed that P-gp was highly expressed in ATL cells, with 70% of the samples showing positive staining. Further analysis revealed that P-gp expression was associated with advanced disease stage and poor prognosis. Additionally, P-gp expression was correlated with resistance to chemotherapy agents commonly used in ATL treatment. These findings suggest that P-gp plays a significant role in drug resistance in ATL and may serve as a potential therapeutic target. By targeting P-gp, it may be possible to overcome drug resistance and improve treatment outcomes for ATL patients.

Effect of indomethacin on the pathophysiology of experimental meningitis in rabbits. The effects of indomethacin on the pathophysiology of experimental meningitis were investigated in rabbits. Meningitis was induced by intracisternal injection of Escherichia coli in the rabbits. Indomethacin, a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug, was administered intraperitoneally as a single dose. The rabbits were divided into two groups: one group received indomethacin treatment, while the other group served as a control. The animals were monitored for changes in cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) parameters and histopathological findings. Indomethacin treatment resulted in a significant reduction in CSF leukocyte count, protein concentration, and lactate levels compared to the control group. Histopathological evaluation also showed a decrease in meningeal inflammation and edema in the indomethacin-treated group. These findings suggest that indomethacin has potential therapeutic effects in the pathophysiology of experimental meningitis.

Anti-Kveim monoclonal antibody.  New monoclonal antibody reacting to epithelioid cells in sarcoid granulomas. Sarcoidosis is a chronic inflammatory disorder characterized by the formation of granulomas in various organs. The use of the Kveim test, which involves inoculating patients with a suspension of sarcoid tissue, has been a valuable diagnostic tool for decades. However, the exact target antigen of the Kveim reagent has remained elusive. In this study, we describe the development of a new monoclonal antibody, named anti-Kveim monoclonal antibody, which specifically reacts with epithelioid cells in sarcoid granulomas. Immunohistochemical analysis using this antibody demonstrated strong staining of epithelioid cells in sarcoid granulomas but not in control tissues. The anti-Kveim monoclonal antibody showed a high sensitivity and specificity in detecting sarcoidosis in a cohort of patients, suggesting its potential as a new diagnostic tool. Further investigations are needed to determine the precise antigen targeted by this antibody and its clinical utility in the management of sarcoidosis.

Speech, velopharyngeal function, and hearing before and after orthognathic surgery.  Articulation, voice, resonance, hearing sensitivity, and middle ear function were examined in 34 patients before and 3, 6, 9, and 12 months after orthognathic surgery. This study examines the effects of orthognathic surgery on speech, velopharyngeal function, and hearing in 34 patients. Tests were conducted before surgery and at 3, 6, 9, and 12 months post-surgery. The assessment included analysis of articulation, voice quality, resonance, hearing sensitivity, and middle ear function. Results showed significant improvements in speech and velopharyngeal function post-surgery, with enhancement in articulation and voice quality. Resonance was also positively impacted, indicating improvements in speech resonance. Interestingly, hearing sensitivity remained relatively stable throughout the study, suggesting no adverse effects of orthognathic surgery on hearing. Middle ear function showed some changes, but further investigation is needed to determine the clinical significance of these findings. Overall, this study demonstrates the positive impact of orthognathic surgery on speech and velopharyngeal function while highlighting the need for continued monitoring of middle ear function.

Effect of hydrocele on testis and spermatogenesis. Hydrocele is a common condition characterized by the accumulation of fluid around the testicle, resulting in swelling and discomfort. This study aimed to investigate the effects of hydrocele on testis and spermatogenesis. Fifteen patients with hydrocele were included in the study, and tissue samples were obtained during surgical intervention. Histopathological analysis revealed significant changes in the testicular architecture, including edema, fibrosis, and congestion. Spermatogenesis was found to be impaired, with a decrease in sperm count and motility, as well as abnormal sperm morphology. Additionally, hormonal analysis showed alterations in testosterone levels. These findings highlight the detrimental effects of hydrocele on testicular function and provide insights into potential mechanisms involved in spermatogenesis dysfunction.

Lymph node metastasis from papillary-follicular thyroid carcinoma in young patients.  A total of 117 patients under 20 years of age with papillary and/or follicular thyroid cancer presented to the M. Fifty-two patients (44.4%) had lymph node metastasis at the time of diagnosis. The mean age at diagnosis was 16.5 years, with a female predominance (73.5%). The most common presenting symptom was a painless neck mass (92.3%). Histopathology revealed papillary thyroid carcinoma in 81.2% of cases and follicular thyroid carcinoma in 18.8%. The majority of patients (80.8%) had multifocal tumors. Lymph node metastasis was found in 53.8% of papillary thyroid carcinoma cases and 14.3% of follicular thyroid carcinoma cases. Lateral neck lymph nodes were the most commonly involved (69.2%). Young patients with papillary-follicular thyroid carcinoma frequently present with lymph node metastasis. Clinicians should consider early evaluation of the neck for lymph node involvement to inform treatment decisions and improve patient outcomes.

Urogenital dysfunction after abdominoperineal resection for carcinoma of the rectum. Urogenital dysfunction is a common complication following abdominoperineal resection (APR) for carcinoma of the rectum. This study aimed to assess the impact of APR on urogenital function in a cohort of patients. Seventy-seven patients who underwent APR between 2005 and 2010 were included in the study. Urogenital function was evaluated using a standardized questionnaire and urodynamic studies. The results showed that urogenital dysfunction was prevalent in the study population, with the majority of patients experiencing symptoms such as urinary incontinence and sexual dysfunction. Urodynamic studies revealed abnormalities in bladder and sphincter function. These findings highlight the importance of preoperative counseling and postoperative management to address urogenital dysfunction and improve the quality of life for patients undergoing APR. Further research is warranted to identify strategies for preventing or managing urogenital dysfunction in this patient population.

A blood-liquid interface for prolonged extracorporeal oxygenation with excellent antithrombogenicity. This study explores a blood-liquid interface for prolonged extracorporeal oxygenation with excellent antithrombogenicity. The interface device consists of a silicone membrane with micropores, coated with a layer of thromboresistant material. In vitro experiments showed that the interface maintained its antithrombogenic properties for up to 72 hours. In vivo experiments using a canine model demonstrated effective oxygenation and prolonged survival without any signs of clot formation. Additionally, the interface device showed optimal gas exchange efficiency. These results provide promising evidence for the potential clinical application of this blood-liquid interface in extracorporeal oxygenation, offering a safe and efficient alternative for patients requiring prolonged respiratory support.

A topographical relationship between Helicobacter pylori and gastritis: quantitative assessment of Helicobacter pylori in the gastric mucosa.  A topographical relationship between the number of Helicobacter pylori in the gastric mucosa and the histological severity of gastritis was studied in 902 pairs of biopsy specimens taken from 314 patients. In this study, we aimed to assess the topographical relationship between Helicobacter pylori (H. pylori) colonization and gastric mucosal inflammation. A total of 902 pairs of biopsy specimens were obtained from 314 patients with gastritis. The number of H. pylori was quantitatively evaluated using real-time polymerase chain reaction. Histological assessment of gastritis severity was performed based on the updated Sydney classification system. We found a significant correlation between the number of H. pylori and the degree of gastritis inflammation. Higher H. pylori density was associated with increased severity of gastritis in both the antrum and corpus regions. These findings suggest that H. pylori colonization plays a crucial role in the development and progression of gastric mucosal inflammation.

Evaluation of argon laser surgery in children under 13 years of age. This study aimed to evaluate the safety and efficacy of argon laser surgery in children under 13 years of age. A total of 50 pediatric patients with various ophthalmic conditions underwent argon laser surgery under general anesthesia. The surgical outcomes and complications were assessed during a follow-up period of 6 months. The results showed that argon laser surgery was effective in treating a range of ocular pathologies, including retinopathy of prematurity, retinal tears, and intraocular tumors. The procedure was well tolerated by all patients, with no major intraoperative or postoperative adverse events reported. Visual acuity improved significantly in the majority of cases, leading to improved quality of life. These findings suggest that argon laser surgery is a safe and effective treatment option for pediatric patients under 13 years of age, providing long-lasting positive outcomes. Further studies are warranted to validate these results and explore the potential benefits in larger patient populations.

Portal vein resection with a new antithrombogenic catheter. Portal vein resection is often necessary in liver surgery, but it is associated with a high risk of thrombosis. We present a novel technique using a new antithrombogenic catheter to reduce the risk of clot formation. A total of 25 patients with portal vein involvement in hepatobiliary tumors underwent portal vein resection using the new catheter. The catheter had a heparin-coated inner surface, which prevented thrombus formation. Postoperative course was uneventful in all cases, with no evidence of portal vein thrombosis or related complications. Follow-up imaging confirmed patency of the portal vein in all patients. This new technique provides a safe and effective method for portal vein resection, reducing the risk of thrombosis and associated complications. Further studies are needed to validate these findings and compare outcomes with traditional techniques.

Pancreatic mucinous cystadenocarcinoma with pseudosarcomatous mural nodules.  A report of a case with immunohistochemical study. This report presents a case of pancreatic mucinous cystadenocarcinoma with pseudosarcomatous mural nodules in a 60-year-old woman. The tumor was discovered incidentally during evaluation for unrelated symptoms. Histological examination revealed a cystic neoplasm with epithelial lining and mural nodules composed of spindle cells. Immunohistochemical analysis showed positive staining for vimentin and smooth muscle actin, indicating mesenchymal differentiation of the nodules. This case highlights the challenging diagnosis of pseudosarcomatous mural nodules and emphasizes the importance of incorporating immunohistochemical analysis in the evaluation of pancreatic cystic neoplasms. Understanding the histological characteristics and immunophenotypic features can aid in accurate diagnosis and appropriate management of this rare variant of pancreatic cystadenocarcinoma.

Argon green (514 nm) versus krypton red (647 nm) modified grid laser photocoagulation for diffuse diabetic macular edema. This study aimed to compare the efficacy and safety of argon green (514 nm) and krypton red (647 nm) modified grid laser photocoagulation in the treatment of diffuse diabetic macular edema (DME). A total of 100 patients with DME were randomly assigned to receive either argon green or krypton red laser photocoagulation. Best-corrected visual acuity (BCVA) and central macular thickness (CMT) were measured at baseline and at 12 months after treatment initiation. The results showed that both argon green and krypton red laser photocoagulation led to a significant improvement in BCVA and reduction in CMT. However, there was no statistically significant difference between the two treatment groups in terms of BCVA improvement or CMT reduction. Additionally, the incidence of adverse events was similar between the two groups. These findings suggest that both argon green and krypton red laser photocoagulation are effective and safe treatment options for diffuse DME.

The febrile alcoholic in the emergency department. Febrile alcoholics presenting to the emergency department pose a diagnostic challenge due to overlapping clinical manifestations of alcohol withdrawal and infectious causes. This study aims to characterize the clinical features, laboratory findings, and outcomes of febrile alcoholic patients in the emergency department setting. A retrospective analysis of medical records identified 100 febrile alcoholic patients admitted over a one-year period. The most common presenting symptoms were fever, altered mental status, and tachycardia. Laboratory investigations revealed elevated white blood cell count, abnormal liver function tests, and positive blood cultures in a subset of patients. The majority of patients were diagnosed with infectious causes, including pneumonia and urinary tract infections, while a smaller proportion had alcohol withdrawal syndrome or other non-infectious causes. Understanding the clinical profile of febrile alcoholic patients can aid clinicians in prompt diagnosis and appropriate management in the emergency department.

Effect of felbamate on plasma levels of carbamazepine and its metabolites.  Felbamate (FBM) is a novel antiepileptic drug (AED) currently undergoing clinical evaluation in the United States. This study aimed to investigate the effect of felbamate (FBM) on plasma levels of carbamazepine (CBZ) and its metabolites in patients with epilepsy. A total of 40 patients on stable CBZ treatment were enrolled in the study, and FBM was added as adjunctive therapy. Plasma levels of CBZ, carbamazepine-10,11-epoxide (CBZ-E), and carbamazepine-10,11-diol (CBZ-D) were measured before and 1, 2, and 4 weeks after FBM initiation. The results showed that FBM significantly increased the plasma levels of CBZ and CBZ-E, while it had no significant effect on CBZ-D levels. The magnitude of the increase in CBZ and CBZ-E levels was greater in patients receiving higher doses of FBM. The findings suggest that FBM may alter the metabolism of CBZ, leading to increased plasma levels of CBZ and its active metabolite CBZ-E. Further studies are needed to investigate the clinical implications of these interactions.

Cortical tremor: a variant of cortical reflex myoclonus. Cortical tremor, a variant of cortical reflex myoclonus, is characterized by involuntary rhythmic muscle contractions originating from the cerebral cortex. We present a case series of 10 patients diagnosed with cortical tremor, all of whom exhibited similar clinical and electrophysiological features. The tremor was predominantly in the upper limbs, with a frequency of 2-4 Hz. It was induced by specific triggers such as action or intention to move and improved with distraction or relaxation. Electromyography showed bursts of muscle activity with a cortical origin. Imaging studies revealed no structural abnormalities in the brain. Treatment with antiepileptic drugs or botulinum toxin injections provided partial symptomatic relief in some patients. Cortical tremor is a distinct entity within the spectrum of cortical reflex myoclonus and should be considered in patients presenting with this type of tremor.

Angioedema from angiotensin converting enzyme inhibitors: a cause of upper airway obstruction. Angiotensin converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors are commonly used medications for the treatment of hypertension. However, angioedema, a rare side effect of ACE inhibitors, can lead to potentially life-threatening upper airway obstruction. We present a case series of four patients who developed angioedema resulting in upper airway edema and obstruction requiring emergent intervention. All patients had a history of ACE inhibitor use and developed symptoms within hours to days after initiation or dose escalation. Prompt recognition and immediate treatment with airway management and cessation of the ACE inhibitor were crucial for successful outcomes. Clinicians should be aware of this potential complication when prescribing or escalating doses of ACE inhibitors and promptly address symptoms to prevent life-threatening complications.

Transbronchial biopsies in children after heart-lung transplantation.  Sixty transbronchial biopsies have been performed in eight children after heart-lung transplantation. We conducted a study to assess the utility of transbronchial biopsies in children who underwent heart-lung transplantation. A total of eight children were included in this study, and 60 transbronchial biopsies were performed on them. The objective of these biopsies was to evaluate the presence of rejection or other pulmonary complications in these patients. We analyzed the biopsy samples for histological evidence of rejection, infection, or other pathological changes. Out of the 60 biopsies, 15 showed evidence of rejection, while 10 had evidence of infection. Other complications such as bronchiolitis obliterans and lymphocytic bronchiolitis were observed in a small subset of patients. Our findings suggest that transbronchial biopsies are a valuable tool in the post-transplantation monitoring of children who have undergone heart-lung transplantation, allowing for early detection of rejection and prompt intervention.

Optimal interpretation of the supine exercise electrocardiogram in patients with right bundle branch block. In patients with right bundle branch block (RBBB), interpreting the supine exercise electrocardiogram (ECG) can pose challenges due to overlapping features. This study aimed to determine the optimal interpretation strategy for the supine exercise ECG in patients with RBBB. A retrospective analysis was conducted on 100 patients with RBBB who underwent supine exercise testing. Four different interpretation strategies were compared: using only exercise criteria, using only supine criteria, using combined exercise and supine criteria, and using a combination of exercise and supine criteria with specific RBBB interpretation rules. The results showed that using a combination of exercise and supine criteria with specific RBBB interpretation rules yielded the highest sensitivity and specificity in detecting ischemic ST-segment changes and exercise-induced arrhythmias. This suggests that incorporating specific RBBB interpretation rules along with exercise and supine criteria can optimize the interpretation of the supine exercise ECG in patients with RBBB, improving diagnostic accuracy and clinical decision-making.

Use of a knee-brace for control of tibial translation and rotation. The use of a knee brace for control of tibial translation and rotation is a common treatment modality for knee instability and ligament injuries. The knee brace provides external support and stabilization to the affected knee joint by restricting excessive movement. It is particularly effective in cases of anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) injuries, where tibial translation and rotation are significant contributors to knee instability. The knee brace helps to reduce pain, prevent further damage, and promote healing by providing stability during activities of daily living and sports. Different types of knee braces, including prophylactic, functional, and rehabilitative braces, can be used based on the specific needs of the patient. Proper selection and fitting of the brace, along with patient education and rehabilitation, are essential for optimal outcomes.

Limitation of transcatheter arterial chemoembolization using iodized oil for small hepatocellular carcinoma. Transcatheter arterial chemoembolization (TACE) using iodized oil is a commonly used treatment for small hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC). However, its effectiveness is limited in certain cases. This study aims to evaluate the limitations of TACE using iodized oil for small HCC. A retrospective analysis was conducted on 50 patients with small HCC who underwent TACE using iodized oil. The overall response rate was 66%, with a complete response rate of 40% and a partial response rate of 26%. The main limitation of this treatment was the high rate of tumor recurrence, which was observed in 56% of patients after a median follow-up of 12 months. Other limitations included complications such as liver abscess and liver failure. Alternative or complementary treatments should be considered to improve outcomes for patients with small HCC.

Left ventricular diastolic dysfunction presenting as ascites: the importance of clinically assessing central venous pressure. A 55-year-old man presented with ascites, initially thought to be due to liver cirrhosis. However, further evaluation revealed left ventricular diastolic dysfunction as the underlying cause. This case highlights the importance of centrally assessing venous pressure in patients presenting with ascites, as it can aid in identifying cardiac etiologies. Delayed recognition of this condition may lead to unnecessary investigations and delays in appropriate management. Therefore, clinicians should consider diastolic dysfunction as a potential cause of ascites, particularly in patients with risk factors such as hypertension or diabetes. Prompt identification and treatment of cardiac dysfunction can improve patient outcomes and prevent unnecessary interventions.

Cutaneous manifestations of multiple myeloma. Cutaneous manifestations, although rare, can occur in patients with multiple myeloma (MM). This study aimed to analyze the prevalence and characteristics of cutaneous involvement in MM patients. A total of 38 MM patients with skin lesions were included in the study. The most common cutaneous manifestations observed were plasmacytomas, followed by purpura and nodules. Skin involvement was more frequently observed in patients with advanced-stage disease and high International Staging System scores. Immunohistochemical analysis revealed a predominance of CD138+ plasma cells in skin lesions. The presence of cutaneous manifestations was associated with a shorter overall survival. In conclusion, cutaneous involvement in MM patients is an indicator of advanced disease and poor prognosis.

Dietary management of acute childhood diarrhea: optimal timing of feeding and appropriate use of milks and mixed diets. This study aimed to evaluate the optimal timing of feeding and appropriate use of milks and mixed diets in the dietary management of acute childhood diarrhea. A total of 100 children with acute diarrhea were randomly assigned to receive early feeding (within 6 hours of admission) or delayed feeding (after 24 hours of admission). The primary outcome measure was the duration of diarrhea. Secondary outcome measures included stool consistency, weight gain, and nutritional status. Results showed that early feeding was associated with a shorter duration of diarrhea (p < 0.01) and improved stool consistency (p < 0.05) compared to delayed feeding. There was no difference observed in weight gain or nutritional status between the two groups. Moreover, the use of milks and mixed diets was found to be safe and effective in promoting recovery from acute childhood diarrhea.

Autoimmune enteropathy and colitis: is there a generalised autoimmune gut disorder? Children with protracted diarrhoea, circulating enterocyte autoantibodies, and an enteropathy showing features of inappropriate HLA molecule expression on the jejunal crypt epithelium, often present with persistent blood and mucus in their stools. This study aims to investigate the potential association between autoimmune enteropathy and colitis, suggesting the existence of a generalized autoimmune gut disorder. Children suffering from protracted diarrhoea, along with the presence of circulating enterocyte autoantibodies, exhibit an enteropathy characterized by abnormal expression of HLA molecules on the jejunal crypt epithelium. These children commonly experience persistent blood and mucus in their stools. The study provides evidence of a possible link between autoimmune enteropathy and colitis, suggesting that they may share a common autoimmune mechanism. Further research is warranted to elucidate the underlying pathophysiology and explore potential targeted therapeutic interventions for this proposed generalized autoimmune gut disorder.

Renal effects of cyclosporine. Cyclosporine is a widely used immunosuppressant drug in organ transplantation. Although its main action is on the immune system, it can also have significant effects on the kidneys. This abstract reviews the renal effects of cyclosporine. Cyclosporine can cause acute nephrotoxicity, leading to reversible decreases in glomerular filtration rate and increases in serum creatinine levels. It can also lead to chronic nephropathy, characterized by interstitial fibrosis, tubular atrophy, and progressive renal dysfunction. Cyclosporine-induced hypertension and electrolyte disturbances, such as hypomagnesemia and hyperkalemia, are also commonly observed. Regular monitoring of renal function and blood pressure is essential in patients receiving cyclosporine therapy to prevent or manage these renal complications.

Indications of the carbon dioxide laser in tracheobronchial pathology of the infant and young child: 14 cases.  Fourteen children aged between 6 months and 7 years (mean age = 3. This study aimed to evaluate the indications of carbon dioxide laser in tracheobronchial pathology in infants and young children. Fourteen patients, with an average age of 3.6 years, were included in the study. Individuals presented with various tracheobronchial pathologies, including subglottic stenosis, tracheomalacia, obstructive lesions, and tracheal web. Carbon dioxide laser treatment was performed successfully in all cases, with no major complications reported. The results showed improvement in symptoms such as dyspnea, stridor, and recurrent respiratory infections. In conclusion, the carbon dioxide laser was found to be an effective and safe treatment option for tracheobronchial pathology in infants and young children. Further studies with larger sample sizes are warranted to validate these findings.

Ciliary motility in two patients with yellow nail syndrome and recurrent sinopulmonary infections. Yellow nail syndrome (YNS) is a rare disorder characterized by yellow nails, lymphedema, and respiratory manifestations. Ciliary dysfunction has been implicated in the pathogenesis of YNS. We present two cases of patients with YNS who developed recurrent sinopulmonary infections and were found to have abnormal ciliary motility on electron microscopy. Both patients had chronic sinusitis, bronchiectasis, and a history of recurrent pneumonia. Ciliary motility studies showed reduced beat frequency and coordination. Genetic testing for primary ciliary dyskinesia (PCD) was negative. Treatment with long-term macrolide antibiotics led to clinical improvement in both cases. Our findings suggest that ciliary dysfunction may contribute to the recurrent infections seen in patients with YNS and that macrolide antibiotics may be an effective treatment option for these patients.

Interaction of sodium sensitivity and stress in young adults.  The interaction of sodium sensitivity and stress-induced cardiovascular reactivity was studied in white and black young adults aged 18-23 years. This study investigated the interaction between sodium sensitivity and stress-induced cardiovascular reactivity in young adults. The cohort included white and black individuals aged 18-23 years. Sodium sensitivity was assessed through dietary manipulation and measurement of blood pressure response. Stress-induced cardiovascular reactivity was evaluated using laboratory stress tasks. Results showed that both sodium sensitivity and stress contributed to increased blood pressure response among the participants. However, the interaction between sodium sensitivity and stress was different among white and black individuals. White participants with high sodium sensitivity exhibited greater cardiovascular reactivity during stress compared to those with low sodium sensitivity. In contrast, black participants showed no significant difference in cardiovascular reactivity based on sodium sensitivity. These findings highlight the complex interplay between sodium sensitivity, stress, and cardiovascular health in young adults.

Familial trigeminal neuralgia and Charcot-Marie-Tooth neuropathy. Familial trigeminal neuralgia and Charcot-Marie-Tooth neuropathy are both hereditary neurological disorders that can cause significant pain and dysfunction. Trigeminal neuralgia is characterized by sudden, severe facial pain, often triggered by simple activities such as talking or eating. Charcot-Marie-Tooth neuropathy affects the peripheral nerves, leading to muscle weakness and atrophy in the limbs. Despite their distinct clinical presentations, recent studies have suggested a possible link between these two conditions. We present a case study of a patient with a family history of Charcot-Marie-Tooth neuropathy who developed symptoms of trigeminal neuralgia later in life. Genetic testing revealed a mutation in the same gene associated with their familial neuropathy, suggesting a shared genetic etiology. This case highlights the importance of considering underlying genetic factors in patients with familial trigeminal neuralgia and Charcot-Marie-Tooth neuropathy, and the potential for future research to uncover common mechanisms underlying these conditions.

Clinical significance of intratesticular arterial anatomy. Understanding the intratesticular arterial anatomy is crucial for diagnosing and treating male infertility. In a study of 100 patients, the correlation between intratesticular arterial anatomy and testicular histology was examined. It was found that certain abnormalities in arterial blood supply were associated with specific histopathological patterns in the testicular tissues. These aberrations included decreased blood flow, branching anomalies, and the presence of angiomatous patterns. Additionally, it was observed that patients with abnormal arterial anatomy had a higher prevalence of impaired spermatogenesis and testicular atrophy. These findings highlight the clinical significance of evaluating intratesticular arterial anatomy in the assessment of male infertility. By identifying and addressing vascular abnormalities, clinicians can potentially improve fertility outcomes through targeted interventions such as angioplasty or embolization. Further research is warranted to explore the therapeutic implications of managing intratesticular arterial anomalies.

Impact of active immunisation against enteritis necroticans in Papua New Guinea. This study aimed to evaluate the impact of active immunisation against enteritis necroticans in Papua New Guinea. A total of 10,532 individuals from high-risk areas were included in the study. The incidence of enteritis necroticans decreased from 9.2 cases per 100,000 population to 1.4 cases per 100,000 population after the implementation of active immunization. The vaccine coverage among the target population was 82%. The most common adverse events following immunization were mild and transient. The overall effectiveness of the vaccine was found to be 85%. This study demonstrates the significant impact of active immunization on the reduction of enteritis necroticans cases in Papua New Guinea. Further efforts should be made to increase vaccine coverage and ensure sustained protection against this life-threatening disease.

Increased MEPP frequency as an early sign of experimental immune-mediated motoneuron disease. Immune-mediated motoneuron disease (IMMD) is a progressive neurodegenerative disorder characterized by motoneuron dysfunction and muscle weakness. Early detection of IMMD is crucial for timely intervention and improved patient outcomes. This study aimed to assess the potential of measuring miniature endplate potential (MEPP) frequency as an early diagnostic marker of IMMD. Using an experimental mouse model, we found that MEPP frequency was significantly increased in affected mice compared to controls. This increase was observed as early as 4 weeks post-induction, preceding the onset of clinical symptoms. Furthermore, MEPP frequency correlated with disease severity, suggesting its potential as a prognostic indicator. These findings highlight the utility of MEPP frequency measurement as a non-invasive and early diagnostic tool for IMMD. Further research is warranted to validate these findings in human patients and explore the underlying mechanisms driving the observed changes in MEPP frequency. Early detection of IMMD may enable timely intervention and improved management strategies for this debilitating condition.

Definitive mandibular replacement using reconstruction plates.  Mandibular defects following radical cancer surgery continue to provide challenges to head and neck surgeons. Mandibular defects resulting from radical cancer surgery pose significant difficulties for head and neck surgeons. This study focuses on the use of reconstruction plates for definitive mandibular replacement. A comprehensive review of the literature supports the effectiveness of reconstruction plates in restoring mandibular function and facial symmetry. Preoperative planning, accurate placement, and appropriate fixation techniques are crucial for successful outcomes. The selection of the appropriate reconstructive material is also important, considering factors such as patient age, bone quality, and defect size. Various techniques for shaping and contouring the reconstruction plates are described, including computer-aided design and three-dimensional printing. Complications associated with reconstruction plates, such as plate exposure and infection, are discussed, and strategies to minimize these complications are suggested. The results of this study demonstrate that reconstruction plates offer a reliable and durable solution for mandibular replacement, promoting improved quality of life and esthetic outcomes for patients with mandibular defects. Further research and advancements in technology are expected to continue enhancing the efficacy and application of reconstruction plates in mandibular reconstruction.

Auras and subclinical seizures: characteristics and prognostic significance. Auras and subclinical seizures are neurological phenomena that have been studied for their potential prognostic significance. Auras are subjective sensory experiences that precede epileptic seizures, while subclinical seizures are epileptic activity that does not result in overt clinical manifestations. This review aims to summarize the characteristics and prognostic significance of auras and subclinical seizures in epilepsy patients. Auras can manifest as a wide range of sensory symptoms, such as visual, auditory, olfactory, and somatosensory disturbances. They provide useful insights into the localization of epileptic foci and may predict the occurrence of subsequent clinical seizures. Subclinical seizures, identified through electroencephalography (EEG) monitoring, have also been found to have prognostic significance. Patients with frequent subclinical seizures are at higher risk of developing drug-resistant epilepsy and cognitive decline. Recognizing and monitoring auras and subclinical seizures can aid in individualizing treatment strategies, optimizing patient care, and improving long-term outcomes for epilepsy patients. Further research is needed to elucidate the mechanisms underlying these phenomena and explore their potential therapeutic implications.

Auditory-evoked responses in benign intracranial hypertension syndrome. Benign intracranial hypertension syndrome (BIH) is a condition characterized by elevated intracranial pressure without any apparent cause. This study aimed to investigate auditory-evoked responses (AER) in patients with BIH. A total of 25 patients diagnosed with BIH and 25 healthy controls were included in the study. AERs were recorded using electroencephalography (EEG) during auditory stimulation. Results showed significantly delayed latencies and reduced amplitudes of AER components in the BIH group compared to the control group. These alterations were particularly evident in the later components of AER, suggesting dysfunction in higher-level auditory processing. These findings provide insight into the underlying pathophysiology of BIH and may contribute to the development of objective diagnostic and monitoring tools for this condition. Further research is needed to elucidate the exact mechanisms involved and potential therapeutic implications.

Results of treatment of displaced patellar fractures by partial patellectomy. Displaced patellar fractures are commonly treated by open reduction and internal fixation techniques. However, in some cases, partial patellectomy may be performed as an alternative treatment option. This study aimed to evaluate the outcomes of patients undergoing partial patellectomy for displaced patellar fractures.

A retrospective analysis was conducted on patients who underwent partial patellectomy for displaced patellar fractures between 2010 and 2018. Clinical and radiographic data were collected and analyzed.

A total of 45 patients were included in the study. The mean age of the patients was 52 years, with a male predominance. The most common mechanism of injury was a direct fall onto the knee. Postoperatively, all patients underwent a standardized rehabilitation protocol.

At a mean follow-up of 24 months, satisfactory clinical outcomes were observed in 80% of the patients. However, radiographic evaluation showed moderate to severe degenerative changes in the patellofemoral joint in 65% of the cases. Complications, such as hardware failure and wound infection, were observed in 15% of the patients.

In conclusion, partial patellectomy for displaced patellar fractures can lead to satisfactory clinical outcomes in the majority of cases. However, caution should be exercised regarding the potential for subsequent degenerative changes in the patellofemoral joint.

Prolonged confusion following convulsions due to generalized nonconvulsive status epilepticus.  Among patients with a prolonged confusional state after convulsive seizure, we diagnosed 8 cases as generalized nonconvulsive status epilepticus. We report on 8 cases of patients who experienced prolonged confusion following convulsions, which were diagnosed as generalized nonconvulsive status epilepticus. These patients presented with altered mental status and prolonged confusion after a convulsive seizure. Electroencephalogram (EEG) monitoring revealed continuous epileptiform discharges in all cases. The average duration of the nonconvulsive status epilepticus was 36 hours. Treatment with antiseizure medications resulted in resolution of the confusion in all cases. These findings highlight the importance of considering generalized nonconvulsive status epilepticus as a potential cause of prolonged confusion following convulsions. Prompt recognition and treatment of this condition is crucial to prevent long-term cognitive impairment and improve patient outcomes. Further studies are needed to better understand the pathophysiology and optimal management of generalized nonconvulsive status epilepticus.

Clinical and manometric aspects of diffuse esophageal spasm in a cohort of subjects evaluated for dysphagia and/or chest pain. This study aimed to evaluate the clinical and manometric aspects of diffuse esophageal spasm (DES) in a cohort of subjects with dysphagia and/or chest pain. A total of [number] subjects were included in the study. Clinical data, including symptoms, duration, and associated conditions, were collected from all participants. Manometric studies were performed to assess the esophageal motility. The results showed that [percentage] of subjects with dysphagia and/or chest pain had DES. The most common symptoms reported were [symptoms], and the duration of symptoms ranged from [range]. Manometric studies revealed abnormal esophageal motility patterns consistent with DES in all DES-positive subjects. In conclusion, DES is a common condition in subjects presenting with dysphagia and/or chest pain. Further research is needed to better understand the underlying mechanisms and develop effective treatment strategies for DES.

Portal vein resection with a new antithrombogenic catheter. Portal vein resection is a complex surgical procedure commonly performed in hepatobiliary surgery. However, one of the major challenges in this procedure is the risk of postoperative thrombosis, which can lead to severe complications. In this study, we present a new antithrombogenic catheter designed specifically for portal vein resection. The catheter utilizes a novel coating material that prevents the formation of blood clots, reducing the risk of postoperative thrombosis. A total of 50 patients undergoing portal vein resection were included in this study. The outcomes, including the occurrence of postoperative thrombosis, were compared with a control group of patients who underwent portal vein resection without the new catheter. Our results showed a significant reduction in postoperative thrombosis in the study group compared to the control group. The new antithrombogenic catheter presents a promising approach to improve the safety and outcomes of portal vein resection surgery. Further studies are warranted to validate these findings and assess long-term durability.

T cell subsets (Tc, Th, Ts, Tsi) and IL2 receptor-bearing cells in peripheral blood of patients in the acute phase of alcoholic hepatitis. In this study, T cell subsets and IL2 receptor-bearing cells were analyzed in the peripheral blood of patients in the acute phase of alcoholic hepatitis. Thirty patients diagnosed with alcoholic hepatitis were included in the study. Tc, Th, Ts, and Tsi subsets were assessed by flow cytometry, while IL2 receptor-bearing cells were measured by ELISA. The results showed a significant decrease in the proportion of Tc and Th subsets, as well as an increase in Tsi subset in patients compared to healthy controls. Additionally, IL2 receptor levels were significantly higher in patients with alcoholic hepatitis. These findings suggest an imbalance in T cell subsets and increased IL2 receptor expression in the acute phase of alcoholic hepatitis. Further studies are needed to explore the clinical implications of these alterations in immune response.

Biology of basal cell carcinoma (Part I). Basal cell carcinoma (BCC) is the most common type of skin cancer, predominantly affecting individuals with fair skin. This review article emphasizes the cellular and molecular biology underlying BCC development. BCC arises from basal cells in the epidermis and adnexal structures. Genetic alterations, including mutations in the hedgehog signaling pathway genes and tumor suppressor genes, such as TP53 and PTCH1, play a crucial role in BCC pathogenesis. Environmental factors, ultraviolet radiation, and immunosuppression contribute to BCC development. Dysregulation of cell proliferation, cell cycle control, apoptosis, and DNA repair mechanisms also contribute to BCC tumorigenesis. Understanding the biology of BCC can aid in the development of targeted therapies for this prevalent and often recurrent skin cancer.

Ultrasonography and magnetic resonance imaging in Leigh disease. Leigh disease is a rare inherited disorder characterized by progressive neurological deterioration. This study aimed to evaluate the utility of ultrasonography (US) and magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) in the diagnosis of Leigh disease. US and MRI findings were compared in a cohort of patients with confirmed Leigh disease. US showed characteristic findings such as bilateral symmetric basal ganglia lesions and thalamic abnormality in most patients. MRI demonstrated similar findings, but was more sensitive in detecting additional abnormalities in the brainstem and cerebellum. US was found to be a valuable initial screening tool for Leigh disease, while MRI provided a more comprehensive assessment of the extent and distribution of brain abnormalities in these patients.

Subtrochanteric fractures treated with interlocking nailing.  In a prospective study of 31 subtrochanteric fractures treated with Grosse-Kempf interlocking nails with a followup period of at least 1 year, there was a 87. 1% (27/31) union rate, and a union period of 4. This prospective study aimed to evaluate the outcome of interlocking nailing for the treatment of subtrochanteric fractures. A total of 31 patients with subtrochanteric fractures were included in the study, and they were followed up for at least 1 year. The union rate was found to be 87.1% (27/31), indicating a successful outcome. The average union period was 4.6 months. These results highlight that interlocking nailing is an effective treatment option for subtrochanteric fractures, leading to a high rate of fracture union. Further research in larger patient populations with longer follow-up periods would be beneficial to confirm these findings.

Isolated calf venous thrombosis: diagnosis with compression US. Compression ultrasound (US) is an effective method for diagnosing isolated calf venous thrombosis (LCVT), a condition that can lead to potentially life-threatening deep vein thrombosis. In this study, 123 patients with suspected LCVT underwent compression US for diagnosis. The sensitivity and specificity of compression US were calculated using venography as the reference standard. The results showed that compression US had a sensitivity of 87% and a specificity of 97% for detecting LCVT. The positive predictive value and negative predictive value were 92% and 95%, respectively. Overall, compression US proved to be a reliable and accurate tool for diagnosing isolated calf venous thrombosis. It can be recommended as the initial imaging modality for patients with suspected LCVT, allowing for timely and appropriate management of this condition.

Life-threatening complications during anaesthesia in a patient with a ventriculo-atrial shunt and pulmonary hypertension [published erratum appears in Anaesthesia 1991 Mar;46(3):241] A 6-year-old patient with hydrocephalus who underwent revision of a ventriculo-atrial shunt is described. This case report describes a 6-year-old patient with hydrocephalus who developed life-threatening complications during anesthesia for ventriculo-atrial shunt revision. The patient had a pre-existing ventriculo-atrial shunt and pulmonary hypertension. The anesthesia management involved careful hemodynamic monitoring and the use of specific drugs to maintain stable blood pressure. Despite the challenges posed by the patient's condition, the surgery was successfully completed without any major complications. This case highlights the importance of tailored anesthesia management in patients with complex cardiac and pulmonary conditions undergoing neurosurgical procedures.

Resting metabolic rate and energy balance in amenorrheic and eumenorrheic runners. This study aimed to investigate the differences in resting metabolic rate (RMR) and energy balance between amenorrheic and eumenorrheic runners. A total of 24 female runners, including 12 amenorrheic and 12 eumenorrheic, were recruited for the study. RMR was measured using indirect calorimetry, and energy intake and expenditure were assessed through food diaries and activity monitors, respectively. The results showed that amenorrheic runners had a significantly lower RMR compared to eumenorrheic runners after adjusting for lean body mass. Furthermore, amenorrheic runners had a significantly higher energy intake and expenditure compared to eumenorrheic runners. Despite this, amenorrheic runners had a negative energy balance, indicating that they were not meeting their energy needs. These findings suggest that amenorrheic runners may have a reduced RMR and struggle to maintain energy balance, potentially impacting their overall health and athletic performance. Further research is needed to better understand the mechanisms underlying these differences and develop appropriate interventions.

Periurethral colonic-type polyp simulating urethral caruncle. We present a case of a periurethral colonic-type polyp that initially resembled a urethral caruncle. A 54-year-old female presented with a painful and rapidly growing mass in the urethral meatus. Clinical examination suggested a urethral caruncle, but biopsy revealed a colonic-type polyp with no evidence of malignancy. In order to completely remove the lesion and minimize recurrence, a transurethral resection was performed. Histopathological examination confirmed the diagnosis of a periurethral colonic-type polyp. This case highlights the importance of considering unusual etiologies when evaluating urethral masses and the necessity of histopathological examination for accurate diagnosis and appropriate management. Awareness of this rare entity is crucial to avoid misdiagnosis and unnecessary treatment.

Achieving pH control in the critically ill patient: the role of continuous infusion of H2-receptor antagonists. Maintaining pH control in critically ill patients is crucial for optimal outcomes. This study investigated the efficacy of continuous infusion of H2-receptor antagonists in achieving pH control in this population. A retrospective analysis was conducted on 150 patients admitted to the intensive care unit who received continuous infusion of H2-receptor antagonists for pH control. The majority of patients (85%) achieved pH control within 24 hours of initiating the infusion. Additionally, there was a significant improvement in pH levels over time. Continuous infusion of H2-receptor antagonists appears to be an effective strategy for achieving and maintaining pH control in critically ill patients.

Fatal pulmonary venoocclusive disease secondary to a generalized venulopathy: a new syndrome presenting with facial swelling and pericardial tamponade. We present a case of a previously unreported syndrome characterized by fatal pulmonary venoocclusive disease and generalized venulopathy. The patient initially presented with facial swelling, which was followed by the development of pericardial tamponade. Despite aggressive medical management and surgical intervention, the patient's condition rapidly deteriorated, and they ultimately succumbed to respiratory failure. Histological analysis revealed occlusion of pulmonary venules and systemic venulopathy. This case highlights the importance of recognizing this syndrome, as early diagnosis and intervention may improve outcomes in patients presenting with facial swelling and pericardial tamponade.

Complications in hyperthermia treatment of benign prostatic hyperplasia.  Of 435 patients treated with local hyperthermia to the prostate 27 had 29 complications, for an over-all complication rate of 6. OBJECTIVES: Hyperthermia treatment is commonly used for benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) but can be associated with complications. This study aimed to evaluate the complication rate of hyperthermia treatment in patients with BPH. RESEARCH DESIGN AND METHODS: A total of 435 patients with BPH underwent local hyperthermia treatment to the prostate. The occurrence of complications was assessed, and the overall complication rate was calculated. RESULTS: Out of the 435 patients, 27 patients experienced a total of 29 complications, resulting in an overall complication rate of 6%. The most common complications included urinary retention, urinary tract infection, and hematuria. CONCLUSIONS: This study highlights the importance of considering potential complications associated with hyperthermia treatment for BPH. Further research is needed to improve patient selection and optimize the safety profile of this procedure.

Leukemias of indeterminant lineage. Leukemias of indeterminate lineage are a group of hematological malignancies characterized by the inability to identify the specific cell lineage from which the cancer cells originate. This poses significant challenges for diagnosis and treatment, as the classification of these leukemias relies on the identification of cell lineage markers. In this study, we analyzed a cohort of patients with leukemias of indeterminate lineage and found diverse immunophenotypic profiles, suggesting a heterogeneous nature of these malignancies. Genomic analysis revealed recurrent genetic alterations, including chromosomal translocations and gene mutations, which may contribute to the pathogenesis of these leukemias. Further characterization and understanding of the molecular mechanisms underlying this group of leukemias will aid in the development of targeted therapies for improved patient management.

Thyrotoxicosis induced by topical iodine application. Thyrotoxicosis, characterized by elevated levels of thyroid hormones, can rarely be induced by topical iodine application. We present a case of a 47-year-old female who developed thyrotoxicosis following the application of iodinated antiseptic solution to a skin wound. Laboratory testing revealed increased levels of free thyroxine and suppressed thyroid-stimulating hormone, consistent with thyrotoxicosis. The patient had no previous history of thyroid dysfunction or exposure to iodine-containing medications. Thyrotoxicosis resolved after discontinuation of the iodine application and initiation of beta-blocker therapy. This case highlights the importance of considering topical iodine as a potential cause of thyrotoxicosis, particularly in patients without other risk factors for thyroid dysfunction.

Eosinophilia-myalgia syndrome associated with L-tryptophan ingestion. Eosinophilia-myalgia syndrome (EMS) is a rare condition associated with the ingestion of L-tryptophan, an amino acid supplement commonly used for sleep and mood enhancement. We report a case of a 45-year-old woman who presented with several weeks of generalized body pain, muscle weakness, and skin rash. Laboratory tests revealed elevated eosinophil count and muscle enzyme levels, consistent with EMS. The patient reported a history of L-tryptophan use for insomnia. Further investigation confirmed the diagnosis, as the symptoms resolved upon discontinuation of L-tryptophan. EMS is a potentially life-threatening condition characterized by eosinophilia, myalgia, skin involvement, and multiorgan dysfunction. Prompt diagnosis and cessation of L-tryptophan use are crucial for management. Awareness among healthcare providers and patients regarding the association between EMS and L-tryptophan ingestion is important in preventing unnecessary morbidity and mortality.

Growth velocity before sudden infant death. In this study, we investigated the growth velocity before sudden infant death (SID) in a cohort of infants. A total of 103 infants who experienced SID were included in the analysis. Growth parameters, including weight, length, and head circumference, were measured at multiple time points during infancy. The growth velocity, defined as the change in growth parameters over time, was calculated using a linear regression model. Our results showed that infants who later experienced SID had a significantly slower growth velocity compared to infants who did not experience SID. Specifically, a decrease in weight and length growth velocity was observed starting from around 4 months of age. These findings suggest that impaired growth velocity may be a potential marker for increased risk of SID and may have implications for monitoring and intervention strategies in infants. Further research is needed to elucidate the underlying mechanisms linking growth velocity and SID.

Palliation of malignant esophageal obstruction. Malignant esophageal obstruction is a debilitating condition that often leads to significant dysphagia and poor quality of life in patients with advanced cancer. The management of this condition focuses on providing palliation and improving swallowing function. Currently, there are various treatment options available, including endoscopic dilatation, stent placement, laser therapy, and surgical palliation. Each approach has its advantages and limitations, and the choice of treatment depends on the patient's overall health status and the palliative goals. Endoscopic approaches, such as dilatation or stent placement, are minimally invasive and can provide immediate relief of dysphagia. Laser therapy can also be effective in reducing tumor size and improving esophageal patency. Surgical options, such as bypass procedures or esophageal diversion, may be considered in selected cases. A multidisciplinary approach, involving gastroenterologists, surgeons, and palliative care specialists, is crucial to ensure optimal management and improve the quality of life for patients with malignant esophageal obstruction.

How long can a coronary reperfusion catheter be placed in acute coronary occlusion following failed transluminal coronary angioplasty? A case report. This case report presents the use of a coronary reperfusion catheter in a patient with acute coronary occlusion following failed transluminal coronary angioplasty (TCA). After unsuccessful attempts to restore blood flow using TCA, a coronary reperfusion catheter was inserted to maintain revascularization. The catheter remained in place for an extended duration due to persistent occlusion. The patient experienced immediate relief of symptoms, and angiography confirmed successful reperfusion. This case highlights the potential benefit of using a coronary reperfusion catheter as a salvage option in cases of failed TCA. However, the optimal duration of catheter placement remains unclear, as longer periods may increase the risk of complications. Further research is needed to determine the appropriate timing and duration of catheter use in this context.

Molecular and hematologic characterization of Scottish-Irish type (epsilon gamma delta beta)zero thalassemia. Scottish-Irish type (epsilon gamma delta beta)zero thalassemia is a rare genetic disorder characterized by severe anemia and abnormal hemoglobin production. In this study, we aimed to molecularly and hematologically characterize this condition. Molecular analysis revealed a deletion of the epsilon, gamma, delta, and beta globin genes on one allele, resulting in the absence of these globin chains in the affected individuals. Hematological findings showed severe microcytic hypochromic anemia, reduced mean corpuscular volume, and elevated levels of fetal hemoglobin. These findings are consistent with the known pathophysiology of thalassemia. Further research is needed to explore potential therapeutic strategies for managing this rare form of thalassemia.

Diagnostic significance of carcinoembryonic antigen in the differential diagnosis of malignant mesothelioma. Malignant mesothelioma (MM) is a challenging disease to diagnose due to its similarity in clinical presentation with other cancers. This study aimed to determine the diagnostic significance of carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) in the differential diagnosis of MM. A total of 150 patients with suspected MM were enrolled, including 50 MM cases, 50 lung cancer cases, and 50 benign pleural disease cases. Serum CEA levels were measured and compared among the three groups. The results showed that the mean CEA level was significantly higher in the MM group compared to the benign pleural disease group (p<0.001), while no significant difference was found between the MM and lung cancer groups (p=0.086). Using a cutoff value of 5 ng/mL, the sensitivity and specificity of CEA in detecting MM were 76% and 74%, respectively. In conclusion, CEA can be a valuable biomarker for distinguishing MM from benign pleural disease, but its diagnostic sensitivity and specificity are limited in discriminating MM from lung cancer. Further investigations are warranted to identify more reliable diagnostic markers for MM.

The anatomy and physiology of nerve injury. Nerve injury can have significant effects on the anatomy and physiology of the nervous system. Understanding these effects is crucial for successful diagnosis and treatment. In this review, we discuss the various aspects of nerve injury, including the types of nerve injuries, the mechanisms of injury, and the resulting anatomical and physiological changes.

Nerve injuries can be classified into three main types: neurapraxia, axonotmesis, and neurotmesis. Neurapraxia is the mildest form of nerve injury and involves temporary conduction blockage without structural damage. Axonotmesis is a more severe form, where the axon is damaged but the connective tissue remains intact. Neurotmesis is the most severe form, involving complete nerve transection.

Following nerve injury, there are several anatomical changes that occur. These include Wallerian degeneration, where the distal axon segment degenerates, and axon sprouting, where adjacent axons grow into the denervated area. These changes can lead to the formation of neuromas, nerve entrapment, and nerve compression.

Physiologically, nerve injury can result in altered conduction velocities, decreased or absent sensory and motor function, and changes in reflexes. The degree of impairment depends on the severity and location of the injury.

In conclusion, nerve injury can have profound effects on the anatomy and physiology of the nervous system. Understanding these changes is essential for accurate diagnosis and effective management of patients with nerve injuries.

Combined laminoplasty and posterolateral fusion for spinal canal surgery in children and adolescents. Spinal canal stenosis in children and adolescents can be challenging to manage surgically. This study aims to evaluate the efficacy of combined laminoplasty and posterolateral fusion as a treatment option for this patient population. Medical records of 37 patients (mean age: 12.9 years) who underwent the procedure were retrospectively analyzed. The main indications for surgery were spinal canal stenosis due to developmental or congenital causes. Postoperatively, patients were followed for a mean duration of 34 months. Clinical outcomes were assessed using various measures, including the Japanese Orthopedic Association scale and visual analog scale for axial pain. Radiographic evaluation included measurement of fusion and spinal canal diameters. Results showed significant improvements in clinical outcomes, with a mean increase in Japanese Orthopedic Association scores from 6.4 to 12.2. Adequate fusion was achieved in all patients, with no incidence of pseudarthrosis. Additionally, postoperative spinal canal diameters were significantly increased. In conclusion, combined laminoplasty and posterolateral fusion is a safe and effective surgical option for children and adolescents with spinal canal stenosis.

Bleeding ectatic vascular lesion involving the sigmoid colon, endoscopically indistinguishable from angiodysplasia, in an 8-yr-old boy. We present a case of an 8-year-old boy with a bleeding ectatic vascular lesion involving the sigmoid colon. Endoscopically, the lesion appeared indistinguishable from angiodysplasia. The patient presented with chronic anemia and required repeated blood transfusions. Colonoscopy revealed a 3-cm vascular lesion in the sigmoid colon, which was actively bleeding. The lesion was successfully treated with endoscopic therapy using argon plasma coagulation. Histopathological examination confirmed the diagnosis of an ectatic vascular lesion. Ectatic vascular lesions are rare in children, especially in the colon. They are characterized by dilated and tortuous blood vessels in the submucosa, which can lead to chronic gastrointestinal bleeding. Endoscopic therapy, such as argon plasma coagulation, is a safe and effective treatment option for controlling bleeding in these cases. Long-term follow-up is recommended to monitor for recurrence or development of new lesions.

Pelvic lipomatosis associated with cystitis glandularis and adenocarcinoma of the bladder. We present a case of a 56-year-old male with pelvic lipomatosis, cystitis glandularis, and adenocarcinoma of the bladder. The patient initially presented with lower urinary tract symptoms and hematuria. Imaging studies revealed extensive pelvic fat deposition and bladder wall thickening. Cystoscopy confirmed the presence of adenocarcinoma. Histopathological examination of the bladder biopsy showed glandular metaplasia consistent with cystitis glandularis. The patient underwent radical cystectomy with urinary diversion. Pelvic lipomatosis is a rare condition characterized by excessive adipose tissue infiltration in the pelvis, often associated with benign or malignant urologic conditions. Its association with cystitis glandularis and adenocarcinoma of the bladder is extremely rare. Despite the challenging diagnosis and management, early detection and timely intervention led to a favorable outcome in this case. Further studies are needed to better understand the etiology and optimal management of this rare entity.

Relationship of ischemic heart disease to sudden death. Ischemic heart disease (IHD) is a leading cause of mortality worldwide, and sudden death is a common and devastating consequence. The relationship between IHD and sudden death is complex, with various factors contributing to this outcome. Atherosclerosis, a chronic inflammatory process in the coronary arteries, is the underlying pathogenesis of IHD and can lead to plaque rupture or erosion, causing acute coronary syndromes such as myocardial infarction. Sudden death often occurs as a result of fatal arrhythmias, particularly ventricular fibrillation or tachycardia, triggered by acute myocardial ischemia. Other factors, including left ventricular dysfunction, structural heart abnormalities, and genetic predisposition, further increase the risk of sudden death in patients with IHD. Understanding these interrelationships is crucial for risk stratification, prevention, and management strategies to reduce the burden of sudden death in individuals with IHD.

Possible mechanisms of abnormal norepinephrine sensitivity and reactivity of resistance vessels and the development of hypertension in spontaneously hypertensive rats. This study aimed to understand the mechanisms underlying abnormal norepinephrine sensitivity and reactivity of resistance vessels in spontaneously hypertensive rats (SHR), as well as their association with the development of hypertension. We examined the role of the sympathetic nervous system and the adrenergic receptor system in SHR. Our findings indicate that SHR exhibit increased norepinephrine sensitivity and reactivity in their resistance vessels. This abnormality may be attributed to alterations in the adrenergic receptor system, such as increased alpha-adrenergic receptor density and enhanced receptor-mediated vasoconstriction. These changes contribute to the development and maintenance of hypertension in SHR. Further investigations are needed to elucidate the precise mechanisms involved and to identify potential therapeutic targets for hypertension treatment.

Psychological stress and the fibrositis/fibromyalgia syndrome. Psychological stress has been identified as a potential trigger for the development and exacerbation of fibrositis/fibromyalgia syndrome (FMS), a chronic musculoskeletal disorder characterized by widespread pain and tenderness. This review examines the relationship between psychological stress and FMS, focusing on the underlying mechanisms and potential treatment strategies. Multiple studies have demonstrated that psychological stress can lead to alterations in stress response systems, including the hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal axis and the autonomic nervous system, in individuals with FMS.
