We analyzed medical records of 100 Fontan patients and identified 30 cases with thrombotic events post-operatively. Among these cases, 17 patients had coagulation factor abnormalities. Our results suggest that coagulation factor abnormalities, including deficiencies in antithrombin III, protein C, and protein S, may contribute to the development of thrombotic complications in Fontan patients. Further studies are needed to validate these findings and determine the optimal management strategies for preventing thrombotic events in this high-risk population.

Current status of duplex Doppler ultrasound in the examination of the abdominal vasculature. Duplex Doppler ultrasound is a valuable tool in the examination of the abdominal vasculature. This study aims to evaluate the current status of duplex Doppler ultrasound in this field. A total of 200 patients were included in the study, and the examination was performed using a high-resolution ultrasound machine equipped with a color Doppler system. The main indications for the examination were suspected arterial or venous disease, abdominal aortic aneurysm, or renal artery stenosis. The results were compared with other imaging modalities, such as computed tomography angiography or magnetic resonance angiography, and surgical findings when available. Duplex Doppler ultrasound showed excellent sensitivity and specificity in detecting arterial and venous diseases, with a diagnostic accuracy of over 90%. It was particularly useful in the evaluation of renal artery stenosis and detection of postoperative complications. However, its accuracy in evaluating small vessels and calcified plaques was limited. In conclusion, duplex Doppler ultrasound is a reliable and non-invasive imaging modality for the examination of the abdominal vasculature, providing valuable diagnostic information in various clinical scenarios.

Community lifestyle characteristics and risk of acute lymphoblastic leukaemia in children. There is evidence suggesting that community lifestyle characteristics may play a role in the development of acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) in children. This retrospective study aimed to investigate the association between community lifestyle characteristics and the risk of ALL in children. The study included 130 cases of ALL and 260 age- and sex-matched controls. Data on various community lifestyle characteristics, such as smoking rates, air pollution levels, and pesticide use, were collected. The results showed that higher smoking rates, higher levels of air pollution, and increased pesticide use were significantly associated with an increased risk of ALL in children. These findings suggest that community lifestyle characteristics may contribute to the development of ALL, highlighting the need for implementing strategies to reduce these risk factors in order to prevent the disease in children.

Mapping of the locus for X-linked cardioskeletal myopathy with neutropenia and abnormal mitochondria (Barth syndrome) to Xq28.  X-linked cardioskeletal myopathy with neutropenia and abnormal mitochondria is clinically characterized by congenital dilated cardiomyopathy, skeletal myopathy, recurrent bacterial infections, and growth retardation. Barth syndrome is a rare X-linked disorder characterized by dilated cardiomyopathy, skeletal myopathy, neutropenia, and abnormal mitochondria. This study aimed to map the disease locus responsible for Barth syndrome to a specific chromosome region. Through genetic analysis of affected families, the locus was identified as Xq28. Clinical features of Barth syndrome include early-onset dilated cardiomyopathy, muscular weakness, recurrent bacterial infections, and growth retardation. The identification of the disease locus provides valuable insights into the molecular basis of Barth syndrome and paves the way for further research to elucidate the underlying pathogenic mechanisms. This information is crucial for accurate diagnosis, genetic counseling, and potential development of targeted therapies.

Topical fibronectin and aprotinin for keratectomy wound healing in rabbits. The study aimed to investigate the effects of topical fibronectin and aprotinin on keratectomy wound healing in rabbits. Rabbits were divided into three groups: a control group, a fibronectin-treated group, and an aprotinin-treated group. A keratectomy was performed on all rabbits, and the treatment groups received either topical fibronectin or aprotinin while the control group received no treatment. The healing process was monitored by assessing the re-epithelialization rate, corneal haze, and collagen density at different time points.

The results showed that both fibronectin and aprotinin treatment significantly improved the re-epithelialization rate compared to the control group. Fibronectin treatment also resulted in a lower corneal haze score compared to the control group, indicating better transparency of the cornea. However, collagen density did not differ significantly between the groups.

In conclusion, topical fibronectin and aprotinin application showed positive effects on keratectomy wound healing in rabbits. Fibronectin improved re-epithelialization and transparency of the cornea, while aprotinin enhanced re-epithelialization. These findings suggest the potential use of fibronectin and aprotinin as therapeutic agents for promoting wound healing in corneal surgeries.

Translocation breakpoint of acute promyelocytic leukemia lies within the retinoic acid receptor alpha locus. Acute promyelocytic leukemia (APL) is a subtype of acute myeloid leukemia (AML) characterized by a unique translocation involving the retinoic acid receptor alpha (RAR伪) gene locus. This translocation results in the fusion of the RAR伪 gene with a partner gene, leading to the formation of a chimeric protein and disruption of normal hematopoietic differentiation. The precise location of the translocation breakpoint within the RAR伪 locus has been a subject of investigation. In this study, the translocation breakpoint was identified within intron 2 of the RAR伪 gene. The identification of the translocation breakpoint provides valuable insights into the molecular pathogenesis of APL and may have implications for diagnostic and therapeutic approaches. Understanding the precise molecular events underlying APL can aid in the development of targeted therapies for this aggressive form of leukemia.

Hepatocellular carcinoma with tumor thrombus extending into the right atrium: report of a successful resection with the use of cardiopulmonary bypass. We present a case of hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) with tumor thrombus extending into the right atrium, successfully resected using cardiopulmonary bypass (CPB). A 62-year-old male with a history of chronic liver disease presented with HCC accompanied by tumor thrombus extending into the right atrium. After a thorough evaluation, surgical resection using CPB was planned. The tumor thrombus was removed from the right atrium, followed by left hepatectomy, cholecystectomy, and segmentectomy of segment IVb and VIII. The patient had an uneventful postoperative course and was discharged on the 16th postoperative day. Pathological examination confirmed the presence of HCC with tumor thrombus. This case highlights the successful use of CPB in the resection of HCC with tumor thrombus extending into the right atrium, offering a potential curative treatment option for these challenging cases. Further studies are needed to establish the optimal management strategy for such cases.

Antithrombotic efficacy of continuous extradural analgesia after knee replacement.  We have studied the effect of extradural analgesia on postoperative venous thrombosis in patients undergoing knee arthroplasty. In this study, we investigated the antithrombotic efficacy of continuous extradural analgesia in patients undergoing knee arthroplasty. A total of [number] patients were included in the study and were randomly assigned to receive either continuous extradural analgesia or standard analgesic treatment. The occurrence of postoperative venous thrombosis was evaluated through regular ultrasound examinations. 

Our results showed that patients who received continuous extradural analgesia had a significantly lower incidence of postoperative venous thrombosis compared to those who received standard analgesic treatment. This suggests that continuous extradural analgesia may have a protective effect against venous thrombosis in patients undergoing knee arthroplasty. 

These findings warrant further investigation and may have implications for the management of postoperative pain and thromboembolic complications in this patient population.

Brainstem auditory evoked response and subcortical abnormalities in autism. This study aimed to investigate brainstem auditory evoked response (BAER) and subcortical abnormalities in individuals with autism. BAER assessments were conducted on 30 children with autism and 30 typically developing children. Results showed that children with autism had significantly delayed BAER peak latencies compared to typically developing children. Additionally, children with autism exhibited subcortical abnormalities, including smaller brainstem auditory pathway volume and decreased white matter integrity. These findings suggest that altered BAER responses and subcortical abnormalities are present in individuals with autism, indicating potential impairments in auditory processing and neural connectivity. Further research is needed to understand the underlying mechanisms and potential implications for improving interventions and diagnostic tools for individuals with autism.

Repeat hepatic resection for primary and metastatic carcinoma of the liver. Repeat hepatic resection is a viable treatment option for patients with primary or metastatic carcinoma of the liver. In this retrospective study, the authors analyzed the outcomes and complications associated with repeat hepatic resection in 150 patients. The median interval between the primary and repeat hepatic resections was 21.2 months. The overall survival rate at 5 years was 51.3%, and the disease-free survival rate was 35.6%. The most common postoperative complications included liver failure, wound infection, and hemorrhage. However, the authors found that the preoperative liver function, tumor characteristics, and surgical expertise significantly influenced the outcomes. Patients with adequate liver function and limited tumor burden were more likely to benefit from repeat hepatic resection. In conclusion, repeat hepatic resection can be considered a safe and effective treatment option for select patients with primary or metastatic carcinoma of the liver.

Extrahepatic metabolism of morphine occurs in humans.  The pharmacokinetics of morphine was studied in six patients in whom a radiologic localization of an insulinoma was to be performed under general anesthesia. In patients with Crohn's disease, the presence of a complex ileovaginal fistula along with obstructive uropathy can pose significant diagnostic and therapeutic challenges. This study aimed to analyze the technical considerations and review the literature related to this condition. Patients presenting with symptoms such as weight loss, malnutrition, and persistent vaginal discharge should raise suspicions of an ileogenital fistula. Preoperative evaluation of the gastrointestinal and genitourinary systems is crucial for accurate localization and identification of concomitant fistulae. Surgical intervention involves preoperative ureteral catheters, resection of diseased bowel and fistulous segments, and interposition of healthy tissue (e.g., omentum) between the bowel anastomosis and vaginal cuff. In other research, the pharmacokinetics of morphine were investigated in six patients who required radiologic localization of an insulinoma under general anesthesia. Results indicated that morphine metabolism occurs primarily through extrahepatic pathways, highlighting the need for careful consideration of dosing and potential drug interactions in such patients.

Inflammatory abdominal aortic aneurysm: an indication for the retroperitoneal approach. Inflammatory abdominal aortic aneurysm (IAAA) is a rare condition characterized by chronic perianeurysmal inflammation. Surgical repair is the standard treatment, but the approach can vary based on the degree of inflammation and involvement of vital structures. The retroperitoneal approach offers advantages, including decreased risk of contamination of the peritoneal cavity and better exposure to the aneurysm sac. In this study, we present a case series of patients with IAAA who underwent surgical repair using the retroperitoneal approach. We evaluate the feasibility and outcomes of this approach, focusing on perioperative complications, operative time, blood loss, length of hospital stay, and long-term outcomes. Our findings suggest that the retroperitoneal approach is a safe and effective option for surgical repair of IAAA, with promising outcomes and a low rate of complications.

Bilateral vocal cord teflon injection. Bilateral vocal cord teflon injection is a surgical procedure performed to treat vocal cord paralysis or vocal cord dysfunction. This study presents a case series of 15 patients who underwent bilateral vocal cord teflon injection for various underlying conditions, such as postoperative recurrent laryngeal nerve palsy or idiopathic vocal cord paralysis. The procedure involved injecting teflon into the vocal folds to improve vocal cord function and reduce dysphonia. The results showed that bilateral vocal cord teflon injection led to significant improvement in vocal cord mobility and voice quality, with all patients reporting subjective improvement in their voice symptoms. Complications were minimal, with only one case of temporary hoarseness. This study supports the use of bilateral vocal cord teflon injection as an effective and safe treatment option for vocal cord paralysis or dysfunction.

Streptococcal antibody cross-reactivity with HLA-DR4+VE B-lymphocytes. The cross-reactivity of Streptococcal antibodies with HLA-DR4+VE B-lymphocytes has been investigated to understand the potential role of streptococcal infections in autoimmune diseases associated with HLA-DR4, such as rheumatoid arthritis. The study aimed to determine if streptococcal antibodies could bind to HLA-DR4+VE B-lymphocytes and induce their activation. Results showed that streptococcal antibodies were able to bind to HLA-DR4+VE B-lymphocytes, leading to their activation, as indicated by increased expression of activation markers. These findings suggest a possible mechanism by which streptococcal infections may contribute to the development of autoimmune diseases in individuals carrying HLA-DR4. Further research is warranted to elucidate the specific pathways involved and their potential therapeutic implications.

Prostacyclin-to-thromboxane A2 ratio in arteriogenic impotence. Arteriogenic impotence is a condition characterized by an inability to achieve or maintain an erection due to inadequate blood flow to the penis. Prostacyclin (PGI2) and thromboxane A2 (TXA2) are two important substances involved in the regulation of vascular tone in the penis. A low prostacyclin-to-thromboxane A2 ratio has been implicated in endothelial dysfunction and the development of arterial insufficiency. This study aimed to investigate the prostacyclin-to-thromboxane A2 ratio in patients with arteriogenic impotence. Serum levels of PGI2 and TXA2 were measured in 50 patients with arteriogenic impotence and 50 age-matched healthy controls. The results revealed a significantly lower prostacyclin-to-thromboxane A2 ratio in the impotence group compared to the control group. This suggests that an imbalance between PGI2 and TXA2 may play a role in the pathophysiology of arteriogenic impotence, providing a potential target for therapeutic interventions.

Cerebral venography with MR.  The authors describe a two-dimensional time-of-flight magnetic resonance (MR) angiography technique to create projection venograms of the head. In this study, the authors present a novel approach for creating projection venograms of the head using a two-dimensional time-of-flight magnetic resonance (MR) angiography technique. The technique offers several advantages over traditional approaches, including improved contrast between vessels and surrounding tissues, ability to visualize venous structures not easily seen with other imaging methods, and the potential for three-dimensional reconstructions. The authors demonstrate the utility of this technique in a series of cases, showcasing its ability to accurately depict normal anatomy, as well as detect and characterize various pathological conditions such as dural sinus thrombosis and arteriovenous malformations. Overall, this technique has the potential to serve as a valuable diagnostic tool for evaluating cerebral venous pathology, guiding treatment decisions, and monitoring therapeutic interventions.

Hemodynamic effects of partial correction of chronic anemia by recombinant human erythropoietin in patients on dialysis.  Eighteen patients on chronic hemodialysis with renal anemia were treated with recombinant human erythropoietin (r-HuEPO). This study aimed to evaluate the hemodynamic effects of partial correction of chronic anemia by recombinant human erythropoietin (r-HuEPO) in patients on dialysis. Eighteen patients with renal anemia on chronic hemodialysis were included in the study. r-HuEPO was administered to achieve a target hemoglobin level of 10 g/dl. Hemodynamic parameters were assessed before and after treatment. The mean arterial pressure increased significantly from 84 卤 7 to 89 卤 8 mmHg after r-HuEPO therapy (p < 0.001). Cardiac index also showed a significant increase from 2.3 卤 0.6 to 2.9 卤 0.8 L/min/m^2 (p < 0.001). Furthermore, systemic vascular resistance decreased from 1614 卤 416 to 1317 卤 488 dyn路s/cm^5 (p < 0.001). In conclusion, partial correction of chronic anemia using r-HuEPO in dialysis patients led to significant improvements in hemodynamic parameters, including mean arterial pressure, cardiac index, and systemic vascular resistance.

Genitourinary cancer in the elderly. Genitourinary cancer is a common malignancy among elderly individuals. This study aimed to evaluate the characteristics and outcomes of elderly patients with genitourinary cancer. A retrospective analysis was conducted on 105 elderly patients (鈮65 years old) diagnosed with genitourinary cancer. The most common types of cancer were prostate cancer (55.2%) and bladder cancer (24.8%). Comorbidities were present in 68.6% of patients, with hypertension being the most common (42.9%). Treatment modalities included surgery, chemotherapy, and radiation therapy. Overall survival at 5 years was 50.9%. Factors associated with poor prognosis included advanced stage, presence of comorbidities, and higher grade tumors. These findings emphasize the importance of tailored treatment approaches for elderly patients with genitourinary cancer.

Late luteal phase dysphoric disorder in young women. This study aimed to investigate the presence of late luteal phase dysphoric disorder (LLPDD) in young women. A total of 100 participants aged 18 to 30 years were included in the study. Participants were assessed for LLPDD symptoms using the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders (DSM-5) criteria. The results showed that 20% of the participants met the criteria for LLPDD. Significant differences were found in mood symptoms, with women experiencing irritability, anxiety, and depression during the late luteal phase. Other symptoms, such as fatigue, food cravings, and sleep disturbances, were also reported. This study highlights the high prevalence of LLPDD in young women, suggesting the need for early diagnosis and appropriate management strategies.

Reference values for the Mini-Mental State Examination (MMSE) in octo- and nonagenarians The Mini-Mental State Examination (MMSE) was used in a population survey of all inhabitants of Leiden, the Netherlands, over 85 years (n = 1258). A study was conducted to establish reference values for the Mini-Mental State Examination (MMSE) in individuals aged 80 and above (n = 1258) in Leiden, the Netherlands. The mean MMSE score was found to be 23.8 with a standard deviation of 4.0. The scores decreased with increasing age, and females had slightly lower scores compared to males. The MMSE scores also showed a negative correlation with the number of medications taken. These findings suggest that the MMSE reference values should be age-specific and higher than previously reported for octo- and nonagenarians. This study provides valuable reference values for clinicians and researchers working with older adults in the Leiden population.

Olfactory neuroblastoma: clinicopathologic and immunohistochemical characterization of four representative cases. Olfactory neuroblastoma (ONB) is a rare malignant tumor arising from the olfactory epithelium. In this study, we present the clinicopathologic and immunohistochemical features of four representative cases of ONB. The patients ranged in age from 32 to 63 years, and all presented with symptoms related to nasal obstruction or epistaxis. Histologically, all cases exhibited a characteristic pattern of small round cells arranged in lobules or nests with associated rosette-like structures. Immunohistochemical staining demonstrated diffuse positivity for neuron-specific enolase, synaptophysin, and S-100 protein, while cytokeratin AE1/AE3 and CD56 showed variable staining patterns. Three cases showed positive staining for vimentin, suggesting a mesenchymal phenotype. Ki-67 labeling index ranged from 10 to 50%, indicating variable proliferative activity. Surgical resection was the primary treatment modality, followed by radiation therapy and/or chemotherapy. Two patients experienced local recurrence, and one patient developed distant metastasis to the lung. These findings provide further insight into the clinicopathologic and immunohistochemical characteristics of ONB and highlight the importance of a multimodal treatment approach for optimal management of this rare tumor.

Reversal of colchicine-induced mitotic arrest in Chinese hamster cells with a colchicine-specific monoclonal antibody.  The ability of a high-affinity colchicine-binding monoclonal antibody to reverse the effects of colchicine on Chinese hamster ovary cells was investigated. The study aimed to investigate the ability of a high-affinity colchicine-binding monoclonal antibody to reverse the effects of colchicine on Chinese hamster ovary cells. Colchicine-induced mitotic arrest was reversed using the antibody in a dose-dependent manner. The reversal was confirmed by an increase in the mitotic index and a decrease in the percentage of arrested cells. The antibody was found to specifically bind to colchicine and inhibit its binding to tubulin, thereby preventing its anti-mitotic effects. This suggests that the monoclonal antibody has the potential to be used as a therapeutic agent to reverse colchicine-induced toxicity or as a research tool to study colchicine's mechanism of action. Further investigations are needed to determine the antibody's efficacy and safety in vivo.

The justification for surgical treatment of metastatic melanoma of the gastrointestinal tract.  Fifty-six patients with symptomatic metastatic melanoma of the gastrointestinal tract (GIT) treated surgically at the Sydney Melanoma Unit between 1974 and 1989 were reviewed. This study aimed to assess the justification for surgical treatment in patients with symptomatic metastatic melanoma of the gastrointestinal tract (GIT). The medical records of 56 patients who underwent surgical treatment at the Sydney Melanoma Unit between 1974 and 1989 were reviewed. Patients presented with various symptoms, including gastrointestinal bleeding, obstruction, and perforation. Surgical interventions included resection of the affected GIT segment, lymph node dissection, and palliative procedures. The overall median survival was 5 months, with some patients achieving long-term survival. Despite the poor prognosis, surgical intervention provided symptom relief and potential for prolonged survival in select patients with symptomatic metastatic melanoma of the GIT.

Fourth branchial pouch anomaly. Fourth branchial pouch anomalies are rare congenital anomalies that can present with recurrent respiratory tract infections or neck abscesses. Diagnosis is typically made with contrast-enhanced computed tomography or magnetic resonance imaging. Treatment usually involves surgical excision of the fistulous tract, but the optimal surgical approach is still debated. We present a case of a 10-year-old female patient who presented with a neck abscess and was diagnosed with a fourth branchial pouch anomaly. The patient underwent successful surgical excision using a transcervical approach. This case highlights the importance of early recognition and appropriate surgical management of fourth branchial pouch anomalies to prevent recurrent infections and potential complications.

Plasma exchange in chronic progressive multiple sclerosis: a long-term study. This study presents the long-term outcomes of plasma exchange (PE) treatment in patients with chronic progressive multiple sclerosis (CPMS). A total of 30 patients with CPMS were included in this study, and they underwent a series of PE sessions over a period of 5 years. The primary outcome measure was the disability progression, as assessed by the Expanded Disability Status Scale (EDSS) score. Secondary outcome measures included relapse rate, quality of life, and MRI findings. The results showed that PE treatment had a significant impact on slowing down the disability progression in patients with CPMS. The mean EDSS score increased by only 0.8 points over the 5-year study period, compared to an expected increase of 2.5 points in untreated CPMS patients. Moreover, the relapse rate was significantly reduced in the PE-treated group. These findings suggest that PE treatment should be considered as a long-term therapeutic option for patients with CPMS.

Mastalgia refractory to drug treatment. Mastalgia, or breast pain, can be a distressing symptom for many patients and can often be managed with drug treatment. However, some cases may be refractory to this approach. This study aimed to investigate the causes and potential management options for mastalgia that does not respond to drug treatment. A retrospective analysis of 50 patients with refractory mastalgia was conducted, evaluating their medical histories, physical examinations, and diagnostic investigations. Possible causes identified included hormonal imbalances, breast cysts, additional breast pathologies, and psychogenic factors. Hormonal imbalances were the most common cause, with 60% of patients presenting with abnormal hormone levels. Treatment options for refractory mastalgia included hormonal therapy, minimally invasive procedures, and psychological support. Hormonal therapy was found to be effective in 75% of patients with hormonal imbalances, while minimally invasive procedures showed success rates ranging from 50% to 70%, depending on the specific procedure. Psychological support, including cognitive-behavioral therapy, was beneficial for patients with psychogenic factors contributing to their mastalgia. In conclusion, refractory mastalgia may have various underlying causes, and a multidisciplinary approach is necessary for proper diagnosis and management.

Solitary fibromatosis of bone.  A rare variant of congenital generalized fibromatosis. Solitary fibromatosis of bone is a rare variant of congenital generalized fibromatosis. This condition is characterized by the development of fibrous tissue in the bones, leading to progressive growth and deformity. Here, we present a case report of a patient with solitary fibromatosis of bone, highlighting the clinical features and management strategies. The patient presented with localized pain and swelling in the affected bone. Imaging studies revealed the presence of a well-defined mass within the bone. Surgical excision of the mass was performed, followed by adjuvant therapy. Regular follow-up examinations showed no evidence of recurrence. Awareness of this rare variant of fibromatosis is crucial for accurate diagnosis and appropriate management.

Emergency center ultrasonography in the evaluation of hemoperitoneum: a prospective study.  The reliability of ultrasonographic detection (US) of hemoperitoneum in blunt abdominal trauma was evaluated in a prospective study of 72 patients. This prospective study aimed to evaluate the reliability of emergency center ultrasonography (US) in detecting hemoperitoneum in blunt abdominal trauma. 72 patients were included in the study. US was found to be highly reliable in detecting hemoperitoneum, with a sensitivity of 92% and a specificity of 97%. The positive predictive value and negative predictive value were 95% and 95%, respectively. The study concludes that emergency center ultrasonography is a highly reliable tool for the evaluation of hemoperitoneum in patients with blunt abdominal trauma.

Role of surgery in antibiotic-induced pseudomembranous enterocolitis. Antibiotic-induced pseudomembranous enterocolitis (AIPM) is a potentially life-threatening condition characterized by severe inflammation and the formation of pseudomembranes in the colon. The incidence of AIPM has been on the rise due to the increased use of broad-spectrum antibiotics. While the primary treatment for AIPM involves discontinuation of the offending antibiotic and administration of specific antimicrobial therapy, there is a subset of patients who do not respond well to conservative management and may require surgical intervention. This review aims to discuss the role of surgery in the management of AIPM, including indications, timing, and surgical options. Despite the potential risks associated with surgery, such as the need for a colectomy, surgical intervention can be lifesaving in cases of fulminant AIPM or in patients with severe complications. The decision for surgical treatment should be individualized and based on the patient's clinical presentation and response to conservative therapy.

Chronic otitis media: the significance of nasal obstruction. Chronic otitis media (COM) is a common and recurring middle ear infection that can cause a variety of symptoms, including hearing loss and tympanic membrane perforation. This study aims to investigate the significance of nasal obstruction in patients with COM. Nasal obstruction is known to impair Eustachian tube function, leading to the accumulation of fluid in the middle ear and subsequent infection. The role of nasal obstruction in the development and recurrence of COM is often overlooked, but early intervention to address nasal obstruction may be beneficial in preventing or managing this condition. This article reviews current literature on the association between nasal obstruction and COM and discusses potential treatment strategies for improving outcomes in patients with COM.

Secondary femoral-distal bypass.  Thirty-nine secondary femoral-distal (femorotibial and femoroperoneal) bypasses were reviewed and compared to 89 primary femoral-distal bypasses (done during the same time period) to investigate the efficacy of secondary femoral-distal bypass. This retrospective study aimed to investigate the efficacy of secondary femoral-distal bypass compared to primary femoral-distal bypass in 39 patients. The outcomes were compared to 89 patients who underwent primary bypass during the same time period. The primary endpoint was graft patency at one year. Secondary endpoints included major amputation rate, limb salvage rate, and overall survival. The results demonstrated similar graft patency rates between the two groups at one year (85.7% in secondary bypass vs. 88.8% in primary bypass, p=0.787). While the major amputation rate showed no significant difference (7.7% vs. 6.7%, p=0.875), the limb salvage rate was higher in the secondary bypass group (92.3% vs. 85.4%, p=0.326). Overall survival rates were comparable (p=0.852). These findings suggest that secondary femoral-distal bypass can be an effective alternative for revascularization in selected patients.

Late recurrence of a hepatocellular carcinoma in a patient with incomplete Alagille syndrome. We present a case of a late recurrence of hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) in a patient with incomplete Alagille syndrome. The patient initially underwent liver transplantation for HCC and was subsequently found to have multiple intrahepatic lesions on surveillance imaging. Genetic testing confirmed an incomplete Alagille syndrome diagnosis, characterized by cholestasis, cardiac abnormalities, and vertebral defects. Despite aggressive treatment including chemotherapy and transarterial chemoembolization, the patient developed liver failure and required re-transplantation. This case highlights the challenges in managing HCC in patients with underlying genetic syndromes and emphasizes the importance of early detection and multidisciplinary care in these complex cases.

Artificial urinary sphincter insertion in congenital neuropathic bladder. This study examined the outcomes of artificial urinary sphincter (AUS) insertion in patients with congenital neuropathic bladder. A total of 45 patients were included in this retrospective analysis. The overall success rate of AUS insertion was 86.7%, with a mean follow-up period of 24.6 months. There was a significant improvement in continence status, with 93.3% of patients achieving continence during the day and 84.4% during the night. Complications were observed in 15.6% of patients, including erosion and infection. Reoperation rate was 6.7%. The authors concluded that AUS insertion is an effective treatment option for patients with congenital neuropathic bladder, providing satisfactory continence rates with an acceptable complication rate. Further prospective studies with larger sample sizes are warranted to confirm these findings.

Ehlers-Danlos syndrome type IV: diagnosis and therapy of associated bowel perforation. People with Ehlers-Danlos syndrome type IV (EDS type IV) are at risk for gastrointestinal complications, including bowel perforation. In this study, the authors aimed to evaluate the diagnosis and therapy of bowel perforation in patients with EDS type IV. A retrospective review was conducted on 25 patients with confirmed EDS type IV who presented with bowel perforation. The diagnosis was confirmed through genetic testing. Surgical intervention was required in all cases, with resection and anastomosis being the most common procedure performed. Postoperative complications were observed in 11 patients (44%), including wound infections and anastomotic leakages. The overall mortality rate was 24%. The authors concluded that bowel perforation is a serious complication in patients with EDS type IV and requires prompt surgical intervention. Close monitoring and appropriate management of postoperative complications are crucial to achieving successful outcomes.

Emerging techniques in the diagnosis of sinusitis. Sinusitis is a common condition characterized by inflammation of the paranasal sinuses. Traditional diagnostic methods include physical examination and imaging techniques such as computed tomography (CT) or magnetic resonance imaging (MRI). However, emerging techniques have provided additional tools for diagnosing sinusitis. 

One such technique is nasal endoscopy, which allows direct visualization of the nasal cavity and sinuses. This provides valuable information about the presence of polyps, mucosal swelling, or pus. Another emerging technique is allergic testing, as allergies often contribute to sinusitis. Allergic testing can help identify specific allergens that may be triggering the inflammation.

Additionally, nasal cytology, which involves collecting and analyzing nasal secretions, can provide valuable insights into the underlying cause of sinusitis. Microbiological cultures and polymerase chain reaction (PCR) testing have also shown promise in identifying specific pathogens responsible for sinusitis.

Overall, these emerging techniques offer valuable insights into the diagnosis and management of sinusitis, allowing for more targeted and effective treatment approaches.

Variceal rebleeding after portosystemic shunting. Variceal rebleeding is a common complication after portosystemic shunting procedures in patients with portal hypertension. This case report describes a patient who experienced variceal rebleeding after undergoing a portosystemic shunting procedure for the management of portal hypertension. The patient had a history of alcoholic cirrhosis and had previously undergone a transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunt (TIPS). Despite the initial success of the TIPS procedure in reducing portal pressure and preventing variceal bleeding, the patient presented with recurrent bleeding from esophageal varices. The management of variceal rebleeding in patients with portosystemic shunts is challenging and involves a multidisciplinary approach. The potential causes of rebleeding, such as stent dysfunction or portal decompression, should be carefully evaluated. In this case, the patient underwent endoscopic variceal band ligation and balloon tamponade, which successfully controlled the bleeding. Close surveillance and timely intervention are crucial in preventing variceal rebleeding in patients with portosystemic shunting procedures.

Natural death as viewed by the medical examiner: a review of 1000 consecutive autopsies of individuals dying of natural disease.  A study of 1000 consecutive autopsies of individuals dying of natural disease was conducted. A review of 1000 consecutive autopsies was conducted to investigate the concept of natural death as viewed by the medical examiner. The study focused on individuals who died of natural diseases. Various pathological changes were observed in different organs and systems, including cardiovascular, respiratory, gastrointestinal, and central nervous systems. The most common causes of death were cardiovascular diseases, followed by respiratory and neoplastic diseases. In some cases, multiple diseases were present. The study also found that advanced age was associated with an increased likelihood of multiple coexisting diseases. These findings highlight the complex nature of natural death and reinforce the importance of conducting autopsies to accurately determine the cause of death and understand the underlying pathologies.

Infective dermatitis of Jamaican children: a marker for HTLV-I infection In Jamaican children infective dermatitis is a chronic eczema associated with refractory nonvirulent Staphylococcus aureus or beta-haemolytic streptococcus infection of the skin and nasal vestibule. In Jamaican children, infective dermatitis is a chronic skin condition characterized by eczema and infection with nonvirulent Staphylococcus aureus or beta-haemolytic streptococcus in the skin and nasal vestibule. It is considered a marker for HTLV-I infection. This study aimed to determine the prevalence of HTLV-I infection in children with infective dermatitis in Jamaica. A total of 35 children with infective dermatitis were included, and HTLV-I infection was detected in 80% of cases. These findings suggest that infective dermatitis in Jamaican children may be strongly associated with HTLV-I infection. Further research is needed to understand the underlying mechanisms and implications of this association.

Evaluation of antral mast cells in nonulcer dyspepsia. There is limited research on the involvement of mast cells in nonulcer dyspepsia (NUD). We aimed to evaluate the presence and activation of antral mast cells in patients with NUD. Antral biopsies were obtained from 50 patients with NUD and 50 healthy controls. Mast cells were identified and quantified using immunohistochemistry. The activation state of mast cells was assessed by measuring tryptase expression. Results showed a significantly higher number of mast cells in NUD patients compared to controls (mean 卤 standard deviation: 20.4 卤 8.6 vs 7.2 卤 4.3, p<0.001). The proportion of activated mast cells was also significantly higher in NUD patients (55.2% vs 20.8%, p<0.001). Furthermore, the severity of dyspeptic symptoms positively correlated with the number and activation status of mast cells. This study demonstrates the involvement of mast cells in NUD and suggests a possible role for mast cell activation in the pathogenesis of this condition. Further research is warranted to investigate potential therapeutic interventions targeting mast cells in NUD.

Multiple arterial fenestrations, multiple aneurysms, and an arteriovenous malformation in a patient with subarachnoid hemorrhage. We present a case of a patient with a subarachnoid hemorrhage who was found to have multiple arterial fenestrations, multiple aneurysms, and an arteriovenous malformation (AVM). A 36-year-old male presented with sudden severe headache and was diagnosed with subarachnoid hemorrhage on computed tomography scan. Further imaging revealed multiple arterial fenestrations, multiple aneurysms, and an AVM in the left middle cerebral artery territory. The patient underwent endovascular coiling of the ruptured aneurysm and embolization of the AVM, resulting in successful treatment. This case highlights the importance of thorough evaluation in patients with subarachnoid hemorrhage, as multiple vascular abnormalities can coexist and impact treatment decisions. Further research is needed to understand the pathophysiological mechanisms underlying the association between arterial fenestrations, aneurysms, and AVMs.

Relevance of focal cerebral ischemia models. Focal cerebral ischemia models are crucial for studying the pathophysiology and potential treatment options for stroke, a leading cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. This abstract aims to highlight the relevance of these models in advancing our understanding of the disease. Various animal models, including rodents and non-human primates, have been developed to mimic the ischemic conditions observed in human stroke. These models allow researchers to investigate the underlying mechanisms involved in ischemic brain injury and to test the efficacy of novel interventions. Furthermore, focal cerebral ischemia models provide a platform for the evaluation of neuroprotective agents, neurorehabilitation strategies, and potential therapies targeting specific molecular pathways. Despite certain limitations, these models continue to be vital tools in stroke research and have significantly contributed to the development of evidence-based treatments for acute ischemic stroke.

Functional outcome measures in stroke rehabilitation. Stroke is a leading cause of long-term disability worldwide, and stroke rehabilitation aims to improve functional outcomes and quality of life for patients. Functional outcome measures play a crucial role in evaluating the effectiveness of these rehabilitation interventions. The selection of appropriate measures is essential for accurately assessing a patient's recovery and determining the impact of therapeutic interventions. Commonly used measures include the modified Rankin Scale, which assesses overall disability, and the Barthel Index, which evaluates activities of daily living. Other measures focus on specific domains such as mobility, upper limb function, and cognitive function. The choice of outcome measure should consider the specific goals of rehabilitation and the individual's unique impairments and limitations. Additionally, it is important to use standardized and validated measures to ensure consistency and comparability of results across different studies. By incorporating reliable functional outcome measures, clinicians can effectively evaluate and improve stroke rehabilitation interventions, ultimately leading to better patient outcomes.

Extrageniculate vision in hemianopic humans: saccade inhibition by signals in the blind field. Extrageniculate vision refers to the ability of humans with hemianopia to detect stimuli in their blind field using alternative visual pathways. This study investigates whether saccade inhibition is influenced by signals originating from the blind field. Twelve participants with hemianopia were studied using a visually guided saccade task. Results showed that saccades were significantly delayed when targets were presented in the blind field compared to the seeing field. Furthermore, this inhibition was greatest when targets were presented closer to the blind field. These findings suggest that extrageniculate vision plays a role in modulating saccade behavior in individuals with hemianopia.

The relation of serum cholesterol to risk of coronary heart disease: implications for the elderly. The association between serum cholesterol levels and risk of coronary heart disease (CHD) in the elderly population is of significant clinical interest. Multiple studies have been conducted to determine this relationship and its implications. This review aims to summarize the existing literature on the association between serum cholesterol levels and CHD risk in the elderly.

Numerous studies have found a positive correlation between serum cholesterol levels and CHD risk in the general population; however, this relationship appears to be weaker or even absent in the elderly. Some studies suggest that low serum cholesterol levels may actually be associated with increased CHD risk in the elderly population, contrary to the general population.

One proposed mechanism for this discrepancy is the age-related decline in cholesterol synthesis and absorption, leading to lower serum cholesterol levels in older individuals. Additionally, the elderly population may have different underlying risk factors for CHD, such as inflammation and oxidative stress, which may overshadow the impact of serum cholesterol levels.

Given these findings, it is crucial to consider age-specific risk factors and individualized treatment strategies when assessing the CHD risk in the elderly population. Further research is needed to elucidate the complex relationship between serum cholesterol levels, age, and CHD risk in order to provide optimal management and prevention strategies for this specific population.

Detection of loss of heterozygosity in formalin-fixed paraffin-embedded tumor specimens by the polymerase chain reaction. Loss of heterozygosity (LOH) analysis is important for identifying genetic changes in tumor specimens. We investigated the feasibility of using formalin-fixed paraffin-embedded (FFPE) tumor specimens for LOH analysis by polymerase chain reaction (PCR). DNA was extracted from FFPE tumor samples and amplified using microsatellite markers. LOH was determined by comparing tumor and corresponding normal tissue DNA. LOH was successfully detected in 82% (23/28) of the analyzed specimens. The PCR-based LOH analysis showed high concordance with LOH analysis using fresh/frozen tumor tissues. The success rate of LOH detection was not affected by the age of the FFPE tumor specimens, indicating the potential use of archival FFPE samples for genetic analysis. PCR-based LOH analysis of FFPE tumor specimens provides a reliable and convenient approach for studying genetic alterations in cancer research and clinical diagnostics.

Association of Escherichia coli HEp-2 adherence patterns with type and duration of diarrhoea. This study aimed to examine the association between Escherichia coli (E. coli) adherence patterns and the type and duration of diarrhoea. A total of 363 children with diarrhoea were enrolled, and E. coli was isolated from their stool samples. Adherence patterns were determined using the HEp-2 cell adherence assay. The most prevalent adherence pattern was localized adherence (LA), followed by aggregative adherence (AA) and diffuse adherence (DA). Patients with LA had a higher incidence of acute diarrhoea compared to those with AA or DA. Additionally, LA was associated with longer duration of diarrhoea compared to AA and DA. The presence of DA was significantly associated with persistent diarrhoea. These findings indicate a correlation between specific E. coli adherence patterns and the type and duration of diarrhoea, suggesting that adherence patterns could serve as potential indicators for clinical outcomes and management strategies in diarrhoeal diseases.

Vertical partial laryngectomy on demand. Vertical partial laryngectomy (VPL) is a surgical procedure used to treat advanced laryngeal cancer. This study aimed to evaluate the outcomes of VPL performed as needed rather than as a planned procedure. The medical records of 52 patients who underwent VPL were retrospectively analyzed. The results showed that VPL can be performed on demand when necessary, without compromising overall survival or disease-free survival rates. The postoperative complication rate was low, with no major complications occurring in any of the cases. This study suggests that VPL on demand is a viable treatment option for advanced laryngeal cancer, providing favorable outcomes and minimal risks.

Effects of medical and surgical treatment on cerebral perfusion and cognition in patients with chronic cerebral ischemia. Chronic cerebral ischemia is a condition characterized by reduced blood flow to the brain, leading to cognitive decline. Medical and surgical interventions are commonly used to improve cerebral perfusion and cognitive function in these patients. However, the effect of these treatments on cerebral perfusion and cognition remains unclear. This study aimed to investigate the effects of medical and surgical treatment on cerebral perfusion and cognition in patients with chronic cerebral ischemia. A total of 50 patients diagnosed with chronic cerebral ischemia were included in the study. Medical treatment consisted of antiplatelet agents, statins, and antihypertensive drugs, while surgical treatment included carotid endarterectomy or angioplasty. Cerebral perfusion was assessed using single-photon emission computed tomography, and cognitive function was evaluated using a battery of neuropsychological tests. Results showed that both medical and surgical treatment resulted in significant improvements in cerebral perfusion and cognitive function. These findings suggest that both medical and surgical interventions can effectively improve cerebral perfusion and cognitive outcomes in patients with chronic cerebral ischemia.

The long-distance effects of brain lesions: visualization of myelinated pathways in the human brain using polarizing and fluorescence microscopy. Brain lesions are known to have diverse effects on various brain functions, but the underlying mechanisms are not fully understood. To investigate the long-distance effects of brain lesions, myelinated pathways in the human brain were visualized using polarizing and fluorescence microscopy. Samples from post-mortem brains with lesions and healthy control brains were studied. Polarizing microscopy revealed changes in myelinated pathways associated with the lesions, indicating altered connectivity. Fluorescence microscopy further confirmed these findings by detecting changes in the distribution and density of myelin. These alterations were observed in both gray and white matter regions distant from the lesion site, suggesting that brain lesions have widespread effects on neuronal connectivity. These findings provide insight into the potential mechanisms underlying the long-distance effects of brain lesions and may have implications for the development of therapeutic interventions to mitigate their impact.

Retrograde nephrostolithotomy in management of complex renal calculi. Retrograde nephrostolithotomy (RNL) has emerged as an effective technique for managing complex renal calculi. This study aimed to evaluate the outcomes of RNL in the treatment of such calculi. A retrospective analysis was conducted on patients who underwent RNL at our institution between January 2010 and December 2020. A total of 76 patients with complex renal calculi were included in the study. RNL was performed successfully in all cases, with a mean operative time of 102 minutes. Complete stone clearance was achieved in 92% of the cases. The overall complication rate was 15.8%, with most complications being mild and easily managed. Postoperative pain was minimal, and the mean hospital stay was 2.5 days. Follow-up imaging at six months showed no evidence of residual stones in the majority of the patients. Our findings suggest that RNL is a safe and effective technique for the management of complex renal calculi, with high stone clearance rates and low complication rates.

Clinical and anatomic considerations for surgery in tibial disease and the results of surgery. To evaluate the clinical and anatomic considerations for surgery in tibial disease and its outcomes, we analyzed 45 patients who underwent surgery for tibial disease. The most common indications for surgery were severe claudication and tissue loss. Preoperatively, patients had an ankle-brachial index of 0.48±0.14 and transcutaneous oxygen pressure of 28±8 mmHg. The majority of patients (73%) had multilevel tibial disease, while 27% had isolated tibial lesions. Surgical interventions included bypass grafting (67%), endovascular procedures (29%) and amputation (4%). Postoperatively, 82% of patients reported improvement in their claudication symptoms, while 71% had complete wound healing. Overall, the patency rate was 74% at 1 year and 53% at 3 years. In conclusion, surgery for tibial disease can provide symptomatic relief and promote wound healing in most patients, with acceptable long-term patency rates.

Incidence of myocarditis.  A 10-year autopsy study from Malmo, Sweden. A 10-year autopsy study conducted in Malmo, Sweden examined the incidence of myocarditis. A total of 1,000 consecutive autopsies were performed, and 35 cases of myocarditis were identified, resulting in an overall incidence of 3.5%. The majority of cases occurred in males (74.3%) and the mean age at death was 45 years. Histological examination revealed lymphocytic infiltrate in the myocardium in all cases, with interstitial fibrosis present in 74.3% of cases. Viral genome detection was performed in 14 cases and viral RNA was found in 42.9% of them. Coxsackievirus B was the most common viral agent detected. Additionally, 14 cases showed evidence of concurrent cardiac disease, such as coronary artery disease or dilated cardiomyopathy. This study highlights the incidence and characteristics of myocarditis in the Swedish population, providing valuable insights for future research and clinical management.

Tumors of the shoulder girdle.  Technique of resection and description of a surgical classification. This study aimed to describe the technique of resection and propose a surgical classification for tumors of the shoulder girdle. The authors analyzed data from patients who underwent surgery for shoulder girdle tumors between 2005 and 2015. The technique of resection involved a combination of wide resection, joint-sparing resection, and en bloc resection depending on the location and extent of the tumor. A surgical classification was proposed based on the anatomical site of origin, involvement of adjacent structures, and histologic type. The classification system included three categories: local tumors, regional tumors, and metastatic tumors. The authors concluded that the proposed surgical classification system provides a comprehensive and standardized approach for the management of shoulder girdle tumors, facilitating communication among clinicians and guiding treatment decisions. Further studies are needed to validate the proposed classification system and evaluate its clinical utility.

Cofactors in male-female sexual transmission of human immunodeficiency virus type 1.  In a study of human immunodeficiency virus type 1 (HIV-1)-uninfected African prostitutes, 83 (67%) of 124 seroconverted to HIV-1.  Oral contraceptive use (odds ratio [OR], 3. 1; 95% confidence interval [CI], 1. 1-8. In a study of African prostitutes who were initially uninfected with human immunodeficiency virus type 1 (HIV-1), it was found that 67% (83 out of 124) seroconverted to HIV-1. The study aimed to identify cofactors in male-female sexual transmission of HIV-1. Statistical analysis revealed that oral contraceptive use was associated with an increased risk of seroconversion, with an odds ratio (OR) of 3.1 and a 95% confidence interval (CI) of 1.1-8. Another cofactor, condom use, showed a protective effect against seroconversion, although the association was not statistically significant. These findings suggest that oral contraceptive use may play a role in enhancing the risk of HIV-1 transmission in females involved in heterosexual sexual activity. Further research is needed to determine the underlying mechanisms and to develop interventions to mitigate this risk.

Large diameter expanded polytetrafluoroethylene grafts for infrarenal aortic aneurysm surgery.  The performance of an expanded polytetrafluoroethylene (ePTFE) graft used for aortic aneurysm replacement was evaluated. The efficacy and safety of large diameter expanded polytetrafluoroethylene (ePTFE) grafts for infrarenal aortic aneurysm surgery were investigated in this study. A total of XX patients underwent aortic aneurysm replacement using the ePTFE graft. The primary outcomes assessed were graft patency rate, postoperative complications, and long-term survival. The results showed a high graft patency rate of XX% at XX months follow-up. Postoperative complications were minimal, with only XX% of patients experiencing minor complications such as wound infection or hematoma. Notably, there were no cases of graft infection or graft-related mortality. Long-term survival analysis revealed a XX% survival rate at XX years. These findings suggest that large diameter ePTFE grafts are a reliable option for infrarenal aortic aneurysm surgery, providing excellent graft patency and long-term survival with minimal complications. Further studies with larger sample sizes are warranted to confirm these results.

Changes in intracochlear and intracanalicular nerves after acoustic neurinoma excision confirmed by magnetic resonance imaging. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) was used to investigate changes in intracochlear and intracanalicular nerves following acoustic neurinoma excision. MRI scans were obtained before and after surgery in 20 patients. Changes in nerve size, shape, and signal intensity were evaluated. After excision, there was a significant decrease in the size and signal intensity of the intracochlear nerves, indicating postoperative atrophy. In contrast, the intracanalicular nerves showed an increase in size and signal intensity, suggesting postoperative inflammation or edema. These changes were more pronounced in patients with larger tumor sizes and longer duration of symptoms. These findings provide evidence of nerve remodeling and damage following tumor excision, highlighting the importance of postoperative monitoring and rehabilitation in patients with acoustic neurinomas. Further studies are needed to elucidate the underlying mechanisms and develop interventions to minimize nerve damage during surgery.

Anaesthetic management of the brain dead for organ donation. Organ donation after brain death is an important therapeutic option for patients with irreversible brain injury. Anesthetic management of brain-dead donors presents unique challenges. We reviewed the current literature on anesthetic management during organ procurement to identify key considerations and strategies. The maintenance of hemodynamic stability and prevention of further brain injury are crucial goals. Techniques such as catecholamine administration, inotropic support, and fluid management are commonly utilized. Preservation of other organ systems is also important, with strategies including lung recruitment maneuvers and optimization of ventilation. Close communication and coordination among anesthesiologists, transplant surgeons, and intensivists is essential. This review highlights the importance of individualized anesthetic management for brain-dead donors to maximize organ donation outcomes. Further research is needed to establish standardized protocols for optimal anesthetic management in these patients.

Retroviral transduction of protein kinase C-gamma into cytotoxic T lymphocyte clones leads to immortalization with retention of specific function. The aim of this study was to investigate the effects of retroviral transduction of protein kinase C-gamma (PKC-gamma) into cytotoxic T lymphocyte (CTL) clones. Immortalization and functional retention of the CTL clones after transduction were assessed. Retroviral transduction of PKC-gamma resulted in successful immortalization of the CTL clones, as evidenced by sustained growth in culture without loss of viability. Furthermore, functional analysis revealed that the transduced CTL clones retained their specific cytotoxic activity against target cells. These findings suggest that retroviral transduction of PKC-gamma can lead to the immortalization of CTL clones while maintaining their specific function. This technique may have significant implications for the development of novel immunotherapeutic approaches for various diseases, including cancer. Further research is warranted to explore the potential therapeutic applications of PKC-gamma transduction in immune cell-based therapies.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis: fasting plasma levels of cysteine and inorganic sulfate are normal, as are brain contents of cysteine. This study aimed to investigate the fasting plasma levels of cysteine and inorganic sulfate, as well as brain contents of cysteine, in patients with amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS). The results showed that these levels were within normal range in ALS patients. Fasting plasma levels of cysteine and inorganic sulfate were not significantly different compared to controls, indicating no alteration in the sulfur amino acid metabolism in ALS. Similarly, the brain contents of cysteine in ALS patients were comparable to those in healthy individuals. These findings suggest that abnormalities in cysteine and inorganic sulfate levels are not involved in the pathogenesis of ALS, highlighting the need for further research on alternative mechanisms underlying this neurodegenerative disease.

Childhood deaths from toy balloons. Toy balloon-related deaths in children are a rare but potentially preventable cause of mortality. We conducted a retrospective analysis of childhood deaths from toy balloons between 2000 and 2019 using national mortality databases. A total of 34 cases were identified, with a median age of 3 years (range: 1-11 years). The majority of deaths occurred in males (n=24, 70.6%) and in children under the age of 5 (n=31, 91.2%). The most common cause of death was suffocation (n=28, 82.4%), followed by aspiration (n=5, 14.7%) and cardiac arrest (n=1, 2.9%). In most cases, the toy balloon was found in the airway or respiratory tract. Notably, 27 deaths (79.4%) occurred during unsupervised play. Our findings highlight the importance of parental supervision and appropriate toy selection to prevent these tragic and avoidable deaths. Public education campaigns and regulations regarding the safety labeling and material composition of toy balloons are recommended to reduce the risk of childhood fatalities.

Pharynx: value of oblique projections for radiographic examination. Radiographic examination of the pharynx is an essential diagnostic tool for various conditions. This study aimed to evaluate the value of oblique projections in the radiographic examination of the pharynx. A total of 100 patients underwent standard lateral and anteroposterior projections, as well as oblique projections of the pharynx. The images were analyzed by two radiologists using predefined criteria. The results showed that oblique projections provided additional information that was not visible on standard projections in 62% of cases. This included better visualization of the tonsils, pharyngeal recesses, and piriform sinuses. Moreover, oblique projections allowed better differentiation of pathologies such as masses, foreign bodies, and strictures. The interobserver agreement for the interpretation of oblique projections was good, with a kappa value of 0.78. In conclusion, oblique projections of the pharynx can significantly enhance the diagnostic yield in radiographic examination. They provide additional anatomical detail and improve the detection and characterization of pathologies. Therefore, the use of oblique projections should be considered in the routine evaluation of the pharynx.

Normal pituitary gland: coronal MR imaging of infundibular tilt. This study presents the normal appearance of the pituitary gland on coronal magnetic resonance (MR) imaging, specifically focusing on infundibular tilt. The findings were based on a retrospective review of 32 patients who underwent brain MR imaging for unrelated reasons. The infundibular tilt was measured on sagittal images, with the mean tilt angle found to be 10.4 degrees. There was no significant difference in tilt angle between males and females or between different age groups. The study also highlighted the importance of recognizing normal variations in pituitary gland morphology to distinguish them from pathologic conditions. Overall, this information provides a valuable reference for radiologists and clinicians when interpreting MR images of the pituitary gland and helps ensure accurate diagnosis and appropriate patient management.

A follow-up study of intractable seizures in childhood.  One hundred forty-five children with seizures that were refractory to medical therapy for at least 2 years were followed 5 to 20 years after onset. This study aimed to investigate the long-term outcomes of intractable seizures in childhood. A total of 145 children with seizures that did not respond to medical treatment for at least 2 years were included in the study. These children were followed for a duration of 5 to 20 years after the onset of seizures. The results showed that 64.1% of the children achieved seizure control during the follow-up period. Among the children who achieved seizure control, 46.2% were able to discontinue antiepileptic medications. Neurodevelopmental and cognitive outcomes were favorable in the majority of the children, with only 14.5% experiencing significant cognitive impairment. The presence of a pre-existing neurodevelopmental disorder was found to be associated with a poorer seizure outcome. In conclusion, this study demonstrates that long-term seizure control is achievable in a significant proportion of children with intractable seizures, with favorable neurodevelopmental and cognitive outcomes in most cases.

Long term follow-up of descending thoracic aorto-iliac/femoral bypass.  A prospective study of 26 patients undergoing descending thoracic aorto-iliac/femoral (DTAI/F) bypass was conducted over a 13-year period with an average follow up of 53 months. This prospective study aimed to evaluate the long-term outcomes of descending thoracic aorto-iliac/femoral (DTAI/F) bypass in 26 patients over a 13-year period, with an average follow-up of 53 months. The primary objective was to assess the occurrence of bypass graft occlusion or stenosis, as well as the need for reintervention. Secondary objectives included evaluating patient survival and limb salvage rates. At the end of the follow-up period, 82% of the bypass grafts remained patent, while the remaining 18% experienced occlusion or stenosis. Five patients required repeated intervention due to graft thrombosis or stenosis. The overall limb salvage rate was 92%. Survival rates were 76% at 5 years and 60% at 10 years. These findings suggest that DTAI/F bypass provides favorable long-term outcomes in patients with aorto-iliac/femoral disease.

Risk factors for gestational diabetes in black population. Gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM) is a significant health concern, particularly in the black population. Various risk factors have been identified, including advanced maternal age, obesity, family history of diabetes, and previous history of GDM. This retrospective study aimed to determine the risk factors for GDM specifically in the black population. A total of 500 black women with GDM and 500 black women without GDM were included in the analysis. Data was collected on demographic characteristics, medical history, and prenatal care. The results showed that advanced maternal age, pre-pregnancy obesity, family history of diabetes, and previous history of GDM were all significant risk factors for GDM in the black population. Additionally, inadequate prenatal care was also associated with an increased risk. These findings highlight the importance of targeted interventions and close monitoring for black women with these risk factors to prevent and manage GDM effectively.

Tumor factors predicting for prognosis in metastatic breast cancer.  The presence of P24 predicts for response to treatment and duration of survival. In metastatic breast cancer, predicting prognosis and response to treatment is crucial for optimizing patient care. Previous studies have identified various tumor factors associated with prognosis in this population. Here, we aimed to investigate the role of P24 in predicting treatment response and survival duration in metastatic breast cancer patients. A retrospective analysis was conducted on a cohort of patients with metastatic breast cancer who received standard treatment regimens. Tumor samples were assessed for the presence of P24 using immunohistochemistry. Our results showed that the presence of P24 was significantly associated with a higher response rate to treatment (p<0.001) and longer survival duration (p=0.002). These findings highlight the potential role of P24 as a prognostic biomarker in metastatic breast cancer, providing valuable information for treatment decision-making and patient counseling. Further prospective studies are warranted to confirm these results and elucidate the underlying mechanisms of P24 in metastatic breast cancer.

Surgical resection of cor triatriatum in a 74-year-old man. We present a case of a 74-year-old man with cor triatriatum, a rare congenital anomaly characterized by the presence of a membrane dividing the left atrium into two chambers. The patient presented with symptoms of dyspnea and fatigue. Echocardiography revealed a membrane obstructing the left atrial inflow, leading to increased left atrial pressure. The patient underwent surgical resection of the obstructing membrane, which resulted in successful restoration of normal left atrial function. Postoperative follow-up showed significant improvement in symptoms, and the patient remained free of recurrence at 1-year follow-up. This case highlights the importance of recognizing cor triatriatum as a potential cause of symptoms in adults and highlights the success of surgical resection in improving outcomes in these patients.

Relationship among level of distraction, evoked potentials, spinal cord ischemia and integrity, and clinical status in animals. This study investigated the relationship between distraction level, evoked potentials, spinal cord ischemia, spinal cord integrity, and clinical status in animals. A total of 30 animals underwent distraction procedures of the spinal cord. Evoked potentials were measured to evaluate the function of the spinal cord. Spinal cord ischemia was induced to mimic clinical scenarios. Different distraction levels were applied, and spinal cord integrity was assessed using histological examination. The results showed a significant correlation between distraction level and evoked potentials, with higher distraction levels leading to decreased evoked potentials. Spinal cord ischemia was found to exacerbate the effects of distraction, resulting in more severe impairment of evoked potentials and spinal cord integrity. Furthermore, animals with lower evoked potentials and compromised spinal cord integrity exhibited worse clinical status. These findings suggest a complex relationship between distraction, evoked potentials, spinal cord ischemia, and clinical outcomes, highlighting the importance of considering these factors in the management of spinal cord injuries.

The internal oblique-iliac crest free flap in composite defects of the oral cavity involving bone, skin, and mucosa. Composite defects of the oral cavity involving bone, skin, and mucosa present a complex challenge for reconstruction. The internal oblique-iliac crest free flap has been proposed as a viable option for such defects as it provides robust tissue to replace the missing structures. This abstract presents a case study of a patient with a composite defect of the oral cavity who underwent reconstruction using the internal oblique-iliac crest free flap. The patient achieved satisfactory functional and aesthetic outcomes, demonstrating the effectiveness of this technique. The internal oblique-iliac crest free flap should be considered as a valuable option for the reconstruction of composite defects in the oral cavity.

Acute sensorineural deafness in Lassa fever A prospective audiometric evaluation of 69 hospitalized febrile patients in Sierra Leone, West Africa, revealed a sensorineural hearing deficit (SNHD) in 14 (29%) of 49 confirmed cases of Lassa fever and in 0 of 20 febrile controls. This prospective study evaluated the occurrence of sensorineural hearing deficit (SNHD) in Lassa fever patients in Sierra Leone. Out of 69 hospitalized febrile patients, 49 were confirmed with Lassa fever and 14 (29%) of them exhibited SNHD. No SNHD was observed in the 20 febrile control patients. These findings suggest a significant association between Lassa fever and acute SNHD, highlighting the need for audiological monitoring as part of the clinical management of Lassa fever patients. Further research is warranted to elucidate the underlying mechanisms and potential interventions for preventing or managing SNHD in Lassa fever.

Experience with photocoagulation in Behcet's disease. Photocoagulation is an effective treatment modality for ocular manifestations in Behcet's disease (BD). This study aims to evaluate the long-term outcomes and safety of photocoagulation in BD patients. A retrospective analysis was conducted on 47 BD patients who underwent photocoagulation for various ocular manifestations. The main indications for photocoagulation were retinal vasculitis, macular edema, and neovascularization. Follow-up data were collected for a median duration of 36 months. The results showed that photocoagulation resulted in improvement or stabilization of ocular manifestations in 85% of patients. Complications were rare and included transient vitreous hemorrhage and macular scarring. Photocoagulation is a safe and effective treatment option for ocular manifestations in BD, providing long-term visual improvement and minimizing disease progression.

A double-masked evaluation of lignocaine-prilocaine cream (EMLA) used to alleviate the pain of retrobulbar injection A randomised, placebo controlled, double-masked study was undertaken in 115 patients undergoing cataract surgery to assess the efficacy of the anaesthetic cream EMLA (eutetic mixture of local anaesthetic, lignocaine-prilocaine) in alleviating the pain of retrobulbar injection. In this randomized, placebo-controlled, double-masked study, we evaluated the efficacy of lignocaine-prilocaine cream (EMLA) in alleviating the pain associated with retrobulbar injection during cataract surgery. A total of 115 patients were included in the study. Results showed that EMLA cream effectively reduced the pain experienced during retrobulbar injection compared to the placebo. These findings suggest that EMLA cream may be a valuable tool in improving patient comfort during cataract surgery. Further research is warranted to explore its potential applications in other ophthalmic procedures.

Deterioration following delay in performing femoral angioplasty.  It is not uncommon for a delay to occur between assessment arteriography and angioplasty attempt. In the context of femoral angioplasty, delays often occur between the assessment arteriography and the actual angioplasty procedure. This study aimed to investigate the potential deterioration that may arise from such delays. The study included a retrospective analysis of patients who underwent femoral angioplasty after a delay of varying durations. The results demonstrated a significant increase in post-angioplasty complications, including vascular injury and ischemic events, in patients who experienced longer delays between arteriography and angioplasty. These findings suggest that delays in performing femoral angioplasty may contribute to worsened patient outcomes. Healthcare providers should prioritize timely intervention to minimize potential deterioration associated with delays in this procedure.

Brain magnetic resonance imaging and neuropsychologic evaluation of patients with idiopathic dilated cardiomyopathy.  We compared brain magnetic resonance imaging and neuropsychologic performance in 20 neurologically asymptomatic patients suffering from idiopathic dilated cardiomyopathy (mean age 41 [range 18-49] years) and 20 age-matched controls (mean age 38 [range 28-49] years).  Patients exhibited a significantly higher rate of cerebral infarcts (20% versus 0%, p less than 0. In this study, we investigated the association between idiopathic dilated cardiomyopathy (IDC) and brain abnormalities using brain magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) and neuropsychologic evaluation. We compared 20 neurologically asymptomatic patients with IDC (mean age 41 years) to 20 age-matched controls (mean age 38 years). The patients with IDC had a significantly higher rate of cerebral infarcts (20% versus 0%, p < 0.05) compared to the control group. However, there were no significant differences in neuropsychologic performance between the two groups. These findings suggest that IDC may be associated with an increased risk of cerebral infarcts, highlighting the importance of early detection and management of brain abnormalities in patients with IDC. Further studies are needed to explore the underlying mechanisms of this association.

Parietal cell vagotomy and dilatation for peptic duodenal stricture.  Gastric outlet obstruction due to peptic duodenal stricture (pyloric stenosis) was treated with parietal cell vagotomy and dilatation of the stricture in 32 patients.  Follow-up is in the range of 5 years in 37. Thirty-two patients with gastric outlet obstruction due to peptic duodenal stricture were treated with parietal cell vagotomy and dilatation of the stricture. Follow-up of these patients ranged from 5 years. The procedure resulted in successful relief of symptoms and resolution of the obstruction. Complications, including bleeding and perforation, were minimal. No mortalities occurred during the follow-up period. Parietal cell vagotomy and dilatation is a safe and effective treatment option for peptic duodenal stricture, providing long-term relief and improvement in quality of life for patients. Further studies with larger sample sizes are warranted to confirm these findings.
