Trends in conserving treatment of invasive carcinoma of the breast in females. Invasive carcinoma of the breast is a common malignancy in females, and treatment strategies have evolved over time. The aim of this study was to identify trends in the conserving treatment of invasive breast cancer. A retrospective analysis was conducted on a cohort of female patients with invasive breast carcinoma from 2000 to 2020. Data on patient demographics, tumor characteristics, and treatment modalities were collected. The results showed a significant increase in the utilization of breast-conserving surgery, including lumpectomy and oncoplastic techniques, compared to mastectomy. This shift towards conservative treatment was accompanied by advancements in radiation therapy, including the implementation of partial breast irradiation techniques. The findings highlight a growing preference for breast conservation while ensuring oncological safety. These trends in treatment may have significant implications for patient outcomes and quality of life. Further studies are warranted to evaluate long-term oncological outcomes and patient satisfaction.

The effect of omental pedicle graft transfer on spinal microcirculation and laminectomy membrane formation.  The properties of the omentum and its effect on spinal neurologic disease was investigated. The impact of omental pedicle graft transfer on spinal microcirculation and the formation of laminectomy membrane were examined in a study involving patients with spinal neurologic disease. The properties of the omentum and its effects on the disease were investigated. The study found that omental pedicle graft transfer resulted in improved spinal microcirculation and a reduction in laminectomy membrane formation. These findings suggest that omental pedicle graft transfer may be a beneficial treatment option for patients with spinal neurologic disease, as it positively influences spinal microcirculation and prevents the formation of laminectomy membrane. Further research is warranted to fully understand the potential of omental pedicle graft transfer in this context.

Successful liver transplantation in a patient with a thrombosed portomesenteric system after multiple failed shunts. This report presents a case of successful liver transplantation in a patient with a thrombosed portomesenteric system after multiple failed shunts. The patient had a history of chronic liver disease and portal hypertension, leading to the development of portomesenteric thrombosis. Multiple attempts were made to establish successful shunts, but all failed due to thrombosis recurrence. As a result, the patient's condition continued to deteriorate. Liver transplantation was then considered as the most viable option. The procedure was successful, and post-transplantation follow-up showed normalization of liver function. This case highlights the importance of liver transplantation in patients with thrombosed portomesenteric systems when conventional shunt procedures fail.

Late relapse with nodular lymphoma after treatment for diffuse non-Hodgkin's lymphoma. Late relapse of nodular lymphoma after treatment for diffuse non-Hodgkin's lymphoma is a rare occurrence. We report a case of a 46-year-old male who presented with generalized lymphadenopathy two years after achieving complete remission from diffuse non-Hodgkin's lymphoma. Histopathological examination confirmed the diagnosis of nodular lymphoma. The patient was treated with salvage chemotherapy followed by autologous stem cell transplantation, resulting in complete remission. Late relapse of nodular lymphoma after treatment for diffuse non-Hodgkin's lymphoma poses a diagnostic challenge and requires prompt intervention. This case highlights the importance of long-term surveillance and aggressive treatment strategies in managing relapsed lymphomas. Further studies are needed to better understand the underlying mechanisms and improve outcomes in this unique patient population.

The freckle sign--an endoscopic feature of the cecum. The "freckle sign" is a unique endoscopic feature observed in the cecum during colonoscopy. It appears as multiple small, brownish pigmented spots resembling freckles scattered throughout the mucosa. The significance and clinical implications of this finding are still unclear, but it has been associated with various conditions such as colorectal cancer, inflammatory bowel disease, and diverticular disease. Some studies suggest that the freckle sign could represent early mucosal changes or a marker of inflammatory activity in the cecum. Further research is needed to establish the diagnostic and prognostic value of the freckle sign and its correlation with specific underlying pathologies.

Lipolytic factors associated with murine and human cancer cachexia. Cancer cachexia, characterized by weight loss and muscle wasting, is a common complication in both murine and human cancer patients. Lipolytic factors have been implicated in the pathophysiology of cancer cachexia, as they contribute to the loss of adipose tissue. In murine models, tumor-derived factors such as tumor necrosis factor alpha (TNF-伪) and interleukin-6 (IL-6) have been shown to stimulate lipolysis, leading to increased release of fatty acids. In human cancer patients, elevated levels of TNF-伪, IL-6, and other lipolytic factors have also been observed. In addition to tumor-derived factors, host-derived factors such as catecholamines and glucocorticoids may contribute to the lipolytic process. Understanding the role of lipolytic factors in cancer cachexia may provide opportunities for developing targeted therapies to prevent or reverse muscle wasting in cancer patients. Further research is needed to elucidate the specific mechanisms by which lipolytic factors contribute to cachexia and to identify potential therapeutic targets.

Molteno implants and operating microscope-induced retinal phototoxicity. Molteno implants are commonly used in the surgical treatment of glaucoma. However, there have been reports of retinal phototoxicity associated with the use of operating microscopes during implant placement. We present two cases of retinal phototoxicity following Molteno implant surgery, emphasizing the importance of minimizing light exposure to the retina during these procedures. In our first case, a 50-year-old patient developed decreased visual acuity and central scotoma in the operated eye. Fundus examination revealed macular pigmentary changes and retinal nerve fiber layer thinning. In our second case, a 65-year-old patient experienced sudden vision loss and visual field defect following Molteno implant surgery. Fundus examination showed retinal pigment epithelium changes and macular edema. Both patients had a history of prolonged microscope exposure during surgery. These cases highlight the need for cautious use of operating microscopes and appropriate protective measures to prevent retinal phototoxicity during Molteno implant surgery.

Otitis media in day-care children. Otitis media is a common condition among day-care children, but its management and impact are still a concern. This study aims to review the existing literature on the prevalence, risk factors, diagnosis, and treatment of otitis media in day-care children. A systematic search was conducted, and relevant articles were analyzed. The prevalence of otitis media was found to be higher in day-care children compared to those not attending day care. Several risk factors including younger age, bottle-feeding, and attendance at large day-care centers were identified. The diagnosis of otitis media in day-care children is often challenging due to a lack of specific symptoms and difficulty in obtaining adequate samples for culture. Antibiotics are commonly prescribed for the treatment of otitis media, but the rise of antibiotic resistance is a concern. Non-pharmacological interventions such as pneumococcal vaccination and education on hygiene practices were found to be effective in reducing the incidence of otitis media. In conclusion, a comprehensive approach that includes both preventive measures and appropriate management strategies is crucial in the care of day-care children with otitis media.

Micromotion of cemented and uncemented femoral components. Micromotion of cemented and uncemented femoral components in total hip arthroplasty (THA) is a topic of significant interest in orthopedic surgery. Cemented components have long been the gold standard in THA, with good long-term results. However, concerns regarding cement particle disease and aseptic loosening have led to the development of uncemented components. Micromotion, defined as the small amplitude motion between the implant and host bone, can affect the long-term stability and success of THA. Studies have shown that cemented components provide immediate stability due to the cement mantle, while uncemented components rely on osseointegration. This abstract aims to review the current literature on micromotion and its effects on cemented and uncemented femoral components in THA, including the factors affecting micromotion and strategies to reduce it.

Posterior transfer of the adductors in children who have cerebral palsy.  A long-term study. This long-term study aimed to evaluate the outcomes of posterior transfer of the adductors in children with cerebral palsy. A retrospective review of medical records and follow-up assessments was conducted for 35 patients who underwent posterior transfer of the adductors between 2000 and 2010. The mean follow-up duration was 7.2 years. Clinical assessments included the Modified Tardieu Scale for spasticity, the Gross Motor Function Classification System (GMFCS), and the Functional Independence Measure (FIM). The results showed a significant improvement in spasticity, as indicated by a decrease in the Modified Tardieu Scale scores. Additionally, there was a significant improvement in gross motor function, as indicated by a decrease in the GMFCS levels. The functional independence, assessed by the FIM, also showed significant improvement. This study provides evidence supporting the efficacy of posterior transfer of the adductors in improving spasticity, motor function, and functional independence in children with cerebral palsy.

Amebic meningoencephalitis in a patient with AIDS caused by a newly recognized opportunistic pathogen.  Leptomyxid ameba. We present a case of amebic meningoencephalitis in a patient with AIDS caused by a newly recognized opportunistic pathogen, Leptomyxid ameba. A 45-year-old male with a history of AIDS and low CD4 count presented with headache, altered mental status, and seizures. MRI revealed multiple ring-enhancing lesions in the brain. Cerebrospinal fluid analysis showed elevated protein and pleocytosis. Microscopic examination of the cerebrospinal fluid revealed the presence of trophozoites and cysts consistent with Leptomyxid ameba. Serologic studies for other opportunistic infections, including cytomegalovirus, toxoplasmosis, and cryptococcosis, were negative. The patient was started on antifungal therapy with amphotericin B and flucytosine, but unfortunately, his condition rapidly deteriorated, and he passed away. This case highlights the importance of considering Leptomyxid ameba as a potential opportunistic pathogen in immunocompromised individuals with central nervous system infections, particularly in the setting of AIDS. Further research is needed to better understand the epidemiology, pathogenesis, and optimal treatment strategies for this emerging pathogen.

Multiple noncontiguous spine fractures.  The data from a prospective study of 508 spine injuries were reviewed to determine the incidence of multiple noncontiguous spine fractures. A prospective study of 508 patients with spine injuries was conducted to investigate the incidence of multiple noncontiguous spine fractures. Among the study population, 32 patients (6.3%) were identified with multiple noncontiguous spine fractures. The majority of these patients (78.1%) had fractures involving the cervical and thoracic spine, while the remaining cases involved the lumbar spine. Motor vehicle accidents were the most common cause of these fractures (62.5%). Patients with multiple noncontiguous spine fractures had a higher rate of neurological deficits compared to those with single fractures. These findings highlight the importance of comprehensive evaluation and management of spine injuries to identify and address multiple noncontiguous fractures.

Sequential esophageal motility studies after endoscopic injection sclerotherapy: a prospective investigation.  To assess prospectively the effects of endoscopic intravariceal sclerosis (EIS) on esophageal function, we performed esophageal manometry on 13 cirrhotic patients before EIS, 24 h after the second session and 4 wk after the fourth session. This prospective study aimed to investigate the effects of endoscopic intravariceal sclerosis (EIS) on esophageal function through sequential esophageal motility studies. Thirteen cirrhotic patients underwent esophageal manometry prior to EIS, 24 hours after the second session, and 4 weeks after the fourth session. Results showed that EIS had no significant impact on lower esophageal sphincter (LES) pressure or peristaltic amplitude. However, there was a significant increase in LES relaxation duration 24 hours after the second session, which returned to baseline levels after 4 weeks. These findings suggest that EIS does not affect LES pressure or peristaltic amplitude, but transiently prolongs LES relaxation. Further studies are necessary to explore the clinical implications of these findings.

Risk of cancer death in first-degree relatives of patients with hereditary non-polyposis cancer syndrome (Lynch type II): a study of 130 kindreds in the United Kingdom. A study conducted in the United Kingdom evaluated the risk of cancer death in first-degree relatives of patients with hereditary non-polyposis cancer syndrome (HNPCC) or Lynch type II. The study included 130 kindreds and found a significantly increased risk of cancer death in these relatives. Specifically, there was an increased risk of colorectal, endometrial, ovarian, urinary tract, pancreatic, and gastric cancers. The risk was higher in relatives of individuals with HNPCC-associated mutations compared to relatives without mutations. Additionally, the risk was greater for individuals aged 50 years or older compared to those younger than 50 years. These findings highlight the importance of genetic counseling and surveillance for first-degree relatives of HNPCC patients to prevent cancer-related morbidity and mortality.

Managing geriatric arrhythmias, II: Drug selection and use [published erratum appears in Geriatrics 1991 Jun;46(6):100] Age-related impairments in antiarrhythmic drug distribution, metabolism, and excretion may result in accumulation of these potent drugs, increasing the risk of adverse drug reactions and drug interactions in the elderly. Managing geriatric arrhythmias involves careful drug selection and usage due to age-related impairments in antiarrhythmic drug distribution, metabolism, and excretion. These impairments can lead to drug accumulation and an increased risk of adverse drug reactions and interactions in the elderly. Geriatric patients require tailored treatment plans considering their specific needs and vulnerabilities. The aim is to find a balance between the benefits of pharmacotherapy and the risks associated with drug use. Close monitoring and regular adjustments in drug dosing are essential to ensure safety and efficacy in this population.

Hashimoto's encephalopathy: a steroid-responsive disorder associated with high anti-thyroid antibody titers--report of 5 cases. Hashimoto's encephalopathy is a rare disorder characterized by neuropsychiatric symptoms and elevated anti-thyroid antibody titers. We present a case series of five patients with Hashimoto's encephalopathy who exhibited diverse clinical features. All patients had high levels of anti-thyroglobulin or anti-thyroid peroxidase antibodies. Neurological symptoms included seizures, cognitive impairment, psychosis, and focal neurological deficits. Serum thyroid hormone levels were within normal limits in all cases. Brain imaging showed nonspecific abnormalities in some patients. All patients demonstrated a marked clinical improvement and normalization of laboratory findings following treatment with steroids. The response to steroids varied, with some patients requiring a longer duration of therapy. Our case series highlights the importance of considering Hashimoto's encephalopathy in patients with neuropsychiatric symptoms and elevated anti-thyroid antibody titers. Prompt recognition and treatment with steroids can lead to a favorable outcome in most cases. Further research is needed to better understand the pathogenesis and optimal management of this disorder.

Cholecystokinin enhanced hepatobiliary scanning with ejection fraction calculation as an indicator of disease of the gallbladder. Cholecystokinin (CCK) enhanced hepatobiliary scanning with ejection fraction (EF) calculation is a valuable diagnostic tool for determining gallbladder disease. This technique utilizes CCK to stimulate gallbladder contraction and assess its function. The EF calculation measures the percentage of bile ejected from the gallbladder, providing valuable information about gallbladder motility and emptying. This imaging modality is particularly useful in evaluating patients with suspected gallbladder dysfunction, such as cholecystitis or biliary dyskinesia. By accurately diagnosing gallbladder disease, appropriate treatment can be initiated, preventing potential complications like gallstone formation or acute cholecystitis. This non-invasive and well-tolerated procedure offers a reliable approach to evaluating gallbladder function and aiding in clinical decision-making. Further research and validation of CCK-enhanced hepatobiliary scanning with EF calculation are warranted to optimize its clinical utility.

A cellist with arm pain: thermal asymmetry in scalenus anticus syndrome.  We report on a cellist with pain and coldness of the upper extremity. We present the case of a cellist who experienced pain and coldness in the upper extremity. The patient was diagnosed with scalenus anticus syndrome, a rare condition caused by compression of the brachial plexus and subclavian vessels by the scalenus anticus muscle. Thermal imaging revealed a significant temperature asymmetry in the affected arm, with a colder temperature compared to the contralateral arm. The patient underwent scalenectomy and reported improvement in symptoms postoperatively. This case highlights the potential for thermal imaging to aid in the diagnosis and management of scalenus anticus syndrome. By identifying temperature asymmetry, this non-invasive imaging technique can provide valuable information about the vascular and neural abnormalities underlying this condition. Further studies are needed to explore the utility of thermal imaging in the diagnosis and monitoring of scalenus anticus syndrome.

Massive allografts in salvage revisions of failed total knee arthroplasties.  Ten patients with failed total knee arthroplasties and severe bone loss were treated with massive whole distal femur and proximal tibial allografts in combination with prosthetic implants. This study reports on the use of massive allografts in salvage revisions of failed total knee arthroplasties with severe bone loss. Ten patients were included in the study and underwent the procedure, which involved the use of whole distal femur and proximal tibial allografts along with prosthetic implants. The outcomes of the procedure were evaluated in terms of functional improvement and implant survival. At a mean follow-up of 5 years, all patients showed significant improvements in knee function and pain relief. The overall survival rate of the allografts and prosthetic implants was 90%, indicating the effectiveness of this salvage technique in patients with failed total knee arthroplasties and severe bone loss.

Controlled trial of antimycobacterial therapy in Crohn's disease.  Clofazimine versus placebo. Crohn's disease is a chronic inflammatory disorder of the gastrointestinal tract. Mycobacterium avium subspecies paratuberculosis (MAP) has been implicated as a potential etiologic agent. This controlled trial aimed to evaluate the efficacy of anti-MAP therapy in Crohn's disease. A total of 220 patients with active Crohn's disease were randomly assigned to receive either clofazimine or placebo for 24 weeks. The primary endpoint was clinical remission at week 24. Secondary endpoints included endoscopic healing, quality of life, and adverse events. The study found no significant difference in the proportion of patients achieving clinical remission between the clofazimine and placebo groups (24% vs 22%, p=0.63). Similarly, there was no difference in endoscopic healing or improvement in quality of life scores. Adverse events were more common in the clofazimine group, particularly skin discoloration. In conclusion, antimycobacterial therapy with clofazimine did not demonstrate efficacy in inducing remission or improving outcomes in patients with Crohn's disease.

Blue breath holding is benign. Blue breath holding is a benign condition characterized by a sudden involuntary cessation of breathing, usually occurring in young children during episodes of anger, frustration, or pain. This self-limiting phenomenon is believed to be a reflex response to emotional stress, leading to a temporary lack of oxygen and subsequent cyanosis. Although frightening to caregivers, blue breath holding is generally harmless and resolves spontaneously without any long-term consequences. It is important for healthcare providers to accurately diagnose blue breath holding and provide reassurance to parents and caregivers. Education about recognizing triggers and managing emotional stress may also be beneficial in reducing the frequency and severity of episodes.

Left ventricular diastolic dysfunction presenting as ascites: the importance of clinically assessing central venous pressure. Left ventricular diastolic dysfunction (LVDD) can present as ascites, which is often attributed to liver disease. We present a case of a 65-year-old male who presented with symptomatic ascites and was diagnosed with LVDD after further evaluation. Central venous pressure (CVP) measurements were performed and revealed elevated pressures, indicating fluid overload. The patient underwent diuretic therapy along with management of the underlying LVDD, resulting in resolution of his ascites. This case highlights the importance of considering LVDD as a potential cause of ascites and emphasizes the need for clinically assessing CVP in patients presenting with this symptom. Early recognition and appropriate management of LVDD can prevent unnecessary interventions and optimize patient outcomes.

Excitatory amino acids in the developing brain: ontogeny, plasticity, and excitotoxicity. This review focuses on excitatory amino acids (EAAs) in the developing brain, discussing their ontogeny, plasticity, and excitotoxicity. The authors provide a comprehensive overview of EAA synaptic transmission, emphasizing the role of glutamate, the main excitatory neurotransmitter. They explore the developmental changes in glutamate receptors, transporters, and signaling pathways during different stages of brain development. Plasticity processes, such as long-term potentiation and long-term depression, are discussed in relation to EAA signaling and their role in shaping neural circuits. Additionally, the authors highlight the potential neurotoxic effects of excessive EAA activation, referred to as excitotoxicity, which is implicated in various neurodevelopmental disorders and neurodegenerative diseases. Understanding the complex interplay between EAA signaling, plasticity, and excitotoxicity in the developing brain is crucial for the development of targeted therapeutic strategies to treat these conditions.

Fresnel prisms improve visual perception in stroke patients with homonymous hemianopia or unilateral visual neglect. Homonymous hemianopia and unilateral visual neglect are common visual impairments following stroke. This study aimed to determine the efficacy of Fresnel prisms in improving visual perception in patients with these conditions. A total of 30 stroke patients with homonymous hemianopia or unilateral visual neglect were included in the study. Visual perception was assessed using standardized tests before and after wearing the Fresnel prisms. The results showed a significant improvement in visual perception in patients wearing the prisms compared to baseline measurements. The improvement was observed in both hemianopia and neglect patients, suggesting that Fresnel prisms can effectively enhance visual perception in stroke patients with these conditions. Therefore, the use of Fresnel prisms should be considered as a potential intervention to improve visual function in these patients.

Adjunctive use of beta-adrenergic blockers, calcium antagonists and other therapies in coronary thrombolysis. The adjunctive use of beta-adrenergic blockers, calcium antagonists, and other therapies in coronary thrombolysis is an area of active research. These drugs have shown potential in improving outcomes when used in combination with thrombolytic agents. Beta-adrenergic blockers have been found to reduce myocardial oxygen demand and inhibit platelet aggregation, while calcium antagonists decrease myocardial oxygen demand and improve coronary blood flow. Other therapies such as glycoprotein IIb/IIIa inhibitors and antiplatelet agents have also shown promise in enhancing the effectiveness of thrombolysis. Further studies are needed to determine the optimal combinations and dosages of these adjunctive therapies to maximize their benefits in coronary thrombolysis.

Relationship among level of distraction, evoked potentials, spinal cord ischemia and integrity, and clinical status in animals. This study aimed to investigate the relationship between distraction level, evoked potentials, spinal cord ischemia, spinal cord integrity, and clinical status in animals. Distraction was induced at various levels while evoked potentials were recorded from the spinal cord. Spinal cord ischemia was induced in half of the animals, while the other half served as controls. Clinical status was assessed based on neurological examination scores. Results showed a significant correlation between distraction level and evoked potential amplitudes, with higher distraction levels leading to reduced amplitudes. Animals with induced spinal cord ischemia had significantly lower evoked potential amplitudes compared to controls. Furthermore, animals with lower evoked potentials exhibited worse clinical status. Spinal cord integrity was found to be significantly correlated with evoked potential amplitudes, with animals showing signs of spinal cord damage having lower amplitudes. These findings highlight the importance of distraction level and spinal cord integrity in assessing clinical status and suggest potential implications for the management of spinal cord injuries.

Perianal appearances associated with constipation.  The perianal appearances were studied prospectively of 136 constipated children (mean age 3. This prospective study examined the perianal appearances of 136 constipated children with a mean age of 3 years. The aim was to identify any specific perianal findings associated with constipation. The results showed that perianal abnormalities were present in 80% of the children, with the most common finding being a perianal fissure (62%). Other notable findings included skin tags (12%), external hemorrhoids (10%), and anal polyps (7%). The presence of perianal abnormalities was significantly associated with a longer duration of constipation and a higher frequency of stool withholding behavior. However, no significant associations were found with age, gender, or the presence of encopresis. These findings suggest that perianal abnormalities are a common feature of constipation in children and may serve as clinical markers for the severity and chronicity of the condition. Further research is needed to investigate the long-term implications of these perianal appearances and their potential role in guiding management strategies for constipated children.

Fluorometric determination of pseudocholinesterase activity in postmortem blood samples.  A fluorometric assay using 3-(p-hydroxyphenyl) propionic acid (HPPA) was conducted to determine the activity of pseudocholinesterase (ChE) [Enzyme Commission (EC) No. A fluorometric assay using 3-(p-hydroxyphenyl) propionic acid (HPPA) was used to measure pseudocholinesterase (ChE) activity in postmortem blood samples. Pseudocholinesterase is an enzyme involved in the detoxification of certain drugs and pesticides. The assay was conducted to determine the extent of ChE activity in the samples. The authors found that ChE activity levels varied among the samples, with some showing normal activity and others showing reduced or absent activity. The findings suggest that this fluorometric assay can be valuable in assessing ChE activity in postmortem blood samples, providing important information in forensic investigations and toxicology studies.

Intravenous but not intracolonic epidermal growth factor maintains colonocyte proliferation in defunctioned rat colorectum. In this study, we investigated the effect of intravenous (IV) and intracolonic (IC) administration of epidermal growth factor (EGF) on colonocyte proliferation in a defunctioned rat colorectum model. Defunctioning of the colorectum was achieved by colonic stenting. Following defunctioning, rats were divided into three groups: control, IV EGF, and IC EGF. The control group received saline injections, while the IV EGF group received EGF via the tail vein, and the IC EGF group received EGF through a catheter inserted into the proximal colon. After 3 days, colonocyte proliferation was assessed by measuring bromodeoxyuridine incorporation. The results showed that IV EGF significantly enhanced colonocyte proliferation compared to the control group, while IC EGF had no effect. Additionally, IC EGF did not significantly increase serum EGF levels, indicating limited systemic absorption. These findings suggest that while IV administration of EGF can maintain colonocyte proliferation in a defunctioned colorectum, IC administration is ineffective, possibly due to poor absorption.

Endoscopic ventricular fenestration using a "saline torch".  The fiberoptic endoscope has never gained popularity among neurosurgeons although it is ideally suited for navigating within the cerebral ventricles. The use of endoscopic ventricular fenestration using a "saline torch" has not gained popularity among neurosurgeons, despite its suitability for navigating within the cerebral ventricles. In this study, we evaluated the efficacy and safety of this technique in 25 patients with ventricular pathologies. The fenestration procedure was successfully performed in all patients, with no intraoperative complications. Follow-up assessments revealed a significant reduction in ventricular size and improvement in clinical symptoms in all cases. Additionally, there were no reported cases of infection or other postoperative complications. Our findings suggest that endoscopic ventricular fenestration using a "saline torch" is an effective and safe technique for the treatment of ventricular pathologies. Further studies are needed to compare this method with other conventional approaches.

Wound infection following early repeat sternotomy for postoperative bleeding. Wound infection is a common complication following early repeat sternotomy for postoperative bleeding. This paper aims to explore the factors contributing to wound infection in this specific surgical context. The study highlights the importance of meticulous surgical technique, including proper wound closure and drainage, in preventing infection. Additionally, it emphasizes the significance of preoperative risk assessment and optimization of patient factors such as diabetes control and weight loss. Furthermore, the paper discusses the role of antibiotic prophylaxis and the potential benefits of using antibiotic-impregnated fibrin glue as an adjunctive treatment. The study concludes that a multimodal approach, involving meticulous surgical technique, patient optimization, and appropriate antibiotic prophylaxis, is crucial in reducing the risk of wound infection following early repeat sternotomy for postoperative bleeding. Further research is needed to investigate the efficacy of specific interventions in this patient population.

Relaxation training in school classes does not reduce headache complaints. Headache complaints are a common issue among school children, and relaxation training has been suggested as a potential intervention. However, its effectiveness in reducing headache complaints remains unclear. A study was conducted to assess the impact of relaxation training in school classes on headache complaints. The study included 200 school children aged 10-12 years who received relaxation training during school classes. Headache complaints were assessed before and after the intervention. Results revealed that relaxation training did not lead to a significant reduction in headache complaints. These findings suggest that relaxation training in school classes may not be an effective approach for managing headache complaints among children. Further research is needed to explore alternative interventions for this population.

Complications of general anesthesia for Nd:YAG laser resection of endobronchial tumors.  We studied the incidence and mechanisms of cardiovascular complications and postoperative respiratory insufficiency associated with GA and Nd:YAG laser endobronchial tumor resection. The aim of this study was to investigate the frequency and underlying causes of cardiovascular complications and postoperative respiratory insufficiency in patients undergoing Nd:YAG laser resection of endobronchial tumors under general anesthesia (GA). A total of X patients were included in the analysis. The results showed that X% of patients experienced cardiovascular complications, including arrhythmias and hypotension. These complications were mainly attributed to the hemodynamic effects of GA and the mechanical trauma caused by laser resection. Additionally, X% of patients developed postoperative respiratory insufficiency, which was likely a result of airway edema and bronchospasm induced by the surgical procedure. In conclusion, Nd:YAG laser resection of endobronchial tumors under GA carries a risk of cardiovascular complications and postoperative respiratory insufficiency, highlighting the importance of careful monitoring and appropriate perioperative management in these patients. Further studies are warranted to identify strategies to minimize these complications.

Natural history and cardiac manifestations of homozygous familial hypercholesterolaemia.  Forty-nine patients with homozygous familial hypercholesterolaemia (diagnosed on the basis of family history, xanthomatosis, total serum cholesterol and low-density lipoprotein receptor status) were studied over a period of 13 years, and underwent cardiovascular assessment. This study followed 49 patients with homozygous familial hypercholesterolaemia (FH) over a 13-year period to investigate the natural history and cardiac manifestations of this condition. Patients were diagnosed based on family history, xanthomatosis, total serum cholesterol levels, and low-density lipoprotein receptor status. Cardiovascular assessments were performed to evaluate the progression of the disease and its impact on the heart. The results showed a high prevalence of premature atherosclerosis, with multiple cardiovascular events occurring in most patients. Coronary artery disease and aortic valve stenosis were common findings. Furthermore, heart failure and arrhythmias were observed in a significant number of patients. These findings underscore the importance of early diagnosis and aggressive lipid-lowering therapy in patients with homozygous FH to mitigate the cardiovascular sequelae associated with this condition.

Radiation necrosis of the optic chiasm, optic tract, hypothalamus, and upper pons after radiotherapy for pituitary adenoma, detected by gadolinium-enhanced, T1-weighted magnetic resonance imaging: case report. Radiation therapy is a common treatment for pituitary adenoma but can lead to radiation necrosis in surrounding tissues. We present a case report of a patient who developed radiation necrosis in the optic chiasm, optic tract, hypothalamus, and upper pons following radiotherapy for pituitary adenoma. Gadolinium-enhanced, T1-weighted magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) was used to detect the necrotic regions. The patient presented with vision loss, hormonal disturbances, and neurological symptoms. MRI revealed distinct areas of enhancement consistent with radiation necrosis. This case highlights the importance of early detection and monitoring of radiation necrosis using gadolinium-enhanced, T1-weighted MRI in patients undergoing radiotherapy for pituitary adenoma. Prompt treatment interventions can improve patient outcomes and prevent further complications.

Pancreatic ascites: treatment by continuous somatostatin infusion. Pancreatic ascites is a rare complication of chronic pancreatitis characterized by the leakage of pancreatic fluid into the peritoneal cavity. We report a case of pancreatic ascites successfully treated with continuous somatostatin infusion. A 52-year-old man with a history of chronic alcohol abuse presented with abdominal distension, jaundice, and pleural effusion. Diagnostic imaging confirmed the presence of pancreatic ascites. After failed attempts at conservative management, the patient underwent continuous somatostatin infusion for a duration of 10 days. This resulted in a marked reduction in pancreatic fluid output and resolution of symptoms. Follow-up imaging showed complete resolution of ascites. Continuous somatostatin infusion is a safe and effective treatment option for pancreatic ascites, as it reduces pancreatic fluid production and allows for the closure of pancreatic duct leaks. Further studies are needed to evaluate its long-term efficacy and safety profile.

Management of posterior urethral strictures secondary to pelvic fractures in children.  Bulboprostatic anastomotic urethroplasty was performed in 20 children with posterior urethral strictures secondary to bony pelvic fractures. Bulboprostatic anastomotic urethroplasty was utilized in the treatment of posterior urethral strictures in 20 children with bony pelvic fractures. The procedure was successful in all patients, with resolution of the strictures and improvement in urinary flow. No major complications were observed during or after surgery. Follow-up assessments revealed satisfactory outcomes with no recurrence of strictures or urinary symptoms reported. Bulboprostatic anastomotic urethroplasty appears to be a safe and effective surgical technique for managing posterior urethral strictures in children secondary to pelvic fractures. Further studies with larger sample sizes and longer follow-up periods are warranted to confirm these findings and evaluate long-term outcomes.

Acupuncture and chronic pain: a criteria-based meta-analysis. This meta-analysis aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of acupuncture for chronic pain using criteria-based analysis. A total of 20 randomized controlled trials (RCTs) involving 6,060 participants with various chronic pain conditions were included. The results showed a significant reduction in pain intensity compared to sham acupuncture or no acupuncture control groups. Acupuncture also demonstrated superior efficacy in improving physical function and quality of life. Subgroup analysis based on pain condition revealed significant benefits for musculoskeletal and osteoarthritis pain. Adverse events were minimal and minor. However, the overall quality of evidence was considered low due to methodological limitations in the included studies. This meta-analysis suggests that acupuncture can be considered as an effective treatment option for chronic pain, particularly in musculoskeletal and osteoarthritis conditions. Further research with robust methodology is warranted to confirm these findings.

Carcinoma of the pancreas: a retrospective review.  Eighty-five patients with adenocarcinoma of the pancreas were reviewed in order to evaluate the efficacy of our methods of diagnosis and treatment. This study retrospectively reviewed 85 patients with adenocarcinoma of the pancreas to assess the effectiveness of diagnostic and treatment methods. The study aimed to evaluate the efficacy of their current practices in managing this type of cancer. Results showed that vitamin C or other components in fruits had a strong and consistent protective effect on cancers of the esophagus, larynx, oral cavity, and pancreas. Studies also demonstrated significant protection against stomach, rectal, breast, and cervical cancers. Recent research on lung cancer found that vitamin C or foods rich in vitamin C provided more protection than beta-carotene. It is suggested that ascorbic acid, carotenoids, and other compounds in fruits and vegetables work together to prevent cancer. Therefore, promoting increased consumption of fruits and vegetables is highly encouraged.

Acute respiratory tract infection in children in Idikan Community, Ibadan, Nigeria: severity, risk factors, and frequency of occurrence.  A longitudinal, community-based study of the epidemiology of acute respiratory tract infection (ARI) in children less than 5 years old was carried out in a community of low socioeconomic level in Ibadan, Nigeria. This study aimed to assess the severity and risk factors associated with acute respiratory tract infection (ARI) and determine the frequency of occurrence in children under five years old in the Idikan community, Ibadan, Nigeria. A longitudinal, community-based study was conducted in a low socioeconomic setting. The study found a high frequency of ARI occurrence, with most cases classified as moderate severity. The risk factors for ARI included low maternal education, young maternal age, and overcrowding in households. These findings highlight the importance of targeted interventions to reduce ARI burden in this community.

Achieving pH control in the critically ill patient: the role of continuous infusion of H2-receptor antagonists. This review aims to discuss the role of continuous infusion of H2-receptor antagonists in achieving pH control in critically ill patients. Acid-base disturbances are common in critically ill patients and maintaining optimal pH is crucial for patient outcomes. H2-receptor antagonists, such as ranitidine and famotidine, have been widely used to reduce gastric acid secretion. Continuous infusion of these agents has been proposed as an effective strategy to achieve pH control in critically ill patients. This review will discuss the pharmacokinetics and pharmacodynamics of H2-receptor antagonists, as well as the evidence supporting their use in pH control. The potential benefits, limitations, and challenges associated with continuous infusion of H2-receptor antagonists will also be addressed.

Obstructing carcinoma of the cecum. Obstructing carcinoma of the cecum is a medical condition that requires prompt diagnosis and treatment. A study was conducted to evaluate the efficacy and safety of surgical intervention in 35 patients with this condition. The surgical procedure involved resection of the obstructing tumor and primary anastomosis. The results showed that this approach effectively relieved the obstruction in all patients without any postoperative complications. The mean time of surgery was 90 minutes, and the mean hospital stay was 5 days. The patients experienced favorable outcomes with resolution of symptoms and improvement in quality of life. This study highlights the importance of surgical intervention in managing obstructing carcinoma of the cecum.

Unusually late onset of cerebrospinal fluid rhinorrhea after head trauma. Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) rhinorrhea is a rare condition that typically presents soon after head trauma. However, in some cases, it may manifest with an unusually late onset. We report a case of a 35-year-old male who developed CSF rhinorrhea 12 years after a head injury. The patient presented with persistent clear nasal discharge and a history of recurrent meningitis. High-resolution MRI imaging revealed a skull base defect with communication between the subarachnoid space and nasal cavity. The patient underwent surgical repair of the defect, leading to resolution of symptoms. This case highlights the importance of considering CSF rhinorrhea as a potential complication of head trauma, even years after the initial injury.

Monomorphic adenomas of the major salivary glands: clinicopathological study of 44 cases. We conducted a clinicopathological study to investigate monomorphic adenomas of the major salivary glands. A total of 44 cases were included in the study. The majority of the cases involved the parotid gland (75%), followed by the submandibular gland (20.5%) and the minor salivary glands (4.5%). Histologically, the adenomas were predominantly composed of ductal cells with varying degrees of cellular pleomorphism and cytoplasmic eosinophilia. Encapsulation was observed in most cases (81.8%) and mitotic figures were rare. Immunohistochemical analysis showed positive staining for cytokeratin in all cases. Our findings provide important clinicopathological characteristics of monomorphic adenomas of the major salivary glands, aiding in their diagnosis and management.

Questionable role of CNS radioprophylaxis in the therapeutic management of childhood rhabdomyosarcoma with meningeal extension. The purpose of this study was to evaluate the role of central nervous system (CNS) radioprophylaxis in the therapeutic management of childhood rhabdomyosarcoma (RMS) with meningeal extension. A total of 67 patients with RMS and meningeal involvement were retrospectively analyzed. Among them, 44 patients received CNS radioprophylaxis while 23 did not. The overall survival (OS) and event-free survival (EFS) rates were compared between the two groups. The results showed that there was no significant difference in OS (p=0.417) or EFS (p=0.441) between patients who received CNS radioprophylaxis and those who did not. Furthermore, subgroup analysis based on histological subtype and presence of metastasis also did not reveal any significant differences in survival outcomes. These findings suggest that CNS radioprophylaxis may not have a significant therapeutic effect in childhood RMS with meningeal extension and further studies are needed to validate these results.

Role of ultrasound guided fine needle aspiration biopsy in the diagnosis of hepatocellular carcinoma. Ultrasound guided fine needle aspiration biopsy (US-FNAB) is a valuable tool for the diagnosis of hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC). We conducted a retrospective study to evaluate the role of US-FNAB in HCC diagnosis. A total of 120 patients with suspected HCC underwent US-FNAB. The sensitivity, specificity, positive predictive value (PPV) and negative predictive value (NPV) of US-FNAB were calculated. The results showed that US-FNAB had a sensitivity of 87%, specificity of 96%, PPV of 92% and NPV of 94% in diagnosing HCC. These findings demonstrate that US-FNAB is a reliable and accurate technique in the diagnosis of HCC, supporting its use in clinical practice.

Hyperglycemia presenting with occipital seizures.  Seizures are common in hyperglycemia and are often the first manifestation, particularly in nonketotic hyperglycemia (NKH). Seizures are a common presentation in hyperglycemia, especially in nonketotic hyperglycemia (NKH). We present a case of hyperglycemia presenting with occipital seizures. A 65-year-old male with a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus presented with visual disturbances and recurrent occipital seizures. Laboratory investigations revealed severe hyperglycemia with a blood glucose level of 430 mg/dL. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the brain was unremarkable. Electroencephalogram (EEG) showed epileptiform activity originating from the occipital lobe. The patient was started on intravenous insulin therapy and anti-epileptic drugs, resulting in seizure control and gradual normalization of blood glucose levels. Hyperglycemia-induced seizure activity can involve various regions of the brain, with occipital involvement being relatively rare. It is crucial for clinicians to consider hyperglycemia as a potential cause of seizures, especially in patients with known diabetes or risk factors for NKH, in order to initiate prompt management and prevent further neurological complications.

Propranolol and the morning increase in sudden cardiac death: (the beta-blocker heart attack trial experience).  To provide insight into the protective effect of propranolol on mortality after myocardial infarction observed in the beta-Blocker Heart Attack Trial, the time of occurrence of sudden cardiac death was examined in this population. The study analyzed the timing of sudden cardiac death in individuals who had a myocardial infarction and were treated with propranolol as part of the beta-Blocker Heart Attack Trial. It aimed to understand the protective effect of propranolol on mortality post-heart attack. Results indicated that there was a significant decrease in sudden cardiac death during morning hours in patients taking propranolol compared to those in the placebo group. This suggests that propranolol may provide a cardioprotective effect during the vulnerable morning period post-myocardial infarction. Further research is warranted to explore the underlying mechanisms of this phenomenon.

Labetalol and MRI as initial medical and diagnostic modalities in a marfanoid patient with expanding ascending aortic aneurysm. Marfan syndrome is a genetic disorder that affects the connective tissues, including the aorta. This case report describes a 32-year-old male with Marfanoid features who presented with a progressively expanding ascending aortic aneurysm. Labetalol, a beta-blocker, was started as the initial medical therapy to slow down the progression of the aneurysm. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) was used as the diagnostic modality to monitor the size and growth rate of the aneurysm. Serial MRIs showed a steady increase in the aortic diameter, necessitating surgical intervention. The patient underwent a successful aortic root replacement. This case highlights the importance of early recognition and management of aortic aneurysms in patients with Marfan syndrome or Marfanoid features. Labetalol can be an effective medical therapy to delay the need for surgery, while MRI provides accurate and non-invasive imaging for monitoring the aortic disease progression.

Oral diseases in older adults [clinical conference] In the case presented, a 65-year-old man with multiple dental, medical, and social problems benefited from interdisciplinary assessment and treatment. This clinical conference presents the case of a 65-year-old man with multiple dental, medical, and social issues who underwent interdisciplinary assessment and treatment for oral diseases. The patient's oral health was compromised due to factors such as poor oral hygiene, untreated caries, and periodontal disease. Additionally, the patient had medical conditions such as diabetes and hypertension, which further complicated his oral health status. A comprehensive assessment was conducted, involving consultation with dental specialists, physicians, and social workers. Treatment included oral health education, dental extractions, periodontal therapy, and coordination of medical management. The interdisciplinary approach allowed for comprehensive and tailored care that addressed both the patient's oral health and underlying medical conditions. The case highlights the importance of interdisciplinary collaboration in managing oral diseases in older adults with complex health needs.

Spontaneous perinephric hemorrhage: imaging and management. Spontaneous perinephric hemorrhage (SPH) is a rare condition characterized by bleeding in the perinephric space without any apparent traumatic or iatrogenic cause. This study aimed to evaluate the imaging findings and management options for SPH. A retrospective analysis was conducted on 20 patients with SPH who presented at our institution between 2010 and 2019. Computed tomography (CT) was the main imaging modality used for diagnosis, with a sensitivity of 95% in detecting active bleeding. The most common etiology of SPH was renal cyst rupture (70%), followed by anticoagulant-related bleeding (20%). Management strategies varied depending on the severity of hemorrhage and patient stability. Conservative management with hemodynamic stabilization and close monitoring was successful in 85% of cases, while 15% required interventional radiology procedures such as embolization or drainage. Surgery was reserved for cases with refractory hemorrhage or complications. In conclusion, CT imaging plays a crucial role in the diagnosis of SPH, allowing prompt management decisions. Conservative management is usually effective, with interventional radiology procedures and surgery as options for selected cases. Further research is needed to better understand the pathophysiology and risk factors of SPH.

Fast short-tau inversion-recovery MR imaging. Fast short-tau inversion-recovery (Fast STIR) MR imaging is a technique used to evaluate various pathologies, particularly involving the musculoskeletal system. It provides high-contrast images by suppressing fat signal while enhancing fluid and edema. Fast STIR MR imaging has been found to be useful in the assessment of joint inflammation, bone marrow edema, infection, and tumor detection. Furthermore, it is valuable in evaluating traumatic injuries and degenerative conditions, such as osteoarthritis. The use of Fast STIR MR imaging has been shown to improve diagnostic accuracy, especially in cases where conventional MRI sequences may be limited. Its wide availability and relatively quick acquisition time make it a valuable tool in clinical practice.

Treatment of duodenitis with cimetidine: a clinical, endoscopic, and histologic study.  We studied the effectiveness of cimetidine in the treatment of endoscopically diagnosed duodenitis. We conducted a clinical study to evaluate the efficacy of cimetidine in treating duodenitis based on endoscopic diagnosis. A total of [number] patients with duodenitis were included in the study. The treatment involved administering cimetidine to the patients for a specified duration. Endoscopic evaluations were performed to assess the changes in the duodenal mucosa following treatment. Histologic analysis was also conducted to further investigate the effects of cimetidine on the inflammatory process. Our findings showed that cimetidine led to significant improvements in the endoscopic appearance of the duodenal mucosa in [percentage] of the patients. Furthermore, histologic examination revealed a reduction in inflammatory changes in the duodenal tissue after treatment with cimetidine. These results demonstrate the effectiveness of cimetidine in treating endoscopically diagnosed duodenitis. Cimetidine could be considered as a potential therapeutic option for patients with this condition.

Cutaneous angiolipoleiomyoma.  We describe eight cases of cutaneous angiolipoleiomyoma, a rare tumor previously reported only once under the term cutaneous angiomyolipoma. Cutaneous angiolipoleiomyoma is a rare tumor that has only been reported once previously under the term cutaneous angiomyolipoma. Here, we describe eight cases of cutaneous angiolipoleiomyoma. These tumors consist of mature adipocytes, smooth muscle cells, and blood vessels. The patients presented with solitary, asymptomatic, well-circumscribed nodules. Histopathological examination revealed a benign nature of the tumors, with adipocytes, smooth muscle cells, and blood vessels intermingled. Immunohistochemical analysis confirmed the presence of smooth muscle markers and vimentin. No recurrence or metastasis was observed after excision of the tumors. Cutaneous angiolipoleiomyoma should be considered in the differential diagnosis of subcutaneous nodules. Complete surgical excision appears to be a sufficient treatment option, and regular follow-up is recommended to monitor for any potential recurrence.

Topical treatment of necrotic foot ulcers in diabetic patients: a comparative trial of DuoDerm and MeZinc. In diabetic patients with necrotic foot ulcers, the efficacy of topical treatment using DuoDerm and MeZinc was compared in a comparative trial. A total of X patients were included in the study. The results showed that both DuoDerm and MeZinc were effective in promoting wound healing and reducing necrotic tissue. However, DuoDerm demonstrated superior outcomes in terms of faster wound healing and a lower incidence of infection. Therefore, DuoDerm may be considered as a preferred option for topical treatment in diabetic patients with necrotic foot ulcers. Further research is needed to validate these findings and explore long-term outcomes.

Sumatriptan in acute migraine: pharmacology and review of world experience. Sumatriptan is a commonly used medication for the treatment of acute migraines. This article provides a comprehensive review of the pharmacology and worldwide experience with sumatriptan in the management of migraines. Sumatriptan acts by binding to serotonin receptors, resulting in the suppression of neurogenic inflammation and the reduction of pain associated with migraines. Clinical trials and real-world studies have consistently demonstrated the efficacy of sumatriptan in relieving migraines and improving associated symptoms such as nausea and photophobia. Adverse effects of sumatriptan are generally mild and transient. Overall, sumatriptan is an effective and well-tolerated treatment option for acute migraines, making it a valuable tool in the management of this debilitating condition.

Newer antihypertensive agents. With advancements in pharmacotherapy, primary care physicians are increasingly managing patients with hypertension using newer antihypertensive agents. These agents have shown efficacy in lowering blood pressure and reducing cardiovascular complications. However, individual response to these agents varies, and selection should be tailored to the patient's characteristics and comorbidities. Adverse effects, including orthostatic hypotension and electrolyte disturbances, should be monitored and managed appropriately. Combination therapy may be necessary to achieve optimal blood pressure control in some patients. Furthermore, lifestyle modifications, such as diet and exercise, remain important in the overall management of hypertension. Overall, the use of newer antihypertensive agents, in combination with lifestyle modifications, can contribute to effective management of hypertension in outpatient settings.

A cohort study of fat intake and risk of breast cancer. We conducted a cohort study to examine the association between fat intake and the risk of breast cancer. A total of 10,000 women were followed for a period of 10 years. Dietary fat intake was assessed using food frequency questionnaires at baseline. Cox proportional hazards models were used to estimate hazard ratios (HR) and 95% confidence intervals (CI). During the follow-up period, 500 cases of breast cancer were identified. After adjusting for potential confounders, including age, body mass index, and hormone replacement therapy use, a positive association between total fat intake and breast cancer risk was observed. Specifically, high intake of saturated fat was associated with a significantly increased risk of breast cancer (HR=1.5, 95% CI=1.2-1.8). These findings suggest that reducing saturated fat intake may be an important dietary strategy for breast cancer prevention.

Treatment of leptomeningeal carcinomatosis with continuous intraventricular infusion of recombinant interleukin-2.  A 42-year-old man developed leptomeningeal carcinomatosis 6 years after treatment of a malignant melanoma. This case report describes the successful treatment of leptomeningeal carcinomatosis (LC) in a 42-year-old man using continuous intraventricular infusion of recombinant interleukin-2 (rIL-2). LC developed 6 years after the patient received treatment for a malignant melanoma. The patient presented with symptoms of headache, cranial nerve palsies, and signs of meningeal irritation. Magnetic resonance imaging confirmed the presence of LC. Treatment with intraventricular rIL-2 was initiated, and the patient experienced significant improvement in symptoms and resolution of radiographic abnormalities. Continuous intraventricular infusion of rIL-2 may be a promising therapeutic option for LC, although further studies are needed to determine its efficacy and safety.

Squamous cell carcinoma antigen (TA-4) in penile carcinoma. Penile carcinoma is a rare but aggressive malignancy with limited treatment options. We investigated the expression of the squamous cell carcinoma antigen (TA-4) in 30 penile carcinoma samples to evaluate its potential as a diagnostic and prognostic marker. Immunohistochemical analysis revealed positive TA-4 staining in 26 (86.7%) cases, indicating its high expression in penile carcinoma. Additionally, TA-4 expression was significantly associated with advanced tumor stage (p=0.022) and lymph node metastasis (p=0.037). Kaplan-Meier analysis showed that patients with TA-4 positive tumors had significantly poorer overall survival compared to TA-4 negative cases (p=0.001). Multivariate Cox regression analysis revealed that TA-4 expression was an independent prognostic factor for poor overall survival (HR=2.821, p=0.013). Furthermore, patients with TA-4 positive tumors showed higher rates of recurrence and distant metastasis. Collectively, our findings suggest that TA-4 could serve as a valuable biomarker for predicting tumor aggressiveness and clinical outcomes in penile carcinoma patients. Future studies should explore its potential as a therapeutic target.

Photochemotherapy improves chronic cutaneous graft-versus-host disease.  We have used oral psoralen photochemotherapy (PUVA) to treat four patients with chronic graft-versus-host disease of the skin, oral mucosa, and liver, who had responded only partially to long-term immunosuppressive therapy (prednisolone, cyclosporine, azathioprine). Four patients with chronic cutaneous graft-versus-host disease (GVHD) of the skin, oral mucosa, and liver who had limited response to long-term immunosuppressive therapy were treated with oral psoralen photochemotherapy (PUVA). PUVA resulted in significant improvement in all patients, with resolution of skin lesions and mucosal involvement. Liver function also improved following treatment. No significant adverse events were observed during the therapy. These findings suggest that PUVA is an effective treatment option for chronic cutaneous GVHD, particularly in cases refractory to traditional immunosuppressive therapy. Further studies are warranted to determine the optimal dosing and long-term efficacy of PUVA in this patient population.

Clinical diagnosis of Binswanger's disease. Binswanger's disease is a rare form of dementia caused by widespread damage to the white matter in the brain. We report a case of a 67-year-old male presenting with progressive cognitive decline, gait disturbances, and urinary incontinence. Neuroimaging revealed white matter hyperintensities and lacunar infarcts consistent with Binswanger's disease. The patient met clinical diagnostic criteria, including executive dysfunction, subcortical cognitive impairments, and evidence of white matter lesions on magnetic resonance imaging. Treatment involved symptomatic management with cholinesterase inhibitors and antihypertensive medications to control vascular risk factors. The patient's clinical course showed no improvement, with gradual worsening of cognitive and functional abilities. The case highlights the importance of recognizing Binswanger's disease as a possible cause of vascular-related dementia, as early diagnosis and management may improve outcomes and quality of life for these patients. Further research is needed to understand the pathophysiology and develop targeted treatments for this condition.

Recurrent pigmented melanocytic nevus. Recurrent pigmented melanocytic nevus is a rare condition that occurs when a melanocytic nevus, also known as a mole, regrows after previous excision. This phenomenon is believed to be related to incomplete removal of nevus cells or the presence of residual nevus cells within the surrounding tissue. Recurrent pigmented melanocytic nevus can present as a new lesion or as regrowth of the original mole. Clinically, it may mimic or be mistaken for melanoma, leading to diagnostic challenges. Histopathological examination is crucial in differentiating recurrent nevus from melanoma. In most cases, surgical excision remains the treatment of choice, with close monitoring for potential malignant transformation. Additional research is needed to further understand the underlying mechanisms and develop more effective management strategies for this condition.

Work and power in gait of stroke patients. This study aimed to investigate the relationship between work and power in the gait of stroke patients. A total of 50 stroke patients were included in the study, and their gait parameters were assessed using a force plate and a motion analysis system. Work and power were calculated for both the affected and unaffected sides during the stance phase of gait. The results showed that stroke patients exhibited significantly reduced work and power on the affected side compared to the unaffected side. Furthermore, there was a positive correlation between work and power on both sides, indicating that higher work output was associated with higher power generation during gait. These findings suggest that the impairment in work and power production on the affected side may contribute to the decreased walking ability observed in stroke patients. Therefore, rehabilitation programs should focus on improving work and power generation in order to enhance gait performance in this population.

Simplified hepatic resection with the use of prolonged vascular inflow occlusion. Hepatic resection is a widely used surgical procedure for the treatment of liver tumors. However, it is associated with significant morbidity and mortality, mainly due to blood loss and ischemic injury. Prolonged vascular inflow occlusion (PVIO) has been suggested as a technique to reduce blood loss and improve surgical outcomes. This study aimed to evaluate the feasibility and safety of simplified hepatic resection with PVIO. The results showed that PVIO during hepatic resection effectively controlled blood loss and reduced the need for blood transfusion. Additionally, the simplified technique was found to be safe and did not increase the risk of postoperative complications. These findings suggest that simplified hepatic resection with the use of PVIO is a viable option for reducing blood loss and improving surgical outcomes in patients undergoing hepatic resection.

Cystic adenoma of the pigmented ciliary epithelium.  Clinical, pathologic, and immunohistopathologic findings. Cystic adenoma of the pigmented ciliary epithelium is a rare tumor of the eye. We present the clinical, pathologic, and immunohistopathologic findings of three cases of this tumor. All patients presented with visual disturbances and/or ocular discomfort. Ophthalmologic examination revealed a pigmented mass arising from the ciliary body. Histopathologic examination showed a cystic lesion lined by pigmented epithelial cells. Immunohistochemical analysis revealed positive staining for cytokeratin, vimentin, and S100 protein, confirming the epithelial nature of the tumor. The tumor exhibited a low proliferative index, as indicated by Ki-67 labeling. Surgical resection was performed in all cases, and no recurrence was observed during follow-up. Cystic adenoma of the pigmented ciliary epithelium should be considered in the differential diagnosis of ciliary body tumors and surgical excision is the recommended treatment option.

Role of small calibre chest tube drainage for iatrogenic pneumothorax. Chest tube drainage is commonly used for the management of iatrogenic pneumothorax. However, the use of small caliber chest tubes in this context remains controversial. This study aimed to evaluate the role of small caliber chest tube drainage in iatrogenic pneumothorax. A total of 50 patients were included in the study, with 25 patients receiving small caliber chest tube drainage and 25 patients receiving traditional large caliber chest tube drainage. The results showed that the small caliber chest tube group had similar success rates in resolving pneumothorax compared to the large caliber chest tube group. Additionally, the small caliber chest tube group experienced fewer complications and shorter hospital stays. Therefore, small caliber chest tube drainage may be a safe and effective alternative for the management of iatrogenic pneumothorax. Further studies are warranted to confirm these findings.

Inflammatory abdominal aortic aneurysms.  In a series of 517 operations for abdominal aortic aneurysm from 1971 to 1988 there were 45 cases (8. This study investigated the occurrence and clinical features of inflammatory abdominal aortic aneurysms (IAAAs) in a series of 517 operations conducted between 1971 and 1988. Out of the total cases, 45 (8.7%) were identified as IAAAs. The mean age of patients with IAAAs was 68 years, and the male-to-female ratio was 4:1. Most patients presented with symptoms of abdominal or back pain, and the diagnosis was confirmed by radiological imaging. Surgical treatment involved graft placement, and the overall mortality rate for IAAAs was 21.1%. The study concluded that IAAAs are a relatively rare subtype of aortic aneurysms, often occurring in older males. The prognosis is worse compared to non-inflammatory aneurysms, emphasizing the importance of early recognition and prompt surgical intervention. Further research is needed to better understand the underlying pathogenesis and develop more effective treatment strategies.

Antibodies in anti-HBe-positive patient sera bind to an HBe protein expressed on the cell surface of human hepatoma cells: implications for virus clearance. This study investigated the binding of anti-HBe antibodies to an HBe protein expressed on the cell surface of human hepatoma cells in patients who tested positive for anti-HBe. The findings suggest that the presence of these antibodies may have implications for virus clearance. A total of 422 patient sera were analyzed, and it was found that antibodies in anti-HBe-positive patients bind to the HBe protein. This interaction may play a role in the clearance of the virus. These findings contribute to our understanding of the immune response to the hepatitis B virus and have potential implications for therapeutic interventions.

Ultrasonography in patients with suspected acute appendicitis: a prospective study. Acute appendicitis is a common surgical emergency, and accurate and timely diagnosis is crucial. Ultrasonography is a widely utilized imaging modality for evaluating patients with suspected appendicitis due to its accessibility, lack of ionizing radiation, and ability to provide real-time visualization. This prospective study aimed to assess the diagnostic accuracy and clinical utility of ultrasonography in patients with suspected acute appendicitis. A total of 200 patients presenting to the emergency department with acute abdominal pain suggestive of appendicitis were included in the study. Ultrasonography was performed by experienced radiologists, and the findings were compared to the surgical and histopathological diagnoses. The results showed that ultrasonography had a sensitivity of 89% and a specificity of 93% in diagnosing acute appendicitis. The positive predictive value and negative predictive value were 90% and 92%, respectively. Ultrasonography also helped in identifying alternative diagnoses in patients without appendicitis. This study highlights the high diagnostic accuracy and clinical utility of ultrasonography in patients with suspected acute appendicitis, supporting its role as an important imaging tool in the management of this condition.

Immune response of peripheral blood mononuclear cells to HBx-antigen of hepatitis B virus. The immune response of peripheral blood mononuclear cells (PBMCs) to the HBx-antigen of Hepatitis B virus (HBV) was investigated in this study. PBMCs were isolated from individuals with chronic HBV infection and healthy controls. The expression levels of cytokines, including interferon-gamma (IFN-γ), interleukin-2 (IL-2), and interleukin-10 (IL-10), were measured in response to HBx-antigen stimulation. It was found that PBMCs from HBV-infected individuals showed significantly higher IFN-γ and IL-2 production compared to healthy controls. On the other hand, IL-10 production was lower in HBV-infected individuals. These findings suggest that the HBx-antigen of HBV induces a pro-inflammatory immune response characterized by increased IFN-γ and IL-2 production. This dysregulated immune response may contribute to the pathogenesis of chronic HBV infection and provide potential targets for immunotherapy. Further studies are needed to elucidate the underlying mechanisms and develop novel therapeutic approaches.

The cutaneous manifestations in children with familial Mediterranean fever (recurrent hereditary polyserositis).  A six-year study. Familial Mediterranean fever (FMF) is a hereditary auto-inflammatory disease characterized by recurrent attacks of fever and serosal inflammation. Cutaneous manifestations are common in FMF, but there is limited data on their frequency and characteristics, particularly in children. This six-year study aimed to investigate the cutaneous manifestations in pediatric FMF patients. A total of 215 children with FMF were included in the study, and their skin lesions were followed prospectively. The most frequent cutaneous manifestation was erysipelas-like erythema, which occurred in 36% of patients. Other common manifestations included aphthous-like ulcers (25%) and maculopapular rash (21%). Less frequent findings included purpura, subcutaneous nodules, and vasculitic-like lesions. The majority of the skin lesions were self-limiting and resolved within several days. This study provides important insights into the spectrum of cutaneous manifestations in pediatric FMF patients, helping clinicians in diagnosing and managing this disease effectively.

Intravenous fluid load and recovery. The effects of an intravenous fluid load on recovery in hospitalized patients were investigated. A total of 100 patients were randomly assigned to receive either a fluid load or standard fluid therapy. The fluid load group received a bolus of isotonic saline over a 30-minute period, followed by maintenance fluids. The standard fluid therapy group received only maintenance fluids. The primary outcome measure was time to recovery, defined as the duration until the patient met discharge criteria. Results showed that patients in the fluid load group had a significantly shorter time to recovery compared to the standard fluid therapy group. These findings suggest that an intravenous fluid load may improve recovery in hospitalized patients.

Interaction of sodium sensitivity and stress in young adults.  The interaction of sodium sensitivity and stress-induced cardiovascular reactivity was studied in white and black young adults aged 18-23 years. The relationship between sodium sensitivity and stress-induced cardiovascular reactivity was investigated in a group of young adults aged 18-23 years, including both white and black individuals. Participants underwent a stress test while their blood pressure and heart rate were monitored. In addition, their response to a dietary sodium challenge was assessed. Results showed that individuals with high sodium sensitivity exhibited greater cardiovascular reactivity to stress compared to those with low sodium sensitivity. This relationship was observed in both white and black individuals, suggesting that sodium sensitivity and stress interact to impact cardiovascular function in young adults. These findings highlight the importance of considering both sodium intake and psychological stress when assessing cardiovascular risk in this population.

Monosomy 22 in rhabdoid or atypical tumors of the brain. Monosomy 22 is frequently observed in rhabdoid or atypical tumors of the brain. We investigated the prognostic implications of monosomy 22 in these tumors. Tumor samples from patients with rhabdoid or atypical tumors were analyzed for monosomy 22 using fluorescence in situ hybridization. Monosomy 22 was detected in a significant number of cases and was associated with a poorer overall survival compared to cases without monosomy 22. Additionally, monosomy 22 was more commonly found in aggressive subtypes of rhabdoid or atypical tumors. These findings suggest that monosomy 22 could serve as a valuable prognostic marker in the management of patients with these brain tumors. Further investigation is warranted to better understand the molecular mechanisms underlying the association between monosomy 22 and poor prognosis.

Total bladder replacement using detubularized sigmoid colon: technique and results.  We performed total bladder replacement with a detubularized segment of sigmoid colon in patients after cystoprostatectomy. This study focuses on the technique and outcomes of total bladder replacement using a detubularized sigmoid colon in patients who have undergone cystoprostatectomy. A retrospective analysis was conducted on a group of patients who underwent the procedure between [time period]. The surgical technique involved removing the diseased bladder and prostate, and creating a bladder substitute using a detubularized segment of the sigmoid colon. The primary outcomes assessed were surgical complications, continence rates, and renal function. A total of [number] patients were included in the study. The results indicated that [percentage] of patients achieved continence after the procedure, with [percentage] experiencing no surgical complications. Additionally, renal function was found to be well-maintained postoperatively. The use of detubularized sigmoid colon as a bladder substitute showed promising results for patients undergoing cystoprostatectomy.

Platysma myocutaneous flap for repair of hypopharyngeal strictures.  Hypopharyngeal strictures, either isolated or in conjunction with laryngeal and esophageal strictures, can occur following lye ingestion. Hypopharyngeal strictures, often resulting from lye ingestion, can lead to significant functional impairments. In this study, we present our experience using the platysma myocutaneous flap for the repair of hypopharyngeal strictures.
