A total of 17 patients with hypopharyngeal strictures, with or without associated laryngeal and esophageal strictures, underwent surgical repair using this technique. The surgical procedure involved using the platysma myocutaneous flap to reconstruct the strictured hypopharyngeal segment. The overall success rate of the procedure was 82.4%, with only 3 patients experiencing recurrence of the stricture. No major complications related to the flap were encountered. The platysma myocutaneous flap is a reliable and effective surgical option for the repair of hypopharyngeal strictures, offering good functional outcomes with low complication rates.

Radiographic techniques and efficacy in evaluating esophageal dysphagia. Radiographic techniques are commonly used to evaluate esophageal dysphagia, but the efficacy of these techniques remains unclear. This study aimed to assess the effectiveness of various radiographic methods in diagnosing and determining the severity of esophageal dysphagia. Forty-eight patients with symptoms of dysphagia underwent barium swallow studies, esophagram, and videofluoroscopic swallowing studies. The results were compared to findings from endoscopic evaluations and manometric studies. The overall accuracy, sensitivity, and specificity of each technique were determined. The results showed that videofluoroscopic swallowing studies had the highest overall accuracy (87.5%), sensitivity (93.3%), and specificity (75.0%) compared to barium swallow studies and esophagram. The study highlights the importance of videofluoroscopic swallowing studies in diagnosing and assessing the severity of esophageal dysphagia. Further research is needed to validate these findings and explore the potential of new imaging techniques in this field.

Complications associated with limb salvage for extremity sarcomas and their management.  A retrospective clinical review of 100 consecutive patients with extremity sarcomas managed by limb salvage operations was performed to evaluate local tumor control and morbidity. A retrospective clinical review of 100 patients with extremity sarcomas who underwent limb salvage operations was conducted to assess local tumor control and complications. The study found that limb salvage operations had a successful tumor control rate. However, complications were observed in a significant number of patients, including infection, wound healing issues, and nerve damage. These complications were managed using various strategies, such as antibiotics, wound care, and physical therapy. This study highlights the importance of careful monitoring and appropriate management of complications in patients undergoing limb salvage operations for extremity sarcomas.

Effect of motilin on gastric emptying in patients with diabetic gastroparesis. This study aimed to investigate the effect of motilin on gastric emptying in patients with diabetic gastroparesis. Twelve patients diagnosed with diabetic gastroparesis participated in the study. Each patient underwent a standardized solid meal gastric emptying study using scintigraphy. After an initial baseline study, patients received intravenous motilin or saline in a randomized, double-blind crossover design. Gastric emptying was assessed by measuring the half-emptying time (T1/2) and calculating the gastric emptying coefficient (GEC). Results showed that motilin significantly accelerated gastric emptying compared to saline, as evidenced by a decrease in T1/2 and an increase in GEC. Subgroup analysis showed that patients with more severe gastroparesis tended to have a greater response to motilin. No significant adverse effects were observed during or after motilin administration. These findings suggest that motilin may be a potential therapeutic option for improving gastric emptying in patients with diabetic gastroparesis. Further research is needed to explore the optimal dosage and long-term effects of motilin in this patient population.

Malignant potential of juvenile polyposis coli. Juvenile polyposis coli (JPC) is a rare inherited disorder characterized by the development of multiple polyps in the gastrointestinal tract. Although most JPC cases are benign, there is a potential for malignant transformation of these polyps. A retrospective study of 102 patients with JPC found that 8% of patients developed colorectal cancer. The mean age of patients at cancer diagnosis was 45 years. Risk factors for malignant transformation included a family history of colorectal cancer and the presence of adenomatous changes in the polyps. Regular surveillance colonoscopy is recommended for individuals with JPC to detect and intervene early in cases of malignancy.

Immune-competent cells of regional lymph nodes in colorectal cancer patients: II. This study focuses on the analysis of immune-competent cells in regional lymph nodes of colorectal cancer patients. In a previous study, the authors found a decrease in the number and activity of immune-competent cells in the lymph nodes. In this follow-up study, immunohistochemical analysis was performed to investigate the presence and distribution of T cells, B cells, macrophages, and dendritic cells in the lymph nodes. It was found that the numbers of T cells and dendritic cells were significantly higher in lymph nodes with tumor invasion, compared to those without invasion. B cell numbers were higher in lymph nodes without invasion. Additionally, the authors observed an increase in the expression of inhibitory molecules in immune-competent cells within metastatic lymph nodes. These findings provide further insight into the immune response within regional lymph nodes in colorectal cancer patients, and may have implications for immune-based therapies in the future.

Disruption of the human SCL locus by "illegitimate" V-(D)-J recombinase activity. The SCL gene, which plays a crucial role in hematopoiesis, is frequently disrupted in T-cell acute lymphoblastic leukemia (T-ALL). This study aimed to investigate the mechanism behind SCL gene disruption. In situ hybridization and immunohistochemical analysis were performed on T-ALL samples to identify the presence of recombinase activity. Results showed evidence of "illegitimate" V-(D)-J recombinase activity at the SCL locus. This abnormal recombination was associated with the loss of SCL gene function. The findings suggest that illegitimate V-(D)-J recombinase activity is a contributing factor in the development of T-ALL by disrupting the SCL locus. Further research is needed to better understand the underlying mechanisms and potential therapeutic targets.

Orchiectomy versus oestrogen in the treatment of advanced prostatic cancer. This study aims to compare the efficacy of orchiectomy and estrogen therapy in the management of advanced prostatic cancer. A retrospective analysis was performed on a cohort of 100 patients with advanced prostatic cancer who received either orchiectomy or estrogen therapy as primary treatment. The median overall survival was found to be significantly higher in the orchiectomy group (45 months) compared to the estrogen group (30 months). Furthermore, patients in the orchiectomy group had a higher rate of disease control and a lower rate of disease progression compared to the estrogen group. These findings suggest that orchiectomy may be a more effective treatment option for advanced prostatic cancer compared to estrogen therapy. Further prospective studies are warranted to validate these findings.

Blood flow direction in the lumbar nerve root. Understanding the blood flow direction in the lumbar nerve root is crucial for diagnosing and managing various spinal pathologies. In this study, we investigated the blood flow direction in the lumbar nerve root using color Doppler ultrasonography in 50 healthy volunteers. Our findings revealed a consistent blood flow pattern in the lumbar nerve root, with blood flow direction predominantly anterograde. Additionally, we observed a small percentage of cases with retrograde blood flow, suggesting a possible variation in blood flow dynamics within the lumbar nerve root. These findings contribute to our understanding of the vascular physiology of the lumbar spine and may have implications for the development of targeted interventions for spinal pathologies involving the lumbar nerve root.

Murine mast cells synthesize basement membrane components. Mast cells, known for their role in allergic reactions, have been found to synthesize basement membrane components in mice. Our study aimed to investigate the presence and function of mast cells in the production of basement membrane components. We utilized immunofluorescence staining and confocal microscopy to detect the presence of mast cells and examined their expression of key basement membrane proteins, such as laminin and collagen IV. Results showed that mast cells in murine tissues, including the skin and intestine, exhibited strong immunoreactivity for basement membrane components. Furthermore, we confirmed the synthesis of these components by mast cells through in vitro experiments, wherein mast cells were observed to secrete laminin and collagen IV. These findings suggest that mast cells play a previously unrecognized role in basement membrane synthesis and remodeling, highlighting their potential contribution to tissue homeostasis and repair.

The role of fistulography in fistula-in-ano. Fistulography is a diagnostic procedure used in the evaluation of fistula-in-ano, a common condition characterized by abnormal tracts connecting the anal canal to the perianal area. This study aimed to examine the role of fistulography in the management of fistula-in-ano. A retrospective analysis was performed on patients who underwent fistulography followed by surgical intervention. Fistulography accurately depicted the anatomy of the fistula tract in the majority of cases, providing valuable information for surgical planning. In addition, fistulography enabled visualization of associated abscesses or anatomical variations that could impact surgical approach. The findings from this study suggest that fistulography is a useful tool in the management of fistula-in-ano, aiding in accurate diagnosis and guiding appropriate surgical management. Further prospective studies are warranted to validate these findings and determine the optimal role of fistulography in the management of this condition.

The axilla: not a no-go zone Many surgeons, particularly in the UK, give inadequate primary treatment to patients with operable breast cancer. Inadequate primary treatment of operable breast cancer patients by UK surgeons is a concern. The axilla, a region historically considered a no-go zone due to fears of increased morbidity, is often not properly examined for lymph node involvement. This study aimed to evaluate the impact of axillary examination on patient outcomes. A total of 583 patients with operable breast cancer were included in the analysis. Results showed that inadequate primary treatment was given to 198 patients, with only 58% receiving proper axillary examination. Lymph node involvement was found in 24% of cases. Overall, the study highlights the need for improved education and training among surgeons to ensure proper assessment of the axilla in order to provide adequate primary treatment for operable breast cancer patients.

Primary intratemporal tumours of the facial nerve: diagnosis and treatment. Primary intratemporal tumors of the facial nerve are rare and their diagnosis and treatment can be challenging. We present a case series of 12 patients with primary intratemporal tumors of the facial nerve. The most common presenting symptom was facial weakness, followed by facial pain and hearing loss. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) was found to be the most useful diagnostic modality. Surgical excision was the mainstay of treatment, with facial nerve preservation as the primary goal. Facial nerve function improved in the majority of cases, although complete recovery was achieved in only a few patients. Adjuvant radiation therapy was given in select cases. In conclusion, early diagnosis and prompt surgical intervention are crucial for optimizing outcomes in patients with primary intratemporal tumors of the facial nerve.

Adult T-cell leukaemia/lymphoma in Brazil and its relation to HTLV-I In a series of fourteen patients with adult T-cell lymphoma-leukaemia (ATLL) in Brazil the main features were lymphadenopathy, hepatosplenomegaly, hypercalcaemia, and high leucocyte counts, with abnormal lymphoid cells which had irregular nuclei. This study examines the characteristics and relationship of adult T-cell lymphoma-leukemia (ATLL) with HTLV-I in Brazil. The study includes 14 patients with ATLL who exhibited lymphadenopathy, hepatosplenomegaly, hypercalcemia, and high leukocyte counts. The lymphoid cells of these patients had irregular nuclei. The findings suggest a strong association between ATLL and HTLV-I in Brazil. Further research is needed to understand the underlying mechanisms and develop effective management strategies for ATLL. The results of this study contribute to the existing knowledge on the epidemiology and clinical presentation of ATLL in Brazil, aiding in better diagnosis and treatment of this disease.

Second cancer after radiation therapy for cancer of the uterine cervix.  Radiation-induced cancers after radiation therapy for cancer of the uterine cervix were investigated on 11,855 patients including 5725 patients treated with radiation therapy alone, 1969 postoperative radiation therapy and 4161 surgery alone. We conducted a study to investigate the occurrence of second cancers following radiation therapy for cancer of the uterine cervix. The study cohort comprised 11,855 patients, including 5,725 who received radiation therapy alone, 1,969 who had postoperative radiation therapy, and 4,161 who underwent surgery alone. After a median follow-up of 10 years, a total of 674 second cancers were identified. The incidence of second cancers was significantly higher in the radiation therapy alone group compared to the surgery alone group (p<0.001). The most common second cancer sites were the bladder, rectum, and bones. Furthermore, the risk of developing a second cancer increased with longer time since radiation therapy. These findings highlight the importance of long-term cancer surveillance in patients treated with radiation therapy for uterine cervical cancer.

Triggers of transient myocardial ischemia: circadian variation and relation to plaque rupture and coronary thrombosis in stable coronary artery disease. Transient myocardial ischemia is a common occurrence in patients with stable coronary artery disease (CAD). This study aimed to investigate the triggers of transient myocardial ischemia and their relation to plaque rupture and coronary thrombosis. Circadian variation in ischemic events was observed, with a peak incidence in the early morning hours. Plaque rupture was found to be the most common trigger of transient myocardial ischemia, followed by coronary thrombosis. These findings highlight the importance of identifying and managing these triggers to prevent ischemic events in patients with stable CAD. Further research is needed to determine optimal treatment strategies for reducing the risk of recurrent ischemia.

Rib infarcts and acute chest syndrome in sickle cell diseases. Rib infarcts and acute chest syndrome (ACS) are well-recognized complications of sickle cell disease (SCD). However, the relationship between rib infarcts and ACS remains poorly understood. We present the case of a 24-year-old male with SCD who presented with severe chest pain and dyspnea. Imaging revealed multiple rib infarcts and evidence of ACS. Rib infarcts are thought to result from vaso-occlusion in the ribs, leading to ischemia and infarction. The development of ACS, characterized by chest pain, dyspnea, and pulmonary infiltrates, is believed to be a consequence of underlying vaso-occlusive processes and resulting lung injury. The association between rib infarcts and ACS suggests a common pathophysiology involving vaso-occlusion and tissue ischemia. Further research is needed to elucidate the mechanisms underlying rib infarcts and their contribution to the development of ACS in SCD. Increased awareness of this association may aid in early recognition and management of these potentially severe complications.

Risk factors for transmission of hepatitis B virus to Gambian children [published erratum appears in Lancet 1990 Dec 22-29;336(8730):1596] Risk factors for hepatitis B virus transmission were examined in 973 Gambian children aged 6 months to 5 years. We examined risk factors for hepatitis B virus (HBV) transmission in 973 Gambian children aged 6 months to 5 years. Blood samples were tested for HBV markers, and household information was collected through interviews. The prevalence of HBV infection was 9.9%, with higher rates in older children and those with multiple household contacts. Maternal HBV infection, home births, and traditional scarification were also associated with increased transmission. These findings suggest the need for targeted prevention strategies, including vaccination of infants and education on safe delivery practices, to reduce HBV transmission in this population.

Cerebral infarction: early detection by means of contrast-enhanced cerebral arteries at MR imaging. Early detection of cerebral infarction is crucial for prompt treatment and improved patient outcomes. This study aimed to evaluate the role of contrast-enhanced cerebral arteries at MR imaging in the early detection of cerebral infarction. A total of 100 patients with suspected acute ischemic stroke were included in the study. All patients underwent MR imaging with contrast enhancement. The presence of cerebral infarction was identified based on signal intensity changes and abnormal vessel wall enhancement in the affected arteries. The results showed that contrast-enhanced MR imaging had a high sensitivity and specificity in detecting cerebral infarction, with a sensitivity of 92% and specificity of 98%. The use of contrast-enhanced MR imaging can aid in early detection of cerebral infarction, allowing for timely intervention and better patient outcomes.

Modified anterior compartment resection. Modified anterior compartment resection is a surgical technique used in the treatment of certain tumors or conditions involving the anterior compartment of the body. This technique involves the removal of a specific compartment or portion of a compartment to achieve better tumor control and minimize damage to surrounding structures. This abstract summarizes the key points of modified anterior compartment resection, including its indications, surgical approach, and potential benefits. The technique offers a tailored and targeted approach to surgical resection, allowing for improved tumor clearance while preserving function and minimizing complications. Further studies are needed to assess the long-term outcomes and compare the efficacy of this technique with other surgical approaches in different clinical scenarios.

Early gastric cancer.  Endoscopic diagnosis of depth of invasion. The aim of this study was to evaluate the accuracy of endoscopic diagnosis in determining the depth of invasion in early gastric cancer. A retrospective analysis was performed on 105 patients who underwent endoscopic resection of early gastric cancer. The depth of invasion was assessed preoperatively by endoscopy and compared with the histopathological findings from the resected specimens. The overall accuracy of endoscopic diagnosis in determining the depth of invasion was found to be 76.2%. The sensitivity, specificity, positive predictive value, and negative predictive value were 91.3%, 68.8%, 89.2%, and 76.9% respectively. Subgroup analysis based on tumor location and macroscopic type demonstrated varying levels of accuracy. The study concludes that endoscopic diagnosis is a useful tool in determining the depth of invasion in early gastric cancer, although it has limitations and should be used in conjunction with other diagnostic methods for optimal patient management.

Peritoneal dialysis in the geriatric patient. Peritoneal dialysis (PD) is a commonly used renal replacement therapy in geriatric patients with end-stage renal disease (ESRD). However, there are unique considerations in this population that can affect the success and outcomes of PD. This study aimed to evaluate the use of PD in geriatric patients and identify factors associated with its effectiveness. A retrospective analysis was conducted on a cohort of geriatric patients (age 鈮65) who initiated PD between 2010 and 2018. The primary outcomes assessed were technique survival, peritonitis rates, and mortality. The results showed that PD was a feasible and effective alternative to hemodialysis in geriatric patients, with high technique survival rates and acceptable peritonitis rates. Mortality was mainly attributed to underlying comorbidities rather than PD-related complications. Adequate patient selection, careful monitoring, and appropriate management of comorbidities are vital in optimizing PD outcomes in the geriatric population.

Study of preneoplastic changes of liver cells by immunohistochemical and molecular hybridization techniques. The aim of this study was to investigate preneoplastic changes in liver cells using immunohistochemical and molecular hybridization techniques. Liver tissue samples from 40 patients with chronic liver disease were examined. Immunohistochemistry was used to detect specific markers of preneoplastic changes, including altered expression of oncogenes and tumor suppressor genes. Molecular hybridization techniques were used to assess DNA alterations and aberrant gene expression. Results showed widespread alterations in the expression of oncogenes and tumor suppressor genes in liver cells, suggesting the presence of preneoplastic changes. Additionally, DNA alterations and abnormal gene expression were observed in a subset of samples. These findings provide further insight into the early stages of liver carcinogenesis and may have implications for early detection and treatment of liver cancer.

Environmental risk factors in siblings with Parkinson's disease. Parkinson's disease (PD) is a neurodegenerative disorder characterized by motor symptoms such as tremors, rigidity, and bradykinesia. The etiology of PD is not fully understood, but both genetic and environmental factors are thought to play a role. In this study, we investigated the environmental risk factors in siblings with PD. We conducted a case-control study including 50 pairs of siblings with PD and 50 matched controls. Participants completed a questionnaire to assess various environmental exposures, including pesticide use, well water consumption, smoking, and occupational exposures. The results showed that siblings with PD had a significantly higher prevalence of pesticide use, well water consumption, and occupational exposures compared to the control group. These findings suggest that environmental factors, particularly pesticide exposure, well water consumption, and occupational exposures, may contribute to the development of PD in siblings. Further research is needed to better understand the mechanisms by which these exposures increase the risk of PD and to identify potential preventive strategies.

Common headaches: type, duration, frequency and implications.  Questionnaires completed by 327 preclinical medical and dental students showed that 97. 9% had experienced headaches, most frequently attributed to insufficient sleep (38. A study was conducted on 327 preclinical medical and dental students to assess the prevalence and characteristics of headaches. Results showed that 97.9% of the participants had experienced headaches. The most common cause of headaches was attributed to insufficient sleep, reported by 38.5% of the participants. Other causes included stress (27.5%), eye strain (21.7%), and dehydration (12.2%). The duration of headaches varied, with the majority lasting between 1 to 4 hours (52.3%) and occurring 1 to 3 times per week (44.3%). Headaches were found to have implications on daily functioning, including difficulty concentrating (64.8%) and decreased productivity (53.2%). These findings highlight the need for interventions targeting sleep hygiene and stress management to alleviate headaches in this population.

Diffuse hemangiomatosis of the spleen: splenic hemangiomatosis presenting with giant splenomegaly, anemia, and thrombocytopenia. Diffuse hemangiomatosis of the spleen is a rare condition characterized by the abnormal proliferation of blood vessels in the spleen. We present a case of splenic hemangiomatosis in a 45-year-old male who presented with symptoms of giant splenomegaly, anemia, and thrombocytopenia. Diagnostic imaging revealed multiple vascular lesions throughout the spleen, confirming the diagnosis. The patient underwent splenectomy, and histopathological examination confirmed the presence of benign hemangiomatous lesions. Despite the rarity of this condition, it should be considered in the differential diagnosis of patients presenting with massive splenomegaly and hematological abnormalities. Splenectomy remains the mainstay of treatment, providing symptomatic relief and preventing potential complications.

Scleroderma and L-tryptophan: a possible explanation of the eosinophilia-myalgia syndrome. Eosinophilia-myalgia syndrome (EMS) is a rare condition characterized by eosinophilia and myalgia. It has been associated with the use of L-tryptophan, a dietary supplement. However, the exact mechanism underlying the development of EMS remains unclear. We present a case of a patient with scleroderma who developed EMS following the use of L-tryptophan. Scleroderma is a connective tissue disorder characterized by fibrosis and immune dysregulation. We propose that the immune dysregulation in scleroderma predisposed this patient to the development of EMS after exposure to L-tryptophan. This case highlights a possible association between scleroderma and EMS and provides insights into the underlying pathophysiology.

Prognostic factors and value of adjunctive nephrectomy in patients with stage IV renal cell carcinoma. This study aimed to determine prognostic factors and evaluate the value of adjunctive nephrectomy in patients with stage IV renal cell carcinoma (RCC). The retrospective analysis included 213 patients diagnosed with stage IV RCC. Univariate and multivariate analyses were performed to identify prognostic factors associated with overall survival (OS). The study found that the Eastern Cooperative Oncology Group performance status, the presence of distant metastasis, and the number of metastatic sites were significant prognostic factors for OS. Additionally, patients who underwent nephrectomy had a longer median OS compared to those who did not undergo nephrectomy. However, on multivariate analysis, patient age, histological subtype, and the presence of sarcomatoid features were not significantly associated with OS. In conclusion, adjunctive nephrectomy may be valuable in patients with stage IV RCC, as it was associated with improved survival. Further studies are needed to validate these findings and identify patient subgroups that would benefit the most from nephrectomy.

Anomalous origin of the left coronary artery from the pulmonary artery. Anomalous origin of the left coronary artery from the pulmonary artery (ALCAPA) is a rare congenital heart defect characterized by abnormal blood flow to the heart muscle. This study aimed to describe the clinical and echocardiographic characteristics of ALCAPA in a cohort of patients. A total of 18 patients diagnosed with ALCAPA were included in the study. The majority of patients presented with symptoms of heart failure, including tachypnea, tachycardia, and poor feeding. Echocardiographic evaluation revealed abnormal flow patterns and myocardial dysfunction in all patients. Surgical correction was performed in all cases, with good outcomes observed in the majority of patients. This study highlights the importance of early diagnosis and prompt surgical intervention in patients with ALCAPA to prevent adverse outcomes. Further research is needed to better understand the long-term prognosis and optimal management strategies for this rare condition.

Hyperfunctioning metastatic follicular thyroid carcinoma in Pendred's syndrome. Pendred's syndrome is a rare genetic disorder characterized by hearing loss and goiter. We present the case of a 34-year-old female with Pendred's syndrome who developed hyperfunctioning metastatic follicular thyroid carcinoma. The patient initially presented with weight loss, palpable thyroid nodule, and symptoms of thyrotoxicosis. Imaging revealed multiple hyperfunctioning thyroid nodules with metastatic disease to cervical lymph nodes. She underwent total thyroidectomy and lymph node dissection, followed by radioactive iodine therapy. Histopathology confirmed follicular thyroid carcinoma. Genetic testing revealed a mutation in the pendrin gene associated with Pendred's syndrome. This case highlights the importance of considering thyroid malignancy in Pendred's syndrome patients presenting with hyperthyroidism and emphasizes the need for regular surveillance in this population.

Estrogen receptors in the external anal sphincter. The estrogen receptor (ER) is known to play a significant role in the physiology of various tissues and organs. However, its presence and function in the external anal sphincter (EAS) are not well understood. This study aimed to investigate the expression and distribution of ER in the EAS. Immunohistochemical analysis of EAS samples obtained from human cadavers revealed the presence of ERα and ERβ in the muscle fibers and surrounding connective tissue. Furthermore, ERα was found to be more abundant than ERβ in the EAS. These findings suggest that estrogen signaling may have a role in the regulation of EAS function and provide insights into potential therapeutic targets for conditions involving the EAS dysfunction.

Middle cerebral artery strokes causing homonymous hemianopia: positron emission tomography. We present a case study of a patient with homonymous hemianopia caused by a middle cerebral artery (MCA) stroke, which was evaluated using positron emission tomography (PET). The patient experienced sudden onset of left-sided visual field loss, consistent with right MCA territory involvement. Neuroimaging with PET showed decreased metabolic activity in the right occipital lobe, confirming the diagnosis of homonymous hemianopia. PET imaging also revealed hypoperfusion in the affected MCA territory. Our findings suggest that PET can be a valuable tool in assessing functional deficits in stroke patients, particularly in cases of visual field loss. Further research is needed to investigate the usefulness of PET in guiding treatment decisions and monitoring recovery in patients with MCA stroke-induced hemianopia.

Splicing defect at the ornithine aminotransferase (OAT) locus in gyrate atrophy. Gyrate atrophy is a rare autosomal recessive disorder characterized by progressive vision loss and a late-onset chorioretinal degeneration. This study focuses on a specific genetic defect at the ornithine aminotransferase (OAT) locus that contributes to the development of gyrate atrophy. The OAT gene is responsible for the conversion of ornithine to glutamate, thus regulating ornithine levels in the body. Mutations in the OAT gene result in a splicing defect, leading to a deficiency in OAT activity and an accumulation of ornithine. This excessive ornithine is toxic to the retina, causing the characteristic retinal degeneration seen in gyrate atrophy patients. The study identifies and characterizes specific mutations in the OAT gene associated with the splicing defect and further investigates the impact of these mutations on OAT activity. Understanding the underlying genetic defect in gyrate atrophy contributes to the development of targeted therapies for this debilitating condition.

Quantifying language development from birth to 3 years using the Early Language Milestone Scale. Language development is a critical aspect of early childhood development. The Early Language Milestone Scale (ELMS) is a reliable tool for evaluating language skills in children aged from birth to 3 years. This study aimed to quantify language development using ELMS in a sample of infants and toddlers. A total of 500 children were assessed at regular intervals over a 3-year period. Results demonstrated significant and consistent language development across all age groups, with a steady increase in language abilities as children progressed in age. The ELMS proved to be a valuable and effective method for measuring language development, providing valuable insights into the linguistic skills of young children. This research contributes to our understanding of language acquisition and may inform early intervention strategies for children with language delays or disorders.

Association between urinary symptoms at 7 years old and previous urinary tract infection. This study aimed to investigate the association between urinary symptoms at 7 years old and previous urinary tract infection (UTI). A total of 320 children with a history of UTI were included, and their urinary symptoms were assessed using a standardized questionnaire. The results showed that children who had experienced UTI were more likely to have urinary symptoms at 7 years old, such as urgency (OR=1.86, 95% CI 1.21-2.85) and nocturia (OR=2.14, 95% CI 1.12-4.09). Furthermore, a higher number of previous UTIs was associated with an increased risk of urinary symptoms. These findings suggest a possible long-term impact of UTIs on lower urinary tract function in children.

Current status of duplex Doppler ultrasound in the examination of the abdominal vasculature. Duplex Doppler ultrasound has become a widely used imaging modality for evaluating the abdominal vasculature. This noninvasive technique combines B-mode ultrasound with Doppler ultrasound to assess blood flow patterns and detect abnormalities in the blood vessels. In the past decade, significant advancements have been made in the technology and interpretation of duplex Doppler ultrasound, enhancing its clinical utility. This review summarizes the current status of duplex Doppler ultrasound in the examination of the abdominal vasculature, focusing on its applications in evaluating the aorta, renal arteries, mesenteric arteries, and hepatic vasculature. It discusses the advantages and limitations of duplex Doppler ultrasound compared to other imaging modalities, such as computed tomography angiography and magnetic resonance angiography. Furthermore, it highlights recent developments, such as the use of contrast-enhanced ultrasonography and three-dimensional imaging, which have further improved the diagnostic accuracy and therapeutic guidance provided by duplex Doppler ultrasound. Overall, duplex Doppler ultrasound has emerged as a valuable tool in the evaluation of abdominal vasculature, offering a noninvasive and cost-effective alternative to invasive procedures.

Premalignant lesions: role of antioxidant vitamins and beta-carotene in risk reduction and prevention of malignant transformation. This study investigated the role of antioxidant vitamins and beta-carotene in the prevention and reduction of risk for malignant transformation in premalignant lesions. A total of 526 patients with various premalignant lesions were enrolled in a double-blind, placebo-controlled trial. The patients were randomly assigned to receive either antioxidant vitamins (vitamin C, E, and beta-carotene) or placebo for a median duration of 4 years. The results showed a significant reduction in the risk of malignant transformation in the antioxidant group compared to the placebo group (p<0.001). The risk reduction was particularly evident in patients with oral leukoplakia and actinic keratosis. However, no significant effect was observed in patients with cervical intraepithelial neoplasia. These findings suggest that antioxidant vitamins and beta-carotene may have a role in the prevention and risk reduction of malignant transformation in premalignant lesions, particularly in certain types of lesions.

Percutaneous pedestal in cochlear implantation.  Direct electrical connection between an external sound-processing device and intracochlear electrodes is accomplished via a percutaneous pedestal. The percutaneous pedestal is a method used in cochlear implantation to establish a direct electrical connection between an external sound-processing device and intracochlear electrodes. This technique allows for improved stimulation of the auditory nerve and better hearing outcomes for individuals with severe hearing loss. The pedestal is inserted through the skin and into the cochlea, providing a stable and reliable connection. This abstract highlights the importance of the percutaneous pedestal in cochlear implantation and its role in improving auditory function in individuals with hearing impairment.

Experimental alcoholic skeletal muscle myopathy is characterised by a rapid and sustained decrease in muscle RNA content.  An investigation was made into the effects of ethanol feeding (36% of total calories) on skeletal muscle. This study aimed to investigate the impact of ethanol feeding on skeletal muscle in experimental alcoholic skeletal muscle myopathy. The findings revealed a rapid and sustained decrease in muscle RNA content. Ethanol consumption, accounting for 36% of total calories, was observed to have detrimental effects on skeletal muscle. Further research and analysis were conducted to understand the specific mechanisms underlying this muscle myopathy. The results provide significant insights into the potential consequences of alcohol abuse on skeletal muscle health. This study contributes to the growing body of evidence highlighting the negative impact of ethanol on skeletal muscle and emphasizes the need for prevention and intervention strategies to address alcohol-related myopathies.

Nausea, vomiting, and retching. Nausea, vomiting, and retching are common symptoms encountered in various medical conditions. They can result from a wide range of etiologies including gastrointestinal disorders, medication side effects, pregnancy, central nervous system abnormalities, and systemic illnesses. Effective treatment of these symptoms is essential for adequate patient management and improved quality of life. This review discusses the evaluation and management of nausea, vomiting, and retching. Non-pharmacological interventions such as dietary modifications and behavioral techniques are discussed, as well as pharmacological options including antiemetics. The importance of tailoring treatment to the underlying cause of symptoms and potential adverse effects of medications are emphasized to optimize patient outcomes.

Repair of coarctation with persistent fifth arterial arch and atresia of the fourth aortic arch. Coarctation of the aorta is a common congenital heart defect, but coexisting abnormalities of the aortic arch are rare. We present a case of a 2-month-old male with coarctation of the aorta and a persistent fifth arterial arch with atresia of the fourth aortic arch. After surgical repair of the coarctation and reconstruction of the aortic arch, the patient showed significant improvement in symptoms and hemodynamics. This case highlights the importance of considering unusual aortic arch anomalies in patients with coarctation of the aorta and the successful management of this complex condition through surgical intervention.

Immunohistochemical demonstration of keratin in ameloblastoma as an indication of tumor differentiation. Ameloblastoma is a rare and locally aggressive odontogenic tumor. Differentiating between the follicular and plexiform histological subtypes of ameloblastoma is important for treatment planning, as the follicular subtype has a higher potential for recurrence and malignancy. In this study, we investigated the expression of keratin, an epithelial differentiation marker, in ameloblastoma specimens using immunohistochemistry. We found that keratin expression was significantly higher in the follicular subtype compared to the plexiform subtype. These findings suggest that keratin expression can serve as an indication of tumor differentiation in ameloblastoma, with the follicular subtype showing a more differentiated phenotype. This information may help in determining the prognosis and selecting appropriate treatment strategies for patients with ameloblastoma.

Risk of myocardial infarction and death during treatment with low dose aspirin and intravenous heparin in men with unstable coronary artery disease.  The RISC Group 796 men with unstable coronary artery disease (unstable angina or non-Q-wave myocardial infarction [MI] ), were randomised to double-blind placebo-controlled treatment with oral aspirin 75 mg/day and/or 5 days of intermittent intravenous heparin.  The risk of MI and death was reduced by aspirin. This study aimed to assess the risk of myocardial infarction (MI) and death in men with unstable coronary artery disease treated with low dose aspirin and intravenous heparin. A total of 796 men with unstable angina or non-Q-wave MI were enrolled in the study and randomized to receive double-blind placebo-controlled treatment with oral aspirin (75 mg/day) and/or intermittent intravenous heparin for 5 days. The results showed that aspirin significantly reduced the risk of MI and death in these patients. This suggests that low dose aspirin may be a beneficial treatment option for men with unstable coronary artery disease.

Embolization with particles in thoracic intramedullary arteriovenous malformations: long-term angiographic and clinical results. Intramedullary arteriovenous malformations (AVMs) in the thoracic region can cause significant neurological deficits due to vascular steal phenomenon and venous hypertension. This study aimed to evaluate the long-term angiographic and clinical outcomes of embolization with particles in the treatment of thoracic intramedullary AVMs. Twenty-six patients with thoracic AVMs were treated with embolization using PVA particles, and follow-up angiography was performed at 3, 6, and 12 months after treatment. Clinical outcomes were assessed using modified Rankin Scale (mRS) scores. The mean follow-up period was 39 months. Angiographic results showed complete occlusion in 80% of patients, partial occlusion in 8%, and no occlusion in 12% at the last follow-up. Clinical improvement was observed in 84.6% of patients, with 76.9% achieving mRS scores of 0-2. Complications occurred in five patients, including transient neurological deficits and pulmonary embolism. In conclusion, embolization with particles is a safe and effective treatment option for thoracic intramedullary AVMs, leading to long-term angiographic occlusion and clinical improvement in the majority of patients.

Mucogenic secondary open-angle glaucoma in diffuse epithelial ingrowth treated by block-excision. We present a case of a 65-year-old male who developed diffuse epithelial ingrowth (DEI) leading to mucogenic secondary open-angle glaucoma (MSOG). The patient underwent block-excision surgery to remove the DEI. The surgical procedure involved creating a flap in the cornea and removing the entire epithelial ingrowth along with any associated ocular surface irregularities. Post-operatively, the patient experienced a significant decrease in intraocular pressure and improvement in visual acuity. There were no complications or recurrence of DEI during the follow-up period of six months. Block-excision appears to be an effective treatment option for cases of MSOG associated with DEI, providing relief from glaucoma and restoring visual function. Further studies are warranted to validate these findings.

Persistent uptake of indium-111-antimyosin monoclonal antibody in patients with myocardial infarction. Indium-111-antimyosin monoclonal antibody (AMAb) imaging was performed in 23 patients with recent myocardial infarction (MI) to assess persistent uptake in infarcted areas. Our findings demonstrate that: (1) Persistent AMAb uptake was observed in all patients with recent MI, indicating ongoing myocardial necrosis and myocyte death. (2) The extent and intensity of AMAb uptake correlated with the degree of myocardial injury, as evidenced by cardiac enzyme levels and electrocardiographic changes. (3) Follow-up studies revealed that persistent AMAb uptake gradually decreased over time, suggesting ongoing myocardial healing and scar formation. (4) The persistence of AMAb uptake may serve as a prognostic indicator for adverse cardiac events and the need for further interventions. In conclusion, indium-111-AMAb imaging provides valuable insights into the pathophysiology and dynamics of myocardial infarction, potentially aiding in risk stratification and treatment planning for patients with acute coronary syndromes.

Functional outcomes following selective posterior rhizotomy in children with cerebral palsy. Selective posterior rhizotomy (SPR) is a surgical procedure commonly used to treat children with cerebral palsy (CP) who experience spasticity. However, there is limited research on the functional outcomes of SPR in this population. The aim of this study was to evaluate the functional outcomes of SPR in children with CP. A total of XX children with CP who underwent SPR were included in the study. Assessment tools such as the Gross Motor Function Measure-88 (GMFM-88) and the Pediatric Evaluation of Disability Inventory (PEDI) were used to measure functional outcomes preoperatively and postoperatively. The results showed significant improvements in gross motor function and daily living skills following SPR. Additionally, the improvements were sustained at follow-up assessments. These findings suggest that SPR can lead to positive functional outcomes in children with CP and support its use as an effective treatment option for spasticity in this population. Further research with larger sample sizes and longer follow-up periods is warranted to validate these findings.

Historical review of pancreaticoduodenectomy. Pancreaticoduodenectomy, also known as Whipple procedure, is a surgical procedure used to treat various diseases of the pancreas and surrounding structures. This historical review aims to provide a comprehensive overview of the development and evolution of pancreaticoduodenectomy techniques. 
The procedure was first described in 1898 by Dr. Allen O. Whipple and has since undergone significant modifications, leading to improved surgical outcomes. Early techniques had high morbidity and mortality rates, but advancements in surgical skills, anesthesia, and perioperative care have contributed to improved patient outcomes in recent years. The introduction of pylorus-preserving techniques and modifications in the reconstruction of the gastrointestinal tract have further enhanced postoperative recovery and long-term quality of life. Additionally, advancements in imaging technology and preoperative evaluation have aided in patient selection and surgical planning. Overall, this historical review highlights the evolution of pancreaticoduodenectomy techniques, emphasizing the importance of surgical innovation and multidisciplinary collaboration in improving patient outcomes.

Chronic Lyme disease with an expansive granulomatous lesion in the cerebellopontine angle.  Expansive granulomatous lesions in the posterior cranial fossa are rare and have not been reported in conjunction with Lyme disease. This case report describes a rare presentation of chronic Lyme disease with an expansive granulomatous lesion located in the cerebellopontine angle. Granulomatous lesions in the posterior cranial fossa are uncommon and have not been previously associated with Lyme disease. A 54-year-old male presented with symptoms of 8 months duration including headaches, ataxia, and hearing loss. Magnetic resonance imaging revealed a mass lesion in the cerebellopontine angle. Surgical resection of the lesion was performed, and histopathological examination showed features consistent with a granulomatous process. Serologic testing confirmed the diagnosis of Lyme disease. This unusual presentation emphasizes the need for considering Lyme disease in the differential diagnosis of expansive granulomatous lesions in the posterior cranial fossa.

Magnetic resonance imaging in idiopathic retroperitoneal fibrosis: measurement of T1 relaxation time.  Magnetic resonance imaging at 0. We sought to determine if magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) could be used to measure T1 relaxation time in patients with idiopathic retroperitoneal fibrosis (IRF). Twenty-five patients with confirmed IRF were included in the study. MRI scans were performed using a 1.5 Tesla scanner. T1 relaxation time was measured in the affected retroperitoneal regions of each patient. Additionally, T1 relaxation time was measured in the liver as a control. The mean T1 relaxation time in the affected retroperitoneal regions was significantly higher compared to the liver (p < 0.001). There was no significant difference in T1 relaxation time between patients with unilateral and bilateral IRF. Our findings suggest that MRI can accurately measure T1 relaxation time in patients with IRF. This technique may prove valuable for the diagnosis and monitoring of disease progression in IRF patients.

Transcranial electrical motor evoked potentials as a prognostic indicator for motor recovery in stroke patients. Stroke patients often have limited motor recovery, and predicting their potential for functional improvement is important for personalized rehabilitation planning. Transcranial electrical motor evoked potentials (tEMEPs) have been proposed as a prognostic indicator for motor recovery. To investigate this, a study was conducted including 82 stroke patients. Their motor function was assessed using the Fugl-Meyer Assessment (FMA) score, and tEMEPs were recorded from the affected hemisphere. The results showed that tEMEP amplitudes were significantly correlated with FMA scores at both baseline and follow-up assessments. Additionally, the tEMEP amplitudes were predictive of motor recovery with a high accuracy level. Therefore, tEMEP can serve as a valuable tool for predicting motor recovery in stroke patients and aid in developing personalized treatment plans.

Postinduction repression of the beta-interferon gene is mediated through two positive regulatory domains. In this study, we investigated the mechanisms involved in the postinduction repression of the beta-interferon gene. Using various molecular techniques, we identified two positive regulatory domains that are responsible for this repression. Our results suggest that these regulatory domains play a crucial role in mediating the postinduction repression of the beta-interferon gene.

Furthermore, we found that the repression is mediated through the binding of specific repressor proteins to these regulatory domains. These proteins inhibit the activity of the transcription factors that are necessary for the expression of the beta-interferon gene.

Understanding the molecular mechanisms underlying the postinduction repression of the beta-interferon gene is of great importance, as it may provide new insights into the regulation of immune responses and the development of therapeutic approaches for inflammatory and autoimmune diseases. Our findings highlight the complexity of gene regulation and emphasize the need for further research in this area.

Continent ileocolonic urinary reservoirs for filling and lining the post-exenteration pelvis. Continent ileocolonic urinary reservoirs have been used for reconstructing the urinary tract after pelvic exenteration procedures. This study aimed to evaluate the outcomes and complications associated with using these reservoirs. A retrospective chart review of patients who underwent pelvic exenteration and continent ileocolonic urinary reservoir reconstruction was conducted. The study included 25 patients with various malignancies. The main outcomes examined were continence, renal function, and postoperative complications. The majority of patients achieved continence after reservoir reconstruction, with only a few experiencing minor leakage. There were no significant changes in renal function postoperatively. Complications, including reservoir stenosis and urinary tract infections, were relatively rare. Continent ileocolonic urinary reservoirs are a viable option for filling and lining the post-exenteration pelvis, providing good continence outcomes and preserving renal function.

Exercise capability in heart failure: is cardiac output important after all? The exercise capability of 39 patients with severe chronic heart failure was assessed in several ways and compared with measurements of cardiac output.  The relation between cardiac index and exercise tolerance measured on a treadmill was poor (r = 0. This study aimed to determine the impact of cardiac output on exercise capability in patients with severe chronic heart failure. 39 patients with the condition were assessed using various measures of exercise tolerance, which were then compared to measurements of cardiac output. The results showed a weak correlation between cardiac index and exercise tolerance on a treadmill (r=0.xx, p=0.xx). This suggests that cardiac output may not have a significant influence on exercise capability in patients with severe chronic heart failure. Further research is needed to fully understand the factors that contribute to exercise tolerance in this population.

Routes and incidence of communication of lumbar discs with surrounding neural structures. Understanding the communication routes and incidence of lumbar discs with surrounding neural structures is crucial in diagnosing and treating lumbar disc pathology. In this study, we aimed to investigate the routes and incidence of communication between lumbar discs and adjacent neural structures. A total of 50 patients with lumbar disc pathology were included in the study. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) was used to visualize the lumbar discs and their relationship with adjacent neural structures. Our findings revealed that communication between lumbar discs and neural structures occurred more frequently than previously reported. The most common route of communication was posterior, followed by lateral and anterior routes. These findings highlight the need for clinicians to consider the potential involvement of adjacent neural structures when diagnosing and devising treatment plans for patients with lumbar disc pathology. Improved understanding of these communication routes can contribute to more effective management and improved patient outcomes.

Rapid control of refractory atrial tachyarrhythmias with high-dose oral amiodarone.  To shorten the delay in the onset of antiarrhythmic effect when using amiodarone for the conversion of refractory atrial tachyarrhythmias to sinus rhythm, 19 patients were given oral amiodarone according to a high-dose loading protocol. In this study, 19 patients with refractory atrial tachyarrhythmias were treated with high-dose oral amiodarone to achieve rapid control of the condition. A loading protocol was followed to minimize the delay in the onset of antiarrhythmic effect. The patients were monitored for the conversion of tachyarrhythmias to sinus rhythm and any adverse effects of the treatment. Results showed that the high-dose oral amiodarone protocol was effective in achieving prompt control of refractory atrial tachyarrhythmias, with 17 patients successfully converting to sinus rhythm within an average of 48 hours. Adverse effects were minimal and manageable. These findings suggest that high-dose oral amiodarone can be a favorable treatment option for patients with refractory atrial tachyarrhythmias.

Malignant glandular triton tumor. Malignant glandular triton tumor (MGTT) is a rare and aggressive subtype of malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumor (MPNST). We present the clinical features and outcomes of seven patients diagnosed with MGTT between 2010 and 2019. The mean age at diagnosis was 45 years, with a male predominance (5 males and 2 females). All patients presented with a rapidly growing tumor and pain. Five patients had tumors in the head and neck region, while two had tumors in the lower extremities. Histopathological examination revealed glandular and neurogenic differentiation in all cases. Five patients underwent surgical resection, while two received neoadjuvant chemotherapy followed by surgery. The overall survival rate was 42.9%, with a mean survival time of 20 months. The prognosis of MGTT remains poor, highlighting the need for early detection and aggressive treatment strategies.

Reversed lateralization of cognitive functions in right handers. This study aimed to investigate the occurrence of reversed lateralization of cognitive functions in right-handed individuals. A total of 50 right-handers were included in the study, with 30 individuals showing reversed lateralization and 20 individuals exhibiting the typical pattern of left hemisphere dominance. Neuropsychological assessments were conducted to evaluate various cognitive functions, including language, visuospatial abilities, and executive functions. Findings revealed that individuals with reversed lateralization exhibited atypical patterns of language lateralization, with right hemisphere dominance for language functions. Additionally, these individuals showed superior visuospatial abilities compared to those with typical lateralization, suggesting enhanced right hemisphere involvement. However, no significant differences were observed in executive functions between the two groups. These findings contribute to our understanding of the variability in brain lateralization among right-handers and highlight the need for further research to elucidate the underlying mechanisms of reversed lateralization and its implications for cognitive functioning.

Ichthyosis, mental retardation, and asymptomatic spasticity. Ichthyosis, mental retardation, and asymptomatic spasticity is a rare genetic disorder characterized by the presence of ichthyosis (abnormal scaling of the skin), mental retardation, and spasticity (muscle stiffness and spasms). This disorder has been described in only a few cases in the medical literature. In this case report, we present the clinical findings and diagnostic challenges of a patient with ichthyosis, mental retardation, and asymptomatic spasticity. The patient exhibited severe scaling and dryness of the skin, global developmental delay, and stiffness in the limbs without any accompanying pain or functional impairment. Genetic testing revealed a novel mutation in a gene associated with the formation and maintenance of the skin barrier. This report highlights the importance of recognizing and diagnosing this rare disorder, as early intervention and management strategies can help improve the quality of life for affected individuals.

Early gastric cancer.  Twenty-eight-year experience.  A retrospective study of early gastric cancer (60 patients) was performed to evaluate its diagnosis and treatment. A retrospective study was conducted to evaluate the diagnosis and treatment of early gastric cancer. Over a 28-year period, 60 patients with early gastric cancer were included in the study. The most common presenting symptom was epigastric pain, followed by weight loss and dyspepsia. Endoscopic examination revealed superficial lesions in all cases, with 70% of the tumors located in the distal stomach. The majority of patients underwent curative resection, either by subtotal or total gastrectomy. The overall 5-year survival rate was found to be 82%. Factors associated with poor prognosis included tumor size, depth of invasion, lymph node involvement, and distant metastasis. Furthermore, the presence of lymphovascular invasion was a significant predictor of poorer outcomes. These findings emphasize the importance of early detection and aggressive surgical management in improving the prognosis of patients with early gastric cancer.

Surgical treatment of active native valve endocarditis.  A report is presented of 24 patients (23 male), mean age 38 years, who underwent surgery for active native valve endocarditis of the left heart in 1975-1988. This study presents the surgical treatment outcomes of 24 patients (23 male) with active native valve endocarditis of the left heart. The mean age of the patients was 38 years, and the surgeries were performed between 1975 and 1988. The patients underwent surgical intervention due to active infection in the native valves of the heart. Different surgical techniques, such as valve replacement and repair, were utilized depending on the extent of the infection and valve damage. The study evaluates the short-term and long-term outcomes of these surgeries, including postoperative complications, recurrence of infection, and survival rates. The results provide insights into the effectiveness of surgical treatment for active native valve endocarditis and offer guidance for clinical management.

Response to suxamethonium in a myasthenic patient during remission. We report a case of a myasthenic patient in remission who exhibited a prolonged response to suxamethonium during anesthesia. The patient, a 48-year-old male, was diagnosed with myasthenia gravis and had been in a stable remission for the past two years. During a surgical procedure, he received suxamethonium as a muscle relaxant, which resulted in a prolonged neuromuscular blockade and delayed recovery. Subsequent investigations revealed a decrease in acetylcholine receptor density and post-junctional fold length at the neuromuscular junction. Physicians should be aware of the possibility of abnormal responses to suxamethonium in myasthenic patients, even during periods of remission. Close monitoring and appropriate adjustments in the anesthesia plan are warranted to ensure patient safety.

Interpleural analgesia [published erratum appears in Heart Lung 1991 Jul;20(4):413] Postoperative pain relief is necessary not only for patient comfort, but also to facilitate ventilation and ambulation. Postoperative pain relief is crucial for patient comfort, as well as to enhance ventilation and ambulation. Interpleural analgesia is a method used to achieve effective postoperative pain control. This technique involves the administration of local anesthetic into the interpleural space, resulting in effective analgesia. This abstract highlights the importance of postoperative pain relief and the role of interpleural analgesia in achieving this.

Mobile knee reconstructions after resection of malignant tumors of the distal femur. Resection of malignant tumors in the distal femur often requires reconstruction to restore stability and function. We report our experience with mobile knee reconstructions in 11 patients. The average age of the patients was 45 years, and the average follow-up period was 46 months. The reconstruction technique involved a modular prosthesis with a rotating hinge design, allowing for preservation of limb length and mobility. Complications included infection in one case and dislocation in another. The average Musculoskeletal Tumor Society score was 83.9, indicating satisfactory functional outcomes. Mobile knee reconstructions can be a viable option for patients undergoing distal femur tumor resection, providing good functional results and improved quality of life.

Serial CA 125 levels during chemotherapy for metastatic or recurrent endometrial cancer. In this study, we evaluated the serial CA 125 levels during chemotherapy in patients with metastatic or recurrent endometrial cancer. A total of 25 patients were enrolled and received various chemotherapy regimens including paclitaxel, carboplatin, and doxorubicin. CA 125 levels were measured before treatment initiation and at regular intervals during chemotherapy. 

At baseline, all patients had elevated CA 125 levels with a mean value of 240 U/mL. During chemotherapy, there was a significant decrease in CA 125 levels with a mean reduction of 45% (p < 0.001). The decline in CA 125 levels was observed as early as the second cycle of chemotherapy and continued throughout the treatment course. 

Patients who achieved a complete response to chemotherapy had a greater reduction in CA 125 levels compared to those with stable or progressive disease (mean reduction of 65% vs. 38%, p = 0.01). 

Serial monitoring of CA 125 levels during chemotherapy is a valuable tool for assessing treatment response and guiding clinical decision-making in patients with metastatic or recurrent endometrial cancer. Further studies are warranted to explore its potential as a surrogate marker for prognosis and survival.

Role of systemic therapy in advanced non-small-cell lung cancer. This review discusses the role of systemic therapy in the treatment of advanced non-small-cell lung cancer (NSCLC). NSCLC is a common and aggressive form of lung cancer with limited treatment options. Systemic therapy, including chemotherapy and targeted therapy, has been widely used in the management of advanced NSCLC. Chemotherapy regimens, such as platinum-based doublets, have shown modest improvements in overall survival and disease control. Recently, targeted therapies, such as tyrosine kinase inhibitors, have revolutionized the treatment landscape for patients with specific genetic alterations. Immunotherapy, specifically immune checkpoint inhibitors, has also emerged as a promising treatment option. However, the optimal sequencing and combination of these therapies remain areas of ongoing research and clinical investigation in advanced NSCLC.

An inner city cancer prevention clinic. This study aims to evaluate the impact of an inner city cancer prevention clinic on patient population. A retrospective analysis of patients attending the clinic over a one-year period was conducted. Data including demographics, risk factors, cancer screening and prevention interventions, and patient outcomes were collected and analyzed. Results showed that the clinic served a diverse population, with a high proportion of low-income individuals and minority groups. The clinic successfully provided comprehensive cancer prevention services, including education, screening, and vaccination. Significant improvements were observed in cancer screening rates and adherence to preventive practices among clinic attendees. These findings highlight the importance of targeted interventions in underserved communities to reduce cancer health disparities.

Unusual blink reflex with four components in a patient with periodic ataxia. This case report presents a patient with periodic ataxia and an unusual blink reflex characterized by four components. The patient, a 54-year-old male, experienced episodes of ataxia every few months, accompanied by dysarthria and gaze evoked nystagmus. Neurological examination revealed preserved sensory system and cranial nerves. Electromyography showed four components in the blink reflex, including an early excitatory (R1) and inhibitory (R2) response, followed by a late excitatory (R3) and inhibitory (R4) response. This unique blink reflex pattern has not been previously described in patients with periodic ataxia. The underlying pathophysiological mechanisms for this abnormal blink reflex are yet to be fully understood. Further studies are needed to explore the potential diagnostic and therapeutic implications of this finding in patients with periodic ataxia.

Ischaemic heart disease among men in Norway during the period 1966-1985: two counties with different mortality time trends.  We have examined regional differences in mortality from ischaemic heart disease, including sudden, unexpected death (IHD/SUD), among Norwegian men aged 30-69 years, during the period 1966-1985. This study investigated regional differences in mortality from ischaemic heart disease (IHD), including sudden and unexpected death (IHD/SUD), among Norwegian men aged 30-69 years between 1966 and 1985. Two counties with distinct mortality time trends were analyzed. Overall, the mortality rates from IHD/SUD increased during the study period, although the rates varied between the two counties. In one county, the mortality rate steadily increased, while in the other county, the rate initially rose but then declined. These findings suggest that factors influencing the mortality from IHD/SUD may vary between regions. Further research is needed to understand the underlying causes and potential interventions to reduce IHD-related mortality.

pH-adjustment and discomfort caused by the intradermal injection of lignocaine [published erratum appears in Anaesthesia 1991 Mar;46(3):242] One hundred adult day-case patients who required intravenous access had cannulae inserted using local anaesthesia with 1% lignocaine, 1% lignocaine with adrenaline or the corresponding pH-adjusted solutions. Intradermal injection of local anaesthesia with lignocaine can cause discomfort due to pH-adjustment. This study aimed to compare the effectiveness of various lignocaine solutions in reducing pain during intravenous cannula insertion. One hundred adult day-case patients were included, and cannulae were inserted using 1% lignocaine, 1% lignocaine with adrenaline, or pH-adjusted solutions. It was found that the pH-adjusted solutions were more effective in reducing discomfort compared to lignocaine solutions. These findings highlight the importance of pH-adjustment in local anaesthesia administration to minimize injection-related discomfort for patients.

Histochemical demonstration of 5'-nucleotidase activity in inflammatory muscle disease. Inflammatory muscle diseases (IMDs) are characterized by muscle inflammation and weakness. The histopathological assessment of 5'-nucleotidase (5'-NT) activity in muscle biopsy samples has been proposed as a marker for IMDs. We conducted a study to investigate the histochemical demonstration of 5'-NT activity in 35 patients diagnosed with different forms of IMD. We found that 5'-NT activity was significantly increased in muscle fibers of patients with IMD compared to controls. Furthermore, 5'-NT activity correlated with disease severity and progression. These findings suggest that histochemical demonstration of 5'-NT activity may be a useful tool for the diagnosis and monitoring of IMDs. Further studies are needed to validate these findings and understand the underlying mechanisms of 5'-NT dysregulation in inflammatory muscle disease.

An epidemic outbreak of cryptosporidiosis: a prospective community study from Guinea Bissau.  In the first year of a prospective community study of childhood diarrhea conducted in a semiurban area in the capital of Guinea Bissau, Cryptosporidium sp. This study investigates an epidemic outbreak of cryptosporidiosis in Guinea Bissau. Over the course of one year, a prospective community study was conducted in a semiurban area of the country's capital. Cryptosporidium sp. was identified as the causative agent of childhood diarrhea in this study. The outbreak had a significant impact, affecting a substantial number of individuals in the community. The findings suggest that cryptosporidiosis is a significant public health concern in Guinea Bissau and highlights the need for effective prevention and control measures. Further research is required to understand the epidemiology and transmission dynamics of this parasite in the study population.

Prediction of cognitive change as a function of preoperative ability status among temporal lobectomy patients seen at 6-month follow-up. This study aimed to examine the relationship between preoperative cognitive ability status and postoperative cognitive change in patients who underwent temporal lobectomy. Fifty patients were assessed preoperatively and at a 6-month follow-up using a comprehensive neuropsychological battery. Preoperative ability status was categorized as intact cognition, mild cognitive impairment (MCI), or dementia. Postoperative cognitive change was evaluated using reliable change indices. Results showed that patients with intact cognition at baseline demonstrated minimal cognitive decline postoperatively. In contrast, patients with MCI and dementia at baseline exhibited significant cognitive decline. Furthermore, baseline ability status was found to significantly predict postoperative cognitive change, with higher baseline cognitive ability associated with less cognitive decline. These findings suggest that preoperative cognitive ability status may serve as an important prognostic indicator for postoperative cognitive outcomes in patients undergoing temporal lobectomy. Future research should explore potential mechanisms underlying these observed associations and investigate interventions that may mitigate cognitive decline in vulnerable patient populations.

Antiepileptic drugs, cognitive function, and behavior in children: evidence from recent studies.  The effects of antiepileptic drugs (AEDs) on cognitive function and behavior in children are reviewed on the basis of published studies. This review examines the impact of antiepileptic drugs (AEDs) on cognitive function and behavior in children by summarizing recent studies. The findings suggest that AEDs can have significant effects on these domains. Some AEDs, such as valproate, have been associated with cognitive impairments, while others, such as levetiracetam, have shown potential cognitive-enhancing effects. AEDs have also been found to influence behavior, with some drugs increasing the risk of aggression and hyperactivity. The effects of AEDs on cognition and behavior appear to be influenced by factors such as age, seizure type, and treatment duration. Further research is needed to better understand and address these effects in pediatric populations.

Spontaneous perinephric hemorrhage: imaging and management. Spontaneous perinephric hemorrhage (SPH) is a rare condition characterized by bleeding within the perinephric space without an identifiable cause. This study aims to evaluate the imaging characteristics and management strategies for SPH. A retrospective analysis was performed on 30 patients diagnosed with SPH between 2010 and 2020. The mean age of the patients was 58 years, and the male-to-female ratio was 2:1. Computed tomography (CT) imaging was the most commonly used modality for diagnosing SPH, with characteristic findings including perinephric fluid collections and cortical thickening. Angiography was performed in select cases to identify any underlying vascular abnormalities. Non-operative management was successful in the majority of cases, with conservative measures such as fluid resuscitation and blood transfusion. However, in cases with expanding or persistent hemorrhage, surgical intervention was required, including embolization or nephrectomy. The overall mortality rate was 10%, with death typically associated with delayed diagnosis or significant comorbidities. In conclusion, CT imaging plays a crucial role in the diagnosis of SPH, and the majority of cases can be managed non-operatively.

New horizons in the treatment of coronary artery thrombosis. Coronary artery thrombosis is a life-threatening condition that can lead to myocardial infarction. This review explores new treatment options for coronary artery thrombosis. Currently, the standard treatment involves administration of antiplatelet and anticoagulant medications along with revascularization procedures such as percutaneous coronary intervention or coronary artery bypass grafting. However, these approaches have limitations and may not always be successful. Emerging therapies, including novel antiplatelet agents, antithrombotic drugs, and endovascular techniques, show promise in improving outcomes for patients with coronary artery thrombosis. Additionally, advancements in imaging modalities and risk stratification tools allow for better identification of high-risk patients and more targeted treatment strategies. A multi-disciplinary approach involving cardiologists, interventional radiologists, and cardiac surgeons is essential for optimizing the management of coronary artery thrombosis.

Threshold perimetry in tilted disc syndrome.  Twelve consecutive patients (17 eyes) with tilted disc syndrome underwent quantified visual field examination with the G1 Octopus program (Interzeag AG, Schlieren, Switzerland). This study aimed to evaluate the visual field changes in patients with tilted disc syndrome using threshold perimetry. Twelve consecutive patients (17 eyes) diagnosed with tilted disc syndrome underwent visual field examination using the G1 Octopus program. The results were analyzed to determine any visual field abnormalities associated with tilted disc syndrome. The study found that all eyes showed visual field defects, predominantly affecting the nasal field. These defects were characterized by arcuate scotomas, corresponding to the location of the tilted disc. Additionally, two eyes demonstrated central scotomas. The severity of visual field defects varied among the patients, with some showing mild defects and others showing more pronounced ones. The authors concluded that threshold perimetry with the G1 Octopus program is useful in detecting and quantifying visual field defects in patients with tilted disc syndrome, providing valuable information for diagnosis and monitoring of this condition.

Long-term medical consequences of incest, rape, and molestation. This study examined the long-term medical consequences of incest, rape, and molestation. Medical records of 100 survivors of these traumas were analyzed for physical and psychological health outcomes. The results showed a high incidence of various medical conditions including sexually transmitted infections, chronic pain, gastrointestinal disorders, and psychiatric disorders such as depression and post-traumatic stress disorder. Survivors also exhibited increased rates of substance abuse and self-harm behaviors. These findings highlight the profound and lasting impact of these traumatic experiences on survivors' health. The study emphasizes the need for comprehensive medical and psychological support for survivors to address their physical and mental health needs. Further research is warranted to explore interventions and strategies for improving the health outcomes of this vulnerable population.

The electrocardiogram in chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) is a common respiratory condition associated with cardiovascular comorbidities. The electrocardiogram (ECG) is a widely used tool to assess cardiac function in COPD patients. This literature review aimed to summarize the current knowledge regarding ECG findings in COPD. Various ECG abnormalities have been reported, including right ventricular hypertrophy, right bundle branch block, and ST-T wave changes. These findings are believed to reflect the underlying pulmonary vascular and cardiac remodeling seen in COPD. Additionally, ECG parameters such as QT interval, heart rate variability, and QT dispersion have been investigated as potential predictors of cardiovascular events in COPD patients. Further research is needed to establish the clinical significance of ECG abnormalities in COPD and their prognostic implications.
