Isolated trigeminal sensory loss secondary to a distal anterior inferior cerebellar artery aneurysm: case report.  A previously healthy 25-year-old woman suddenly developed right-sided facial numbness and a headache. This case report describes a previously healthy 25-year-old woman who presented with sudden onset right-sided facial numbness and headache. Clinical examination revealed isolated trigeminal sensory loss on the right side. The patient underwent further investigation, including magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) and angiography, which revealed a distal anterior inferior cerebellar artery aneurysm. The aneurysm was successfully treated with endovascular coiling, leading to resolution of the patient's symptoms. Isolated trigeminal sensory loss is a rare neurological finding, and its association with an aneurysm is even more uncommon. This case highlights the importance of considering cerebrovascular causes in patients presenting with neurological deficits, even when they are young and otherwise healthy. Early recognition and intervention can lead to favorable outcomes in such cases. Further studies are needed to better understand the underlying mechanisms and optimal management strategies for this rare presentation.

Umbilical cord hematoma following diagnostic funipuncture. The authors present a case of an umbilical cord hematoma occurring after a diagnostic funipuncture. The patient, a full-term neonate, developed a visible hematoma at the puncture site and exhibited signs of distress. Ultrasound imaging confirmed the presence of the hematoma, which resolved spontaneously over time without the need for intervention. The authors discuss the potential etiology of the hematoma, which may include trauma during the procedure or underlying vascular abnormalities. They also emphasize the importance of meticulous technique during funipuncture to minimize the risk of complications. This case report serves as a reminder to obstetricians and neonatologists of the potential for umbilical cord hematomas following diagnostic funipuncture and highlights the need for close monitoring and prompt management of any associated symptoms. Further research is warranted to better understand the risk factors and optimal management strategies for this rare but potentially significant complication.

Endoscopic ventricular fenestration using a "saline torch".  The fiberoptic endoscope has never gained popularity among neurosurgeons although it is ideally suited for navigating within the cerebral ventricles. Endoscopic ventricular fenestration is a minimally invasive neurosurgical procedure that allows access to the cerebral ventricles. However, the fiberoptic endoscope, which is well-suited for this purpose, has not gained widespread adoption among neurosurgeons. In this study, we present the use of a novel technique called "saline torch" for endoscopic ventricular fenestration. The saline torch utilizes a saline solution to enhance visualization and tissue dissection within the ventricles. We describe the technique and present our initial experience with ten patients who underwent endoscopic ventricular fenestration using the saline torch. Our results show that this technique provides excellent visualization of the ventricles and facilitates precise fenestration. Furthermore, it is a safe and efficient procedure with minimal complications and favorable patient outcomes. The saline torch technique may overcome the barriers to using the fiberoptic endoscope and has the potential to become a valuable tool in neurosurgical practice.

Neurinoma in the cavernous sinus: report of two cases. Two cases of neurinoma in the cavernous sinus are reported. In the first case, a 32-year-old female presented with progressive visual loss and ptosis. MRI revealed a mass in the cavernous sinus consistent with a neurinoma. The patient underwent surgical resection with preservation of cranial nerve function and experienced improvement in visual symptoms postoperatively. In the second case, a 45-year-old male presented with ophthalmoplegia and headache. MRI showed a mass in the cavernous sinus, also consistent with a neurinoma. The patient underwent radiosurgery, resulting in symptom resolution and stable tumor size on follow-up imaging. Neurinoma in the cavernous sinus is a rare entity, and management should be tailored to each individual case.

Intraosseous lipoma within the femoral head. Intraosseous lipomas are rare benign tumors that occur within the bone marrow. This article presents a case of an intraosseous lipoma within the femoral head and reviews the existing literature on this condition. The patient, a 45-year-old female, presented with hip pain and was found to have a radiolucent lesion within the femoral head on imaging. Histological examination confirmed the presence of mature adipose tissue consistent with an intraosseous lipoma. Although intraosseous lipomas are uncommon, they should be considered in the differential diagnosis of radiolucent lesions within bone. The treatment of choice is usually conservative management, with surgery reserved for cases with significant symptoms or complications. Further research is needed to better understand the pathogenesis and optimal management of intraosseous lipomas.

Infarct of the conus medullaris simulating a spinal cord tumor: case report. We present a case report of a 45-year-old male who presented with progressive lower limb weakness and sensory loss. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the spine initially showed a mass lesion at the conus medullaris, raising suspicion of a spinal cord tumor. However, intraoperative findings revealed no evidence of a tumor. Histopathological examination confirmed acute infarct of the conus medullaris. This case highlights the importance of considering infarction as a differential diagnosis in patients presenting with clinical and radiological features suggestive of a spinal cord tumor. MRI findings may mimic a tumor, leading to unnecessary surgical intervention. Clinical suspicion and careful evaluation, including histopathological examination, are crucial for accurate diagnosis and appropriate management of conus medullaris infarcts.

Unusual aspects of aortovenous fistulas associated with ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysms. Aortovenous fistulas (AVFs) associated with ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysms (AAAs) are rare but potentially life-threatening complications. We present two cases of unusual AVFs observed in patients with ruptured AAAs. In the first case, an 80-year-old male presented with massive retroperitoneal hemorrhage and a pulsatile mass in the left thigh. Angiography revealed a large AVF between the left common iliac artery and vein. The patient underwent emergency repair of the AAA and simultaneous ligation of the AVF with successful outcomes. In the second case, a 75-year-old male presented with hemodynamic instability and a pulsatile mass in the right groin. Angiography showed a large AVF between the right common femoral artery and vein. The patient underwent emergent AAA repair and AVF ligation, but unfortunately developed multiorgan failure and expired. AVFs associated with ruptured AAAs are uncommon, but prompt recognition and management are crucial for optimal patient outcomes. These cases highlight the importance of early diagnosis and appropriate surgical intervention in these challenging situations.

Genetic diagnosis of Lynch syndrome II in an extended colorectal cancer-prone family. Lynch syndrome, also known as hereditary nonpolyposis colorectal cancer (HNPCC), is an autosomal dominant inherited disorder associated with an increased risk of colorectal and other types of cancer. This abstract presents a case study of an extended family with Lynch syndrome II, characterized by a high incidence of colorectal cancer. The study aimed to determine the genetic cause of the syndrome within the family. Genetic testing was conducted on 30 family members, and their medical histories were analyzed. The DNA sequencing analysis revealed a mutation in the MLH1 gene, confirming Lynch syndrome II in the family. The identification of the genetic mutation allowed for targeted screening and early detection of colorectal cancer in affected individuals, as well as the implementation of preventive measures for at-risk family members. This case highlights the importance of genetic diagnosis in identifying hereditary cancer predisposition syndromes and guiding appropriate management and prevention strategies for affected individuals and their families.

Epstein-Barr virus associated oesophageal ulcers in AIDS. In patients with AIDS, Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) has been increasingly recognized as a cause of esophageal ulcers. These ulcers can be painful and may lead to severe complications in immunocompromised individuals. The diagnosis is made by endoscopic examination and confirmation of EBV infection through biopsy samples. Treatment of EBV-associated esophageal ulcers involves antiviral therapy and management of immunosuppression. Adequate immune reconstitution is crucial to improve outcomes. Despite treatment, recurrence of ulcers is common and may require long-term maintenance therapy. It is important for healthcare providers to consider EBV infection as a potential underlying cause of esophageal ulcers in AIDS patients, as prompt diagnosis and management can lead to improved patient outcomes. Further research is needed to better understand the pathogenesis and optimal treatment strategies for these ulcers.

Recurrence rate after discontinuation of long-term mebendazole therapy in alveolar echinococcosis (preliminary results).  The recurrence rate was investigated in 19 patients with non-resectable alveolar echinococcosis after discontinuation of a long-term therapy with mebendazole (average treatment 4. This study aimed to investigate the recurrence rate in patients with non-resectable alveolar echinococcosis following discontinuation of long-term mebendazole therapy. A total of 19 patients were included, with an average treatment duration of 4.5 years. The results showed that after discontinuation of mebendazole therapy, 11 out of 19 patients experienced disease recurrence. The recurrence rate was found to be 57.9%. These preliminary findings suggest a high risk of recurrence in alveolar echinococcosis following the cessation of long-term mebendazole treatment. Further studies with larger sample sizes and longer follow-up periods are warranted to confirm these results and determine optimal treatment strategies for preventing recurrence in this patient population.

Transient myocardial ischemia and its relation to determinants of myocardial oxygen demand. This study aimed to investigate the relationship between transient myocardial ischemia and determinants of myocardial oxygen demand. A total of 50 patients with documented coronary artery disease underwent 24-hour ambulatory electrocardiographic monitoring. Episodes of transient myocardial ischemia were detected using ST-segment analysis. Measures of myocardial oxygen demand, including heart rate, blood pressure, and rate-pressure product, were recorded during ischemic episodes and compared to non-ischemic periods. Results showed that transient myocardial ischemia episodes were associated with significant increases in heart rate, blood pressure, and rate-pressure product, indicating increased myocardial oxygen demand. These findings suggest that exacerbations of myocardial ischemia may be triggered by increased oxygen demand, emphasizing the importance of monitoring and controlling determinants of myocardial oxygen demand in patients with coronary artery disease.

Surgical results of intrathoracic gastric volvulus complicating hiatal hernia.  From 1981 to 1988, 138 patients with hiatal hernia were treated surgically at our centre. Between 1981 and 1988, a total of 138 patients with hiatal hernia underwent surgical treatment at our center. Among them, a subset of patients developed intrathoracic gastric volvulus as a complication. We aimed to evaluate the surgical outcomes in these patients. The majority of patients (65%) were female, with a median age of 61 years. Preoperative symptoms included dysphagia (62%), heartburn (42%), and chest pain (23%). Surgical repair of the hiatal hernia was performed in all patients, with the addition of gastropexy in 87% of cases. Intraoperatively, organ ischemia was observed in 70% of patients, requiring gastric resection in 16% of cases. The postoperative course was uneventful in 84% of patients, while complications such as pneumonia and wound infection occurred in 16% of cases. Mortality was observed in 2% of patients. Our findings suggest that surgical intervention for intrathoracic gastric volvulus complicating hiatal hernia is a safe and effective treatment option, with favorable outcomes in the majority of cases.

Mesial temporal sclerosis: pathogenesis, diagnosis, and management. Mesial temporal sclerosis (MTS) is a common cause of drug-resistant epilepsy and is characterized by hippocampal sclerosis and neuronal loss in the mesial temporal lobe. The pathogenesis of MTS is widely debated, with proposed mechanisms including genetic factors, febrile seizures, and hypoxia-ischemia. Diagnosis of MTS typically involves clinical evaluation, electroencephalography, neuroimaging (such as magnetic resonance imaging), and histopathologic examination of surgical specimens. Management of MTS focuses on controlling seizures through antiepileptic drugs and, when necessary, surgical intervention such as hippocampal resection or deep brain stimulation. The prognosis for patients with MTS varies, with some individuals achieving seizure freedom while others continue to experience seizures despite treatment. Further research is needed to better understand the pathogenesis of MTS and to develop more effective therapeutic strategies for managing this debilitating condition.

Doppler echocardiographic evaluation of streptokinase lysis of thrombosed right-sided St.  Jude Medical valves in patients with congenital heart defects. The efficacy of streptokinase lysis in thrombosed right-sided St. Jude Medical valves in patients with congenital heart defects was evaluated using Doppler echocardiography. Ten patients, aged 4 to 50 years, who presented with valve thrombosis were included in the study. Doppler echocardiography was performed before and after streptokinase administration to assess the degree of thrombus lysis. The mean valve gradient decreased significantly from 68.4 mmHg to 19.2 mmHg after streptokinase therapy (p < 0.001). Doppler parameters, including mean velocity and peak velocity, also showed a significant improvement following treatment. No adverse events related to streptokinase administration were observed. This study confirms the effectiveness of streptokinase lysis in thrombosed right-sided St. Jude Medical valves in patients with congenital heart defects. Doppler echocardiography provides a valuable tool for assessing therapeutic response in these cases.

Indwelling epidural catheters for pain control in gynecologic cancer patients. Indwelling epidural catheters have been frequently used for pain control in gynecologic cancer patients. A retrospective study was conducted to evaluate the efficacy and safety of this pain management technique. The medical records of 82 gynecologic cancer patients who received indwelling epidural catheters for pain control were reviewed. The majority of patients (76%) reported satisfactory pain relief with the use of the indwelling epidural catheters. The most common complication observed was catheter-related infection, occurring in 17% of patients. Other complications included catheter migration (5%) and catheter dislodgement (4%). No epidural hematoma or neurologic deficit was reported. The study findings suggest that indwelling epidural catheters can provide effective pain control in gynecologic cancer patients. However, careful monitoring and infection control measures should be implemented to minimize complications associated with this technique.

Cumulative load as a risk factor for back pain.  The association between cumulative load (biomechanic load and exposure time integral over the entire work experience) and back pain was investigated in a group of institutional aides with physically stressful jobs. This study aimed to investigate the association between cumulative load and the occurrence of back pain in institutional aides with physically stressful jobs. A total of X participants were included in the study and their cumulative load, including biomechanic load and exposure time integral over their entire work experience, was assessed. The occurrence of back pain was also recorded, and statistical analysis was performed to determine the relationship between cumulative load and back pain. The results showed a significant association between higher cumulative load and increased risk of back pain in the institutional aides. These findings highlight the importance of considering cumulative load as a risk factor for back pain in physically demanding occupations and could potentially inform interventions and preventative strategies for reducing the prevalence of back pain in these individuals.

Perivascular innervation of the cerebral arteries in spontaneously hypertensive rats--an immunohistochemical study. This study aimed to investigate the perivascular innervation of cerebral arteries in spontaneously hypertensive rats (SHR) through immunohistochemical analysis. The cerebral arteries were collected from SHR and normotensive control rats, and were stained with antibodies against tyrosine hydroxylase (TH) and neuronal nitric oxide synthase (nNOS). The results showed a significantly increased perivascular TH-positive nerve fiber density in the SHR compared to the control rats. Additionally, the perivascular nNOS-positive nerve fibers were also elevated in the SHR, but to a lesser extent. These findings suggest that the perivascular innervation of cerebral arteries is altered in hypertensive conditions, with an increased density of TH-positive nerve fibers. Further investigations are warranted to elucidate the role of altered perivascular innervation in the pathophysiology of hypertension.

Chronic Lyme disease with an expansive granulomatous lesion in the cerebellopontine angle.  Expansive granulomatous lesions in the posterior cranial fossa are rare and have not been reported in conjunction with Lyme disease. We present a case of chronic Lyme disease with an unusual finding of an expansive granulomatous lesion in the cerebellopontine angle, a rare occurrence in conjunction with Lyme disease. The patient presented with symptoms of headache, vertigo, and hearing loss. Imaging studies revealed a large lesion in the posterior cranial fossa. Surgical biopsy confirmed the presence of a granulomatous lesion. Polymerase chain reaction testing was positive for Borrelia burgdorferi, further supporting the diagnosis of Lyme disease. The patient was treated with intravenous antibiotics and showed improvement in symptoms. This case highlights the importance of considering Lyme disease in the differential diagnosis of expansive granulomatous lesions in the posterior cranial fossa.

The effect of chemotherapy on growth in the skeletally immature individual.  One hundred twenty-two children with nonmetastatic osteogenic or Ewing's sarcoma were studied to assess the effect of multiagent adjuvant chemotherapy on skeletal growth and final stature. This study aimed to evaluate the impact of multiagent adjuvant chemotherapy on skeletal growth and final stature in skeletally immature individuals with nonmetastatic osteogenic or Ewing's sarcoma. A total of 122 children were included in the study. Various growth parameters were assessed, including standing height, sitting height, lower limb segment length, and upper limb segment length. The results indicated a significant reduction in both standing height and sitting height after chemotherapy. Additionally, lower limb segment length and upper limb segment length were also found to be significantly decreased. These findings suggest that multiagent adjuvant chemotherapy has a negative effect on skeletal growth and may result in compromised final stature in skeletally immature patients with nonmetastatic osteogenic or Ewing's sarcoma. Further research is needed to explore potential interventions to mitigate these adverse effects.

An objective comparison of intrathecal lidocaine versus fentanyl for the treatment of lower extremity spasticity.  The reduction of spasticity after administration of intrathecal fentanyl, 35 micrograms, and intrathecal lidocaine, 50 mg, was compared with preinjection spasticity levels in ten subjects with central nervous system disease or injury. This study aimed to compare the efficacy of intrathecal lidocaine and fentanyl in reducing lower extremity spasticity. Ten subjects with central nervous system disease or injury were included in the study. Pre-injection spasticity levels were compared with the reduction in spasticity after intrathecal administration of fentanyl (35 micrograms) or lidocaine (50 mg). The results showed that both fentanyl and lidocaine effectively reduced spasticity levels. However, lidocaine demonstrated a greater reduction in spasticity compared to fentanyl. These findings suggest that intrathecal lidocaine may be a more effective treatment option for lower extremity spasticity in individuals with central nervous system disease or injury. Further research is warranted to validate these results and explore the optimal dosages for maximal efficacy.

Pearson's marrow-pancreas syndrome. Pearson's marrow-pancreas syndrome is a rare mitochondrial disorder characterized by hematologic abnormalities and exocrine pancreatic dysfunction. We report a case of a 5-year-old male presenting with failure to thrive, developmental delay, pancytopenia, and malabsorptive diarrhea. Laboratory investigations revealed hypocellular bone marrow with vacuolated precursors and a reduced number of mitochondria. Pancreatic biopsy showed acinar atrophy and fatty replacement. Genetic testing confirmed a heterozygous deletion in mitochondrial DNA spanning the MTTL1 gene, consistent with Pearson's marrow-pancreas syndrome. Treatment with supportive care, including blood transfusions and pancreatic enzyme replacement therapy, was initiated. The patient's hematologic parameters and gastrointestinal symptoms improved with treatment, but he continued to exhibit delayed developmental milestones. This case highlights the importance of considering Pearson's marrow-pancreas syndrome in the differential diagnosis of pancytopenia and pancreatic insufficiency in children, especially those with associated developmental delay. Early recognition and intervention are crucial in managing this multisystem disorder. Further research is needed to better understand the pathogenesis, natural history, and optimal management strategies for Pearson's marrow-pancreas syndrome.

Intraoperative massive suprachoroidal hemorrhage during pars plana vitrectomy.  Seven eyes (7 patients) developed massive suprachoroidal hemorrhage (MSCH) during pars plana vitrectomy (PPV) for complicated retinal detachments. Intraoperative massive suprachoroidal hemorrhage (MSCH) is a rare but serious complication that can occur during pars plana vitrectomy (PPV) for complicated retinal detachments. In this study, we report seven cases of MSCH in patients undergoing PPV. The patients presented with symptoms including sudden decrease in vision, pain, and intraocular pressure elevation during surgery. Immediate intervention was required to control the bleeding and prevent further damage. Surgical techniques used to address MSCH included drainage of the suprachoroidal space, tamponade with gas or silicone oil, and suturing of sclerotomies. Despite prompt intervention, visual outcomes were poor, with six of the seven patients experiencing postoperative visual loss. Our findings highlight the need for caution and preparedness during PPV procedures to minimize the risk of MSCH and emphasize the importance of prompt recognition and intervention in managing this devastating complication.

Human cerebral malaria: association with erythrocyte rosetting and lack of anti-rosetting antibodies. Cerebral malaria is a severe and life-threatening complication of Plasmodium falciparum infection, characterized by the sequestration of infected erythrocytes in the brain vasculature. Erythrocyte rosetting, the adhesion of uninfected erythrocytes to infected ones, is believed to contribute to this sequestration process. Despite this association, the role of anti-rosetting antibodies in cerebral malaria is not well understood. In this study, we investigated the presence of anti-rosetting antibodies in patients with cerebral malaria. We found that the levels of anti-rosetting antibodies were significantly lower in cerebral malaria patients compared to patients with uncomplicated malaria. Furthermore, we observed a higher rosetting rate in the erythrocytes of cerebral malaria patients, indicating an increased potential for sequestration in the brain. These findings suggest that the lack of anti-rosetting antibodies in cerebral malaria may contribute to the pathogenesis of this severe form of the disease. Further studies are needed to explore the mechanisms underlying the reduced production of anti-rosetting antibodies and their potential as a therapeutic target for cerebral malaria.

Cor triatriatum dexter: antemortem diagnosis in an adult by cross sectional echocardiography. This case report describes the antemortem diagnosis of cor triatriatum dexter (CTD) in an adult using cross-sectional echocardiography. CTD is a rare congenital anomaly characterized by the presence of a membrane dividing the right atrium into two chambers. A 51-year-old male presented with dyspnea and palpitations. Echocardiography showed a membrane dividing the right atrium, which was confirmed by further imaging modalities. The patient underwent surgical resection of the membrane, relieving the obstruction. Histopathological examination confirmed the diagnosis of CTD. This case highlights the importance of echocardiography in diagnosing CTD, even in adults. Early detection and intervention can result in improved outcomes for patients with this rare cardiac anomaly. Further studies are needed to better understand the clinical presentation, prognosis, and optimal management of CTD in adults.

Questionable role of CNS radioprophylaxis in the therapeutic management of childhood rhabdomyosarcoma with meningeal extension. The role of central nervous system (CNS) radioprophylaxis in the treatment of childhood rhabdomyosarcoma (RMS) with meningeal extension is unclear. We reviewed the therapeutic management of 92 pediatric patients with RMS and meningeal involvement. The use of CNS radioprophylaxis was investigated. The overall survival rate was 65.2%, with a 5-year survival rate of 54.9%. Among the patients receiving CNS radioprophylaxis, the survival rate was 61.5%. There was no significant difference in survival between patients receiving CNS radioprophylaxis and those who did not. Additionally, the overall incidence of CNS relapse was low (5.4%). The results suggest that the role of CNS radioprophylaxis in the therapeutic management of childhood RMS with meningeal extension is questionable in terms of both survival and prevention of CNS relapse. Further studies are needed to determine the optimal treatment approach for this subgroup of patients.

Natural killer cell activity in patients with liver cirrhosis relative to severity of liver damage. The aim of this study was to assess natural killer (NK) cell activity in patients with liver cirrhosis and evaluate its relation to the severity of liver damage. NK cell activity was measured using a standard chromium release assay in 45 patients with liver cirrhosis and 25 healthy controls. The severity of liver damage in cirrhotic patients was determined using the Child-Turcotte-Pugh (CTP) score. Results showed that NK cell activity was significantly lower in cirrhotic patients compared to healthy controls (p<0.001). Furthermore, a significant negative correlation was found between NK cell activity and CTP score (p=0.002). Subgroup analysis based on the etiology of cirrhosis revealed similar findings. These findings suggest that decreased NK cell activity is associated with the severity of liver damage in cirrhotic patients. Further studies are needed to elucidate the underlying mechanisms and explore the potential of targeting NK cell activity as a therapeutic approach in liver cirrhosis.

The neuroradiology of visual disturbances.  The neuroradiology of visual deficits has advanced dramatically in recent years. Advancements in neuroradiology have greatly improved understanding of the underlying causes of visual deficits. Various imaging techniques, such as magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) and computed tomography (CT), have provided valuable insights into the anatomy and pathology of the visual system. 

MRI is particularly useful in evaluating the structural integrity of the visual pathways, including the optic nerves, chiasm, tracts, and radiations. Diffusion-weighted imaging (DWI) and diffusion tensor imaging (DTI) have enabled visualization and quantitative assessment of axonal integrity and connectivity. Functional MRI (fMRI) has revealed the functional organization and activation patterns of the visual cortex, enhancing our understanding of visual processing.

CT, on the other hand, is often employed to assess the bony structures surrounding the visual system, such as the skull base and orbit. It is also utilized to detect and characterize various lesions, such as tumors and hemorrhages, which may cause visual deficits.

These neuroradiological advancements have revolutionized the diagnosis and management of visual disturbances. They have facilitated early detection of pathologies, guided surgical planning, and enabled non-invasive monitoring of treatment response. Further research and technological advancements in neuroradiology are expected to continue enhancing our understanding of visual deficits and optimizing patient care.

Sleep apnoea syndrome associated with maxillofacial abnormalities. This study aimed to evaluate the association between sleep apnoea syndrome (SAS) and maxillofacial abnormalities. A retrospective analysis was conducted on 50 patients diagnosed with SAS, who underwent polysomnography and cephalometric analysis. The results revealed a high prevalence of maxillofacial abnormalities in patients with SAS, with 80% having a Class II skeletal pattern and 48% showing a retrusive mandible. Furthermore, 38% had a narrow pharyngeal airway and 34% had a high maxillary plane angle. These findings suggest a strong correlation between SAS and maxillofacial abnormalities, highlighting the importance of early detection and treatment of these abnormalities in patients with SAS.

Postural hypotension: pressor effect of octreotide not mediated by norepinephrine. Postural hypotension is a condition characterized by a drop in blood pressure upon standing, leading to symptoms such as dizziness and lightheadedness. Octreotide, a synthetic hormone, is known to have a pressor effect and has been used to treat postural hypotension. This study aimed to investigate the mechanism by which octreotide exerts its pressor effect. The results showed that the pressor effect of octreotide was not mediated by norepinephrine, suggesting the involvement of other pathways. Further research is needed to elucidate the exact mechanism of action of octreotide and its potential as a treatment for postural hypotension.

Glucose intolerance and hyperinsulinemia of cirrhosis are not results of spontaneous or surgical portosystemic shunting.  To assess if spontaneous portosystemic shunting from collaterals contributes to the hyperinsulinemia of cirrhosis, 12 patients with alcoholic cirrhosis underwent a 5-hour oral glucose tolerance test 1 day before and 10 days after an elective side-to-side portacaval shunt. This study aimed to investigate if spontaneous portosystemic shunting from collaterals contributes to the hyperinsulinemia of cirrhosis. Twelve patients with alcoholic cirrhosis underwent a 5-hour oral glucose tolerance test before and after an elective side-to-side portacaval shunt. The results showed that glucose intolerance and hyperinsulinemia were not results of spontaneous or surgical portosystemic shunting. There were no significant differences in fasting plasma insulin, glucose, or insulin resistance before and after the shunt. These findings suggest that factors other than portosystemic shunting contribute to the glucose intolerance and hyperinsulinemia observed in cirrhosis. Further research is needed to identify these factors and understand their role in the pathogenesis of cirrhosis-related metabolic abnormalities.

Power drills to fenestrate exposed bone to stimulate wound healing. This study investigates the use of power drills to fenestrate exposed bone in order to stimulate wound healing. Five patients with chronic non-healing wounds were included in the study. Treatment involved using a power drill to create small holes in the exposed bone, followed by wound dressings and regular monitoring. The results showed that power drill fenestration stimulated wound healing, with all patients experiencing granulation tissue growth and wound closure within 4 weeks of treatment initiation. No complications related to the procedure or wound healing process were observed. The use of power drills in wound healing has the potential to improve outcomes for patients with chronic non-healing wounds. Further research is warranted to determine the optimal techniques and protocols for power drill fenestration and to explore its use in different types of wounds and patient populations.

Surgical resection of intrinsic brain stem lesions: an overview. Surgical resection of intrinsic brain stem lesions is a challenging procedure due to the vital anatomical structures and functional imparities associated with this region. This overview focuses on the outcomes and complications of surgical resection in such cases. A comprehensive literature review of studies involving surgical resection of intrinsic brain stem lesions was conducted. The review included studies involving pediatric and adult patients with different types of intrinsic brain stem lesions. Surgical resection was found to be a potentially effective treatment option, with varying degrees of success depending on the lesion type, location, and extent. Complications associated with the procedure included neurological deficits, postoperative hemorrhage, infection, and cerebrospinal fluid leak. Careful patient selection, meticulous surgical techniques, advanced imaging modalities, and intraoperative monitoring are key factors that contribute to favorable outcomes and minimize complications in surgical resection of intrinsic brain stem lesions. Further research is needed to evaluate long-term functional outcomes and optimize surgical approaches for different lesion types.

Experimental oral foreign body reactions: vegetable materials. This study investigates the foreign body reactions to various vegetable materials in experimental oral conditions. Thirty rabbits were orally implanted with different vegetable materials, including corn husks, fruit skins, and vegetable fibers. The foreign body reactions were evaluated at different time intervals using histological analysis. The results showed that all tested vegetable materials induced foreign body reactions characterized by inflammatory cell infiltrates, fibrosis, and granulation tissue formation. Additionally, the severity of the foreign body reactions varied among the different vegetable materials. Corn husks induced the most pronounced reactions, while fruit skins elicited moderate reactions. These findings highlight the potential risk of using certain vegetable materials in oral procedures and emphasize the importance of further research in this field.

Massive splenomegaly.  Superior results with a combined endovascular and operative approach. Massive splenomegaly can lead to significant morbidity and mortality. Traditional treatment options, such as open splenectomy, are associated with increased operative risks. We present a case of a 52-year-old patient with massive splenomegaly due to chronic lymphocytic leukemia who underwent a combined endovascular and operative approach. The patient initially underwent splenic artery embolization to reduce the size of the spleen. Subsequently, a laparoscopic splenectomy was performed to remove the residual splenic tissue. This combined approach resulted in superior outcomes compared to traditional open splenectomy. The patient experienced a significant reduction in spleen size, alleviating symptoms and improving quality of life. We propose that a combined endovascular and operative approach should be considered as an effective treatment option for patients with massive splenomegaly, particularly those with underlying hematologic malignancies.

Vitrectomy retinotomy aspiration biopsy of choroidal tumors We used an investigational technique for the biopsy of intraocular tumors to aid in the diagnosis of three choroidal tumors. We report the use of vitrectomy retinotomy aspiration biopsy as an investigational technique to aid in the diagnosis of three choroidal tumors. The procedure was performed successfully in all cases and provided valuable information for treatment planning. The technique involves vitrectomy followed by retinotomy and aspiration biopsy of the tumor. Histopathological analysis confirmed the diagnosis of choroidal tumors in all three cases. This minimally invasive approach allows for accurate diagnosis without the need for enucleation or extensive surgical interventions. Further studies are warranted to assess the utility and safety of this technique in a larger cohort of patients.

Multiple representations of pain in human cerebral cortex. Pain is a complex phenomenon that involves various regions of the human cerebral cortex. This study aimed to investigate the multiple representations of pain in the cortex using functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI). Twenty-five healthy volunteers were subjected to thermal pain stimuli, while their brain activity was recorded with fMRI. The results showed that pain activated a widespread network of cortical areas, including the primary somatosensory cortex, insula, cingulate cortex, and prefrontal cortex. Additionally, different types of pain (e.g., acute, chronic) were associated with distinct patterns of cortical activation. These findings shed light on the neurobiological basis of pain processing in the human brain.

Dysplasia and DNA aneuploidy in a pelvic pouch. Dysplasia and DNA aneuploidy are common concerns in patients with a pelvic pouch. In this study, we aimed to investigate the presence and significance of dysplasia and DNA aneuploidy in pelvic pouches. A total of 50 patients who underwent pouchoscopy were included in the study. Dysplasia was identified in 15 patients (30%), with 8 cases (53.3%) showing moderate dysplasia and 7 cases (46.7%) showing mild dysplasia. DNA aneuploidy was detected in 12 patients (24%), indicating genomic instability. Patients with dysplasia and DNA aneuploidy were found to have a higher risk of developing pouchitis and pouch neoplasia. This highlights the importance of regular surveillance and early detection of dysplasia and aneuploidy in patients with pelvic pouches. Further research is needed to explore the underlying mechanisms and develop effective interventions for the prevention and management of pouch-related complications.

Tympano-cartilago-stapediopexy: a method to improve hearing in open technique tympanoplasty. Tympano-cartilago-stapediopexy is a surgical technique proposed to improve hearing outcomes in open technique tympanoplasty. This retrospective study evaluated the effectiveness of this technique in 75 patients with chronic otitis media. The procedure involved using cartilage grafts to stabilize the ossicular chain and improve sound transmission. Audiological assessment showed a significant improvement in pure-tone averages and air-bone gaps postoperatively. There were no major complications associated with the procedure. However, further long-term studies are needed to evaluate the durability of hearing improvement and potential complications. Tympano-cartilago-stapediopexy appears to be a promising option for patients undergoing open technique tympanoplasty.

Molecular phenotype of a pediatric small round cell tumor. Small round cell tumors (SRCTs) are a heterogeneous group of aggressive pediatric malignancies that pose diagnostic challenges due to overlapping histological features. This case report aimed to describe the molecular phenotype of a pediatric patient with SRCT. The tumor exhibited diffuse positivity for vimentin, suggesting a mesenchymal origin. Immunohistochemistry further revealed strong expression of CD99 and FLI1, consistent with the diagnosis of Ewing sarcoma. Fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH) analysis identified the presence of EWSR1 gene rearrangement. Additionally, molecular profiling via next-generation sequencing (NGS) revealed somatic mutations in TP53, PIK3CA, and PTEN genes. This case highlights the importance of integrating histological, immunohistochemical, FISH, and NGS analyses for accurate diagnosis and personalized treatment strategies in pediatric SRCTs.

Intraocular lens complications. Intraocular lens (IOL) complications are common in cataract surgery and can significantly impact visual outcomes. This retrospective study aimed to evaluate the frequency and types of IOL complications in a large cohort of patients who underwent cataract surgery with IOL implantation. Data from 2,000 patients were reviewed, and complications were categorized as early or late, and minor or major. The overall incidence of IOL complications was 10.5%, with 6.2% occurring early and 4.3% occurring late. The majority of complications were minor (7.8%), including posterior capsule opacification and decentration. Major complications were less frequent (2.7%) and included IOL dislocation and endophthalmitis. Risk factors associated with complications included older age, pre-existing ocular conditions, and surgical technique. The study highlights the importance of careful patient selection, thorough preoperative assessment, and meticulous surgical technique in reducing the incidence of IOL complications. Further research is needed to identify strategies for minimizing and managing these complications to optimize visual outcomes for cataract surgery patients.

Cutaneous melanoma and bilateral retinoblastoma. Cutaneous melanoma is a malignant tumor arising from melanocytes in the skin, while retinoblastoma is a rare childhood cancer of the retina. The coexistence of these two conditions is extremely rare and poses diagnostic and therapeutic challenges. We present a case of a 35-year-old male with a history of bilateral retinoblastoma who presented with a suspicious skin lesion on his back. Biopsy confirmed the presence of cutaneous melanoma. The patient underwent wide excision of the melanoma followed by adjuvant therapy. Genetic testing revealed a mutation in the RB1 gene, confirming the diagnosis of hereditary retinoblastoma syndrome. The management of this patient was further complicated by the need for surveillance and potential prophylactic measures for both conditions. This case highlights the importance of considering multiple malignancies in patients with a known genetic predisposition and emphasizes the need for interdisciplinary collaboration in the care of these complex cases.

Abdominal wall reconstruction (the "mutton chop" flap). Abdominal wall defects resulting from trauma, infection, or surgery can present a challenging problem for reconstructive surgeons. The "mutton chop" flap is a technique that has been used to reconstruct such defects. This abstract provides a summary of the literature on the use of the mutton chop flap for abdominal wall reconstruction. The technique involves the creation of a flap of tissue from the lateral abdominal wall, which is mobilized and then rotated to cover the defect. The flap provides a reliable and durable option for reconstruction, with low complication rates and good aesthetic outcomes. It can be used in a variety of clinical scenarios, including large defects and contaminated wounds. The mutton chop flap is a valuable tool in the armamentarium of the reconstructive surgeon for abdominal wall reconstruction.

Therapeutic embolization: enhanced radiolabeled monitoring. Therapeutic embolization is a minimally invasive procedure used to treat various medical conditions. This study aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of enhanced radiolabeled monitoring during therapeutic embolization. A total of 60 patients were included in the study, with 30 undergoing standard embolization and 30 undergoing enhanced radiolabeled monitoring. The results showed that the use of enhanced radiolabeled monitoring significantly improved the accuracy of the embolization procedure by providing real-time visualization of the embolic agent distribution. Additionally, this enhanced technique allowed for better assessment of the procedural endpoint and reduced the risk of complications. Overall, the findings highlight the benefits of using enhanced radiolabeled monitoring in therapeutic embolization procedures.

Surrogate receptor-mediated cellular cytotoxicity against malignant human glioma cells. Glioma is a highly aggressive form of brain cancer with limited treatment options. The development of targeted therapies that can specifically attack glioma cells is crucial to improving patient outcomes. Surrogate receptor-mediated cellular cytotoxicity (SRCC) is a novel approach that utilizes engineered cells expressing specific receptors to induce cytotoxicity against tumor cells. In this study, we investigated the efficacy of SRCC against malignant human glioma cells. Our results demonstrate that SRCC can effectively induce cytotoxicity against glioma cells in vitro. Furthermore, we observed that SRCC-mediated cytotoxicity was dependent on the expression of the specific receptor on the engineered cells. Importantly, SRCC did not exhibit significant cytotoxicity against normal human astrocytes, suggesting a favorable safety profile. These findings suggest that SRCC may be a promising therapeutic strategy for targeting malignant glioma cells. Further research is needed to optimize the SRCC approach and evaluate its efficacy in preclinical and clinical settings.

Inflammatory pseudotumor of intra-abdominal lymph nodes manifesting as recurrent fever of unknown origin: a case report. We present a case report of a 42-year-old male presenting with recurrent fevers of unknown origin. Initial investigations revealed elevated inflammatory markers and the presence of intra-abdominal lymphadenopathy. The patient underwent surgical excision of the enlarged lymph nodes, and histopathological examination showed a proliferation of myofibroblastic spindle cells infiltrated by inflammatory cells, consistent with an inflammatory pseudotumor. The patient's symptoms resolved following surgical intervention, and there was no evidence of recurrence at the 6-month follow-up. This case highlights the importance of considering inflammatory pseudotumor as a differential diagnosis in patients with recurrent fever and lymphadenopathy, and emphasizes the potential role of surgical excision in the management of this condition.

Rehabilitation in brain disorders.  1. Rehabilitation plays a vital role in the management of brain disorders, as it aims to improve functional outcomes and enhance the quality of life for affected individuals. This review article provides an overview of rehabilitation strategies employed in common brain disorders, including stroke, traumatic brain injury, and neurodegenerative diseases. The rehabilitation process often begins during the acute phase and continues throughout the subacute and chronic phases of recovery. The interventions utilized in rehabilitation programs include physical therapy, occupational therapy, speech and language therapy, cognitive training, and psychosocial support. These approaches aim to address impairments in motor function, cognition, communication, and psychosocial well-being. Evidence-based rehabilitation techniques, such as constraint-induced movement therapy, task-specific training, and neurofeedback, have shown promising results in promoting neuroplasticity and functional recovery. Furthermore, the importance of multidisciplinary teams, individualized treatment plans, and long-term follow-up is emphasized to optimize rehabilitation outcomes. Future research should focus on identifying optimal timing and intensity of rehabilitation interventions, as well as exploring novel approaches, such as virtual reality and assistive technologies, to further enhance rehabilitation outcomes in individuals with brain disorders.

Gastrointestinal pathology in adult iron overdose.  The gastrointestinal effects of iron overdose have been described in children. Iron overdose is a common form of poisoning, particularly in children. However, the effects of iron overdose on the gastrointestinal tract in adults have not been extensively studied. A retrospective analysis of adult patients who presented with iron overdose was conducted to evaluate the gastrointestinal pathology associated with this condition. A total of 43 patients were included in the study, with a mean age of 35 years. The most common gastrointestinal symptoms observed were abdominal pain (72%) and vomiting (58%). Endoscopic evaluation of the upper gastrointestinal tract revealed erosive gastritis in 37% of patients, while colonoscopy showed mucosal ulcerations in 53% of cases. These findings suggest that iron overdose can lead to significant gastrointestinal pathology in adults, emphasizing the need for prompt recognition and appropriate management of this condition to prevent potential complications.

Antisocial alcoholics: are there clinically significant diagnostic subtypes? Of 360 alcoholic male inpatients assessed with a diagnostic interview, 106 (29%) were found to have a co-occurring diagnosis of antisocial personality. A research study was conducted to determine if there are clinically significant diagnostic subtypes of antisocial alcoholics. The study included 360 alcoholic male inpatients who underwent a diagnostic interview. Out of these individuals, it was found that 106 (29%) had a co-occurring diagnosis of antisocial personality. The results suggest that there may be distinct subtypes of alcoholics with antisocial behavior. Further research is needed to explore these subtypes and their implications for treatment and intervention strategies. This study provides valuable insight into the relationship between alcoholism and antisocial personality disorder.

Locked intramedullary nailing of femoral shaft fractures. Locked intramedullary nailing is a commonly used technique for stabilizing femoral shaft fractures. This retrospective study aims to evaluate the outcomes of locked intramedullary nailing in a cohort of patients with femoral shaft fractures. Data from patients who underwent locked intramedullary nailing for femoral shaft fractures between [time period] were analyzed. The primary outcomes of interest included union rates, complications (such as infection or hardware failure), and functional outcomes. Secondary outcomes included operative time, length of hospital stay, and need for additional procedures. The results demonstrated high union rates, low complication rates, and satisfactory functional outcomes. Locked intramedullary nailing can be considered a reliable and effective treatment option for femoral shaft fractures.

Acute oculogyric crisis after administration of prochlorperazine. We report a case of acute oculogyric crisis following the administration of prochlorperazine. A 45-year-old male patient presented with sudden onset of sustained upward deviation of the eyes shortly after receiving an intramuscular injection of prochlorperazine for nausea. The oculogyric crisis persisted for approximately 15 minutes and was associated with distress and anxiety. Neurological examination was unremarkable, and no other extrapyramidal symptoms were present. The crisis resolved spontaneously and no further episodes occurred. Oculogyric crisis is a rare but known side effect of prochlorperazine, a commonly used antiemetic medication. Clinicians should be aware of this potential adverse reaction and consider alternative treatments if necessary.

Use of monoclonal antibody KP1 for identifying normal and neoplastic human mast cells. The monoclonal antibody KP1 was used to identify normal and neoplastic human mast cells. This study included samples from 24 patients with various mast cell-related diseases and 6 control subjects. Immunohistochemical staining was performed on formalin-fixed, paraffin-embedded tissue sections using KP1 antibody. The results showed that KP1 strongly stained mast cells in normal tissues, including skin and lymphoid organs. In neoplastic mast cells, KP1 showed variable staining intensity, with higher expression observed in aggressive mastocytosis and systemic mastocytosis with associated hematologic non-mast cell lineage disease. These findings suggest that KP1 can be a valuable tool for the identification and characterization of normal and neoplastic human mast cells. Further studies are needed to evaluate its diagnostic and prognostic potential in mast cell-related diseases.

Narrow excision (1-cm margin).  A safe procedure for thin cutaneous melanoma. Narrow excision, defined as a 1-cm margin, has been proposed as a safe and effective surgical procedure for the treatment of thin cutaneous melanoma. We conducted a retrospective study to evaluate the outcomes of patients undergoing this procedure. A total of 200 patients with thin cutaneous melanoma (鈮1 mm thick) were included in the study. The primary endpoint was local recurrence rate. Secondary endpoints included overall survival, disease-free survival, and complication rates. The median follow-up period was 5 years. The local recurrence rate was 2%, and there were no cases of regional or distant metastasis. Overall survival rate at 5 years was 95%. Disease-free survival rate at 5 years was 92%. Complication rates were minimal, with only mild wound infections reported in a few cases. Our findings support the use of narrow excision with a 1-cm margin as a safe and effective treatment option for thin cutaneous melanoma.

Routine and quantitative EEG analysis in Gilles de la Tourette's syndrome. Gilles de la Tourette's syndrome (GTS) is a neurodevelopmental disorder characterized by motor and vocal tics. The aim of this study was to assess the role of routine and quantitative electroencephalogram (EEG) analysis in GTS patients. Seventy-five patients diagnosed with GTS were included, and routine EEG recordings were performed. In addition, quantitative EEG analysis using power spectral analysis was conducted. The results revealed abnormal findings in 46 patients (61.3%) on routine EEG, including slow waves, epileptiform discharges, and focal abnormalities. Quantitative EEG analysis demonstrated increased power in delta and theta bands, suggestive of cortical dysfunction. The findings suggest that routine EEG recording can provide valuable information in assessing GTS patients, as it frequently detects abnormal findings. Furthermore, quantitative EEG analysis may assist in identifying specific cortical abnormalities associated with GTS, emphasizing its potential as a valuable tool in the management and understanding of the disorder.

Interphase cytogenetic analysis in the diagnosis and study of neoplastic disorders. Interphase cytogenetic analysis has emerged as a valuable tool in the diagnosis and study of neoplastic disorders. This technique allows for the detection and analysis of genetic abnormalities in interphase cells without the need for cell division. In this study, we evaluated the utility of interphase cytogenetic analysis in the diagnosis of neoplastic disorders. We assessed a cohort of patients presenting with various types of neoplasms, including leukemias, lymphomas, and solid tumors. Our findings demonstrated the presence of specific chromosomal abnormalities in the neoplastic cells of these patients, which provided important diagnostic and prognostic information. Additionally, interphase cytogenetic analysis allowed for the detection of minimal residual disease and the monitoring of treatment response. Overall, our results highlight the significance of interphase cytogenetic analysis in the comprehensive evaluation of neoplastic disorders, contributing to improved patient management and outcomes.

Potential role of beta-carotene in prevention of oral cancer. This review aims to assess the potential role of beta-carotene in the prevention of oral cancer. Epidemiological studies have indicated that increased intake of dietary antioxidants, such as beta-carotene, may reduce the risk of developing various cancers, including oral cancer. The review examines the available evidence from both animal and human studies to determine the efficacy of beta-carotene in preventing oral cancer. Animal studies have shown promising results, with beta-carotene demonstrating chemopreventive effects by inhibiting the growth of cancer cells and reducing oxidative stress. However, the results from human studies have been inconsistent, with some studies suggesting a protective effect of beta-carotene supplementation, while others have shown no significant benefits. The review also discusses the potential mechanisms by which beta-carotene may exert its anticancer effects, including its antioxidant properties and modulation of gene expression. Further research is necessary to elucidate the optimal dose and duration of beta-carotene supplementation for oral cancer prevention.

Unusual aspects of aortovenous fistulas associated with ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysms. Aortovenous fistulas (AVFs) are rare complications of ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysms (AAAs), with limited information available regarding their characteristics and management. We present a retrospective study of 26 patients diagnosed with AVFs associated with ruptured AAAs, focusing on the unusual aspects of these cases. Among the study population, there was a male predominance (85%) and a mean age of 71 years. The most common presenting symptom was hypotension (88%), followed by an abdominal mass (69%) and abdominal pain (54%). CT angiography was the preferred diagnostic modality, with all patients receiving emergency surgery. The AVF was most commonly found between the AAA and the inferior vena cava (65%), and the majority of patients underwent open repair (81%). Postoperative mortality in our study was 35%, primarily attributed to hemodynamic instability and multisystem organ failure. Our study highlights the rare but significant occurrence of AVFs associated with ruptured AAAs, emphasizing the need for prompt recognition and appropriate surgical management to improve patient outcomes.

General assay for phosphoproteins in cerebrospinal fluid: a candidate marker for paraneoplastic cerebellar degeneration. Paraneoplastic cerebellar degeneration (PCD) is a rare neurological disorder associated with cancer. Early diagnosis is crucial for initiating appropriate treatment and improving patient outcomes. In this study, we developed a general assay for phosphoproteins in cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) as a potential biomarker for PCD. CSF samples from 68 patients with PCD and 86 control subjects were analyzed using an antibody-based method. We observed significantly higher levels of phosphoproteins in the CSF of PCD patients compared to controls. The assay showed a sensitivity of 87.5% and a specificity of 92.4% in distinguishing PCD from non-PCD cases. Importantly, phosphoprotein levels correlated with disease severity and response to therapy. These findings suggest that the general assay for phosphoproteins in CSF holds promise as a candidate marker for PCD, enabling early diagnosis and targeted treatment strategies. Further validation studies with larger cohorts are warranted to confirm these results.

Ulnar nerve decompression with medial epicondylectomy for neuropathy at the elbow.  Ulnar nerve decompression with medial epicondylectomy was performed in 66 elbows between 1966 and 1986 for compressive ulnar neuropathy at the elbow. Between 1966 and 1986, 66 elbows with compressive ulnar neuropathy at the elbow underwent ulnar nerve decompression with medial epicondylectomy. The majority of patients experienced symptoms of numbness and tingling in the ulnar nerve distribution. Postoperative assessments showed improvement in sensory symptoms in 87% of patients and improvement in motor symptoms in 82% of patients. Complications included transient neurapraxia in three cases and nonunion of the medial epicondyle in four cases. Most patients reported good or excellent results, with 80% having no residual symptoms or mild symptoms. Ulnar nerve decompression with medial epicondylectomy appears to be an effective treatment option for compressive ulnar neuropathy at the elbow, providing symptom relief and functional improvement.

Management of renovascular disease. Renovascular disease is a common cause of hypertension and renal dysfunction. The management of this condition involves treating the underlying cause, which is often renal artery stenosis. The two main treatment options for renovascular disease are medical therapy and revascularization. Medical therapy includes the use of antihypertensive medications, lipid-lowering agents, and antiplatelet therapy. Revascularization can be achieved through either surgical or endovascular techniques, such as angioplasty and stenting. The choice of treatment depends on various factors, including the severity of the disease, the presence of comorbidities, and patient preferences. Revascularization procedures have been shown to improve blood pressure control, kidney function, and overall patient outcomes. However, the benefit of revascularization over medical therapy alone remains controversial. Further research is needed to establish the most effective management strategy for renovascular disease.

Skin exudate levels of interleukin 6, interleukin 1 and other cytokines in mycosis fungoides. Mycosis fungoides is a rare type of cutaneous T-cell lymphoma. The exact mechanisms underlying its pathogenesis and progression are not fully understood. This study aimed to investigate the levels of interleukin 6 (IL-6), interleukin 1 (IL-1), and other cytokines in skin exudates of patients with mycosis fungoides. Skin exudate samples were collected from 50 patients with mycosis fungoides and 30 healthy controls. Levels of IL-6, IL-1, and other cytokines were measured using enzyme-linked immunosorbent assays. Compared to healthy controls, patients with mycosis fungoides had significantly higher levels of IL-6 and IL-1 in their skin exudates (p < 0.001). Additionally, levels of other cytokines, including tumor necrosis factor alpha and interferon gamma, were also elevated in the patient group (p < 0.05). These findings suggest that dysregulated cytokine production, particularly IL-6 and IL-1, may contribute to the pathogenesis and progression of mycosis fungoides. Further research is needed to elucidate the specific roles of these cytokines in the development and progression of this disease.

Is liver transplantation justified for the treatment of hepatic malignancies? Twenty-eight patients received orthotopic liver transplants for malignant disease between February 1, 1984, and December 31, 1989.  Preoperative diagnoses included hepatocellular carcinoma (n = 16), cholangiocarcinoma (n = 3), other primary hepatic tumors (n = 6), and metastatic diseases to the liver (n = 3). Liver transplantation as a treatment for hepatic malignancies remains a topic of debate. In a study conducted between February 1984 and December 1989, 28 patients underwent orthotopic liver transplant for malignant diseases. The preoperative diagnoses included hepatocellular carcinoma (n=16), cholangiocarcinoma (n=3), other primary hepatic tumors (n=6), and metastatic diseases to the liver (n=3). The study aimed to evaluate the efficacy of liver transplantation for these malignancies. Further details regarding patient selection, surgical procedure, and post-transplant outcomes are necessary to fully assess the justification and outcomes of liver transplantation for hepatic malignancies. additional information regarding patient selection, surgical procedure, and post-transplant outcomes is necessary in evaluating the justification and outcomes of liver transplantation for hepatic malignancies.

Microstaging of squamous cell carcinomas. Accurate staging of squamous cell carcinomas (SCCs) is crucial for determining prognosis and guiding treatment decisions. This study aimed to evaluate the utility of microstaging in improving the classification of SCCs. A total of 100 histologically confirmed SCC cases were analyzed retrospectively. Each case was microstaged according to the depth of invasion (DOI) and lymphovascular invasion (LVI) status. The results were compared with the conventional staging system, which only considers tumor size and lymph node involvement. Microstaging revealed that 30% of cases had a deeper DOI than initially assessed, while 22% had LVI that was not identified in the conventional staging. These additional findings resulted in an upstaging of 34% of cases. Furthermore, microstaging allowed for better prediction of lymph node involvement, with a significantly higher accuracy compared to conventional staging. These results highlight the importance of microstaging in providing more precise information about the extent of SCCs, leading to improved prognostication and tailored treatment strategies for patients.

An autosomal recessive gene that delays expression of lupus in BXSB mice. This study focuses on the identification of an autosomal recessive gene that delays the expression of lupus in BXSB mice. BXSB mice are commonly used as an animal model for systemic lupus erythematosus. We identified and characterized a novel gene that is responsible for delaying the onset and severity of lupus symptoms in these mice. Through genetic mapping and sequencing analysis, we found that this gene encodes a protein involved in the regulation of immune responses. We also observed that the expression of this gene is significantly reduced in BXSB mice compared to other strains. These findings provide valuable insights into the genetic factors that modulate lupus development and may contribute to the development of targeted therapies for this autoimmune disease.

Intracatheter streptokinase for recurrent peritonitis in CAPD. Recurrent peritonitis is a common and serious complication in patients undergoing continuous ambulatory peritoneal dialysis (CAPD). Streptokinase is a thrombolytic agent that has been used successfully in the treatment of intraluminal fibrin clots and occluded catheters. This prospective study evaluates the efficacy and safety of intracatheter streptokinase in the treatment of recurrent peritonitis in CAPD patients. Twenty patients with recurrent peritonitis were treated with intracatheter streptokinase for a duration of 2 weeks. The treatment was successful in 16 out of 20 patients, with resolution of peritonitis and no recurrence during the 2-week follow-up period. The remaining 4 patients required catheter removal due to persistent infection. No major adverse events or bleeding complications were observed. Intracatheter streptokinase appears to be a safe and effective treatment option for recurrent peritonitis in CAPD patients, offering a potential alternative to catheter removal. Further studies are warranted to confirm these results and determine the optimal dosing regimen.

Isolated ventral pancreatitis in a patient with pancreas divisum. We report a case of isolated ventral pancreatitis in a patient with pancreas divisum. A 45-year-old male presented with severe epigastric pain and elevated pancreatic enzyme levels. Imaging studies revealed a dilated dorsal pancreatic duct and a narrowed ventral pancreatic duct. Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography confirmed the presence of pancreas divisum. Histopathological examination of the pancreatic tissue demonstrated inflammation and necrosis limited to the ventral pancreas. This case highlights the importance of considering isolated pancreatitis in patients with pancreas divisum, especially when the clinical and radiological findings are consistent with involvement of the ventral pancreas. Further studies are needed to better understand the pathogenesis and optimal management of isolated ventral pancreatitis in pancreas divisum.

Kenneth McKenzie, Harvey Cushing, and the early neurosurgical treatment of spasmodic torticollis.  In 1923, Dr. In this historical review, the early neurosurgical treatment of spasmodic torticollis by Dr. Kenneth McKenzie and Dr. Harvey Cushing in 1923 is discussed. McKenzie and Cushing performed ventral rhizotomy and ganglionectomy to treat the condition, which involves involuntary contractions of the neck muscles. They observed significant improvement in symptoms in the majority of their patients, with only a few experiencing limited relief. McKenzie and Cushing reported that the surgery was generally well-tolerated, with no major complications reported. This early work laid the foundation for the future development of surgical techniques for the treatment of spasmodic torticollis. Despite the limitations of this historical study, it highlights the pioneering efforts of McKenzie and Cushing in the field of neurosurgery.

Defective dystrophin in Duchenne and Becker dystrophy myotubes in cell culture. Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD) and Becker muscular dystrophy (BMD) are genetic disorders characterized by the absence or dysfunction of dystrophin, a protein important for muscle structure and function. This study aimed to assess dystrophin expression in cell cultures derived from DMD and BMD patients. Myotubes derived from affected individuals exhibited a complete absence of dystrophin compared to control myotubes. In addition, a high proportion of BMD myotubes showed a shorter dystrophin isoform compared to controls. These findings suggest that the absence or abnormality of dystrophin is a key molecular feature of DMD and BMD. Furthermore, the expression pattern of dystrophin isoforms may differ between DMD and BMD, which could potentially contribute to the phenotypic variation observed in these disorders. This study highlights the importance of understanding the molecular basis of dystrophin dysfunction in DMD and BMD for the development of targeted therapies.

Transesophageal echocardiography in the diagnosis of ostial left coronary artery stenosis. Ostial left coronary artery stenosis (OLCAS) is a potentially life-threatening condition that requires accurate diagnostic methods for early detection and intervention. This study aimed to evaluate the role of transesophageal echocardiography (TEE) in the diagnosis of OLCAS. A retrospective analysis was conducted on 50 patients who presented with suspected coronary artery disease and underwent TEE followed by coronary angiography. TEE accurately identified OLCAS in 45 patients, yielding a sensitivity of 90% and a specificity of 96%. The positive and negative predictive values were 95% and 91%, respectively. Additionally, TEE provided valuable information regarding the location, severity, and extent of stenosis. No complications or adverse events related to TEE were observed. These findings suggest that TEE is a reliable and safe diagnostic tool for the detection of OLCAS, allowing for timely intervention and improved patient outcomes. Further prospective studies are warranted to confirm these findings.

Long-term effects of delapril on renal function and urinary excretion of kallikrein, prostaglandin E2, and thromboxane B2 in hypertensive patients.  The effects of delapril, an angiotensin converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitor, on renal function and the renin-angiotensin and kallikrein-prostaglandin systems were investigated in 10 hypertensive patients who were treated for between 4 months and 1 year. This study aimed to investigate the effects of long-term treatment with the angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitor delapril on renal function and the renin-angiotensin and kallikrein-prostaglandin systems in hypertensive patients. Ten patients were treated with delapril for a duration of 4 months to 1 year. The results showed that delapril treatment had a positive impact on renal function, as evidenced by improvements in renal function parameters. Additionally, delapril was found to increase the urinary excretion of kallikrein, prostaglandin E2, and thromboxane B2, indicating activation of the kallikrein-prostaglandin system. These findings suggest that delapril may have beneficial effects on renal function and the renin-angiotensin and kallikrein-prostaglandin systems in hypertensive patients.

Management of hypertension by reduction in sympathetic activity. Hypertension, also known as high blood pressure, is a common medical condition that may lead to various cardiovascular events if left untreated. Sympathetic overactivity has been implicated in the development and progression of hypertension. In this study, we aimed to investigate the potential of reducing sympathetic activity to manage hypertension. We conducted a systematic review and meta-analysis of studies that evaluated interventions targeting sympathetic activity in hypertensive patients. The interventions included lifestyle modifications, pharmacological agents, and non-pharmacological interventions such as exercise and meditation. Our findings revealed that reducing sympathetic activity through these interventions resulted in a significant reduction in blood pressure levels. These results emphasize the importance of targeting sympathetic overactivity as a therapeutic strategy in the management of hypertension. Further research is warranted to explore optimal interventions and their long-term effects on blood pressure control.

Surgery for acute and chronic cholecystitis.  Cholecystostomy and cholecystectomy remain appropriate and effective therapy for acute and chronic cholecystitis. Cholecystostomy and cholecystectomy are commonly used surgical options for the treatment of acute and chronic cholecystitis. These procedures have proven to be appropriate and effective therapies for this condition. Cholecystostomy involves the insertion of a tube to drain the gallbladder, while cholecystectomy involves the removal of the gallbladder entirely. Both procedures have shown satisfactory outcomes in terms of symptom relief and prevention of further complications. The choice of procedure depends on factors such as the severity of the condition and the patient's overall health. Surgeons should carefully consider the individual patient's characteristics and make an informed decision regarding the most suitable surgical approach.

Bleeding gastroesophageal varices: gastric vein embolization after partial portal decompression. Gastroesophageal varices with bleeding can be a life-threatening complication in patients with portal hypertension. This study aimed to evaluate the efficacy of gastric vein embolization following partial portal decompression for the management of bleeding gastroesophageal varices. Fifteen patients with bleeding varices who underwent a surgical portacaval shunt were enrolled in this study. Gastric vein embolization was performed using cyanoacrylate tissue adhesive. The follow-up period ranged from 6 to 36 months. The results showed successful embolization of gastric veins in all patients, with complete eradication of varices in 13 patients. One patient experienced recurrent variceal bleeding after 9 months and required repeat embolization. No major complications were observed. Gastric vein embolization following partial portal decompression is a safe and effective treatment option for managing bleeding gastroesophageal varices. Further studies and long-term follow-up are warranted to confirm these findings.

Delayed onset of cardiac arrhythmias from sustained-release verapamil. Delayed onset of cardiac arrhythmias is a known complication of sustained-release verapamil therapy. We present a case study of a 58-year-old male with a history of hypertension and atrial fibrillation, who experienced recurrent ventricular tachycardia three days after initiating sustained-release verapamil. The patient had been receiving regular electrocardiogram monitoring, which had been normal prior to verapamil initiation. The delayed onset of ventricular arrhythmias suggests a potential proarrhythmic effect of sustained-release verapamil. Clinicians should be aware of this possible adverse effect, especially in patients with preexisting arrhythmias, and close monitoring should be implemented during the first few days of verapamil therapy. Further studies are warranted to investigate the underlying mechanisms and risk factors associated with this delayed onset effect.

Polyglucosan body disease.  Adult polyglucosan disease has been described in 15 cases. Polyglucosan body disease (PGBD) is a rare progressive neurological disorder characterized by the accumulation of abnormal glycogen-like material, known as polyglucosan bodies, within nerve cells. While PGBD is primarily considered a childhood disorder, adult-onset cases have been reported in a limited number of patients. We present a case report of an adult patient with PGBD, highlighting their clinical presentation, diagnostic workup, and management. We also review the existing literature on adult PGBD cases to provide a comprehensive understanding of the disease. Early recognition of adult PGBD is crucial for appropriate management and genetic counseling. Further research is needed to elucidate the underlying mechanisms and potential treatment options for this rare condition.

Plasma cell granuloma of the nasal cavity treated by radiation therapy. Plasma cell granuloma is a rare benign tumor that can occur in various locations, including the nasal cavity. This study presents the clinical characteristics and treatment outcomes of nasal cavity plasma cell granuloma with radiation therapy. Seven patients with histologically confirmed plasma cell granuloma of the nasal cavity were included in this retrospective analysis. All patients presented with nasal obstruction and/or epistaxis. Radiological imaging showed soft tissue masses in the nasal cavity in all cases. Treatment consisted of radiation therapy with a median dose of 40 Gy. Following treatment, all patients showed complete resolution of nasal symptoms and significant reduction in tumor size on imaging. No acute or late radiation-related toxicities were observed. In conclusion, radiation therapy appears to be an effective and well-tolerated treatment option for nasal cavity plasma cell granuloma, achieving both symptom relief and tumor control.
