The recalcitrant perineal wound after rectal extirpation.  Applications of muscle flap closure. A case of a recalcitrant perineal wound following rectal extirpation is presented. The patient, a 47-year-old male with a history of rectal cancer, developed a non-healing perineal wound despite previous attempts at conservative management. After thorough evaluation, it was determined that a muscle flap closure would be the most appropriate intervention. The procedure involved mobilization and transposition of the gracilis muscle from the medial thigh to the perineal area, followed by meticulous closure of the wound. Postoperative care included strict wound care and antibiotic prophylaxis. The patient exhibited excellent wound healing with no evidence of infection or flap necrosis during the follow-up period of six months. Muscle flap closure represents a valuable option for the management of recalcitrant perineal wounds, providing successful outcomes in terms of wound healing and patient satisfaction. Further studies are warranted to evaluate long-term outcomes and compare alternative approaches.

Surgical correction of hydrothorax from diaphragmatic eventration in children on peritoneal dialysis.  Continuous ambulatory peritoneal dialysis (CAPD) is frequently used in the pediatric age group for reversible and end-stage renal failure. This case report describes the surgical correction of hydrothorax in children on continuous ambulatory peritoneal dialysis (CAPD) due to diaphragmatic eventration. Hydrothorax is a rare but serious complication of CAPD, where dialysate fluid leaks into the pleural cavity. Two pediatric patients undergoing CAPD presented with respiratory distress and were diagnosed with hydrothorax. Surgical correction was performed using laparoscopic exploration and diaphragmatic plication. Both patients experienced resolution of symptoms and improvement in lung function following the procedure. The authors highlight the importance of prompt recognition and appropriate management of hydrothorax in CAPD patients to prevent complications and improve outcomes. They also emphasize the safety and efficacy of laparoscopic diaphragmatic plication as a treatment option in this population.

Progressive coma after the transsphenoidal decompression of a pituitary adenoma with marked suprasellar extension: report of two cases. Transsphenoidal decompression is a common surgical treatment for pituitary adenomas. However, rare complications such as progressive coma can occur. Here, we report two cases of progressive coma following transsphenoidal decompression for pituitary adenomas with marked suprasellar extension. Both patients initially experienced transient improvement after surgery but subsequently developed worsening neurological symptoms, leading to coma within 72 hours. Imaging studies revealed significant suprasellar extension of the adenomas, which likely caused compression and ischemia of surrounding brain tissue. Despite aggressive treatment, both patients deteriorated and eventually died. These cases highlight the potential for severe neurological complications following transsphenoidal decompression for pituitary adenomas with marked suprasellar extension and the need for close monitoring and early intervention in such cases. Further research is required to better understand and prevent these rare complications.

Cytologic features of poorly differentiated 'insular' carcinoma of the thyroid, as revealed by fine-needle aspiration biopsy. Fine-needle aspiration biopsy (FNAB) is a valuable tool for the diagnosis of thyroid cancer. In this study, we examined the cytologic features of poorly differentiated 'insular' carcinoma of the thyroid, a rare and aggressive type of thyroid cancer. Our aim was to identify specific cytologic characteristics that can aid in the accurate diagnosis of this malignancy. 

A retrospective analysis of FNAB specimens from patients with confirmed insular carcinoma of the thyroid was conducted. The cytologic features of these specimens were compared to those of other thyroid malignancies. 

Our findings revealed several distinct cytologic features characteristic of insular carcinoma. These included large pleomorphic cells with high nuclear-cytoplasmic ratios, frequent mitotic figures, and prominent nucleoli. Additionally, the presence of insular clusters and single cells with a trabecular pattern were observed. These features were helpful in differentiating insular carcinoma from other types of thyroid cancer on FNAB specimens. 

In conclusion, the cytologic features of poorly differentiated 'insular' carcinoma of the thyroid, as identified on FNAB, provide valuable diagnostic information. Recognition of these features can aid in the accurate and timely diagnosis of this aggressive malignancy.

Differences between florid osseous dysplasia and chronic diffuse sclerosing osteomyelitis.  Florid osseous dysplasia (FOD) is confused in the literature with chronic diffuse sclerosing osteomyelitis. Florid osseous dysplasia (FOD) and chronic diffuse sclerosing osteomyelitis (CDSO) are two conditions that share clinical and radiographic features, causing confusion in the literature. This study aims to differentiate between FOD and CDSO based on their clinical, radiographic, and histopathological characteristics. FOD primarily affects middle-aged African American females, whereas CDSO is more common in Caucasians of any age. Radiographically, FOD shows round or irregular radiolucencies with a radiopaque center, while CDSO presents with a mixed radiolucent-radiopaque appearance. Histopathologically, FOD is characterized by the presence of fibrous connective tissue and bone trabeculae, and CDSO shows chronic inflammation, sclerosis, and osteoclastic resorption. Accurate diagnosis is essential to prevent unnecessary treatment interventions.

Supported employment: an alternative model for vocational rehabilitation of persons with severe neurologic, psychiatric, or physical disability. Supported employment is an alternative vocational rehabilitation model for individuals with severe neurologic, psychiatric, or physical disabilities. This study aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of supported employment in improving vocational outcomes for this population. A total of 150 participants with disabilities were randomly assigned to either supported employment or traditional vocational rehabilitation programs. Results showed that participants in the supported employment group had significantly higher rates of competitive employment compared to those in the traditional vocational rehabilitation group. Additionally, participants in the supported employment group had higher job satisfaction and improved quality of life compared to the traditional vocational rehabilitation group. These findings suggest that supported employment is a viable and effective alternative model for vocational rehabilitation in individuals with severe disabilities.

A diagnostic expert system for colonic lesions. Colorectal cancer is a leading cause of cancer-related deaths worldwide. Early detection and diagnosis of colonic lesions are crucial in improving patient outcomes. This study presents the development and evaluation of a diagnostic expert system for colonic lesions. The system utilizes a combination of artificial intelligence algorithms and a comprehensive database of clinical, radiological, and histopathological data. A total of 400 patients with suspected colonic lesions were included in the study. The expert system demonstrated excellent diagnostic accuracy, with a sensitivity of 94% and a specificity of 92%. Furthermore, the system exhibited a high level of agreement with expert radiologists and pathologists. These results suggest that the diagnostic expert system holds promise as a valuable tool in the early detection and diagnosis of colonic lesions, ultimately leading to improved patient outcomes and reduced mortality rates. Further validation and refinement of the system are warranted.

Pharmacologic stress imaging. Pharmacologic stress imaging is a widely used technique for the evaluation of myocardial perfusion in patients who are unable to undergo exercise stress testing. This type of imaging involves the administration of pharmacologic agents that mimic the effects of exercise, causing coronary vasodilation and increasing myocardial blood flow. The most commonly used agents include adenosine, dipyridamole, and dobutamine. 

Adenosine is a potent vasodilator that acts on the A2A adenosine receptors in the coronary arteries. It causes dilation of the coronary arteries, leading to an increase in myocardial blood flow. Dipyridamole inhibits the uptake of adenosine, thereby increasing its bioavailability and enhancing its vasodilatory effects. Dobutamine, on the other hand, is a beta-adrenergic agonist that increases myocardial oxygen demand and promotes vasodilation through beta-2 adrenergic receptor stimulation.

Pharmacologic stress imaging is typically performed in conjunction with nuclear imaging techniques such as single-photon emission computed tomography (SPECT) or positron emission tomography (PET). These imaging modalities allow for the detection of perfusion abnormalities and the assessment of myocardial viability.

Overall, pharmacologic stress imaging is a valuable tool in the evaluation of patients with suspected or known coronary artery disease. It provides important information about the presence and severity of myocardial ischemia, aiding in the diagnosis and management of patients with cardiovascular conditions.

A histopathologic study of spinal cord ischemia using an isohistogenic rat upper-half-body transplantation model. In this study, we utilized an isohistogenic rat upper-half-body transplantation model to investigate the histopathologic changes associated with spinal cord ischemia. Twelve rats underwent transplantation surgery, with six serving as controls and six undergoing upper-half-body transplantation to induce spinal cord ischemia. Histopathologic examination of the spinal cord tissue was performed at various time points post-transplantation. The ischemic group exhibited significant histopathologic abnormalities, including neuronal cell loss, axonal degeneration, glial cell activation, and inflammatory infiltrates, compared to the control group. These changes were most pronounced in the gray matter of the spinal cord. Our findings demonstrate the detrimental effects of spinal cord ischemia on histopathologic integrity and provide valuable insights into the pathophysiology of ischemic spinal cord injury.

The incidence of deep vein thrombosis after cementless and cemented knee replacement. This study aimed to compare the incidence of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) after cementless and cemented knee replacement surgeries. A retrospective analysis was conducted on a sample of 150 patients who underwent knee replacement surgery. The patients were divided into two groups: 75 received cementless knee replacements, and 75 received cemented knee replacements. The incidence of DVT was determined by performing Doppler ultrasound scans on all patients postoperatively. The results showed a significantly lower incidence of DVT in the cementless group (4%) compared to the cemented group (12%). These findings suggest that cementless knee replacement may be associated with a lower risk of DVT. Further research is needed to confirm these results and determine the underlying mechanisms.

Reduction in bleeding after heart-lung transplantation.  The importance of posterior mediastinal hemostasis. Bleeding is a common complication after heart-lung transplantation, and measures to reduce postoperative bleeding are crucial. This study aimed to investigate the impact of posterior mediastinal hemostasis on reducing bleeding following heart-lung transplantation. The study included 100 patients who underwent heart-lung transplantation between 2015 and 2020. The patients were divided into two groups: Group A underwent standard hemostasis techniques, while Group B underwent additional posterior mediastinal hemostasis. The outcomes measured were bleeding volume, postoperative transfusion requirements, and postoperative complications. The results showed that Group B, with additional posterior mediastinal hemostasis, had significantly lower bleeding volume and transfusion requirements compared to Group A (p<0.05). Additionally, Group B had a lower incidence of postoperative complications, particularly cardiac tamponade. These findings highlight the importance of posterior mediastinal hemostasis in reducing bleeding after heart-lung transplantation and improving patient outcomes. Further research is warranted to validate these results and refine the technique for optimal results.

Neuroendocrine carcinoma of the ampulla of vater. Neuroendocrine carcinoma of the ampulla of Vater is a rare and aggressive malignant tumor arising from the neuroendocrine cells in the ampulla. It is characterized by a variety of clinical features, including obstructive jaundice, abdominal pain, and weight loss. Diagnostic evaluation involves imaging studies such as CT scan and endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP), which may reveal a mass in the ampulla. Histopathological examination is necessary for a definitive diagnosis, with features such as small round cells with abundant mitotic activity and positive neuroendocrine markers. Treatment options include surgical resection, chemotherapy, and radiation therapy. Despite advancements in therapeutic modalities, the prognosis for patients with this condition remains poor, highlighting the need for further research and improved treatment strategies.

Co-trimoxazole for childhood febrile illness in malaria-endemic regions. In malaria-endemic regions, the use of co-trimoxazole for childhood febrile illness was studied. A total of 2,179 children aged 2 to 59 months were randomly assigned to receive either co-trimoxazole or placebo as part of their treatment. The primary outcome measured was the incidence of malaria, while secondary outcomes were all-cause mortality and hospital admissions. Results showed a 25% reduction in the incidence of malaria in the co-trimoxazole group compared to the placebo group (p<0.001). Furthermore, co-trimoxazole was associated with a 30% reduction in all-cause mortality (p=0.02) and a 17% reduction in hospital admissions (p=0.02). These findings suggest that co-trimoxazole prophylaxis should be considered for childhood febrile illness in malaria-endemic regions to reduce malaria incidence, mortality, and hospital admissions.

Immunohistochemical investigations of estrogen receptors in normal and neoplastic squamous epithelium of the vulva. Estrogen receptor (ER) expression in squamous epithelium of the vulva is poorly understood. This study aimed to investigate ER expression in normal and neoplastic vulvar squamous epithelium using immunohistochemical techniques. The study included samples from 30 patients with squamous cell carcinoma of the vulva and 20 control samples from non-neoplastic vulvar epithelium. ER expression was assessed using a semi-quantitative scoring system. Results showed that ER expression was significantly higher in neoplastic squamous epithelium compared to normal epithelium (p<0.001). ER expression was also significantly higher in well-differentiated tumors compared to moderate and poorly differentiated tumors (p=0.03). These findings suggest a potential role for estrogen signaling in vulvar squamous cell carcinoma and may have implications for the development of targeted therapies. Further studies are needed to elucidate the precise mechanisms underlying ER expression in vulvar squamous epithelium.

Spinal accessory nerve palsy: an unusual complication of coronary artery bypass The neurologic complications of coronary artery bypass surgery have been well documented, with a reported incidence of 61% in one large study.  Most injuries to the peripheral nervous system involve the brachial plexus. Spinal accessory nerve palsy is a rare complication of coronary artery bypass surgery. A retrospective review of 115 patients who underwent the procedure revealed one case of spinal accessory nerve palsy. The patient presented with weakness and atrophy of the trapezius muscle on the operated side. The occurrence of this complication is unusual and not commonly reported in the literature. Most neurologic complications of coronary artery bypass surgery involve the brachial plexus. Further studies are necessary to understand the underlying mechanisms and risk factors associated with spinal accessory nerve palsy in the context of coronary artery bypass surgery.

Preferential mitogenic activity for myoblast-like cells can be extracted from uterine leiomyoma tissues. The aim of this study was to determine if uterine leiomyoma tissues exhibit preferential mitogenic activity for myoblast-like cells. Tissue samples were collected from uterine leiomyoma patients and control subjects. Myoblast-like cells were isolated from both the uterine leiomyoma tissues and control tissues, and their mitogenic activity was measured using a cell proliferation assay. The results showed that uterine leiomyoma tissues had a significantly higher mitogenic activity for myoblast-like cells compared to control tissues. This suggests that uterine leiomyoma tissues possess factors that promote the proliferation of myoblast-like cells. Further research is needed to identify these factors and understand their role in the development and progression of uterine leiomyoma.

Levels of mRNA for a putative kainate receptor are affected by seizures. Seizures are known to have an impact on the expression of various genes in the brain. This study focuses on the effect of seizures on the levels of mRNA for a putative kainate receptor. Using animal models of seizures, the researchers observed a significant increase in mRNA expression for the kainate receptor in the hippocampus and cortex following seizure activity. Furthermore, this increase was found to be time-dependent, with the highest levels occurring shortly after the seizure and gradually decreasing over time. These findings suggest that the putative kainate receptor may play a role in the pathophysiology of seizures. Further research is needed to elucidate the exact mechanisms underlying this relationship and to explore the potential therapeutic implications.

Evaluating oxygen delivery and oxygen utilization with mixed venous oxygen saturation monitoring: a case study approach. Monitoring oxygen delivery and utilization is crucial in critically ill patients to guide therapy and assess tissue oxygenation. Mixed venous oxygen saturation (SvO2) monitoring has been widely used as a surrogate marker of global tissue oxygenation. This case study aimed to evaluate the utility of SvO2 monitoring in assessing oxygen delivery and utilization in a patient with septic shock. The patient's clinical course, hemodynamic parameters, and SvO2 levels were analyzed. The results showed that SvO2 monitoring allowed for the early identification of tissue hypoxia and guided therapy interventions to optimize oxygen delivery. It also provided insights into the patient's oxygen utilization and response to treatment. However, limitations such as confounders and the need for invasive monitoring should be considered. Overall, SvO2 monitoring proved to be a valuable tool in assessing tissue oxygenation and guiding therapy in this case of septic shock.

Association of Escherichia coli HEp-2 adherence patterns with type and duration of diarrhoea. The association between Escherichia coli (E. coli) HEp-2 adherence patterns and the type and duration of diarrhoea was investigated. Stool samples were collected from patients with acute, persistent, or chronic diarrhoea, and E. coli isolates were tested for adherence patterns on HEp-2 cells. Three adherence patterns were observed: localized adherence (LA), aggregative adherence (AA), and diffuse adherence (DA). Among the isolates, AA was the most prevalent pattern in all types of diarrhoea, followed by DA and LA. AA was significantly associated with acute and persistent diarrhoea, while DA was associated with chronic diarrhoea. The duration of diarrhoea was longer in patients infected with AA-positive E. coli compared to other patterns. These findings suggest that E. coli adherence patterns may be useful in predicting the type and duration of diarrhoea, providing insights into the pathogenesis and clinical management of E. coli infections.

The Van Nes tibial rotationplasty. The Van Nes tibial rotationplasty is a surgical technique used in the management of severe lower extremity abnormalities, such as sarcomas or congenital anomalies. This procedure involves rotational osteotomy of the tibia, followed by reattachment of the deformed distal portion to the proximal femur to create a functional knee joint.  The primary advantage of this technique is the preservation of the patient's own ankle joint, which allows for improved mobility and function compared to traditional amputation. This abstract presents a case report of a patient who underwent Van Nes tibial rotationplasty for the treatment of a distal femur Ewing's sarcoma, with successful functional outcomes and no evidence of disease recurrence.

Acute oculogyric crisis after administration of prochlorperazine. Prochlorperazine is a commonly used antiemetic medication, but it can rarely cause a rare movement disorder known as oculogyric crisis (OGC). We present a case of a 32-year-old male who developed acute OGC after intravenous administration of prochlorperazine for nausea. The patient experienced involuntary and sustained upward deviation of the eyes, associated with neck dystonia and opisthotonus. Symptoms resolved spontaneously after discontinuation of prochlorperazine and administration of diphenhydramine. OGC is characterized by sudden and sustained involuntary upward deviation of the eyes, often accompanied by dystonia of the head and neck. Prompt identification and discontinuation of the offending agent is crucial for symptom resolution. Awareness of this potential side effect is important for healthcare professionals prescribing prochlorperazine and managing patients presenting with acute OGC.

Choroid plexus tumors in the breast cancer-sarcoma syndrome. Breast cancer-sarcoma syndrome (BCSS) is a rare genetic condition characterized by the co-occurrence of breast cancer and sarcoma. While the presence of choroid plexus tumors (CPTs) in BCSS patients has been reported, their clinical characteristics and outcomes remain poorly understood. In this study, we present the clinicopathological features and management of CPTs in five patients with BCSS. All patients were female and had a history of both breast cancer and sarcoma. The CPTs were found incidentally during follow-up imaging studies and exhibited heterogeneous radiological and histopathological characteristics. Surgical resection was the primary treatment modality, and none of the patients experienced tumor recurrence or metastasis during the follow-up period. These findings contribute to our understanding of CPTs in BCSS and support the importance of regular imaging surveillance in these patients.

Simultaneous superior oblique sheathectomy and inferior oblique tuck in congenital Brown's syndrome. Congenital Brown's syndrome is a rare ophthalmic disorder characterized by limited elevation in adduction and positive forced duction testing of the superior oblique muscle. We report a case of a 7-year-old male with congenital Brown's syndrome who underwent simultaneous superior oblique sheathectomy and inferior oblique tuck. The patient had a history of limited elevation in adduction with poor superduction in the left eye. Surgical intervention was performed due to persistent and symptomatic diplopia. The procedure involved a 12 mm superior oblique sheathectomy combined with a 10 mm inferior oblique tuck. Postoperatively, the patient showed significant improvement in ocular motility, with improved elevation in adduction and elimination of diplopia. No complications were observed during the follow-up period. This case highlights the effectiveness of simultaneous superior oblique sheathectomy and inferior oblique tuck in the management of congenital Brown's syndrome, providing a valuable surgical option for patients who experience persistent symptoms despite conservative treatment. Further studies and long-term follow-up are warranted to evaluate the long-term efficacy and safety of this combined surgical technique.

Oral contraceptives, lipoproteins, and atherosclerosis. This study aims to investigate the relationship between oral contraceptives (OCs), lipoproteins, and atherosclerosis. A total of 100 women on OCs and 100 age-matched control women without OC use were enrolled in this cross-sectional study. Lipoprotein profiles were analyzed, including total cholesterol, low-density lipoprotein cholesterol (LDL-C), high-density lipoprotein cholesterol (HDL-C), and triglycerides. Atherosclerosis was assessed using carotid intima-media thickness (C-IMT) measurements. Results showed that women on OCs had significantly higher levels of total cholesterol and LDL-C, and lower levels of HDL-C compared to controls (p < 0.05). Additionally, OC users had significantly increased C-IMT compared with controls (p < 0.001). Subgroup analysis revealed that OC duration correlated positively with C-IMT and LDL-C levels (p < 0.05). These findings suggest that OC use is associated with adverse changes in lipoprotein profiles and increased risk of atherosclerosis, emphasizing the importance of monitoring lipid profiles in women on OCs for early detection and prevention of cardiovascular diseases.

Clinical observation on the association of gallstones and colorectal cancer.  A possible association between gallstones, colorectal cancer, and gastric cancer was investigated. A retrospective analysis was conducted to investigate the association between gallstones and colorectal cancer, as well as gastric cancer. The study included 500 patients diagnosed with colorectal cancer, 400 patients diagnosed with gastric cancer, and 600 control subjects without any cancer. Medical records were reviewed to identify the presence of gallstones in each group. The results showed a significantly higher prevalence of gallstones in patients with colorectal cancer (26%) compared to control subjects (12%). However, no significant association was found between gallstones and gastric cancer. Subgroup analysis revealed that the association between gallstones and colorectal cancer was stronger in males and older patients. These findings suggest a possible link between gallstones and the development of colorectal cancer. Further studies are needed to elucidate the underlying pathophysiological mechanisms and potential preventive strategies.

Warner-Lambert/Parke-Davis Award lecture. This study investigated the histologic findings of vascular malformations in the face following transarterial embolization using Ethibloc and other agents. A total of 21 malformations, including 11 high-flow arteriovenous malformations and 10 slow-flow malformations, underwent combined embolization and subsequent surgery. Ethibloc, a biodegradable fibrosing agent, was used in 16 cases. Histologic examination of the surgical specimens confirmed the accurate targeting achieved through transarterial injection of Ethibloc. The study revealed the thrombogenic and fibrogenic properties of Ethibloc, leading to degeneration and rupture of some vascular walls. However, no necrosis of interstitial tissue or skin was observed. Although embolization did not provide a cure for facial vascular malformations, it facilitated subsequent surgical treatment in all cases.

Celiac disease, brain atrophy, and dementia. Celiac disease is an immune-mediated disorder triggered by gluten ingestion. It primarily affects the small intestine, but its extra-intestinal manifestations are increasingly recognized. We present a case of a 65-year-old woman with celiac disease who developed progressive cognitive decline and neurological symptoms. Magnetic resonance imaging revealed brain atrophy, particularly affecting the frontal and temporal lobes. Neuropsychological evaluation confirmed dementia. Further investigations ruled out other causes of cognitive impairment. With the combination of clinical features, neuroimaging findings, and response to a gluten-free diet, a diagnosis of gluten-related dementia was made. This case highlights the potential association between celiac disease and neurodegenerative disorders, emphasizing the importance of considering celiac disease in the differential diagnosis of dementia and advocating for timely diagnosis and management of this treatable condition.

Toward a rational therapeutic strategy for arachnoiditis. Arachnoiditis is a debilitating condition characterized by inflammation of the arachnoid layer of the meninges surrounding the spinal cord. This article proposes a rational therapeutic strategy for the management of arachnoiditis based on a comprehensive review of the available literature. The current treatment options for arachnoiditis are limited and mainly focus on symptom relief. However, recent research suggests that targeting the underlying inflammatory pathways may be a promising approach. Anti-inflammatory drugs, such as corticosteroids and non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs, have shown some efficacy in reducing inflammation and pain. Additionally, novel therapeutic approaches such as mesenchymal stem cell therapy and the use of neuroprotective agents have shown promise in preclinical studies. The development of targeted therapies that specifically address the inflammatory processes associated with arachnoiditis could potentially provide more effective and long-lasting relief for patients suffering from this debilitating condition.

Increasing the cancer screening of the medically underserved in south Florida. Cancer screening rates in medically underserved populations, particularly in south Florida, remain below national targets. This study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of a targeted intervention to increase cancer screening rates among this population. A community-based approach, including education, outreach, and access to screening services, was implemented in multiple clinics in south Florida. A total of 500 participants were enrolled, with a mean age of 52 and 65% being female. The intervention included culturally tailored educational materials and reminders, as well as navigation services to facilitate access to screening services. Pre- and post-intervention surveys were conducted to assess changes in knowledge, attitudes, and behaviors related to cancer screening. Preliminary results showed a significant increase in screening rates, with 60% of participants reporting completion of recommended screening tests after the intervention, compared to only 20% before the intervention. These findings highlight the potential impact of targeted interventions on improving cancer screening rates among medically underserved populations and emphasize the importance of addressing barriers to access and awareness in order to reduce health disparities.

Use of intravenous stilbestrol diphosphate in patients with prostatic carcinoma refractory to conventional hormonal manipulation. This study evaluated the use of intravenous stilbestrol diphosphate in patients with prostatic carcinoma that was refractory to conventional hormonal manipulation. Ten patients were treated with intravenous stilbestrol diphosphate. Among them, four patients (40%) showed a partial response with a decrease in prostate-specific antigen levels and improvement in symptoms. No complete responses were observed. Mild side effects were reported in two patients. The median duration of response was 3 months (range, 1 to 7 months). Intravenous stilbestrol diphosphate may have potential as a salvage therapy for patients with prostatic carcinoma refractory to conventional hormonal manipulation, providing a partial response and symptom improvement. Further studies are warranted to determine optimal dosage and assess long-term efficacy.

Outcome of cataract surgery in central India: a longitudinal follow-up study. This longitudinal follow-up study aimed to evaluate the outcome of cataract surgery in central India. A total of 256 eyes of 157 patients who underwent cataract surgery were included in the study. Visual acuity, complications, and subjective satisfaction were assessed at multiple time points post-surgery, including 1 week, 1 month, 3 months, and 6 months. The mean preoperative visual acuity was 2.00卤0.75 logarithm of the minimum angle of resolution (logMAR), which significantly improved to 0.49卤0.47 logMAR at 6 months post-surgery (p<0.001). Complications were observed in 22% of the cases, with posterior capsular opacification being the most common. Overall, 95% of the patients reported satisfaction with the visual outcome. In conclusion, cataract surgery resulted in significant improvement in visual acuity with high patient satisfaction rates in central India. However, the occurrence of complications emphasizes the need for proper follow-up and management post-surgery.

Computed tomography staging of the paranasal sinuses in chronic hyperplastic rhinosinusitis. The aim of this study was to assess the accuracy of computed tomography (CT) staging of paranasal sinuses in chronic hyperplastic rhinosinusitis (CHRS). A total of 120 patients diagnosed with CHRS were included in the study. CT scans were performed and independently evaluated by two radiologists using the Lund-Mackay staging system. Interobserver agreement was assessed using kappa statistics. The results showed substantial interobserver agreement between the two radiologists (kappa = 0.79). CT staging correctly identified the extent of disease in 88% of cases, with a sensitivity and specificity of 87% and 90%, respectively. The most commonly involved sinuses were the maxillary sinuses (87%) and the ethmoid sinuses (75%). Based on these findings, CT staging is a reliable and accurate method for assessing the extent of disease in CHRS, with potential implications for treatment planning and prognostication.

Depression after acute myocardial infarction.  The role of primary care physicians in rehabilitation. After an acute myocardial infarction (AMI), many patients experience depression, which can negatively impact their rehabilitation outcomes. This study aimed to investigate the role of primary care physicians (PCPs) in managing depression in AMI patients during rehabilitation. A randomized controlled trial was conducted with 150 AMI patients assigned to either a PCP intervention group or a control group. The PCP intervention group received regular follow-up visits and specific training to identify and manage depression. Results showed that the PCP intervention group had significantly lower rates of depression compared to the control group at the end of the rehabilitation period. PCPs play a crucial role in identifying and managing depression in AMI patients, contributing to improved rehabilitation outcomes and overall patient well-being.

Dietary predictors of symptom-associated gallstones in middle-aged women.  In 1980, 88,837 women aged 34-59 y completed a semiquantitative food frequency questionnaire and were followed for 4 y. A study was conducted in 1980 to examine the association between dietary patterns and the occurrence of symptoms-associated gallstones in middle-aged women. A total of 88,837 women aged 34 to 59 years completed a semiquantitative food frequency questionnaire and were followed for a period of 4 years. During the follow-up period, 5,766 women reported symptoms associated with gallstones. Multivariate analysis revealed that certain dietary factors were significantly associated with an increased risk of developing symptom-associated gallstones. High intake of refined carbohydrates, low intake of dietary fiber, and high glycemic load were found to be positively associated with the risk of developing gallstone symptoms. Conversely, a high intake of fruits, vegetables, and whole grains was found to be inversely associated with the risk. These findings suggest that dietary modifications, including increased consumption of fiber-rich foods and reduced intake of refined carbohydrates, may play a role in the prevention of symptom-associated gallstones in middle-aged women.

Ureteral obstruction and ureteral fistulas after aortofemoral or aortoiliac bypass surgery. Ureteral obstruction and ureteral fistulas are rare but serious complications that can occur after aortofemoral or aortoiliac bypass surgery. In this retrospective study, we examined the incidence and risk factors associated with these complications in a cohort of 345 patients who underwent these procedures between 2010 and 2015. Ureteral obstruction was identified in 6 patients (1.7%) and ureteral fistulas in 3 patients (0.9%). The most common risk factor for ureteral obstruction was prolonged surgery duration (>5 hours) (p=0.011), while the presence of intraoperative bowel injury was significantly associated with the development of ureteral fistulas (p=0.001). All patients with ureteral obstruction required surgical intervention, while conservative management was successful in treating the patients with ureteral fistulas. Our findings highlight the importance of careful surgical technique and intraoperative monitoring to prevent and detect these complications early.

Patient-controlled analgesia in children.  We report our experience in introducing patient-controlled analgesia at the Royal Hospital for Sick Children, Glasgow.  Twenty-five children used the technique after orthopaedic or general surgery using the Graseby system. This report describes the implementation of patient-controlled analgesia (PCA) in children at the Royal Hospital for Sick Children in Glasgow. Twenty-five children underwent orthopaedic or general surgery and were provided with PCA using the Graseby system. The aim of this study was to assess the feasibility and efficacy of PCA in pediatric patients. Overall, PCA was well-tolerated and effective in providing analgesia in these children. The use of PCA allowed for individualized pain management, with the children able to control their own medication administration within safe limits. The implementation of PCA in pediatric patients is a promising approach to improve pain management and enhance patient satisfaction. Further research is needed to evaluate its long-term outcomes and identify the optimal use of PCA in this population.

Occurrence of beta-hexachlorocyclohexane in breast cancer patients.  The residues of polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbon (PAH) and neutral organochlorine compounds in breast fat of 44 breast cancer patients and 33 women free of cancer were determined. This study aimed to investigate the presence of beta-hexachlorocyclohexane (beta-HCH) in breast cancer patients. The levels of polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbon (PAH) and neutral organochlorine compounds were determined in the breast fat of 44 breast cancer patients and 33 cancer-free women. beta-HCH, a known persistent organic pollutant, was found in significantly higher concentrations in the breast fat of breast cancer patients compared to cancer-free women. This suggests a potential association between beta-HCH exposure and breast cancer. Further research is needed to understand the mechanisms and implications of beta-HCH in breast cancer development. These findings highlight the importance of monitoring and reducing exposure to environmental contaminants in relation to breast cancer risk.

Increased cholecystectomy rates in Saudi Arabia Gallstones have become increasingly prevalent in Saudi Arabia, where cholecystectomy is now one of the commonest major abdominal operations. The aim of this study was to assess the increasing prevalence of gallstones and subsequent increase in cholecystectomy rates in Saudi Arabia. Data from a retrospective analysis of cholecystectomy procedures performed between 2008 and 2018 in Saudi Arabia were analyzed. The results showed a significant increase in the number of cholecystectomies performed, making it one of the most common major abdominal operations in the country. This increase in gallstone prevalence and subsequent need for surgery may be attributed to lifestyle changes, such as changes in diet and physical activity. The findings of this study indicate the need for further research and public health initiatives to address the rising burden of gallstone disease in Saudi Arabia.

Chronic pain in primary care.  Identification and management of psychosocial factors. Chronic pain is a common reason for primary care visits, with psychosocial factors playing a significant role in its identification and management. The purpose of this study was to evaluate the identification and management of psychosocial factors in patients with chronic pain in a primary care setting. A total of 200 patients were enrolled in the study, and their pain severity, psychosocial factors, and management strategies were assessed. It was found that psychosocial factors, such as depression, anxiety, and social functioning, were prevalent in patients with chronic pain. However, the identification and management of these factors were suboptimal, with only a small percentage of patients receiving appropriate interventions. This highlights the need for improved training and awareness among primary care providers regarding the importance of addressing psychosocial factors in the management of chronic pain. Effective identification and management of these factors could lead to better outcomes and improved quality of life for patients with chronic pain.

Transoesophageal echocardiogram may fail to diagnose perioperative myocardial infarction.  We report a case in which a 55-yr-old man undergoing aortocoronary bypass was monitored with electrocardiogram and transoesophageal echocardiogram. In this case report, we present a 55-year-old man who underwent aortocoronary bypass surgery and was monitored using electrocardiogram and transoesophageal echocardiogram (TEE). Despite the use of TEE, a perioperative myocardial infarction (MI) was not detected. The patient exhibited clinical symptoms and ECG changes consistent with an MI, leading to further investigations. Subsequent coronary angiography confirmed the presence of significant coronary artery disease and occlusion requiring stenting. This case highlights the limitations of TEE as a diagnostic tool for perioperative MI and emphasizes the importance of clinical suspicion and complementary imaging modalities such as coronary angiography in cases where TEE fails to detect myocardial ischemia. Clinicians should be aware of these limitations and consider alternative diagnostic approaches when evaluating patients with suspected perioperative MI.

Delayed pharyngoesophageal perforation: a complication of anterior spine surgery.  Stabilization of the cervical spine is often accomplished via an anterior cervical approach. Delayed pharyngoesophageal perforation is a rare but serious complication following anterior spine surgery for stabilization of the cervical spine. This condition occurs when there is a breach in the mucosal integrity of the pharynx or esophagus that goes unrecognized during the initial surgery and presents with symptoms days or weeks later. Risk factors include extended operative time, multiple-level procedures, and the presence of comorbid conditions such as diabetes and smoking. Prompt diagnosis and management are crucial to prevent life-threatening complications such as mediastinitis and sepsis. Treatment often involves surgical repair and appropriate antibiotic therapy. Close monitoring and early recognition of symptoms are essential to prevent delayed pharyngoesophageal perforation in patients undergoing anterior spine surgery.

A new method for mapping hepatic subsegment: counterstaining identification technique. Accurate identification of hepatic subsegments is crucial for surgical planning and intraoperative guidance. The current methods for mapping hepatic subsegments have limitations in terms of accuracy and practicality. In this study, we propose a new technique called the counterstaining identification technique (CIT) for mapping hepatic subsegments. The CIT involves the use of a counterstain to enhance the visualization of hepatic subsegments during liver resection. We evaluated the efficacy of the CIT in ten patients undergoing liver resection and compared it with the traditional method of intraoperative ultrasound. The CIT showed high accuracy in identifying hepatic subsegments, with a mean accuracy rate of 96.7%. The CIT also demonstrated excellent interobserver agreement. The CIT is a promising technique for accurate and practical mapping of hepatic subsegments, which can improve surgical outcomes and patient safety. Further studies are warranted to validate the utility of CIT in a larger cohort of patients.

Effects of nimodipine on cerebral blood flow and neuropsychological outcome after cardiac surgery. This study aimed to investigate the effects of nimodipine on cerebral blood flow and neuropsychological outcome in patients undergoing cardiac surgery. A total of 50 patients were randomly assigned to receive either nimodipine or placebo. Transcranial Doppler ultrasound was used to measure middle cerebral artery blood flow velocity before and after surgery. Neuropsychological tests were conducted preoperatively and on the fifth postoperative day. Results showed that nimodipine significantly increased mean middle cerebral artery blood flow velocity compared to the placebo group. Additionally, nimodipine-treated patients exhibited improved neuropsychological scores compared to placebo-treated patients. These findings suggest that nimodipine may have a beneficial effect on cerebral blood flow and neuropsychological outcome in patients undergoing cardiac surgery. Further studies are warranted to fully understand the potential benefits and mechanisms of nimodipine in this patient population.

Physiologic and pathologic alterations associated with ultrasonically generated shock waves. This study investigates the physiologic and pathologic alterations associated with shock waves generated by ultrasound. Using an animal model, various parameters including blood pressure, heart rate, and electrocardiographic changes were measured following exposure to shock waves. The results revealed a significant increase in blood pressure and heart rate, as well as abnormal electrocardiographic patterns. Histologic examination of cardiac tissue showed evidence of tissue damage and inflammation. Additionally, biochemical analysis demonstrated an increase in markers of oxidative stress and inflammation. These findings suggest that shock waves generated by ultrasound can induce physiologic and pathologic alterations, highlighting the importance of careful monitoring and consideration of potential risks during ultrasound procedures.

Efficacy and complications of radiotherapy of anterior visual pathway tumors. Radiotherapy is a commonly used treatment for tumors in the anterior visual pathway. This study aimed to evaluate the efficacy and complications of radiotherapy in patients with such tumors. Retrospective analysis was conducted on 52 patients who received radiotherapy for anterior visual pathway tumors. Tumor control rate, visual outcome, and complications were assessed. The median follow-up period was 24 months. The overall tumor control rate was 88.5%, with 75% of patients experiencing stable or improved vision. However, complications were observed in 40.4% of patients, including radiation-induced optic neuropathy, cataracts, and radiation retinopathy. These findings highlight the efficacy of radiotherapy in controlling anterior visual pathway tumors, but also emphasize the importance of monitoring and managing potential complications associated with this treatment modality.

Mechanical measures in the prophylaxis of postoperative thromboembolism in total knee arthroplasty. Postoperative thromboembolism is a significant complication following total knee arthroplasty (TKA). This study aimed to evaluate the efficacy of mechanical measures in preventing postoperative thromboembolism in TKA. A total of 100 patients undergoing TKA were divided into two groups: mechanical measures group (n=50) and control group (n=50). Mechanical measures included intermittent pneumatic compression devices and elastic compression stockings. The incidence of postoperative thromboembolism was significantly lower in the mechanical measures group compared to the control group (4% vs. 14%, p=0.04). Furthermore, the mechanical measures group had a lower incidence of deep venous thrombosis (2% vs. 10%, p=0.05). These findings suggest that mechanical measures, such as intermittent pneumatic compression devices and elastic compression stockings, are effective in preventing postoperative thromboembolism in TKA.

Cardiomyopathy associated with the smoking of crystal methamphetamine. Cardiomyopathy is a known complication of crystal methamphetamine use. We present a case series of three patients with cardiomyopathy associated with the smoking of crystal methamphetamine. The patients presented with symptoms of heart failure, including shortness of breath, fatigue, and edema. Echocardiography showed impaired left ventricular systolic function and dilated cardiomyopathy. Coronary angiography ruled out obstructive coronary artery disease. All three patients reported a history of chronic crystal methamphetamine use, with the duration ranging from 2 to 10 years. Although the exact pathophysiology is not fully understood, crystal methamphetamine-induced cardiomyopathy is believed to result from direct toxic effects on cardiomyocytes and catecholamine-induced myocardial damage. Awareness of this rare but serious complication is important for clinicians, as early recognition and cessation of drug use may contribute to improved clinical outcomes.

Photochemotherapy improves chronic cutaneous graft-versus-host disease.  We have used oral psoralen photochemotherapy (PUVA) to treat four patients with chronic graft-versus-host disease of the skin, oral mucosa, and liver, who had responded only partially to long-term immunosuppressive therapy (prednisolone, cyclosporine, azathioprine). This study examines the efficacy of oral psoralen photochemotherapy (PUVA) in treating chronic cutaneous graft-versus-host disease (GVHD). Four patients with GVHD affecting the skin, oral mucosa, and liver, who had previously shown only partial response to long-term immunosuppressive therapy, were treated with PUVA. PUVA therapy involves the administration of oral psoralen, followed by exposure to ultraviolet A light. All four patients showed significant improvement in their GVHD symptoms after PUVA treatment. This suggests that PUVA may be an effective therapeutic option for patients with chronic cutaneous GVHD who do not respond adequately to conventional treatments. Further research with larger patient populations is warranted to confirm these findings.

Spontaneous sump syndrome: Successful treatment by duodenoscopic sphincterotomy. Spontaneous sump syndrome is a rare complication of Billroth II gastrojejunostomy, characterized by bile reflux into the remnant stomach. Here, we present a case of spontaneous sump syndrome successfully treated by duodenoscopic sphincterotomy. A 56-year-old male with a history of gastric ulcer surgery 10 years ago presented with recurrent abdominal pain and bilious vomiting. Endoscopy revealed a patent gastrojejunostomy with bile pooling in the remnant stomach, consistent with spontaneous sump syndrome. Duodenoscopic sphincterotomy was performed to relieve the obstruction and divert bile flow into the duodenum. The patient experienced significant symptom improvement and resolution of bile reflux after the procedure. This case highlights the importance of considering spontaneous sump syndrome as a differential diagnosis in patients with recurrent abdominal pain and bilious vomiting post-gastrectomy, and demonstrates the effectiveness of duodenoscopic sphincterotomy as a treatment option.

Aneuploidy in pancreatic insulinomas does not predict malignancy. Aneuploidy refers to an abnormal number of chromosomes within a cell, and its presence has been suggested to indicate malignancy in pancreatic insulinomas. We aimed to determine if aneuploidy is a reliable marker for malignancy in patients with pancreatic insulinomas. Thirty-seven patients diagnosed with pancreatic insulinomas were enrolled in this study. Tumor samples were obtained from each patient and analyzed for aneuploidy using flow cytometry. The presence of aneuploidy was then correlated with histopathological findings and clinical outcomes. Our results showed that 22 out of the 37 patients had aneuploid tumors, but there was no significant association between aneuploidy and malignancy. Furthermore, patients with aneuploid tumors had similar survival rates compared to those with diploid tumors. In conclusion, aneuploidy does not reliably predict malignancy in pancreatic insulinomas, suggesting that alternative markers should be considered for the assessment of tumor aggressiveness in these patients.

Structural and ultrastructural study of the ovary in childhood leukemia after successful treatment. We conducted a comprehensive structural and ultrastructural study of the ovaries in 15 female patients who had been successfully treated for childhood leukemia. Ovarian biopsies were obtained through laparoscopy and analyzed using light microscopy, electron microscopy, and immunohistochemical staining. Our study aimed to evaluate the impact of leukemia treatment on ovarian morphology and ultrastructure. We observed several important findings, including a reduction in the number of primordial follicles and an increase in fibrosis within the ovarian stroma. Furthermore, we observed abnormal mitochondrial morphology and decreased oocyte granulosa cell communication. These changes suggest potential damage to the ovarian reserve and possible implications for future fertility. Our study provides valuable insights into the long-term effects of leukemia treatment on ovarian function and highlights the need for continued monitoring and counseling of female survivors to assess their reproductive potential.

The management of postoperative chylous ascites. Chylous ascites is a rare complication following surgery and its management remains challenging. In this retrospective study, we analyzed the outcomes of 25 patients with postoperative chylous ascites who underwent various treatment modalities. The majority of patients (64%) were successfully managed conservatively with dietary modifications, total parenteral nutrition, and drainage of the ascitic fluid. However, 36% of patients required additional interventions, including surgical ligation of lymphatic leaks, peritoneovenous shunting, or placement of peritoneal catheters. The choice of treatment modality was guided by the severity of symptoms, underlying pathology, and response to conservative management. Our study highlights the importance of a multidisciplinary approach in the management of postoperative chylous ascites and provides insights into the efficacy of different treatment strategies. Further research is warranted to refine and optimize the management algorithms for this challenging condition.

Effects of supplemental oxygen administration in an infant with pulmonary artery hypertension. This case report describes the effects of supplemental oxygen administration in an infant with pulmonary artery hypertension (PAH). The patient, a 6-month-old male infant with a confirmed diagnosis of PAH, was started on oxygen therapy as an adjunct to standard medical treatment. Serial echocardiograms were performed to assess the impact of supplemental oxygen on pulmonary artery pressure.

After initiation of oxygen therapy, a significant improvement in the patient's symptoms and echocardiographic parameters was observed. Pulmonary artery pressure decreased from 80 mmHg to 50 mmHg, right ventricular size normalized, and tricuspid regurgitation velocity decreased. The patient's oxygen saturation levels also improved.

This case suggests that supplemental oxygen may have a beneficial effect on pulmonary artery pressure and right ventricular function in infants with PAH. Further studies are needed to determine the optimal duration and concentration of oxygen therapy in this patient population.

Local hypothermia to prolong safe tourniquet time.  Local hypothermia was studied as a method to safely prolong tourniquet time for reconstructive procedures of the upper extremity. This study investigated the use of local hypothermia as a technique to extend tourniquet time during upper extremity reconstructive surgeries. A total of 50 patients undergoing reconstructive procedures were divided into two groups: Group A received local hypothermia with a cooling device, while Group B served as the control group without any cooling intervention. The primary outcome measures included tourniquet time and complications related to tourniquet use. The study found that the use of local hypothermia significantly extended the safe tourniquet time compared to the control group (P<0.05). Moreover, no significant differences were observed in postoperative complications between the two groups (P>0.05). Thus, local hypothermia demonstrates promise as a safe and effective method to prolong tourniquet time during upper extremity reconstructive procedures. Further research is warranted to explore its potential applications in other surgical settings.

The vagus nerve, gastric secretions, and their relationship to peptic ulcer disease. This study aimed to investigate the role of the vagus nerve and gastric secretions in peptic ulcer disease (PUD). The vagus nerve has long been implicated in regulating gastric acid secretion, which plays a crucial role in the development of PUD. Activation of the vagus nerve leads to increased acid secretion, while its inhibition results in decreased acid production. Gastric secretions, particularly hydrochloric acid and pepsin, are known to be major contributors to mucosal injury in PUD. Abnormalities in vagal function and excessive gastric acid secretion have been associated with the pathogenesis of PUD. Understanding the relationship between the vagus nerve, gastric secretions, and PUD may provide insights into the development of new treatment strategies for this prevalent disease.

Factor XIIIa in nodular malignant melanoma and Spitz naevi. This study aimed to investigate the expression of Factor XIIIa in nodular malignant melanoma and Spitz naevi. Immunohistochemical staining for Factor XIIIa was performed on tissue samples from 20 cases of nodular malignant melanoma and 20 cases of Spitz naevi. The results showed that Factor XIIIa expression was significantly decreased in nodular malignant melanoma compared to Spitz naevi. Furthermore, a negative correlation was observed between Factor XIIIa expression and tumor thickness in nodular malignant melanoma. These findings suggest that decreased expression of Factor XIIIa may play a role in the progression of nodular malignant melanoma and could potentially serve as a diagnostic marker for this aggressive form of skin cancer.

Temporal bone findings in two cases of head injury. This study examined two cases of head injury and their temporal bone findings. The first case involved a 35-year-old male who suffered a fall and presented with bleeding and hearing loss. Temporal bone examination revealed a fracture of the petrous bone and disruption of the inner ear structures. The second case involved a 42-year-old female who was involved in a motor vehicle accident and presented with vertigo and hearing loss. Temporal bone examination showed fractures involving the petrous bone and the middle ear structures. These findings highlight the importance of thorough temporal bone examination in cases of head injury to accurately diagnose and manage associated complications.

Ascites revealing peritoneal and hepatic extramedullary hematopoiesis with peliosis in agnogenic myeloid metaplasia: case report and review of the literature. We present a case of a 62-year-old male with agnogenic myeloid metaplasia (AMM) who developed ascites due to peritoneal and hepatic extramedullary hematopoiesis (EH). EH, characterized by the proliferation of hematopoietic cells outside the bone marrow, is a rare complication of AMM. The patient also demonstrated peliosis, a condition characterized by blood-filled spaces within organs, in the liver. The diagnosis was confirmed through histopathological analysis of ascitic fluid and liver biopsies. Treatment involved supportive measures and hydroxyurea therapy. This case offers a valuable contribution to the existing literature, as it highlights an uncommon manifestation of AMM. Awareness of this presentation is essential for timely diagnosis and appropriate management. Further research is necessary to understand the underlying mechanisms and establish optimal treatment strategies for patients with AMM-associated EH and peliosis.

CV 205-502--effectiveness, tolerability, and safety over 24-month study.  Twenty hyperprolactinemic women (median prolactin [PRL] 2,989 mU/L, range 1,149 to 11,910 mU/L), previously unsuccessfully treated with bromocriptine, were treated in a prospective study, for 3 to 24 months with the new, nonergot, long-acting, dopamine agonist, CV 205-502. In this prospective study, the effectiveness, tolerability, and safety of CV 205-502, a nonergot, long-acting dopamine agonist, were evaluated in 20 hyperprolactinemic women who had previously been unsuccessfully treated with bromocriptine. The women had a median baseline prolactin level of 2,989 mU/L (range 1,149 to 11,910 mU/L). They were treated with CV 205-502 for a duration of 3 to 24 months. The study aimed to assess the effectiveness of CV 205-502 in reducing prolactin levels and improving symptoms in these patients. The tolerability and safety of the medication were also evaluated. The results of this study will provide valuable insights into the potential of CV 205-502 as an alternative treatment for hyperprolactinemia in patients who do not respond to bromocriptine.

Serum cholesterol levels and survival in elderly hypertensive patients: analysis of data from the European Working Party on High Blood Pressure in the Elderly.  The relation between serum cholesterol and mortality was investigated in 822 elderly hypertensive patients randomly assigned to treatment with diuretics, with or without methyldopa, or placebo. The relationship between serum cholesterol levels and mortality was assessed in 822 elderly hypertensive patients who were randomly assigned to receive diuretics with or without methyldopa, or placebo. The study analyzed data from the European Working Party on High Blood Pressure in the Elderly. Participants' serum cholesterol levels were measured at baseline, and their survival status was followed for a median of 3.8 years. The results showed that higher serum cholesterol levels were associated with increased mortality risk in this population. This finding highlights the importance of managing cholesterol levels in elderly hypertensive patients to improve their long-term outcomes.

Chiari pelvic osteotomy for osteoarthritis. Chiari pelvic osteotomy is a surgical technique used in the management of osteoarthritis. This retrospective study analyzed the outcomes of 67 patients who underwent Chiari pelvic osteotomy for hip osteoarthritis. The patients' demographic data, preoperative functional scores, radiographic measurements, and perioperative parameters were recorded. The mean age of the patients was 56 years, and 54% were females. Significant improvements in functional scores were observed postoperatively, indicating enhanced hip joint function. Radiographic measurements showed corrected coverage of the femoral head within the acetabular socket. The mean follow-up period was 36 months, during which only two patients experienced complications requiring further intervention. The findings of this study suggest that Chiari pelvic osteotomy is an efficacious surgical option for the management of osteoarthritis, providing improved functionality and hip joint alignment. Further long-term studies are warranted to validate these results.

Neurinoma in the cavernous sinus: report of two cases. This report presents two cases of neurinoma in the cavernous sinus. Neurinomas are tumors of the nerve sheath originating from the Schwann cells. The cavernous sinus is a venous structure located at the base of the skull. The clinical symptoms, radiological findings, and surgical management of both cases are detailed. Resection of the tumor was successful in both patients. The postoperative course was uneventful, and both patients showed improvement in their symptoms. Neurinomas in the cavernous sinus are rare, and surgical resection remains the mainstay of treatment. Further studies are needed to evaluate long-term outcomes and optimize treatment strategies.

Overt hepatic encephalopathy precipitated by zinc deficiency. Hepatic encephalopathy (HE) is a known complication of liver disease, characterized by cognitive and neuromuscular abnormalities. We present a case of overt HE precipitated by zinc deficiency. A 55-year-old male with a history of alcohol-related cirrhosis presented with confusion, tremors, and asterixis. Laboratory evaluation revealed low serum zinc levels. The patient was started on zinc supplementation, which resulted in improvement of his cognitive and neuromuscular symptoms. Zinc deficiency can occur in patients with liver disease due to reduced intake, impaired absorption, and increased urinary losses. Zinc plays a vital role in the metabolism and function of the central nervous system, and deficiency can result in neurological manifestations. The occurrence of HE associated with zinc deficiency highlights the importance of considering and addressing nutritional deficiencies in patients with liver disease to prevent and manage complications such as HE. Further research is needed to explore the role of zinc supplementation in the management of HE.

Standards for analysis of ventricular late potentials using high-resolution or signal-averaged electrocardiography: a statement by a task force committee of the European Society of Cardiology, the American Heart Association, and the American College of Cardiology. The standards for analysis of ventricular late potentials using high-resolution or signal-averaged electrocardiography (ECG) are essential for detecting patients at risk of sudden cardiac death. The statement by a task force committee of the European Society of Cardiology, the American Heart Association, and the American College of Cardiology provides recommendations for the proper analysis of ventricular late potentials. The document addresses various aspects such as the acquisition and processing of ECG signals, criteria for defining late potentials, and their significance in predicting arrhythmias. Implementing these standardized guidelines in clinical practice will ensure consistent and accurate assessment of ventricular late potentials, improving risk stratification and patient management.

Angiocentric lymphoma with histologic features of neoplastic angioendotheliomatosis presenting with predominant respiratory and hematologic manifestations. Angiocentric lymphoma is a rare subtype of non-Hodgkin lymphoma that is characterized by neoplastic proliferation of lymphoid cells within the vessel walls. We report a case of angiocentric lymphoma presenting with predominant respiratory and hematologic manifestations. A 67-year-old female presented with fever, cough, and dyspnea for one month. Laboratory investigations revealed leukocytosis and thrombocytopenia. Imaging studies showed multiple nodular opacities in the lungs. Bone marrow biopsy demonstrated infiltration of atypical lymphoid cells. Histopathological analysis of a lung biopsy revealed a neoplastic lymphoid proliferation with angioendotheliomatosis-like features. The patient was diagnosed with angiocentric lymphoma with systemic involvement. She was treated with chemotherapy and achieved a partial response. This case highlights the importance of considering angiocentric lymphoma in the differential diagnosis of respiratory and hematologic manifestations. Awareness of this rare entity may aid in early recognition and appropriate management of such cases.

A successful treatment of an intrarenal arteriovenous fistula by percutaneous embolization. We report a successful case of percutaneous embolization for the treatment of an intrarenal arteriovenous fistula (AVF). A 62-year-old male presented with gross hematuria and flank pain. Imaging studies revealed an intrarenal AVF located in the posterior segmental artery of the right kidney. The patient underwent percutaneous embolization with coils and liquid embolic material. Follow-up imaging showed complete occlusion of the AVF with resolution of symptoms. Intrarenal AVFs are rare vascular complications that can lead to significant morbidity if left untreated. Percutaneous embolization is a minimally invasive and effective treatment option for intrarenal AVFs, providing prompt symptom relief and preventing potential complications. Selecting appropriate embolic materials and technical expertise are crucial for a successful outcome. Further studies are needed to evaluate long-term outcomes and optimal management strategies for intrarenal AVFs.

Lack of late skin necrosis in man after high-dose irradiation using small field sizes: experiences of grid therapy. This study aimed to evaluate the occurrence of late skin necrosis in humans following high-dose irradiation using small field sizes, specifically focusing on the experiences of grid therapy. Data from 30 patients who underwent grid therapy for various tumors were analyzed. The results showed that none of the patients developed late skin necrosis after a median follow-up period of 24 months. This suggests that grid therapy may not pose a significant risk of late skin necrosis, supporting its use as a safe and effective treatment modality for localized tumors. Further studies with a larger sample size are warranted to confirm these findings.

Deteriorating ischemic stroke: risk factors and prognosis.  To determine a risk profile of deterioration in cerebral infarction of less than 8 hours' duration, we studied prospectively a series of clinical and radiologic data in 98 patients. To identify risk factors and prognosis of deterioration in acute ischemic stroke, we conducted a prospective study on 98 patients with cerebral infarction lasting less than 8 hours. Clinical and radiologic data were analyzed to establish a risk profile. Deterioration was observed in 29 patients (30%), with the most common presentation being neurological deficit exacerbation. Multivariate analysis revealed that older age, higher initial NIH Stroke Scale score, larger infarct volume, and atrial fibrillation were significant independent predictors of deterioration. Patients who experienced deterioration had worse functional outcomes at 3 months compared to those without deterioration. Our findings highlight the importance of early identification of patients at risk of deteriorating ischemic stroke for appropriate management and improved outcomes.

Peroneal nerve palsy after total knee arthroplasty.  The prognosis for peroneal palsy after total knee arthroplasty (TKA) is poorly defined. The prognosis for peroneal nerve palsy following total knee arthroplasty (TKA) remains unclear. This retrospective study aimed to evaluate the outcomes of patients with peroneal palsy after TKA. A total of 42 patients with peroneal nerve palsy were included in the study. At final follow-up, 35 patients (83.3%) had complete resolution of their symptoms, while 7 patients (16.7%) had persistent palsy. Factors associated with a higher likelihood of complete recovery included younger age, shorter duration of symptoms, and mild palsy. No significant differences were observed in terms of sex, body mass index, or side of palsy. In conclusion, the majority of patients with peroneal nerve palsy after TKA experienced complete resolution of symptoms. Younger age, shorter symptom duration, and milder palsy were associated with a higher likelihood of recovery. Further research is needed to better understand the prognosis and potential interventions for this complication.

Unknown primary squamous cell carcinoma metastatic to the neck. Unknown primary squamous cell carcinoma metastatic to the neck is a challenging diagnostic dilemma. This study aimed to assess the utility of immunohistochemistry in identifying the primary site of metastasis in 50 cases of metastatic squamous cell carcinoma to the neck with unknown primary. A panel of markers including p40, CK5/6, p63, and CK7 was used to classify the tumors into different subtypes based on their pattern of staining. The results showed that the majority of cases were consistent with a primary in the head and neck region, followed by the lung. The use of immunohistochemistry aided in identifying the primary site in most cases, allowing for appropriate management and treatment. These findings highlight the importance of immunohistochemical analysis in the evaluation of unknown primary squamous cell carcinoma metastatic to the neck.

Tissue changes around loose prostheses. A study was conducted to investigate tissue changes surrounding loose prostheses. The study included 25 patients who underwent surgery for prosthesis extraction due to looseness. Histological analysis was performed on tissue samples obtained from the extraction site. The results revealed various tissue changes, including fibrosis, chronic inflammation, foreign body reaction, and osteolysis. Fibrosis was observed in all cases, indicating a reparative response to the presence of the prosthesis. Chronic inflammation was present in 18 cases, suggesting a prolonged immune response. Foreign body reaction, characterized by the presence of giant cells, was observed in 15 cases. Osteolysis, indicating bone resorption, was seen in 10 cases. These findings highlight the detrimental effects of loose prostheses on surrounding tissues, leading to structural changes and inflammation. Understanding these tissue changes can help improve prosthesis design and surgical techniques to minimize complications associated with prosthesis loosening.

Pneumocystis carinii pneumonia complicating multiple myeloma. Pneumocystis carinii pneumonia (PCP) is a common opportunistic infection in immunocompromised individuals, particularly those with underlying hematologic malignancies such as multiple myeloma. We present a case of a 58-year-old male with multiple myeloma who developed PCP. The patient presented with fever, cough, and shortness of breath, and was found to have bilateral interstitial infiltrates on chest X-ray. Bronchoalveolar lavage obtained from the patient revealed the presence of P. carinii organisms, confirming the diagnosis of PCP. The patient was successfully treated with a combination of trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole and corticosteroids, resulting in clinical improvement. This case highlights the importance of considering PCP in the differential diagnosis of respiratory symptoms in patients with multiple myeloma, as early recognition and prompt treatment can lead to favorable outcomes.

Movement disorders--limb movement and the basal ganglia. Movement disorders are a result of dysfunction in the basal ganglia, a complex circuit of structures involved in motor control. This review focuses on limb movement disorders, including hyperkinetic and hypokinetic disorders. Hyperkinetic disorders, such as dystonia and chorea, manifest as excessive involuntary movements, whereas hypokinetic disorders, such as Parkinson's disease, present with reduced voluntary movements. The basal ganglia maintain a delicate balance between inhibitory and excitatory output to regulate movement. Dysfunction in this system disrupts this balance, leading to abnormal movements. Understanding the pathophysiology of limb movement disorders is essential for accurate diagnosis and appropriate treatment selection. Advances in neuroimaging and genetics have contributed to a better understanding of the underlying mechanisms. Treatment options include pharmacological therapy, deep brain stimulation, and rehabilitation strategies. Further research is needed to uncover novel therapeutic targets and improve patient outcomes in limb movement disorders.

Prospective study of a prosthetic H-graft portacaval shunt.  This study was undertaken to prospectively evaluate the 8-mm Gore-Tex interposition H-graft portacaval shunt. This prospective study aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of an 8-mm Gore-Tex interposition H-graft portacaval shunt in patients requiring portacaval shunt surgery. The study included 34 patients who underwent the procedure for the treatment of portal hypertension. The primary endpoint was the long-term patency rate of the shunt. Secondary endpoints included postoperative complications, mortality, changes in liver function tests, and improvement in clinical symptoms and quality of life. The mean follow-up period was 24 months. The shunt showed excellent patency rates, with 91% of patients maintaining shunt function at the end of the follow-up period. Postoperative complications were observed in 29% of patients, with ascites being the most common complication. Mortality rate was 6% during the follow-up period. Liver function tests showed significant improvement postoperatively. Clinical symptoms and quality of life improved in the majority of patients. In conclusion, the 8-mm Gore-Tex interposition H-graft portacaval shunt demonstrated excellent long-term patency rates and improved clinical outcomes in patients with portal hypertension.

Florid refractory schizophrenias that turn out to be treatable variants of HLA-associated narcolepsy. Florid refractory schizophrenias occasionally exhibit symptoms that resemble HLA-associated narcolepsy, leading to misdiagnosis and inadequate treatment. These cases often display severe psychosis, catatonia, and bizarre behaviors that are resistant to conventional anti-psychotic medications. Identification of the underlying treatable variant is crucial to optimize patient outcomes. Genetic analysis reveals an association between certain HLA subtypes and narcolepsy, suggesting a potential shared immunological etiology. Treatment approaches targeting the underlying narcoleptic component have shown substantial improvement in symptomatology and overall functioning in these cases. Recognizing the link between HLA-associated narcolepsy and schizophrenic-like psychoses can guide clinicians towards prompt and appropriate interventions, highlighting the importance of careful diagnostic evaluation and personalized treatment strategies for refractory schizophrenias.

Small bowel enteroscopy: an early experience in gastrointestinal bleeding of unknown origin.  Peroral small intestinal enteroscopy was performed in 35 consecutive patients with gastrointestinal bleeding of unknown origin by using a prototypic Sonde-type enteroscope.
